Great architecture!!. Do not miss a visit to the Bahia palace!! You will be mesmerised by the architectural details of this place along with the courtyard gardens and the central courtyard.

More beautiful than all Mederssas in Morocco. I have been to almost all popular Mederssas in Morocco. They are all beautiful. But once you enter this palace you will have to come to terms with the real Moroccan art. Must see
Good architecture\design. Very good architecture, however it would be nice if the whole experience was a bit more informative rather than just being a walk in the park!

One of the beautiful place to visit in marrakech.. This beautiful place is surrounded by gardens and flowers.It is conveniently situated near the medina of marrakech.From royal madrasa to set of houses it has all. It got some beautiful crafted decor and painting which is beautifully presrved. The palace is open for all. you will be amazed to see the excellent craftsmanship of the skilled craftsmen used during that period.It is quite big surrounded by lots of gardens and flowers.Indeed a great visit to spend some time and explore the moroccon cultureand feel its essence.

Nice architecture. We learned a little of the history from our guide and checked out some beautiful architecture in only a small fraction of the rooms. The place is massive but getting a guide you can get to the best spots quickly.

Lovely palace full of history. Walking around the Bahia Palace is really a pleasant step back into history -- both of the grand viziers who lived there and the French who took over later. You can actually trace the renovations done by the French as you look at the new style of painting on the wooden doors (flowers instead of the Moroccan/Moorish geometric flourishes), the size of the windows (large for the French) and the "French" doors. It is fascinating to see the rather sterile rooms and then try to imagine the glories of the decor during the period. The architecture and decoration are worth a close look as is the garden which is a calm oasis. Not large but a treat to walk around in the chaos of the city outside. Admission is only 20 dirhams and it is well worth that and more. They were preparing an art exhibit the day we were there but unfortunately we were not staying long enough to take advantage of that.
History. Amazing history of the place. highly recommend this beautiful place and find out its history and heritage.
Another value for money visit. I really enjoyed my relaxing walk. Saw my favourite flower on display. It really is a place of wonder!

Languid journey of discovery. The Bahia palace started off at a disadvantage as we had just come from Granada, heads still reeling from the splendor of the incomparable Alhambra. I was expecting to be underwhelmed but lowered expectations were a gift because the Bahia was a gorgeous discovery on a hot languid afternoon. Whilst the Mudejar ceramic tiles walls are common with all the other great Moorish palaces the Bahia boasts beautifully intricate hand painted Windows and ceilings which are absolute stunning. I spent so long looking upwards my neck got stiff. The Marrakech Biennale was on and there were various contemporary exhibits and installations on which were a pleasurably discordant yet harmonic note with the traditional architecture. The courtyard is stunning and the gardens are brilliant to wander around in the afternoon sun. Time seems to stand still here and you completely forget the hustle and bustle of the Medina which is right outside. Absolutely must see.

Incredible example of Moroccan design. If you are interested in Moroccan design and getting a feel for how the aristocracy lived in Marrakech then this is a must see. The rooms have been beautifully restored and the tile work, colors, and overall architecture are truly incredible to behold.
Excellent. Very cheap to enter and you could spend a couple of hours here easily. There is so much to see. Worth a visit if in Marrakech
Wonderful place . The Bahia Palace is an oasis of calm on a bustling street. The architecture is fantastic and the whole place is very peaceful. Definitely worth a visit.

A must see - really impressive. Beautiful architecture and tiling and it is still so very cheap to get in to this place, you pay virtually nothing.
You will get beautiful photos here.

Nice!. Nice place to spend a couple of hours on a hot afternoon. Lovely decorations and gardens. An art exhibition was on while we were there. The art wasn't my thing but I applaud the efforts to give local artists more visibility. Like most museums in Morocco, this could use more signs and explanations, but it is still very much worth a visit.

palace for rest. Bahia palace is a beautiful and very tranquil place to figure in to your bustling Marrakesh trip. We sat there for a long time just taking in the garden and relaxing. It's relatively small and there isn't all that much to see, but for a quick 30-45 minute stop, it's well worth the visit to restore your senses a bit...

Worth to visit 1-2 Hours visit . We went there by tuk-tuk , it was a nice trip , In the palace it self was very nice , I advice to take a guide because it was no much info about the place . After Bahia you can go to the Badi palace, 400 m

Simple yet full of intricate detail. The palace is simple yet full of intricate detail. It's worth a visit while in the Medina (old town) as it only costs 10 dirhams to enter and pictures don't do it justice. Stroll through all of the rooms to appreciate the mosaic tile work, stucco and calligraphy across the walls and ceilings.Looking around the palace will take about half an hour. I think it's near Kasbah and the Jewish quarter, and the Saadian tombs are nearby too - so you can check out all of these places around the same time

Lovely, but unadorned with exhibits. There were lots of visitors the day we were there, including children from area schools. They were attentive and well-behaved. The palace is large and we read all we could in advance so knew where the rooms were for government officials - off one of the smaller patios - and where the closed-off quarters of concubines were. We were advised to see the Dar Si Said Museum first, so we could compare the unrestored (Dar Si Said) with the restored (Bahia). It was good advice, though neither had the exhibits we hoped for. The Bahia was in better repair, but both need attention. We were later advised that a smaller, private museum between the two had better artifacts. From what we've seen so far, the most informative exhibit was the Berber Museum at the Jardin Majorelle - more complete and well-annotated. Yet, the scale of the Bahia Palace did speak of the regal lifestyle of earlier pashas, if only in architectural terms.

Peace in the middle of chaos. In the middle of all that noise, smell, people and hectic traffic in and around the medina, the Bahia Palace serves as a peaceful getaway. It is spacious with lots of plants/trees and a lovely breeze. The architecture is interesting too.

Good time-passing activity. We had 30mins to spare to went into the Palace to have a quick look around. It costs 10 dirhams to get in so very cheap.
The gardens are nice and the palace is clean however it wasn't the most spectacular place. The architecture and decoration is great but overall we found it a boring experience.
Beautiful palace. Beautiful palace. With a little imagination you can picture what life must have been like. like most places in Makakech, the place was swarming with tourists.
Lovely!. Nice to see this beautiful palace. We spent an hour in there. The gardens are lovely. We loved the stunning mosaics and tiles. Definitely worth a visit!

Outstanding building, wonderful rooms, great exhibition. Amazed at how much there was to enjoy. beautiful rooms with mosaic floors and stained glass windows, and a great selection of artists featured in the art exhibition.

Amazing Place. The place is made up of different riads which are stunning. In parallel there was an art exhibition with some amazing pieces from artists all over the world.
The amount of details in the building is just wow! If you like culture and architecture a must see

A nice quick visit . Some truly beautiful architecture with some well maintained gardens. There isn't however that much to see and you could easily see everything within half an hour. When we visited however there was an art exhibition happening throughout the venue which was very enjoyable.

Nice terrace for drinks but slow service. The terrace was a relaxing location after a visit to the Bahia Palace. Unfortunately the service was incredibly slow and there was only one other table of guests. Good place for a rooftop drink if you're not in a hurry. The place is licensed.

Not much to see. This was our 1st attraction in marakech and as the title suggests there isn't much to see here except for a few old rooms and a large courtyard
Entrance fee of 10 dirhams is a fair price as you can escape the hustle and bustle of the busy marina for a while

Must do attraction. For only 10dh per person you can stroll through beautiful colourful courtyards, arches and fantastic wooden doors with intricate carvings leading off into fabulous rooms were once upon a time housed the concubines. The ceilings everywhere are magnificent...countless photo opportunities everywhere !!
The Palace. This was also one of the places we visited whilst in Marrakech. This was a super day out the this location was well worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Many areas of this complex of buildings had recently been renovated but already tiles were already lose and despite our guide trying to bring this to the attention of the staff none seemed interested. Worth a visit, but not as interesting as some of the other houses in for instance Rabat.
Amazing. This place show the best of Arabic arts. I have enjoyed lots my visit there!! Reccomended if you Wanna spend a relaxing alternoon,
Amazing mosaics!. Worth the visit - a local guide showed us around Marrakesh and this was the first stop. Helped us get oriented and a quiet oasis compared to the market streets and main square!
Huge but not well looked after . It's worth to have a picture of how big this palace was, but it is not well kept. Not on top list but worth going if have spare time

Beautifully decorated palace. It is a pity there are no artefacts left in the building, but the palace itself is worth a visit and a good introduction to moorish/maghrebi architecture and design. Pick your timing because it can be very busy with domestic tourists as well.

Well worth my time. Bahia (Beautiful/Brilliant) Palace took 14 years to build using Morocco’s best craftsmen. One of the most beautiful buildings in Marrakech with its exquisitely painted, inlaid ceilings, gilded, ornate woodwork, mosaic floors and intricate tile work amongst other sights. There are about 150 rooms of which 20 are accessible to visitors including the opulent, still unfinished Harem with its silk panels and stained-glass windows. There is also the Grand & Petit Courts, Courtyards and the Court of Honour where slaves begged for their lives. Past the Harem is a beautiful blossoming garden with fountains.Today, most of the remaining rooms are being occupied by the Moroccan Royal family and others are being renovated. There is a 10dh fee but no information inside that I could find. I also did not see much furniture or period pieces inside. It will take you about an hour to visit the rooms and garden. Don’t stray beyond the allocated path and you end up back at the entrance..Well worth my time even if I did not get to see the whole place which was a little disappointing.

A fabulous example of palatial architecture at the heart of history. One of the past sultans built this palace for his favourite concubines (as you have when you own 80 wives) and it houses not only the biennial contemporary art show, but also and more importantly, some treasures of ancient woodcarving art and ceramic prowess. This display goes on and on as each room further delivers its beauty and you wonder how they managed to keep such hot weather at bay...while keeping the sultans most precious pearl happy. Apparently the furniture once in this palace now beautifies even further one of the many royal palaces of Morrocco. This is a good thing I might add, as too many tourists would probably ruin it. If you want to see your first small palace this is the one to chose to start you have on your discoveries.
Worth a visit!. This place keeps expanding to new and beautiful surroundings! An interesting story and worth a visit.

Very beautiful. It's a well kept palace and is well maintained.the paintings and wall carvings are excellent .the mosaic work is very eye catching the garden is nice. glass windows and doors make it very attractive.the art work is excellent.worth a visit

Yeah mosaics, and.. Weirdness . Went, looked, left. Sort of interesting architecture, slightly more interesting lack of maintenance, even more interesting ticket guy who really couldn't care less about whether you got change or not. He's not letting you in unless you got exact money. Calling it a palace is up for debate. But nice it is, not Peters church awesome, but more like mellow mosaics all over nice. The picture is from an art expo in the.... Palace.

Beautiful palace, but take a guided tour to bring it to life. This is such a beautiful palace in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Really worth the visit. But you need to take a guided tour to bring it to life, otherwise you just see beautiful rooms but you don't get the history and nice stories behind it all.

Great place to visit on any day. Strange to see such a "big" place in the middle of the streets. Would not have guessed the palace and/or garden was as big or captivating as it was when we first found the entrance. worth the visit. Coasts 10dirham (aprox 1eur) each person to enter.

Empty mosaic palace. Garden approach was cool, entry 20 MAD, old palace but just walls and intricate carving. Nothing to bring it to life, no paintings or sculptures or accounts of inhabitants. Not really worth visiting.

Beautiful pateos and mosaics!. Great place for some contemplation, if you like to step away from the heat of the medina.
The palace has some beautiful mosaics, but its not decorated. We visited the palace during the biennale, which brought some extra flavor, but it's quite poor, comparing with others art biennales that I have visited in the past.

Appears in the middle of nowhere!. We came across this when we were wandering around the streets soaking up the vibe on our way back to the medina after visiting the Saadian tombs. Don't miss this place - very interesting old palace that is being restored. A true gem :)

Tiles, ceilings and roses !. This place was lovely - a good hour can be spent wandering around looking at the wonderful mosaic tiles, the intricate ceilings and the courtyards - I would say the better palace to visit.

Hidden Palace. Hidden behind walls and the entrance-gate, this palace is a site well worth visiting on your day in Marrakech. Try to visit in spring and feel all the trees and flowers blossom, releasing an almost unimaginably strong fragrance. Also, come early or later as most of the groups arrive abut 10 or 11.The woodwork is very nice, as are the gardens and the small fountains. It is very easy to find your way around this palace, you follow the rooms around and emerge by the entrance once you´re finished. Parts of it are closed of course, as it is still a functioning palace of the Moroccan Royal family. There is an entrance fee.

An oasis of calm and beauty. If you are longing to get away from the bustle of the medina, spend an hour or two at the Bahia Palace, a real pleasure for lovers of Islamic and Moroccan style. There are beautiful painted ceilings, intricate tile work, ornate woodwork and mosaic floors to admire (and photograph!), as well as gardens with fruit trees and fountains. If you only have time for one palace in Marrakesh, this is the one to see.
Beautiful opulence. The palace is stunning and fascinating with helpful staff. The gardens are quiet with plenty of shady spots. No food or drink available

A Royal Palace in Marrakech. This is one of the Royal Palaces of Morocco, still in use by the Royal family. Tourists are allowed to visit a small part of it, some rooms with exquisite decorations in Arabic and Berber style, and some serve as rooms for exhibitions of modern art. There are two well maintained small courtyard gardens with various plants and fountains. It is also possible to see the newly renovated Harem area and the school part of the Palace. The Palace has a modest gate which is the entrance close to the Mellah/Jewish Quarter. A visit takes about half an hour because of the limited amount of rooms you are allowed to visit, but it is well spent time and worth a visit when in Marrakech. Entrance fee.

Well worth the entry fee. At 10 dhms, less than £1 , it was a bargain. Government run, but the buildings, gardens and architecture were lovely and with a special art expo on it added value, even if the art was a bit modern for the old building.You can pay for a guide, not sure how much, but listening to others they seemed very good.It is a place to meander out of the sun and chaos of the medina, and a lot bigger than expected.We enjoyed it on a lonely planet trek around Marrakech

Beautiful Majestic Building. A truly beautiful palace.You can imagine what the palace must have been like when it was functioning as a royal palace.A calm beautiful place to visit.10 dirhams entrance fee.Worth visiting.
Contemplation. Great place for some contemplation, if you like to step away from the heat of the medina. We visited the palace during the biennale, which brought some extra flavour.

Amazing building with some beautiful architecture. Try not to take over 100 photos!!. This place is a wonderful example of 19th century architecture but has no furnished areas. There was an art installation there when I visited which made it a slightly different experience. The only drawback is there is no signage or guides in English so without a personal guide you don't know what you are looking at.
Beautiful palace . A beautiful palace with exquisite details. The Marrakech Biennale placed several works in rooms here this spring and it was beautifully integrated into the palace.
Beautiful grounds. A million times more worth it than going to the Badi palace. Grounds are actually aesthetically pleasing.

Take a guide or read the book before. If you go there, you must know the history of the monument prior to. We went with a guide who knew the city well and had a great time. The architecture , the history, the legend... All good
Beautiful . A must see when in Marrakech. It's absolutely beautiful. The attention to detail is something!! Stunning work

Such a surprise!. This was an amazing place, with many spaces to visit, with a mix of Moroccan and Spanish influences in the tiling, carving, etc. It was absolutely beautiful. I hadn't expected to step into a place like this and hopefully you can see from a few of my photos how special it is. At the time of my visit there was a contemporary art exhibition in a number of the rooms that led off the central spaces, which added a different dimension.I would really recommend spending an hour or so here.

Great mixture of old and new Morocco . Beautiful palace surroundings with modern art work. Great if you want to escape the sun for a little while. I would go early to avoid the crowds. Cheap admission fee. Toilets on available.

Astounding Detail. This is the most well preserved palace we saw on our travels in Morocco and it has exquisitely well preserved and detailed architecture. The decorative walls, mosaics, patterns, carvings, etc are a wonder to behold. Certainly this is a place to see when spending some time in Marrakech.

A must!. Chef d’oeuvre, this palace is representative of the best traditional Moroccan architecture. It was first build in the 19th century by Ahmed ben Moussa, grand vizier, and dedicated to his favourite wife Bahia “the shining one” (one of the many he lived with in the palace). You can see some of the best expressions in decorative art, beautiful woodcuts on the ceilings, tiles and mosaics. The palace is a vast complex of rooms, courts, basins, fountains (no water thought) and gardens. Groups tend to come to visit this palace around 12am and towards the afternoon… if you want to escape the crowd try to come in the morning, or at least that was our experience.
Its a must. The palace is beautiful, nice gardens and amazing carvings. One of my favorite sightseeings in the city.
Nice to visit. It didn't take that long to wander around, under an hour, although you could spend longer and could also sit and relax in the courtyard for a bit if you wish

Nice to see but have to listen about . Only 10 dirhams to enter!!!! Little bit hard to understand what you see without a guide. All the guides are telling different stories but all are good to know :) take your time to enjoy it. Ussualy full of people around lunch time or before it.

Beautiful tile work and carvings. Like all Moroccan national monuments, it only costs 10 dirhams to get in and at that point, you really can't go wrong.It is basically a series of rooms and courtyards, decorated with intricate carvings and patterned tiles. The ceilings are particularly beautiful.Don't expect it to be stuffed with artifacts and furniture - because it isn't - but just enjoy the cool rooms and the gardens.

Great place. This is a beautiful collection of buildings in the south of the Medina. At the time of our visit, there also was an exhibit under the umbrella of Marrakesh Biennale 2016.A number of stunning courtyards, side rooms, a main square, little buildings, a chapel (?) and lots of mosaics and decorations. Plus there are gardens showing beautiful flowers.Definitely worth a visit!

Interesting place. Quite a find and very interesting to visit. Provides an image of the past, but not a great deal. However what it does offer is of interest to all, particularly to those, like us, who love history.

Oh yeah, this is nice. When you walk in to the first rooms, you think to yourself, this is it? Then the next rooms opens up, then the next court yard opens up, and you are stunned with the beauty and the extravagance of each each. This is definitely worth the 10 dirhams and the long hot walk from the market. Even with the crowds, if you wait long enough, you can actually get lovely photos with no one in it. A photographer's dream.
See it with a guide to get the full story.. The history and the surroundings are awesome. Various displays of art are spread throughout the grounds, accompanied by informative pamphlets.
Beautiful. This beautiful palace is well worth looking around. Very calm & cool interior with beautiful ceilings & floors. Currently has an art exhibition running through many of the rooms.

Another stunning building in Marrakech . Can walk to from the main square in about 10 mins and the palace and grounds are beautiful. All the rooms house art installations from Moroccan artists which is a fantastic idea.

Amazing place. A beautiful building, with so much to see and take in. We went in not expecting much, as the admission was so cheap!
It just kept on giving and giving, and made all the more interesting by the art exhibition that was being housed in the palace. It felt so calm and quiet away from the busy Marrakech steets.
must have seen. this palace is a very nice monument of Marrakech. Do not miss it. It cost you only 10 diran! It gives a good view of the palace architecture of Maroc

Beautiful. The palace is a quiet break from the high-energy of the Medina, and an opportunity to see stunning architectural decorations including tile mosaics, intricate paintings, and beautiful wood and iron work.
beautiful. beautiful and well maintained palace. take 1-2 hours time to visit. visit in the afternoon, as there is los of shade to hide from the afternoon sun
Lovely place to visit. Pleasant and relaxed to visit. Good buildings. Tile work is interesting and the gardens nice to wander around.
Moorish architecture at its best. Only a century old but this visier's palace is a beautiful example of Moorish architecture and is well worth an hour or so to enjoy.

Traditional beauty. A step back in time from the chaos outside. The palace is full of beautifully carved doorways, exotically decorated ceilings, and stunning courtyards. Despite the number of visitors it is a tranquil treat.

worth a visit. very nice and well worth a visit. we had a private guide organized by hotel who took us around. he clearly explained the layout and use of palace with plenty of time to look around. there are few steps and a bit of walking

Exquisite. Bahia Palace is in the Marrakech Medina, better to arrive by foot and enjoy the souk and medina. The architecture and preservation is wonderful, a jewel to see and enjoy. Very interesting the diverse expositions within the palace.
Beautiful scenery!. If you love historic sites make sure you visit the Bahia Palace in Marrakech: guaranteed you'll love it!

colors of love. impressing tribute of beauty from a rich noble to one of his lovers. architecture in general is probably typical but anyway it is a masterpiece 'cause especially decors in the rooms are absolutely stunning.
easy to visit. one of the places to visit more times if you can.
Nothing interesting. Very boring, hard to find, you have to pay the entrance. If the weather is too warm, this is a nice place to go. But otherwise, there is really nothing interesting to see.

A Lovely Place.. We enjoyed visiting this lovely place, which is in very good condition and offers an insight into the life lived by Morrocan royals. It's nicely layed out with a variety of different spaces offering the opportunity to bask in the sunshine or shade. While we were there it was hosting an exhibition of contemporary art, some of which was rather odd but some complemented the setting nicely.
Cheap afternoon . Only 10dh to get in, this is worth popping in if you're passing by. Some stunning parts, some past their best. A nice way to escape the chaos and find some calm.

Beautiful Palace. If you want to escape the mad rush of Marrakech then Palace Bahia is the place. It is full of beautiful courtyards and greenery along with architecture to soak in. A lovely place to walk around and feel like you've gone back in time before all the motorbikes arrived to Marrakech. It costs 1euro and is definitely worth a visit.
Small short visit . Small palace and while lovely architecture, not quite the same I thought it would be. Not must see though a nice daytime visit for 30 mins to and hour
Fascinating. Spend the money to have a good guide explain this complex of buildings to you. It's worth it. Really enjoyed our visit.

Nice and worth a visit. This is nice to walk around, and not expensive, but there is not loads to see and can be done very quickly. its more nice to get away from the constant hassle outside the walls from the locals trying to scam you.

Worth the visit. You got a good sense of times gone by with the architecture and the proportions of space. It was very cheap and well worth the visit doesnt take much of time and was easily accessible
A lovely place to escape the city. Beautiful gardens and architecture and a lovely place to escape the city for an hour or so. Inexpensive place to visit, worth a visit.

nice place . free to visit, theres loads to do and see and this palace is lovely, near the square although we went in horse and carraige as it was a very hot afternoon and it was nice to ride in this. beautiful palace

Breathtaking . I actually don't think I'll be able to adequately convey just how breathtakingly beautiful the Bahia Palace is. I walked in to the first main courtyard after paying and was moved to tears by the sheer beauty of it. It is adorned with the most stunning intricate and ornate carvings and zellige tiles throughout. There are beautiful gardens and fountains within the palace. It's amazing how well preserved it is. They are restoring areas of the palace but there are only a few rooms you can't access. There are currently various art installations displayed within as part of the Marrakech Biennale. At only 10dhs to get in, it is not to be missed!
Beautiful gardens. Lovely gardens nice to walk around and spend half another taking in some lovely surroundings. Quite hard to find but there are some fantastic shops leading up to this place.

Nice, Inexpensive Attraction. The Bahia Palace is not as nice as it probably once was, but I found the walls and gardens to be beautiful. It is a very inexpensive attraction (if I recall, it was 10 dirham, which is about 1 USD), and I thought it was worth the trek out there.
Amazing architecture. loved the tortoise!. A tranquil break from the bustling souks! Lovely tiles/mosaics gardens. Beautiful place to visit, probably took us about an hour in total

Don't bother. There is a 10 dhm ticket and it's just useless. Not much info or history to it. It can be walked through withen 20 mins. I would not have gone if I knew before. Save your time and money!
Worth a visit . Beautiful place where to spend 1-2 hours. Will looked after building, phenomenal gardens. Highly enjoyable and picturesque.

Lovely visit. This was very local to my accommodation and has very cheap entrance fees so is definitely worth a visit. Do not pay for a "guide" as they are not official and will not tell you anything that you can't read yourself. Gardens are absolutely beautiful.

Beautifully restored painted ceilings. A really beautiful palace, with many elements such as painted ceilings that have been recently restored. The Marrakech Biennale was in situ when we visited and for me this brought the rooms alive, they might be a bit sterile otherwise. I just loved the ceilings, which are vibrant and colourful, so often in old buildings the colours have faded, so you don't experience how it looked originally.

A bit too clinical. The Palace has been restored and now contains local art. It has some amazing mosaics and ceilings but I found it a bit too artificial. Most of the guide plaques are in french so I may have missed something - but following an english speaking tour group helped! Entry is only one Euro so well worth a visit if you are looking for something to do - about an hour to walk around the whole palace.

Exquisite.... Bahia means beautiful. A fitting name for this wonder of a palace!Exquisite wood carvings, mosaics, tile work, tiny explosions of colour in every square inch, delicate, intricate, this palace is definitely worth exploring.A beautiful little garden in the middle of the palace creates a lovely green oasis. Given it's labyrinthine layout and lack of signs, it is easy to get lost and miss a few things. Fortunately, we had hired a tour guide who was able to give us a lot of interesting snippets of information and also show us some things that we might otherwise have missed like the room of the favourite queen with it's lovely stained glass windows.Definitely worth a visit and the entrance fee is nominal: 10 dirhams per person.
Very beautiful. This is a mustsee. Very beautiful! Untill may 2016 there is a Biennale (Art) in the palace. Very nice!

I felt I was missing something. I blame Lonely Planet for building up my expectations too much. Bahia Palace has some stunning mosaics and ornate carved painted ceilings, and that's just the first room. Wait, that's every room, and they're all pretty much the same. Or am I missing something? Maybe I didn't see everything? The LP guide speaks of a room for the prince's favourite concubine and that it has fabulous stained glass - we couldn't find it. Maybe it was closed. Part of what makes a great museum is the information available - I don't think I saw any signs other than those for the contemporary art that is being displayed here. Bahia feels like a shell, and it would be so nice if even just one room had been furnished to suggest how it might have looked in its 19th century heyday. WARNING: We bought tickets then had lunch at the restaurant over the road. They weren't happy as the tickets are meant to be used right away. Also, young children (mine is 7) might find nothing of interest here.

tranquility in the heart of the Medina. When you go past the gates you step into a world away from the hustle and bustle of the Medina and approach an area of tranquility. It is exquisitely decorated Palace but i would have loved to have seen more explanation about how the Palace used to utilised.
Better than expected. Museum and beautiful palace. I think it should be rated higher as its the cheapest of the places I visited in Marrakech but definitely the best.
Beautiful Bahia palace. It may not be as monumental as the Badi but as it's still in good condition it's easier to imagine life here. Beautiful with lots of courtyards to sit in.
Best Palace in Marrakech. What a great palace. We were surprised at its beauty. It is kept in a good condition and definitely worth a visit. The gardens are very tranquil.

His Majesty's harem. Definite place to visit if you enjoy architectural work & admire detailed carving. Our guide informed us that this was the structure built by the King for his numerous concubines. From the beautiful gardens at the entry to the detailed work within, you would not even realize where an hour has passed admiring it.

Simply unmissable. Given the our disappointing trip to the Menara gardens and the distance outside the medina of the Majorelle Gardens, the Bahia Palace is an excellent (and very cheap) oasis away from the hustle and bustle of the medina that simply should not be missed. There was a contemporary art exhibition during our visit which was extensive and hugely interesting and the architecture and gardens are breathtaking. In a city as enchanting as Marrakech, Bahia manages to set itself apart.

Different from the Badi and equally great to see. This palace is more of a 19th century palace and gives you a bit more insight on how Moroccan royalty lived during that time period. It is worth seeing in addition to the Badi Palace as a provides a different picture. Different from the Badi and equally great to see
Beauty. Bahia means Beautiful, name of the queen who was very powerful. The King built this lovely palace for her.Lovely courtyards. Great architecture was a fantastic artistic experience.

Wouldn't miss it . We were surprised at how cheap entry was to the palace; at only 10dirhams it was probably some of the best money we spent whilst in Morocco. Inside a series of courtyards and rooms make the Palais Bahia a delight to explore: the highlights were the scent of orange blossom permeating the the beautiful gardens and wonderful and varied Islamic architecture decorating the many wings. During our visit the palace was also hosting an art exhibition and different artists had their works displayed in various rooms, accompanied by pamphlets explaining the work and the introducing the artist. This was a fascinating and fabulous bonus, with some of the contrasts between the work and their astonishingly artistic surroundings being particularly striking. The only thing that would've made the visit better was if we had had a guide to take us through and reveal to us some of the Palais Bahia's history, as I've no doubt it's just as interesting as the palace is beautiful.
Beautiful or should I say Bahia!. Lovely to look around and see how the favourite wife was cosseted in the old days. Lovely mosaics and stucco work, rivals any where iv'e ever seen it.
Beautiful ruins. Very evocative. Good for Moroccan architecture. Marrakech Biennial on display there when we went so some great art too.

One of the best attractions in Marrakech. This beautiful Palace was a surprisingly enjoyable attraction due it well kept interiors and stunning gardens. There was also an interesting art exhibition throughout the palace. Be aware that none French speakers will not gain much knowledge from the Palace as the majority of artefacts are described in French.
Worthwhile stop while in the medina. Beautiful tile work, and painted ceilings. Also a must stop while in the medina. This doesn't take too long so I would recommend visiting the palace
what a beautiful place. Amazing place, completely perfect for a sunny afternoon's wander, courtyards and a lovely inner garden.

Architectural delight. The recently restored rooms of the Bahia Palace revealed a lifestyle that revolved around the four wives and twenty four concubines in the harem of the visor. The tiled mosaics and ornate wood carvings were exquisite. Be careful of the uneven surfaces and steep steps.

Absolutely stunning place for 10DH in. This place is a must-see. Adults pay 10DH in, young kids don't pay. Fell in love with this one, the palace and it's garden, stunning is an understatement and if you love photography like I do, you will get tonnes of picture opportunities here. If you're in Marrakech and don't get to see this beaut, you're missing out.

Escape the busy city and step into this grand architectural palace.. Few mins walk from the Jemma el Fna, we drove there and managed to find parking in the side street. A very picturesque architecture with lovely trees, the halls where full of various artist work. Full of mosaic and lovely carving, well worth a visit.
Brillaint Bahia. This palace was amazing, It was a beautiful sight to see and its architecture was very grand! It is about a 10 or 15 minute walk from Jamaa El Fna.
Lovely for a stroll. Beautiful gardens, near Place de la Prefecture. Walk around and enjoy the flowers and the beautiful buildings

Nice place... but only a small part to see. The Bahia Palace is a beautiful place to visit. Calm and relaxing. Beautiful mosaic, stucco and wood-carving works. Just a pity we can only visit a small part of it.
Attractive intricately painted ceilings and carved plaster. Worth seeing but hard to imagine people in this space without furniture. The favorite wife had the most beautiful ceiling.

A great stop on a walking tour. We visited this as part of walk around the city. It was quite easy to find from El Badi Palace (- we didn't go on a city tour). Lovely and tranquil to walk around - quite a large site with beautiful tile work. There were also a number of interesting art installations. It was only 10dh to enter so was very good value.

Amazing. Once you negotiate your way through the building site around the palace at the moment you find an amazing place. The architecture is stunning with fountains, gardens and tiling merging together. Add to this modern artwork in such a traditional setting at an extremely cheap price for entry and you have an amazing experience.
Must see. Another must for anyone who loves looking at beautiful architecture. The tiling and stucco work is absolutely stunning
Stunning!. Only 10 Dh to visit this amazing palace! Beautifully restored with foundations and gardens. A must see in Marrakech!

Beautiful but soulless. A hollow shell of a palace complex, with beautiful tiles and ceiling decorations, but somehow lacking in charm, unlike the stunning Madrasa Ben Youssef. And not helped by an exhibition of mostly unattractive modern artworks, part of the Marrakech Biennale, in many of the rooms, which really jarred with the style of the building.

Bahia Palace a place of great architectural interest. The Bahia Palace was not easy to find from the square as the regeneration of the streets around it meant walking on the road difficult. However once through into the palace the smell of orange blossom was intoxicating.The architectural Morrocan styled palace is magical. Arches, fountains, the wonderful stucco that looks like a glorious wedding cake and tiled palisades makes this an absolute must see attraction to visit.

Worth checking out. The rooms, especially with all of the brilliant tile work are very nice to see. The entry fee is only 10dh, can visit pretty quickly (we didn't spend too long here). Worth coming for a short time while also seeing other historic sites nearby

Pleasent visit . Bahia Palace is definately an interesting place to visit. For just 10 drh one can enjoyig a walk through beautifully decorated rooms ( and the ceilings!!!!) During our visit in many of the rooms where various exhibitions. I particulary liked audiovisual pieces, the dokumentary about women in Somalia and Mohammed Chabaa 's paintings. We were also interesting in a short about Independency stamps but it was played way to quitetly to understand anything

Beautiful place. 12 Riads connected by gardens and gorgeous rooms. No furniture around but you can marvel at all the decorated floors, walls and ceilings. The courtyards and gardens are beautiful. The old Koranic school which is now a small library so quaint and pretty. The favorite wife's quarters are elegant. Def go!
worth a visit. In the old city & can be visited in daytime when the souqs are quiet, highlight are the ceilings in each area.graham

Gorgeous!. This palace was designed to impress, and it still achieves its purpose! Along with the rooms, courtyards and grounds take note of the doors and ceilings as well--spectacular. The entrance is a bit of a challenge to find and there is a small fee.
Stunning!. Spend a morning in the beautifully decorated Bahia Palace. This was one of the best things we saw in Marrakech.

Beautiful. This attraction is stunning inside and has a nice range of rooms and different exhibitions to see. The entrance fee was 10 dh each but frankly no one checked your ticket, barriers are broken and you just walk straight in. I would probably get a tour here or follow a large group as a lot of the rooms are empty and need explaining and that goes too for some of the exhibitions. However if you are just going to see the stunning architecture then do not pay anything. The courtyards inside are very interesting and the features of the ceilings quite spectacular.
Good . Impressed as wasn't expecting it be that great. Good Value for money. Nice architectural work.They could have made better with small museum

Like in "One Thousand and One Nights". This is a fairy tale palace: differently decorated rooms in different styles and colors with a lot of details, fantastic interior courts with lush tropical vegetation, interesting exhibits of young arabic and berber artists and a very relaxing atmosphere overall.
The nicest palace in Medina. Very nice palace definitely worth the visit. The ceilings are just the most amazing ceiling I have ever seen. Amazing architecture!

Absolutely beautiful . If you're in Marrakech you must go and see the Bahia Palace it is absolutely beautiful. Although it is just the remains of a palace the atmosphere is great and the nesting storks add a certain something.

Quite impressive.. Initially I was a bit underwhelmed when I first entered, but then as you start to walk through each room you realise how decorative it all is. For the price of only 10 dirham it is good value! Architecture was impressive and the ornate floors, walls, ceilings, columns - basically everything - was quite stunning. Easy to spend up to 1 hour here.
A beautiful oasis!. Loved the palace! The Bienal was going on right now and it had modern pieces of art and 3D art instalations that contrasted with this historic and place wonderfully!

Beautiful and loads to see. Entrance was 20 dirhams; totally worth it!!! Loads to see when it comes to architecture, there are many rooms you can enter. Within the rooms there was art. It is really not a waste of the 2 euro's you have to pay

Nice place to escape the crowds of the Medina. For the price, I would recommend visiting the Bahia Palace. 10 MAD to enter and there are interesting art exhibits throughout the palace. It was also the best view of the Medina from the palace terrace. Also fun to see all the cranes nesting on the walls.

Perfect spot to go to. Great atmosphere, good food. The drinks are strong and good. They have hookah if you ask and the service was wonderful. I will definitely come back here. The rooftop is definitely the place to sit if you come here.
Nice gardens . Lovely setting with nice gardens including orange trees. Good for a wander around for an hour or so. And great setting for photos. Palace itself also pretty with mosaics.

Pretty. A bit of an escape from the craziness of the Medina. The palace is pretty and has some very ornate tile and artwork. The entry fee isn't expensive and it's a relaxing place to wander around for an afternoon. There's a stark contrast between the outside walls and the courtyards inside but that is a theme throughout the Medina.
Must see. If you visit Medina in Marrakech, the Bahia Palace is a must see. It is a Oase of quitness and really beautyful whit the lot of different places inside.

Lovely and full of surprises . The more you explore the better it gets...and the tiles and artwork is serene on a sunny day.
Entrance is only 10 MAD per person so worth a visit!
Great place for a rainy day. Huge place with rooms courtyards gardens and a lot of interesting things to explore and see. We managed to spend several hours while it was raining outside.

A Wonder around the Palace. Palais De La Bahia is located in the Médina and was built in the late 19th Century. I didn't sense the brilliance as in the name. The Architecture was impressive. I didn't feel that grande sense that it aspired to. It had it's typical yellow and blue flooring for buildings of importance in Morocco. The Fountains weren't in use. The Courtyard was a large marbled area and the marble is from Italy as with the columns. I can imagine in their times the gardens were beautiful. The rooms in the Palace had no external windows, so the rooms would've offered limited natural lighting. I can't imagine being cooped up in the Palace with all the other wives. Large tour groups throughout it's a good thing I had my personal guide otherwise I wouldn't know a thing. Everything is worth a visit but offered me nothing great. Entrance fee is 10dh maybe some of that needs to be invested in the toilets.

Bahia Palace - fascinating palace every one should visit.. Bahia Palace - Fascinating palace every one should visit. It is built in about year 1700. You will see the highest level of architecture and design with such beautiful ceramic hand crafted walls and celling. Many rooms and halls to visit . It is very fantastic dream place to see the famous palace built in 17 century.
Great visit. A very nice old palace in a beautiful environment. It is one of the most relaxing places to visit if you have half-a-day free during your trip.

Magnificent lovingly-restored palace.. I visited during the Marrakesh Art Biennial, the contrast between some contemporary installations and the beautiful classical rooms and courtyards was sometimes stunning, sometimes intriguing and at times... puzzling, but the grandeur and magnificence of the architecture and the beauty of colors, patterns and designs always came forcefully through.

Very fine architecture and gardens. We visited this palace last week and were very impressed. The palace has some fine examples of Islamic architecture of the period as well as a lovely set of gardens. Well worth a visit.
For architecture lovers. for everyone who likes architecture and history. Good example of Moroccan style architecture, design and decore. And also good for rainy day.

shame about the modern 'art'. An interesting old palace that has a lot of charm however there is a lack of any real information explaining it's history and what info there is is only in French and Arabic. Sadly when I visited a lot of rooms were taken up by modern art exhibitions which are really bad and unsighly
Gorgeous architechture. Gorgeous building! Try to go first thing in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid the tour groups.

an inexpensive gem!. the tickets to this sight are relatively inexpensive, but extremely worthwhile. The grandeur of the palace slowly reveals itself as you explore it. Fantastic for seeing the traditional Morroccan architecture and decoration.

Must see - beautiful palace in Marrakesh . I went to see this palace after having lived in Granada and I found it to be very beautiful and in a similar style as the Alhambra. A great escape from the city, this was my favorite place in Marrakesh. Very inexpensive to visit and worth it.

Beautiful mosaics and lovely white-tiled harem courtyard. This palace is on the south end of the old city of Marrakech and the entrance fee is Dh10 - which was about GBP80p when we travelled. The ceilings feature carved and intricately painted wood and the walls and floors are, as you would expect, covered in mosaics in the traditional colours. The male and harem quarters are segregated, with an expanse of brilliant white floor in the harem. From here you can watch the nesting storks on the nearby tower, which had a attracted a couple of bird watchers. Can get pretty busy but no restrictions on photographs, which isn't always the case in Marrakech.
One of the most beautifull in Marrakech. One of the most beutiful, so must go.- Price..worth more than 10 dirhams.- Time..one hour at list, because it is beautful and big ;)

Definitely worth it. This place looks incredible on picture and in person, cheap entry of ten MAD is totally worth it. There are some signs with background information for the history buffs and art expositions inside as well.

Stunning. We loved this place. So many stunning little details everywhere we looked - on the walls, on the floors (gorgeous mosaic floor tiles), on the doors. And don't forget to look up - the ceilings are just breathtaking. We enjoyed visiting the older palace as well but they couldn't be more different. Very cheap entry too. Just remember to take some water if you're walking about in the heat for a long time.

Not much to see. It is so close to the center, so you might as well visit it. However, you might be somewhat disappointed as there is not so much to see around. You can read the history of it in a book, and it would be totally sufficient.
nice place to visit. certainly an interesting attraction especially just to see the storks that nest in the ramparts. it isworth a visit
Palace visit. Easy to find and beautiful gardens inside the palace. Very cheap entry, 10 drm, A must visit when in Marrakech
Beautiful. Well worth visiting as architecturally stunning. Shame they hadn't mocked up a few rooms to show how people would have lived in them. However, it is still very worth a visit.

Beautiful Palace. Was not sure about this but turned out to be a very beautiful and ornate place it also had a modern art exhibition going on there which was very modern and added to the variety of what to see. It is a lot more mosaics and not much explanation in English.
Worth a view, but. Nowhere near as interesting or extravagant as I was expecting. But still nice to have seen, then again, maybe a guide would have made the difference, who knows!

Palace no.1 to see in Marrakech. What you can see there is pure arabo-andalous architecture and craftsmanship at its best! Colorful tiles, stucco and carved cedar wood. Beautiful courts, fountains and fireplaces. No furniture. It's an oasis of silence. Perfect to escape the hustling and bustling Medina. You enter and feel yourself in another place and time. Birdsong and fresh air replace the noise and pollution of the motorcycles outside. Thanks to the Biennale in Marrakech many efforts have been made in this ancient Sultans Palace. All the floors are renovated now. And finally also the court of the concubines and the wonderful garden are open for visitors again now. Al hamdolillah - well done! ❤️
No more than half an hour needed. Was slightly disappointed the "palace" was not furnished. Yes beautiful ceilings and artistic designs however these can be seen in many riads and restaurants

Morocco's finest craftsmanship and artistry. This place was recommended by locals so we decided to cheek it out.Collections of Morocco's finest craftsmanship and artistry is showcased here. Every door ways, ceilings, walk-through area is exemplifying just that- intricate designs, patterns, and art through out the times.
Really nice. Really nice place to visit. Its not far from the main square. Entry is relly cheap about 10Dh (1 €). !
Ok but not a must. Large palace that did not quite impress or left a mark on me. If you are close to it and have 30 minutes to fill, it is ok to visit but otherwise I would not make it a destination

Lovely. Quite lovely, small, but interesting. But beautiful none the less. One of the few decent places to visit in the Medina since the rest of it is absolutely terrifying and will make you wanted to sprint back to your riad and crawl into fetal position as you cry yourself to sleep every night while downing a bottle of delicious Moroccan wine.
A surprising gem. A really lovely little hideaway with an exquisite courtyard garden, and beautiful painted ceilings and doors.
I have seen many more other palaces more spectacular I am afraid!. Still had enjoyable time there, and we a guide who explained the history behind so it made it more interesting than just looking.

Beautiful palace to visit...there was a modern art exhibition on the day we visited as part of the Marrekech biennial ar. Very good value at only 10 Dhm. About 70 pence lots of amazingly decorated ceilings and tiled floors. About 10-15 mins walk from the main square...but not well sign posted.
Consider a must see. Great art. Abstract. We spent 30 minutes here and saw everything, took photos, etc. A great stop on a walking tour!
Good Place. I enjoyed seeing the palace and looking at the arches and columns. It is a place to visit while in Marrakech! realy good.

Really beautiful architecture. Allocate no more than 2 hours to walk around and take in the stunning detail. I was expecting it be bigger. . We set out from our hotel at around 10am and we were done before lunch. Make sure you charge your cameras/phones- a spot for lovey photos.
Holiday. Another great photo opportunity lots to see storks can be noisy with a click clack but they are supposed to be lucky nice well kept site
Oasis of peace. Interesting early palace with garden courtyards which would be very welcome when it is hot in summer.
Calm experience. Very nice and detailed place to go and see and interesting place which tells you about the history. Theres outside garden and rooms inside with tv screens

Nice. If u got difficulties to find it, only ask other tourist, the marrocan looks helpful but will send u to wrong places, a shop or wants to have money. U can get a wagon with a horse and he will show you all the important places for 20 euro. But walking is very nice in this city and all sightseeing u can walk. Nice small palace but only the garden to see. Nice architecture.

Royal palace with great frescos. Very pretty palace with amazing frescos and stained glass windows. They had a contemporary art exhibit going on that I did not care for. There are many rooms in the palace and it is definitely worth a visit.
Nice experience. I enjoyed seeing the palace and looking at the arches and columns. It is a place to visit while in Marrakech!

a must for two hours. stunning! and a must for your visit. this huge complex offers an amazing insight into local construction and ornamentation - and some very nice exhibits inside the beautifully decorated rooms.
El bahia palace. Amazing place seen as part of a guided tour the gardens and rooms are amazing well worth a visit with someobe who knows its history

Beautiful. Me & my friend had such a lovely afternoon here! It is such a Beautiful place.
We visited in March & the weather was amazing. Not too warm,but still sunny & breezy !
I will definitely recommend Bahia.
Xx

Beautifully serene . Costing only 10Dhs and just around the corner from the tombs, Bahia Palace should be on everyone's list of places to visit when venturing to the south of the medina. There are many photo opportunities and also some artists displaying a few pieces of artwork for those who are interested.
Recommended a day worth exploring.
Nice place, but empty. Beautiful house in the middle of medina, but it was a disappointment not getting any impressions of morrocain life ... Every room empty.

Beautiful architecture. 10Dhs to enter. About a 20-30 min walk from the square. Plenty to wander around. Beautiful gardens. Spent about 45 mins walking around. Seem to have art exhibitions there too but didn't seem to really fit the theme of the palace. Would recommend going to look around.
Stunning. Beautiful building and gardens -see how the other half lived, fabulous mosaics stunning a must see when in Marrakesh !!!
A must!. Don't miss this beautiful palace! Give yourself time to admire the building and the intricate mosaic tile work.

Stunning. Beautiful palace of old. Situated in the maedina not far from the main square. Beautiful and calm compared to the streets. Stunning interiors beautiful tiles and ceilings showcasing modern art.

Endless luxury. You see one room with extravagant mosaics and faboulous roof paintings, and you cannor imagine, that this level of luxury can continue, but it can, and you find yourself wandering open mouthed from one room or one yard to the next in ave of the craftmen behind this palace.
Worth checking out. If you like beautiful architecture, mosaics, and artwork, then you should definitely take some time to visit this palace.

Stunning and worth checking out. This is a stunning place. Beautiful and relaxing. It is very big so you can definitely lose a couple of hours here. The craftsmanship is breathtaking and on a gorgeous sunny day the colours really stand out.

Walking tour of the Medina. This is very worthwhile to visit whilst walking through the Medina. Entry is only 10 dirhams per person and there is a lot to see in this beautiful palace. Certainly one to have on your list

Beautiful mosaics, doors and ceilings.. This is an easy attraction to miss but has so much to offer it is worth a taxi ride to get to and at the same time visit the Jewish Quarter that is being invested in by the Government and is being upgraded. Whilst there look out for the rose market - what a site ! The Bahai Palace has an interesting history and is perfectly restored.

A Palace to wander around.... At only 10 Dirhams to enter, you can't miss this palace. We wanted to have a quick look around but ended up spending more than an hour in this palace - and this was at a rush!This is one of the largest palaces in Marrakech and was built in the early 19th century. Truly beautiful with rich colours everywhere, room after room until you get to the main courtyard and that is even more stunning. Lots of mosaics to look at and beautiful doors everywhere. Everything suggests that this palace was indeed something that was marvelled at back in the days - and even in this day and age, once can see how grand this place would've been. The designs of the building also reminds you of the Ben Youssef medersa - especially some of the calligraphy.There is a small garden area to one side which is also a pleasant and quiet place to be. It is very easy to spend a good couple of hours here. As someone else mentioned, I hope the authorities continue to ensure that this building is looked after - indeed a lot of places in Marrakech, including the Ben Youssef medersa, need more maintenance in order to ensure the generations after us can continue to marvel at some of the older buildings from history.
as the name says beautiful. lovely gardens and architecture, a real gem. Well worth a visit, especially early in the day before it gets over run with people

Nice way to kill an hour. Bahia Palace was built by a sultan for his favorite wife (of which there were three and no less than 24 concubines). The palace is not in use now and is open to the public for about $1 to walk through. The palace is empty now, but the architecture and the attention to details in the tile work, doorways, and gardens are just lovely. It really is a very nice way to spend an hour.

lovely palace with great exhibition . we came to Bahia palace by accident and really enjoyed our time here. the palace is beautiful and in very good condition. during our visit there has also been the Marrakesh Biennale on which was very interesting to see and brought some life into the palace. it's almost free to get in so I can really suggest going there.

Get a guide or you have no idea what is what. This is worth going to, cheap entry etc. There is an awful lot of history here if only you knew what you were looking at. There isn't any furniture etc but the rooms are in tact. There is also a tortoise with a foot missing, have a look for him in the garden area.

Stunning!. Not really a palace. But a grand building of empty rooms. The architecture is really stunning. Lovely photo opportunities and the tiles, walls and ceilings are so pretty.
It is definitely a must see. Only 10 dirhams to enter and they have toilet facilities.
Interesting. Interesting building but no explanation of how it functioned. It was made more interesting when we visited by the presence of lots of modern art forming part of the Bienniale.

Beautiful Palace. We had a private guide for our first morning in Marrakech and the first place he took us to was the beautiful Bahia Palace. We arrived early (about 9.30am) and there were very few people around so we were able to enjoy the Palace and beautiful well kept gardens in peace and quiet. By the time we left about an hour later it was starting to really fill up.The decoration and colours are wonderful here and it is all pristine and clean, our Guide told us that some areas had only just been re-opened after renovation.A lovely place to visit.

while interesting, it doesn't feel like this place get the upkeep it needs. We expected this palace to be a place where we could spend half the day and have a picnic while were at it -not the case. The palace itself is bare other than the preserved walls. There were some walls that had tarps taped to them and left untouched... Needs upkeep!

Historical & Architectural Monument to Love and Beauty. Bahai Palace is a must see so long as you have a private guide to share the history and details of this beautiful place. The architecture is incredible and the history of this beautiful palace is quite a story.

cheap, cool bit under impressed. found this in the hubub, cheap entry,so went in. lovely old buildings, lots of tours going around but it was mainly empty rooms with a few art pieces. Nobody offered us a tour guide, not very well signposted within, but nice all the same apart from the loos. but for the price i could not complain.

Wonderful courtyard and projector presentation. Well kept, parts being remodeled, the area itself is going through a major reconstruction so watch out for that. The palace itself is a nice walk through with a really nice courtyard to sit and meditation for a little. Of course, the architecture, as standard in Marrakesh, is quite artistic and detailed.

Nice pla. The Moroccans are still not very switched on to tourism so there are no leaflets, guide books or signs informing you of what exactly you are looking at. So on the whole a good guide book or guide are essential to get the most from any tourist attraction in Marrakech
A wonderful place to visit. a must if you are visiting marrakesh - take a guide as there is a lot of things to be told about - great few hours of exploring
great historical castle. it a very nice placeto visit;i thing it's been the sultans castle in the ancient times . i highly recommend this place

Good break from the city. The palace was set in pretty gardens and was a welcome break from the madness of the city of Marrakech. It had beautiful tiled areas and attractive roofs that were quite ornate. Well worth a visit and we were lucky to have a sunny day when we were here.

Built by craftsmen from Fez. A stunning place to visit and only 10 dirham to enter. We took loads of photos here including the newly opened fully restored part which was truly beautiful.Allow 2 hours to visit to relax and visit it well.Good on a dry or wet day.

Beautiful palace inside theMedina. Easily located south of the main square, this lovely palace approached along a tree lined drive is worth a visit for an hour or so. Inexpensive to enter and so beautifully constructed its a real 'must- a complete contrast to the El Badi Palace which is also worth a visit but completely different in scale and design. The ceilings at the Bahia Palace are a wonder to behold with fantastic woodcarving, paintwork and plasterwork as well as tiling. Definitely worth it for an hour or so.

Beautiful mosaics everywhere. We got there by car (booked a city tour) and the diver dropped us in front of the entrance. It is one of the must-see points of attraction in Marrakech, with its welcoming and refreshing gardens and the beautiful mosaics. The entrance fee is cheap but even if it were more expensive, i would have considered it money well spent. There's intricate beauty everywhere: painted ceilings, mosaics, carved stucco... Even a few baby kittens laying in the garden :) All in all, a relaxing, peaceful visit to a not-to-be-missed site. Watch out for the vendors, they'll wait for you outside the gates and aggressively try to sell you stuff. I saw some beautiful bracelets there though, but make sure you show interest only if you really-really want to buy something. If not, refuse them firmly and walk away, otherwise they'll chase you and you can't imagine you persistent they are.

The empty palace. If you like mosaics this is the place to visit. It's well signposted until the last 100m when you have to go down a side road, or you could take a horse carriage from the square. The structure is well maintained but looks very empty with no furniture. Without a guide you have to guess at a rooms use. The gardens are a cooling down place and many of the rooms have modern art exhibits in them. There is no place for refreshments in the building so make sure you have some with you

An oasis of beauty in the chaos of Marrakech. wow! what a sight! Again with out hap hazard sight seeing we didn't really know what to expect but this is such a stunning palace. With it's inner garden and beautiful mosaics and engravings it's a little spot of paradise in the desert. So much colour and texture everywhere it still looks luxurious and regal despite being plundered and damaged over the years. A must for any architecture and or history lover.

A Piece of History. The entrance fee is cheap, and well worth it. The details of the architecture is very interesting. The building is fairly well preserved, but there are no furnishings of the era inside. It is just an empty shell today. Still a must see if you are in Marrakech.

Gorgeous. Our family absolutely LOVED this place - it is really - truly - lovely, so interesting, a peek into Morocco's exotic past and well worth visiting if you are interested in architecture and the stunning interiors that are characteristic of this country, which I personally find addictive. With a little bit of imagination, you can 'feel' what it might have been like 300 - 400 years ago, a completely different world.
Great architectural detail. The palace has beautiful ornaments all over it. All with amazing details.. There's also a nice garden in the back.

Sure, tou have to see it. This should be on every tourist list. The site is quiet big and the entrance fee decent (50 dirhams, i think). Stone and Wood carvings, mosaics, painted ceilings, lovely interior garden. Peacefull visit.

Fantastic example. A lovely place to wander around and enjoy the beautiful hand painted ceilings, hand carved stucco, cool rooms and sunny courtyards.We included this in our guided tour which was well worth it, we learnt lots about the history, the lifestyle and culture of those who have lived in and used the palace, lots about the artisans responsible for the exquisite decoration and the materials used. It was very interesting .There was also a modern art/ sculpture exhibition on during our visit and it was a nice addition to see modern displays dotted around, although I could not see any info regarding these pieces and our guide did not know anything about them.

Pretty but small. Really beautiful architecture, nice courtyard and garden area. However, some rooms seemed like they needed some work done in them and it was a bit small - I expected a little more ground. But still a great visit.

It's OK. That's about it . It's worth wandering around, good to take a few photographs of yourself here just to say you have seen and been. But the administration of the palace needs to do more to offer a sense of history.Information was lacking and so was availability of languages with only French and Arabic on offer. If you want to find out more you'll need to book a guide though this can be costly and rack up a bill if you're planning to take day trips elsewhere or visit other palaces as the same will occur.
Huge and beautiful. For the price it is definitely worth visiting it. The place is huge and you can easily get lost. Beautiful pictures on a sunny day.

Stunning tiles and painting. A large area has been restored and opened up since we last visited several years ago. It's a great place to wander around with some wonderful tiling and painting. It's not up to the standard of the Alhambra but that gives you an idea of what to expect.
Go for architecture & decoration. A lovely example of stunning Islamic architecture/decoration - woodwork, carved stucco, mosaic, and painted ceilings.
Nice simple palace. Lovely garden and interesting modern art in the different rooms. Good way to escape the madness of Medina.

Beautiful Palace. Plenty of Historic facts presented by our wonderful guide,Nabil. Beautiful architecture and gardens- so plenty of videoing etc. Lots of restoration work taking place.Would love to return at some point in the future

Tour. Very good trip to see the palace we were lucky to see the opening of the refurbishment of the palace. The history lesson was good beautiful architecture and painstaking work by the artists who created the ceilings and walls .
Beautiful palace. When visiting the palace you get a good impression of the quarters of the sultan who lived here. The inner courts are very beautiful.
great. this is one the best attraction in marrakech that we really loved , interesting and many things to discover about morocco culture ,

A mini Alhambra-esque oasis. Although small, the palace is a pleasant and tranquil break from the busy Medina. Can get busy with tourists because of its size so don't expect the place to yourself. Pretty courtyards.
intersting attraction. we had a visit in bahia palace and it was interesting place , we had a great time disocering this attraction

The beauty of handcraft. Amazing example of arabic handcraft art in the magical palace. It is bigger than it looks from outside and offering amazing examples of zalij, sculptures and other typical arabic mosaics.

Tiles and tiles.. The entrance to this palace is not far from the El Badi Palace. As seems to be the case in Marrakesh the entrance is unassuming. A short walk through a garden which deserves to be better kept than it is, leads to the main entrance. This in turn leads to a series of rooms and courtyards beautifully decorated with tiling , stone carving and painted wood. The courtyards are delightful in mainly white and blue while the rooms luxuriate in myriad colours and gold leaf. There seems to be a never ending chain of these rooms leading one into another. Make sure your camera battery is charged before you visit.You will see a lot of tiled rooms and courtyards in Marrakesh but this place must have some of the best.There are toilets but no café or shop.

little bit of peace and quiet. We stumbled across the palace whilst we were out for a wander and its a nice oasis in the middle of all the hustle and bustle.Going through the main unimposing gate, it opened up to a lovely grown up driveway with orange trees and herbs before you get to the main palace. The architecture and detail is great to have a look around but there is no descriptions of who, what, where or why. So would recommend a guide wether a person or book to aid.
Last stop. It's beautiful but there is so much more to see. I would make it a last stop rather than a first stop. Usually pretty crowded so hard to get a good photo.

Garden and house.. Large house with lots of rooms and a courtyard all rooms ornate with artifacts and history and culture, toilets didn't see a cafe not too busy and cheap entry.Does close some days so be prepared.
Very nice. Nice gardens and great photo opportunities with fabulous mosaics. 10rad to get in but nice for hour walk and to be in the walled city with all its madness.

Beautiful Bahia. The Bahia Palace was built in the late 19th century it is beautifully decorated and captures the essence of the Islamic and Moroccan style.The walls and ceilings are very detailed and it is definitely worth a visit. The palace was cheap to visit it cost 10 Dirhams which is about 80p.Their are a few information plaques but unfortunately they are only in French and Arabic, it would be nice if the information was accessible to more travelers.

Highly recommended architectural site. This is a beautiful example of Moorish architecture, which we thoroughly enjoyed. However, you must see it with a local guide because there are no descriptions in the rooms providing any hint of what one is viewing. Without the historical context provided by the guide, this would be just another dusty building.
A beautiful place to visit. I loved this place! The architecture is very similar to the Alhambra in the south of Spain. Worth the visit.

Beautiful distraction from the busy medina streets. The palace is a big complex which was being restored at the moment we were there. Still, there was enough to see to get a good impression of the massive building and its use. It also provides a nice view on the medina from the watch tower.

Just A Beautiful Building. We visited the Palace on a sunny day which was advantageous because the sun shone through the building, highlighting its best bits. The walls and ceilings are superb to look at and the whole place is very high class (as a palace should be). The palace was cheap to visit (about £1.50p) which made it a real bargain.
Wonderful . Nice castle to visit in Marrakech specially if like Moroccan decorations and ceiling design with a nice garden when you enter the palace
Tranquil . This is worth a visit - although there was quite a few people there. It is very well maintained and tranquil in the hectic medina -

Nice, but pretty small and dark. The garden is a nice place to take pictures but it is also quite dark. You also have to read about the palace yourself, as there is not a lot of explanatory boards or anything. I still recommend visiting, its a sight to see.
Small beautiful palace. Empty but full of architectural interest. 20 minutes max as there's really only ceilings, carved doors and empty courtyards to see but still worthwhile

Very beautiful . This place is beautiful and charming, and the entrance is just 10 dihrams (+-1euro).
Beautiful to visit, relax and take pictures.

Nice building, but not quite a Palace.... After a 20 min walk through the souks we arrived at Bahia 'Palace" and it didn't wow us as much as the college that is, Ben Youssef Madrasa.Again, lots of lovely features, the colouring and architecture are fabulous, but not amazing. Unfortunately, many of these attractions don't attract tourists, but on the upside it means no queues and no photo-bombers. Cheap entry and good pics to be had at Bahia. As always, make sure you look up, as beauty isn't restricted to eye-level, it can be seen from the floors to the ceilings! Its worth the 20-30 min walk, if you want to tick it off your list but not a crucial part of our trip. We enjoyed BYM, Souks and The Royal Mansour Hotel and La Mamounia over Bahia Palace.

Cheap, dark, badly signed. Scrutinise the map near the entrance carefully. It's the only explanation you'll get. All the heavy relief frescoes like every historic site in marrakesh. If they might tell a story it's lost in the lack of captions. Perhaps a guide would assist, but would they know anything or just make it up? Best read an architectural book before. There are lots of rooms off the multiple courts, but little clue for any distinct purposes they may have had.

Beautiful Palace. Bahia Palace is a beautiful building to walk around. The walls, floors and ceilings are all beautifully decorated with intricate and colourful mosaics. You don't really need to pay for a guide, as you can often listen to other tour groups as they move from room to room.It does get quite busy, so best to go in the morning before 11am to avoid the crowds.

Stunning. My French is only so-so and the vast majority of the information here is in French and Arabic. But even with a very limited working knowledge of French, this place is amazing. They also frequently have a local calligraphy artist working. The architecture will absolutely blow your mind. Westerners used to the Greco-Roman building models will certainly appreciate the contrasts in Eastern architecture.

Peace and quiet in the middle of Marrakech. Although it is signposted, one blink of an eye and you walk past it. You know that you are there because of all the boys in front, trying to hassle you. But do go inside, it is sooo worth it, nice and quiet and very cool. High stairs but there again, the upstairs is utterly beautiful. Also watch the birds standing guard.

A true Palace!. Bahia is one of the most beautiful buildings in Morroco! For only 10 Dirhams (1 euro) you can see this attraction. The most beautiful part is the ceilings that have interesting decoration.
Bahia Palace intersting place. our visit to Bahia palce was so different from other places , there much to see and we had a great time there
Nice old palace with spectacular ceilings.. Cheap to visit and well worth it. Good architecture but not a lot else. Look up for max value. Ceilings are amazing.

A cool palace. One great thing about Islamic palaces is that they were built to be cool and are wonderful places to visit on hot days. This one is a beautiful little gem, not vastly interesting but still really worth a short visit.

An oasis of calm. Although the bustle of marakech can be exciting this little gem allows a few moments of peace. It's walls seem to close out all sound. The entrance is along an orange tree lined driveway. The rooms have ornate ceilings and the peace and calm is well v wroth the 10drm enhance fee. The baadi pslace is also nearby and with a visit if only to see the storks
Marrakech Must See.. Cheap entrance fee (DHM 10 pp)Central location in Marrakech.The tiles alone will take your breath away.
Nice. Admission 20DH. WC inside main courtyard. You need 1 or 2 hours in here as there are so many rooms, passageways and courtyards to see. The art work is fantastic
Interesting . Only 10 dirham to get in. You'll have more information if you go with a guide but we just wandered around on our own looking at the lovely architecture and traditional design.
Nice for a wander around. Wandered around here for maybe an hour. It was worth a visit but there's not a whole lot to see really. Maybe with a guide it would have been more interesting.
