Good insight to a previous time. Wish there was more information provided at the Bahia Palace. Although not an ancient building, it was still important and I'm sure there are some interesting facts and stories about it. So many rooms and quite tranquil.

Beautiful. Just amazing loved it. The architecture is astonishing. A must see when in Marrakech. On the way there or way back go to henna art caffe it's on the small street right down of the entrance :).

Nice palace. It is a nice historical palace with nice architecture especially the ceilings, few visitors were there, I saw more beautiful palaces at Egypt but Bahia was generally nice and worth visiting
Calming. Within the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh you find havens of peace and tranquility this is one of them

Beautiful palace despite serious need of renovation.. This palace is definitely worth a visit for the beautiful chambers you can walk through (with or without guide). I explored the site myself, which is perfectly fine although any information concerning the rooms/purpose/decoration is lacking or when available it is only there in Arabic or French. Nonetheless worth a visit that takes you about an hour to an hour and a half. Every room/courtyard has their own special works of art, mosaics, patterns and styles. Really interesting to see! Even though many of the rooms require serious renovation (e.g. faded colors, missing tiles, damaged mosaics) it is still worth a visit and in a way adds to the experience of a past and forgone time. Finally, the entrance fee with only 10DHM per person is certainly not a drawback!

Stemning. I went here with a guide who had alot of information and fun facts about this place. From the outside it doesn't look like anything special, but the inside really is! It's the mother of maroccan design:)

Berber Moorish archeticture. The Bahia palace is one of the highlights in Marrakech.It was built in the 19 c and still keeps its historic halo showing the the way how the Pachas were living in the red city. Its various sections made the visitors lost in the labirynthe of the Moroccan intimate life

Nice architecture. For only 10 dirham (1 euro) a nice place to visit in Marrakech. To see everything takes about 30 minutes and I was impressed but the morrocan architecture and detail.
Besides that the place was empty but that didnt really matter.
Nice historical place . Wonderful palace with a nice and quite athmosphere... good Place to shot awesome pictures. .. you have to visit thus, if you are in marrakesh....

Palatial grandeur. Getting to the palace was quite interesting walking past the herbalist and spice sellers all of whom try to entice you into their shops. I was not prepared for the splendour of the palace. The ceilings were beautiful and wandering around gave you the sense of the splendour the inhabitants lived in.

A little disappointing. As palaces go, this wasn't particularly inspiring. Having visited India last year a with a palace on every corner so it seems this was very tatty and uninspiring. There were some lovely painted ceilings though but don't go expecting to be enthralled

Tiles, painted wood ceiling and doors. You will see the best of Tiles, painted wood ceiling and doors in this palace. It's very close to the Jamaa ul fna square, 15 minutes walking. Entry fee is 10 dirhems.

Embarrassingly cheap!. 10MAD (less that £1) entrance to this beautiful palace which, although empty, is still beautifully preserved.
No information in English but that doesn't matter at all.

Best sections are under renovation & closed to public. Visited the palace twice, first time around was without a guide and was done with the circuit in about 10 minutes. Came the next day with a English guide for the actual storytelling. Did pick up few interesting bits from him along with him telling us the best part of the palace is the back courtyard which was closed to public for renovation. From what i got to see, the Bahia Palace was among the least interesting sites of my 11 days tour. Lot of it may be blamed on the closure of sections, a lot on seeing much better sites in Morocco and a lot on our guide, he provided interesting information on the style of construction but little on the historical facts. The entry to the site is 10 dirham

Real beauty!. Amazingly beautiful traditional architecture! The mosaic floor, the decorations and smallest details - everything is worth seeing. It's a pity that we didn't have a guide to explain more about it but it was so lovely to see all on our own nevertheless!
Historical Interest.. I love historical places where ever they are in the world. Be sure to visit here and take some time to learn about Marrakesh history. As ever lovely architecture.

Worth visiting. We visited on a quiet February - so few people visiting. This made for a peaceful - relatively tourist free visit. As s result it was peaceful, lovely vistas etc. However the ceilings and doorways are beautiful and are well worth seeing on busier days
Interesting old Palace. We enjoyed our walk around Bahia palace with it's ornate interiors and wonderful wood carved features.
Nice place. This was a great place. We enjoyed our time in this place, if u are in marrakech visit bahia place, it worth a visit, its one of the most beautiful place in marrakech
Spectacular tile work. I was fascinated with the beautiful tile works in each of the rooms. Some of the ceilings have intricate paint and tile work. Definitely a place to visit.

Beautiful but quick to look round.. This is a beautfiful, peaceful place to look around. The ceilings are incredible but you do need to use your imagination to picture what the rooms would have been like (most are empty). There were lots of tour groups and so it did ruin the peaceful vibe slightly but it's hard to avoid this. We walked around without a guide and were only there about 20 mins.

Spectacular decorated architecture - free guides help put it in context. After paying 10 dirhams (about 1 Euro) for entry one enters the first courtyard. The separate waiting rooms have symbolism for muslims, jews and others.On entering the main building - a series of rooms with courtyards - one sees truly amazing mosaics, zouak (painted timber), carvings, ceilings and windows.Not to be missed - keep looking up and around and you will continue to be impressed.

One up on Number 10, Downing Street!. Built for the Grand Vizier (read Prime Minister) of the Sultan in the late 1800s this amazing palace was designed to house his wives and concubines, as well as providing a place of business. Like so much of Moroccan architecture, the outside is not particularly impressive, but the inside is beautifully decorated, particularly the ceilings. There is also an interesting burial ground within the walls. The graves with the highest horizontal tombstones marked the final resting places of the most important, and most were aligned with Mecca. However, some were set at right angles so evidently were of a different faith.
Bahia Palace. Beautiful mosaics on the walls and ceilings. I expected a bit more, not a must, but a nice break from the craziness of Marrakech.
it can be better..... Nice... but something missing in there... maybe some details of how it was made everything... like a live artisans... or something a little bit more...

Peaceful cool wander around attractive palace with beautiful cedar carving and tile work. Went as a group with a local guide as part of a walking tour. There are very few exhibits, no furniture etc. however many beautiful rooms with interesting ceilings with carved cedar wood and attractive tile work. Only 10dh entry and a delightful hour or up to 2 hours wander through this palace makes a break from the heat and noise of the central Medina

Beautiful architecture . Yesterday we went to the bahia palace. The garden outside is beautiful. Inside the architecture looks amazing. Nice as Well, is that you could cool down here walking in the shadow. This is a must do of marrakesh.
A little oasis of calm in the bussle. Gorgeous architecture and a really lovely peaceful place for an hours chill in the bussle of Marrakech, and only 10dh to enter!
Old Palace. Moorish architecture at its best. Well preserve houses and rooms within a nice gardens area. Not too expensive to visit, money worth.

Worth a look if you have a few hours spare. Not one of the more significant sites but certainly one worth a couple of hours in the sunshine. More modern than many of the places to visit and one that offers a long drive like entrance and then gives you the direction of travel. Something not found in many sites.
Like most other sites in Marrakech information is lacking,
Do not miss. A quiet oasis of calm just round the corner from Ferblantier square. look up at the wonderful ceilings, and wander slowly through the interlinked spaces.

Beautiful historical Palace , quiet and calm in the busy Medina. We visited early in the morning with our guide. From the entrance lined with bitter orange trees and beautiful flowers, you step into the Palace and are immediately surrounded by quiet cool open rooms with stunning tiles and wonderfully decorated wooden ceilings. A real sense of how these families lived is on offer. No furniture or anything but you can see the unadorned bare bones. We just loved it.
Janzib . Absolute beautiful old palace, really must go and see this..10dirhams per person well spent. Can spend ages looking at the extraordinary architecture.

Step back in time.. Wonderful gardens lead up to a door to wonderland. Such mosaics! This really gives a glimpse into the way life was lived:-). A good point for tourists is that the toilets are clean. Always useful to know.
Beautiful and breathtaking. Amazing Moorish architecture to see while in Marrakech. Beautiful gardens and very serene. No wonder it means "Brilliance" translate from its name.
Holiday in Marrakech.. Extremely interesting visit especially if you pay for an experienced guide . He brings the palace to life. The history is awesome. Not to be missed.
Attractive place. This is well worth an hour of your time, and all for 10 dirham (way less than £1). Beautiful old tiles, carvings, plants etc. Great place for taking photographs.

Very interesting. reat place to visit as is most of Marrakech you just need to get past the attention of the locals but as long as you expect this and are prepared for it then I would definitely recommend as a top place to visit,

Interesting but not a great deal left. Stunning ceilings and stonework but beyond that it's just a maze of rooms with varying level floors. Is it a must-go place? No. It is however an interesting place to experience.

Must See, spendid work of art.. We were with local guide to take us around and explain to us about the palais, the mosaic and craving wood works is superbly done. Amazing skill with the detail and pattern. Take some moment and enjoy it. Entrance fees apply. Worth every penny here, not much.

A great escape. This is a great place to spend some time in Marrakech. It is interesting enough to amuse firva while but most importantly it keeps you off the streets and away from the madness and agression out there!

Nice to see but not necessary . Liked Bahia palace but if you only have a couple days in Marrakech it's not a "must see." Has great colors and tile work and is one of the newer and well maintained palaces.
Beautiful simplicity. A little bare and sparsely decorated, but what is there is lovely, romantic and very worth the effort to find and the small entry fee. It is apart of Marrakech.
A must see. Each ceiling and doorway a breathtaking example of Moroccan art. The detail and intensity of each pattern will defy you to understand the hours it would have taken to create it.

Peaceful with no traders inside and costs less than £1. Well worth a visit. The plaster and carved decoration in here is stunning and the grounds are very well kept. Superb place to collect your thoughts and escape the madness outside. If you do not understand written French I recommend researching the history on wifi before you visit, so you understand what you are looking at when you arrive. 10/10

Extravagant multi-roomed palace. The palace contains many courtyards, some open with gardens, some closed with fountains. Small alcoves or anterooms are divided from larger ones, each in traditional form, tiled, but particularly spectacular are the decorated interiors of the roofs which take many forms. Enclosed gardens break up the form. Altogether it is a delightful place to wisit in a relatively calm part of the city.

Beautiful Palace; not to be missed. . Beautiful palace with wonderful architecture and 'internal' and external gardens, tpathways lined with Saville orange trees, very peaceful and relaxing compared to the hustle and bustle outside! Not to be missed.

Fantastic Palace. maintained well.A guide might be helpful. A beautiful garden as soon as you enter, which leads to a beautifully old styled building (the palace). Great decor, though lacks any signs whatsoever. Might not be a bad idea to get a local guide (we didnt get one) Entry is a less than a Euro!
Oasis of Quiet Midst Turmoil of Marrakesh. Very nice gardins and riads near to main square in Marrakesh. Cheap to get in and a nice tranquil place to wind down if turmoil outside is too much.
Very nice visit. A wonderful and atmospheric place that everyone visiting Marrakech should visit. We liked it very much and look forward to Visiting this palace again.
Beautiful mosaic work. It's amazing to find such a haven in the middle of such a busy hectic place. The architecture and detail is exquisite.

Beautiful Old Palace. Very peaceful with beautiful tiles & decorative woodwork. Stunning ceilings. Pretty courtyards. The rooms are empty of furniture & we were not offered a guidebook. However, it is still worth wandering around the rooms & courtyards. We visited in January but I can imagine it would be a perfect place to get away from the heat in the summer.

One of the best historical places we visited in Marrakech. In this place I would recommend to visit with guide. Its big, pretty well maintained and has many stories. With guide it may easily take 2 hours (I did it on my first visit).

Well Worth a Visit. Decided to walk and find the palace, very calm with the storks nesting to the top of the old walls. Spent a couple of hours walking round, taking in the views and the dont forget to go down into the cellars. Great photos as we visited in winter so not too many other people there at the same time.
Must visit. This was the only palace we visited in 13 days so cant compare to anything else. Cheap entry but must have a guide which we did have

Beautiful palace but take your own guide book. A really lovely palace with some truly stunning decor. Definitely a must-see but I recommend taking your own guide book as there's little information inside and what there is, is mostly not in English.

Gorgeous Architecture and History. Just inside the south end of the Medina this museum is maybe Marrakech's best example of the architecture and history that typify and define this unique city. Entry is approximately 1 Euro per adult and it would be easy to say I wish it was better maintained but they do a good job.
Got lost and stumbled upon this place. It's worth taking a walk around and admiring all the details. It's also a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the medina!
More info. Very good, not obvious where the tour guides were. leaflets would be good.Especially in English, my French is not as good as it should be.

Great building. Great building, nice decoration, nothing inside. Quiet when we visited (winter), which I think was a big plus. Could use better explanations in English about history, specific decorations, etc. Close to other palaces/ruins/tombs in the south of the medina.

Not the most impressive, but worth a look. The Bahia Palace is located in the medina of Marrakech and also within the district of the Mellah (Jewish quarter).We only spent a short time here with our tour group, but learnt about the interesting history with the help of our guide.There are two main Riyadh’s and courtyards, one large and one small of each.The appealing architecture has detailed ceramics, carved wooden columns, designs, decorations and small gardens.
Nice. Nice palace. Very similar to Sevilla Alcazar but really smaller.We went there in the morning and it was very crowded, so much that it was quite impossible to take photos.

LOL. Not sure what to say about this place. Nothing particular to see there. You pay 10 Dirhams to go in and see in total 8 empty rooms and 3 courtyards. The whole trip shouldn't take you more than 10 minutes if you walk slowly.
A part of Marrakech. The Bahia palace is one of the best tourist attractions in Marrakech, and is definitely worth the few Dirham it costs. It is beautiful and shows the deep culture of the city.
Visit with a guide. Visited the Bahia Palace as arranged by our tour & our group had a local guide. The palace was interesting but with the information provided by the guide, it was more so.

Don't go!. We went to Bahia Palace on January 11th as it was our last day in Marrakech and we had a few spare hours until our flight back home.The entry was 1 euro or 10 dirhams.The palace was literally a building with empty rooms,that's it.It lacks something 'going on in there', perhaps a museum or activities,etc. I've noticed a few small signs with explanations what used to be done by the kings in which room, but it clearly lacked some 'visuals' like furniture or something.Very disappointing.No cafes or gift shops inside.
No explanation. Although it might be worthwile, without a guide it is not interesting at all, except for the architecture. No explanation at all.
Lovely. Nice place to visit. Atmospheric and historic, great ceilings and mosaic floors. Must see on holiday.

Nice garden and palace is in OK but bare conditions. Guards are fairly rude and don't expect any change for the admission. Palace is pretty but lacks and furniture or information or photos on how it would have looked in its glory days. Cafe next door has a rooftop terrace which gives a good view down onto the gardens.

Great Architecture. It was only a 5min walk from our Riad and we went quite early.
The architecture is quite impressive and the history is interesting.
Bahia Palace is one of the places to see in Marrakech.

Well worth the money!. It is not spectacular and there is not so much to see acutally, besides the palace itself. The whole building is made up by a set of smaller rooms and a few courtyards, without any decoration besides the mosaic and wall painting.It might not be the best choice for children, nor people out for a "wow-factor", but it is a calm place where you could get a glimce of the former and more glorious Marrakech. The entrance fee is only 10MAD, well below what you would pay for similar attractions in other cities!

Go early in the day. But do go. . Well worth the visit. The architecture is quite impressive and, if you take a good guide, you will find the history of the palace equally interesting. Earlier in the day is better both because it is less crowded and because the light works so much better for pictures.

A must-see!. Bahia Palace must be on the top 5 list of places to see on a visit to Marrakech. We walked it from Djeema el Fna square (about 20 mins), but a horse-drawn carriage would be a nice way to get there. The latter will get you there straightaway; forget the maps and your sense of direction, it is tucked away a little but well worth the visit.

Needs an urgent restoration! . They have been working for years on one of its patios and were not able to finish it... I liked very much this place, but now I think it is getting too deteriorated. Be advise that the region where the palace is located is under a huge renovation, which may take years...
Cool place to see. Definitely get a guided tour if possible. Otherwise you will just be looking at rooms and only admiring the architecture.
Nice way to escape the crowds. A nice peaceful place to escape to from the busy roads of Marrahkesh. Some nice rooms, not too hot, you will not find any locals here only tourists.

A peaceful oasis in bustling Marrakesh. A quiet oasis in bustling Marrakesh and worth spending an hour wandering through the various rooms. Although this was built in 1884 this is a classic example of a Riad in the Medina. A smaller version of Alhambra palace in Granada with lovely decorations and tiling.

Fabulous!. This palace is magnificent, going from room to room to see the amazing craftsmanship in tile work, wood painting, and just the general floor plan of such a massive, lovely place, was a great experience.
very pretty place. we enjoyed walking thru the palace. gardens very nice . fun to see the size of a place someone once lived. worth the trip
Nice place but not a must. A lovely place with lots of mosaic work on the walls, cool for pictures and I would say that's basically it.
Visit to Bahia palace. Pales in comparison to La Alhambra in Granada but a fine example of moorish architecture nevertheless. Spice souks nearby is worth a walk through.

A guide definitely enhances this visit.. We were surprised by the beauty of this place. But without a guide we would not have understood what we were seeing in each room. It would have been just another beautiful Moroccan building. The guide also allowed us to understand the story of the place. It is definitely something you should see while in Marrakech.

A welcomed surprise . We went to this palace a bit uninspired as we had seen many places already in Fez and Marrakech. However we were pleasantly surprised by the different rooms, the paintings in the roofs and the different patios. Definitely recommended!

Fabulous architecture and designs. Nowhere will you see more glorious paintings, tile work, architecture, and gardens than in this glorious site. Wander the rooms to hear stories of harems of concubines, multiple wives, children... The ceilings alone are worth a few hours of staring. Make sure to get a good tour guide to enjoy all the very interesting descriptions of what it was like living within these walls. I would definitely not have wanted to be a woman imprisoned there, as beautiful as it was.
Lovely old palace. We wandered through beautiful carved & decorated doorways into rooms designed to be kept cool, gazing up at the beautiful ornate ceilings & taking lots of photos.

Beautiful. I would expect this to be on every visitors to do list and it is certainly one of the highlights. Entry price is very reasonable, but I would recommend taking a private tour to learn more about the history as there is no information if you visit independently.A very peaceful location, to escape the city for a while. The area accessible to visitors isn't huge, so you can walk around in about 30 mins if you are limited on time, although it's nice to spend a little longer taking it all in.

Nice Place !. You really need to visit this place, its beautiful !Inside a guy decided to become our guide (of course not free) and he was excellent. We learned a lot about the rooms, the construction, the life before etc.... I recommend you to do a visit with a local its much better :)
Beautiful place. Must see.. We loved this palace truly beautiful. Only 10dh entrance The colours and detail. Just go and admire. Great place to take pics. Easy to find in the medina.

Stunning Palace. Very easy to get to from anywhere around the Medina, the Bahia Palace offers a stunning glimpse over the amazing architecture of the time. The palace is impressively big and the gardens around it are beautiful, it is worth a visit. The entry is very cheap at 10 DH, 1 Euro per adult.

Worth the visit....but with a guide. The one time we were looking to be hassled in Marrakech we weren't! It was recommended we get a guide for site (we were told the unofficial guides are just as good) but despite hanging around we couldn't find an english speaking guide. We visited anyway.It was very crowded which made enjoying the serenity of the place and seeing the tiling a little difficult. There is no information available and as the rooms are empty you can't even guess the details of the Palace's history. It was a shame not to have a greater appreciation of its history nor the scale of it (not all is open tothe public). As usual, getting change at the ticket booth was a challenge.We didn't enjoy it as much as the Badi Palace but we do enjoy older history (Badi Palace - c 15th Century vs Bahia Palace - late 1800's).

Stunning ceilings, a must see. This was one place I really wanted to visit and I wasn't disappointed. If you are looking for opulent furnishings you will be disappointed but with every ceiling hand painted, and different there is plenty to see. Beautiful building with an interesting history.
Beautiful Palace. Peaceful place - most likely already on your travel list ... took us 30-40 min to complete it as only a dozen or so rooms to explore.

Crazy Design work to make you marvel. Very cheap (10dH) per person to get in. It takes maybe 20-30 minutes to check out.The attention to detail in the entire place is INSANE. I'm not even someone who's so involved with art but this place makes you stop and wonder just how they did everything. A must when in Marrakech, perfect as a day starter to get your appetite going. Really glad we went.

Lovely spot. A really interesting palace with absolutely beautiful detail in the architecture and design. We visited with a guide, which made it more interesting to learn about the inhabitants and history. Not sure that information would be readily available at the site otherwise. A nice spot to take a break from the bustle of the medina.

Beautiful place. Bahia Place was only a few hundred meters from our Riad so was very easy to find. It's an interesting place with great architecture. The ceilings were quite ornate. It wasn't particularly busy when we went.

Lovely palace . Bahia palace has been beautifully restored and offers a welcome respite from the chaotic medina. The workmanship is incredible, it gives an insight into how people lived. There are lots of guides speaking several languages to guide you through the palace.
interesting place to visit. Lots of interesting rooms and fruit trees, great gardens, must have been very nice to leave in, great reminder of the rich history of the country

Beautiful and well reconstructed / Krásné a dobře zrekonstruované. Beautiful and well reconstructed piece of architecture. Appears an oasis and it is not hard to imagine, how different life from the neighbourhood grand vizier and his wide family had. The entrance fee is surprisingly low, only 10 dirhams. Krásné a dobře zrekonstruované architektonické dílo. Jeví se jako oáza a není těžké si představit, jak odlišný život od nejbližšího okolí hlavní vezír a jeho široká rodina vedli. Vstupné je překvapivě nízké, pouhých 10 dirhamů.

So beautiful. So beautiful and evocative of a past age. It is worth hiring a guide to find out what the different part of the buildings are, as signage is minimal. Can't believe it is so cheap to enter (10 dirhams). It should be doubled to pay for the maintenance
nice visit. We enjoyed this visit. Similar to other moorish places we saw in Spain like the Alhambra but not as grand.

Pretty, but crowded. It was a lovely palace but it was so crowded with people. Without a guide we were just left to marvel at the pretty features. It took us less than a half an hour to see everything. But for ten dhm it was well worth the cost.
Beautiful!. A beautiful place to visit. The architecture is stunning here. It's a popular attraction though so prepare for crowds once you're inside but it's definitely worth a visit!
Interesting. Not a lot to see but quite interesting, massive place must have been amazing when in use. Ladies toilet leaves a lot to be desired try and hold on.

Beautiful place . So we went there on a morning , it is such a pretty palace i started imagining how would it be if it was full of life... We went on our on so i don't really know much of the history of that place but thats fine i can still look it up anytime. What really impressed me though was the sealing, breathtakingly stunning and colorful i swear i could've stared at it for an hour !! It was really pretty. The water fall was not working but i still think the place is worth a little visit.
Gorgeous. A place not to be missed in Marrakesh. Stunning architecture in all its oriiginal glory. Miss anything but not the Bahia Palace.

Quiet oasis close to Mellah. This little palace offers some respite from the noise and smells of the busy outside. Beautiful mosaics and carvings. When you come out turn right into a beautifully renovated part of Marrakech with cute little shops where sellers don't hassle you.

Small palace . Very small old palace worth a quick visit. Nice intricate design but water fountain turned off during our visit. Visit all over in 30 minutes after taking photos. Surprisingly quite busy with tourists.

Nice place to visit but watch out for the oranges.... I visited the Bahia Palace as part of a private tour. The entrance fee is minimal and it is a nice place to wander around for about 30-45 minutes. It is an old palace and has very nice tiles and wood carving. The government could maintain it a bit better. Be careful for the many orange trees because an orange could fall off and hit you in the head. My guide said that the oranges were not good for anything because they tasted bitter. Even worse to have a terrible tasting orange

Splendid . A must while in Marrakech. Leisurely stroll the grounds, but a guided tour provides much more insight. The concubine quarters were under construction when we were there, but that portion of the tour will add more splendor to this fantastic former residents.
Nice palace. Nice palace with some great mosaics. A quiet place just off the busy spices market and the souks. Enjoy a juice at the shop around the corner after your visit.

Good for a brief visit. We supposed here for a visit which ended up being very quick. Nothing is in English so without a guide, it was just old rooms with beautiful architecture and mosaic tiles. We walked through all the expansive rooms and made up our own commentary which was quite funny with a 8 & 11 year old. The entire visit was about 1/2 hr. Loads of nice shops along the way.
Lovely palace with great cats!. The palace was lovely, with gorgeously detailed tiling and ceilings. Cat lovers will also enjoy the entry area's array of stray cats!
Impressive archeticture. The guide went through every single detail of the palace. I recommend a guided tour to appreciate the beauty behind the palace.
Amazing architecture. Loved the quality of the mosaics and the carving. Room after room described a period of wealth and creativity in Morocco.

Could be better. This place is a historical place to visit and the entrance fee is very cheap, however apart from the wall and ground inside the palace there is nothing more to see. You cannot work out what each rooms were what so you can't see a story of the rooms, they don't have guides to tell you what happened where so to be honest the experience was not that great.
Bahia palace . One of the places to visit while in Marrakech. It's a 10dh entrance fee. Once your in you get to see some old architectures and some nice photo opportunities.
Pretty. Very pretty best to visit in the morning as gets busy in the afternoon. The grounds of the palace are great.

not good. the reason i went to this place with my friends is because i heard that this place has a beautiful grand court yard, when we got there we were charged 20dh perv person to enter, but the staff did not tell us that the grand court yard is closed for 3 years for renovation... got ripped off... not happy.do not go until 2018.
Beautiful buildings. Beautiful gardens and buildings for a very decent price. I would definitely recommend a visit. An added bonus is that there are decent restrooms in here, so worth a stop.

Beautiful architecture. It s so fresh inside! U can see million cats all over the place. Hahaha! I m a cat lover. It s cute to be interviwe by architecture students about the Palais. The mosaics are great. 50DHR fee for one adult.
Peaceful and beautiful. Wander through the cool gardens then on through the succession of rooms and courtyards. Each area has its own character and each is beautifully decorated.

Beautiful interior!. So much history with beautiful architecture! Definitely check this palace out - some of the intricate interior is gorgeous. It is typically packed with a lot of tourist though - so had a hard time getting clean shots. But it was worth it. Do have a guide or some sort of guide book to understand the history.

Really lovely buildings!. If you are travelling to Marrakech, Morocco then you should definitely take the time to visit this place. The buildings are beautiful. And the decorations on the walls are really well done.

Beautiful building. Went around 10 and it was quiet which was excellent as the intricate decor is worthy of some photography time. The entrance fee was only 10 dirhams (£1 = 14 dirham) so well worth the pleasant stroll through the courtyards and garden area. It is in the Mella (Jewish area) so you can get your spices at the same time as we were taken to the spice shops nearby by the cook from our Riad to stock up.

Beautifully done. An exquisite restoration of a fabulous palace with room after room of splendid tiling and painted ceilings. It rivals the best of Europe in its scope and magnificence.Easy to walk to and to find from the medina. Closed on Tuesdays.
It is not bad!. I expected more from this place... It is overcrowded of tourists and a little bit far from the centre! I'll probably stay in another place next time!
palace visit. One of the old palace complexes. This one has great rooms with amazing carved roofs and mosaics. Well worth a visit
Must see. One of the beautiful places to visit. Although i am Egyptian i was taken by the the Arctic of the halls in the place.It eas built by the ruler for his beloved beautiful wife

Very detailed and beautiful.. Very detailed and beautiful. Definitely worth a visit. We enjoyed wandering around here for a few hours. It is not huge, but amazingly carved and tiled and it was so relaxing sitting in the garden courtyard. We had lunch at a rooftop terrace restaurant straight across the street from the entry and that was really good food, with an affordable daily prix fix menu.

Beautiful, but very small!. Quite a small trek through tiny streets to get there, and paid 10dhs for the entry. I was a bit disappointed with the small size of the place, as well as decorations that have not been restored properly. Nonetheless, I guess that's all part of the experience. Is it worth the visit? I'd say give it a skip and spend the time somewhere else!
Beautiful. This was a beautiful place and cheap to enter. We spent a good 1.5 hours taking photos and absorbing the amazing design work throughout the palace. A definite must visit!

Interesting Palace - well worth a visit. A very large palace with fantastic rooms and ceilings. The gardens have orange trees providing shade. It would be wonderful if there were some furnished rooms but unfortunately thats all gone

Beautiful visit . Lovely lovely architecture. Peaceful and tranquil and much fun imagining how much it might cost to recreate today. The ceilings are gorgeous and a gem of of local beauty. Very enjoyable.

A great respite . After the craziness of el fna and surrounding souk, Bahia Palace provides a plush break from it all. The gardens and architecture are well worth the visit and a guide can provide an historical edge.

very nice decor. not a palace like England palace' infact it was strange, you walk in and it shows how a man would have lived with 4 wives the different rooms and that Moroccan' decorate theyre hosue from the inside not the outside as it' the inside that matters nice philosophy.there are some graveyards inside aswell. Overall very nice but go with a tour guide as there is nothing to help guide you!

Lovely architecture. Bahia palace is a nice place to visit, it's cheap and not too far from jemaa el fna. It's a beautiful palace which is nice for photos! There's not too much information available unless you get a guide.

Beautiful Place. This site can be visit in 30 mins to an hour. It is a beautiful place, great for photos. Not expensive entrance. If possible, I would suggest to get a tour guide to walk you thru it, so you can better understand it. If travel during the hot season, avoid visiting noon to 4pm.
A must See!!!. If you are in Marrakech don't miss AlBahia Palace, beautiful doors and breathe taking ceilings amazing painting. When you just get inside you would definitely say (Wooow)
Very picturesque . Well worth a visit to see some beautiful architecture and really get a feeling of Marrakesh before you realise the country is poverty stricken

personally I found it a bit disappointing. I like to see more then a ruin, the downstairs was closed, it was nice for a quick stop only. Maybe other people think otherwise.
It was warm in the day, bring a scarf to protect possible naked shoulders (also in winter: hot sun!)

Save your money and visit a real Palace. Poorly curated, very very signs and notices to create interest - devoid of any furniture and difficult to get an idea of its period charm. Building is worth a visit but save your entrance fee and spend it on a drink at the bar in Palais Sebban, very near the Jamaa el Fna main square. The quality of Moroccan carvings and decoration is quite awe inspiring in comparison.

Beautiful ornate example of Moroccan architecture. Although I am glad I visited this palace for the lovely examples of traditional, ornate and beautiful carvings, mosaics etc. I don't feel you need an awful lot of time here. Maybe this is because we were not on a guided tour and so with no signs or information leaflets we were unaware of what most of what we were seeing was. Still worth a visit if interested in viewing traditional architecture etc and only a moderate entrance cost.
Beautiful. A beautiful palace that shows how the wives and concubines lived. It would be great to see how the furniture looked like. But the tile work is beautiful.

beautiful, imagine would be very busy high season. beautiful ceramics, marble and woodwork. Easy to ramble at your own pace. A must ,especially with such a ridiculously small entry fee - providing work and restoration to this wonderful city
interesting attraction. Beautiful ceilings and craftsmanship. Unfortuately, it is being restored and it is evident that not enough preservation has taken place in recent years.

Well worth a visit amazing mosaics. Loved this palace set in the heart of bustling Marakesh. Its a wonderful place to wander around with fabulous rooms showing decorative ceilings fireplaces floors and doors. If you enjoy the history of Marakesh its a must
You don't need a lot of time here. You don't need a lot of time to look around but you need to que to take photos because it was very busy, worth going on the trip.

Morrocain beauty at its best. A def MUST while in Marrakech! We left this palace for the last minute of our trip and regreted so much doing so! It is soooo freaking pretty! Everything you would expect from the pretty Morocco wealth. And better yet, it's in the middle of everything! Don't miss it!

Palais de la Bahia. A lovely little place, not too big and very basic but it has a lovely courtyard and exquisite mosaics, woodwork and intricate masonry. For around £1 GBP entry it's not going to break the bank and for a little more you can get a guided tour giving you a more intimate history of the palace well worth paying for this and it can accessed in various languages.

Break from city noise. Have a break from the city noise by walking around inside the palace and read about the old history of Marrakech. Situated in south Medina. Entrance fee 10 dirham. The palace is empty, so you have to use your imagination when walking around.

Historical Palace in need of restoration. Entry fees was 20mad. Palace is not well kept. Requires cleaning and restoration. None of the rooms labelled hence tourists would require a guide to get the history behind all the rooms.We did not enjoy the palace much. It is a max 30mins tour.
Below avg. Compare it to the pictures u might ve seen prior to visiting the palace...n u ll be disappointed. However as the entry is 20 dhms, so it did not upset us as much.

Beautiful woodwork, lovely courtyard, so-so tour groups. I'd love to spend some time here on my own and get a sense of what it was like when occupied, but there are lots of small groups who seem to multiply and swell in size once inside.Having said that, the mosaics, carvings and especially the ceilings are well worth seeing.It's a short walk from anywhere and almost free at 10 Dhm.

Historic . Very interesting visit went with a guide as part of a tour so was told of all the history of the place. Wasn't too busy and definitely worth a visit. Can be followed with a visit to the Kasbah which is opposite

A Peaceful Oasis. The courtyard is lovely! As are the mosaics and carvings on the walls. While not the most impressive that I saw in Morocco, this is still a great little spot. Perfect place to get out of the mayhem and enjoy some tranquility.
Great. Lovely palace. Lovely art and decor. Can't beat the entry price. 10dh. Had lovely riads, a thirsty fountain in the middle. Go with a guide if you have not read up on the history

Easy walk from the square and worth a visit. Bahia Palace, along with Badi Palace are both within easy walking distance of each other. Each one is very pretty - and a lovely break from the hectic word outside. They lack the information kiosks that many historical sites in other parts of the world have, but just the same, they are worth a visit.

Nothing Special. Seems to be on the tourist trail, but pretty boring with nothing of great significance. Certainly could be a welcome respite from the teeming masses, if so required.Some signs of Arabic culture, but have seen better.
Look to the ceilings.. Beautiful palace to visit, there are no furnishings the palace but look to the ceilings, all are carved from cedar wood and no two are the same absolutely gorgeous.

One of the best places to look at the original architecture of the palaces. Not really exceptionel, but the best place to look at the mosaics and architecture. There are a restaurant just around the corner of the entrence - try the roof terrasse and a mint the.

Worth a visit but not for long. Small palace, bare of furniture but with beautiful ornate doorframes & ceilings throughout & a few pleasant courtyards. Not much in the way of tourist-friendly amenities - very little signage to learn about the history of the place, no guides, onsite cafe or kiosk. Cost us 10 dirhams (£0.66) each to get in and we were there for about 30 mins. You'd struggle to spend more time than that here I reckon.

Free to visit, fun to imagine life here.. Came here with a group tour. It was interesting to see traditional Moroccan architecture and admire the design and craftsmanship in the carved and painted wooden ceilings. These palaces are national treasures and I'm glad this one is open to the public and free so we can come and see the inside.No furnishings so you'll have to use your imagination. Still, it's fascinating.
ah well. another one of those attractions that's a little bit interesting,[ if you have the time ] finding out how life used to be for royalty

Beautiful Building but empty. . I think the title says it all. 10dh to enter so really cheap and uses up 10-15 minutes of your time. Impressive building but could have done with some artifacts inside to make it feel a little more significant. A far cry from museums and buildings in the UK so don't expect a wealth of culture.
Very interesting . Not a very big place as a tourist point of view so will not take you very long to look around. But it's still a very interesting place

Nice palace. This palace has a historical background that you should know before your visit to fulfil your needs, this palace has good mosaic art of morroco and has influence by all members of morroco populations of Jews and Berbers and Moslems, I think you will not lose if you decided to visit Bahia palace.
Beautiful building. A nineteenth century palace with lovely ceilings and decorated doors. Worth paying for a guide so that you know what you are seeing.
FREE TO WANDER AROUND.... Nice gardens and palace to wander through, there was no entry fee. The rooms were empty but a lovely Palace Riad.

Interesting. In Marrakech, this is one of the big attractions and it doesn't let you down.
The surrounding garden and the building are great to see.
This is a place for people who enjoy their architecture and a bit of history.
Nice and relaxing, and gets you out of the dirty heat outside.
Really nice.
AUTHENTIC 'SUMMER' PALACE. There is a small entrance fee. The grounds are not very large but the building is original and the mosaics are brilliant.

Colourful old building. The Bahia Palace is essentially a collection of rooms that housed the hareem with the favourite concubine using the biggest and best room after she gave birth to a son. It doesn't have much information on display (short outline in the first courtyard as you go in) but it seemed to have been built fairly recently mid 1800's It has some superlative islamic decoration nevertheless and its relative youth allows you to appreciate some of the colours and contrasts they used. It was good to get a sense of colour in the doors and ceilings. Well worth the entrance fee. In a side room you will find a man who does a name/words in arabic script for 25dhm. Ok you can get these in loads of places but I appreciated the fact that he seemed so serene while he did the work and deft at some colourful sweeps to embelish the card. A little bit of art. Good place to get one done as a lot of what you see in the souks is neither what it appears to be or the price you think it is.

Great to see. I didn't know what to expect from a Moroccan palace... though I don't think it was this?! It was great to see though. The architecture and the different designs representing different places, different ideas and different religions (my guide talked for about an hour on this topic alone) is really quite fascinating. I really like the riads, or gardens, in the palace as well. It's not super impressive, but if you compare this palace to one in the likes of Europe you'll se just how differently they all lived.

History explained. This is a quiet oasis after struggling through the souk. Internal courtyards with water features and ceramic mosaics and tiles keep it cool. The building is beautiful and worthy of viewing as much as the exhibits are. The gardens also help with the beauty.
Amazing!. Beautiful design, colors, architecture. carving, doors and windows decorations. It is worth to see it.
No much to see. Nothing special not attractive. Just go to say that I visited a palace, but don't loose much time in this visit
Good to see, but not exciting. We were taken to this place by our tour guide. The most interesting was the storks that were nesting on the taller trees.

Incredible moroccan palace. This palace is beautiful, merging impressive architecture and green spaces. It is a true oasis in the city, and the entrance price is really worth: 10 MAD like for most of the other entry fees in the city.
Lovely!. It is an amazing location. Each and every detail of this construction is worthy to be captured in a picture. Great experience.

Not so "brilliant" now but worth the fee. A few rooms giving a taste of the opulence that once was here. You have to look up to see the best of it. An unassuming entrance by current standards, but a green oasis once inside and a calming peace within Keep your eye out for organised tours - you have a choice of getting ahead of them or leaving them to pass if you want to enjoy it in peace. Alternatively hang around and listen in but you won't learn more than you can pick up in guide books or online.Good idea to see this alongside El Badi Palace to get some perspective - it seems to me the only reason Bahia bankrupted Morocco was that El Badi had already used up most of the money!

Nice but don't expect too much. We were disappointed that the gardens are only relatively small, and only line the pavement between the front gate and entrance to the building.Once inside, it's very pleasant and an impressive display of the luxury available to some.It's also relatively cool so a great place to visit to escape the heat and dust for a while.

JAW DROPPING. A beautiful calm peaceful oasis. Entrance only 10 dhirams(0.60p).To walk up the avenue with beautiful plants, trees and flowers worth it. The tiling, fountains and carved doors are awe inspiring. Must see.Careful of steps into each room.

Interesting. The Bahia Palace did not seem to me to be something to go out of your way to see, but if in the area, it is a nice sightseeing break. The experience would be greatly improved if there were signage explaining the various rooms and grounds, rather than having to go there on a tour or use the services of a guide.

Beauty in a time of mediocrity. In the dust, chaos noise and maize of markets that is Marrakech, there are a few 'oases' .. 'musts' to allow the body and soul to take a respite: One of these is the Bahia Palace, just south of 'The Square'.A beautul collection of rooms, courtyards and amazing mosaics and wood carving, it shows you what time ad beauty COULD create, compared with our concrete boxes and mediocrity: What will WE have to show to posterity in 200 years? Froms the Viziers og the 1800's to P.Diddy, this has been the respite of rich Moroccans for 150 years. Breathe out, open your eyes and enjoy its beauty!
quick and easy. Cost 10 dhs to get in. only a small area to cover. over and done with in 10 mins. either do your own research or get a guide to understand the area better.

Stunning ceilings and Courtyard, but nothing inside the buildings. This has been stripped of all but the ceilings and floors, but they are still well worth the visit. The cedar carvings are stunning, and the courtyard is a pleasant place to sit and enjoy the tranquility of the place. The ceilings remind one of the Union in Oxford, and some bizarre Liberty print!
Pretty place. Beautiful place and lovely to visit and see the carvings however we enjoyed badi palace much more and it had more history and more to explore.

Beautiful!. This is an amazingly beautiful palace where every corner surprises you with great tiles or wood carvings or amazing ceilings. Despite being busy it didn't feel crowded and for history buffs there are guided tours too.

YOU CAN SEE EVERYTHING IN ABOUT 5 MINUTES. Trust me on this, go the Palais Badi just around the corner. You can do this Palace in 5 minutes flat. Not meant to be scathing as it is pretty but there is really nothing much to see & is probably the most expensive 'Must Do' in Marrakech (although it is still only a few pounds each)
Must see. This a *must *see* in the Medina - it is simply beautiful. It is just near the Baddi Palace so you can do the two sites in conjunction with each other....

Wonderful architecture and tiling. This was the first visit we made in Marrakech, and it was a great example of the wonderful architecture and tiling that are found throughout Morocco. Colonnaded courtyards, fountains, exquisitely painted ceilings and doors, finely curved woodwork, and a bit of garden too. Worth the very modest entrance fee.

Very impressive. My son & I made this our first calling point on our daily walk from our Riad in the North of the Medina.I must admit that our first reaction was one of slight disappointment at the simple blue & white of the entrance vestibules, but this rapidly changed to awe as we moved into the inner rooms. These have a real wow factor - beautiful intricate detailing on walls and ceilings, and a few stained glass windows. And the garden even looked better on the way out.Not to be missed!

Probably better with a guide. Its very cheap to enter the palace and worth a visit as you explore Marrakech but there is little information as you walk around the building so probably better as part of a half day walking tour with a guide. Shows the attempt at opulence and it's easy to believe that this class divide still exists in Marrakech.

A pleasant, serene place. a great little palace. Although a little sparse and lacking in any exhibits or info, the place itself was beautiful, and the stonework architecture was incredible. A great little walk through the palace for little money.
Great value. Amazing architecture. Lovely palace, still in very good condition. Excellent value for money. Only thing was I'd have liked a little more information about what was what,

Variety of Styles.. This 'palace' is really a collection of interjoining buildings each with it's own style. Nor really a palace, but more a riad. Several have courtyards with peripheral rooms. Together, they make a pleasant building well worth a visit.

Beautiful design but no explanations!. We visited on an unusually wet day in Marrakech and thought it was beautiful - the colours and tiles were wonderful. However, there were no explanations about what the palace was built for, when it was built, who lived there or what each room was used for - seems a shame to not share more of the history with visitors.
Nice for a wander, worth visiting. A nice palace for a wander , with some lovely looking rooms and typical Moroccan styling. Would recommend a visit.

Well worth the visit, a little crowded.. Very beautiful in general.
Fantastic ceramic work.
Beautiful gardens.
Good to see evidence of periods of broad religious acceptance.
Good visit. I would suggest a guide when you visit this and other site in marrakech . You get so much more from the visit. This place is full of history and very interesting

Great history. Great value for money at 10 Dirham.
Easy to find. Lovely gardens. Beautiful example of centuries old architecture and skilled workmanship.
Fab place to spend an afternoon.

Must See. Only a portion of this palace is open to the public (admission 10 dirhams). There is a series of rooms opening on internal courtyards. There are floor to ceilings decoration. The painted, gilded inlaid woodwork ceilings are breathtaking and colours are still fresh. The stucco work is so delicate that it looks like lace. It is a marvel of a bygone age of craftsmanship where only basic tools were available. As with many sites in Marrakech, there are loads of stray cats - best not to touch them as they are flee ridden.

Only did sights in Marrakech. Inexpensive to get in, not at all busy in October. Could perhaps have done with a guide to explain the history and give some interesting details. Unfortunately no boards with information in English! Beautiful ceilings. Enjoyed our visit.

One of many!. We visited so many palaces while we were in Marrakesh - all interesting in their own right, but it is difficult to remember details of them individually when you get home! They are all worth visiting and cost very little to get in, just 1 or 2 pounds.

Local guide brings the palace alive. You really need a guide to appreciate this palace. Our local guide was very informative about the styles of architecture and decoration we were seeing from room to room. The mosaics on the floors and walls are in good condition. The gardens are lush and beautiful. The wood carving and painting is awesome with great attention to detail. Lots of doors, windows and other features to enjoy. The pictures only tell part of the story that a guide fills in by describing the various designs and lettering and their purpose.One example. The courtyards are square, with the center open to the sky. The center floor is sunken a few inches so that rain water can drain and will not get into the living areas.Note in the pictures a ceiling that looks multicolored when viewed straight up, but is red when viewed at an angle. This is done by the sides of the beams being painted solid red, while the ceiling and bottoms of the beams are painted in intricate patterns.
Beautiful Moroccan details!. Really a lovely sight to see during the day. The detailing is exactly what you would expect of a Moroccan palace!

For the architecture. It is central, it is cheap, so why not. But if you expect gold and glitter you may be disappointed. From the outside it doesn't look much like a castle, but the inside has lots of details for those who are into architecture. It is a cultural pearl, but it didn't really excite me.

Moroccan architecture at its average.. There is nothing here but walls and gardens. The detailing on the Palace was lovely, yet nothing that you can't see better examples of all around Morocco. The huge organised groups of tourists also made this place unbearable as it was such a struggle to maneuver around them whilst they took up entire rooms or patios. I would strongly recommend a trip to the palace ruins instead which is a 5 minute walk away.

Beauty everywhere you look.. We went to have a look around the Bahia Palace today and it was well worth a visit. The architecture is reminiscent of the Alhambra Palace in Granada, Spain although on a much, much smaller scale. Although you try, you can never capture it all on the camera. You just need to sit back, spend some time and take it all in.

Visit was okay, but so much lost potential... . The palace is not extremely old, mid 19th century (so it has a limited history) , but unless you have a guide with you (which we didn't) don't count too much on indication panels as we saw only one or two of them. That, for example, could be something easy enough to fix. Also, I became a real fan during my visit of morroco of carved wood and mosaics, which the palace shows plenty of BUT it is absolutely not looked after or maintained at all. There was a pigeon nest over a beautiful carved door, I admit the baby pigeons were cute but I'm not sure the known corrosive effect of those birds dejections is just as cute. An other point, less serious, but it still shows that the monument is not taken care of is the completely worn painting on the walls. It wouldn't take much to give the palace a fresh turn which would render the visit much more striking for the eyes. However from the actual state it is in, we can only imagine what it must have looked like in its early days with the mix of vivid blue and white colours. It is certainly a beautiful palace, which clearly gives an example of typical morrocan architecture but is wasn't, at least for us, a "wow" experience. I would advice it as something to do if you have spare time but do not make it a priority in your "to-do list" for morroco.
gorgeous!!!. highly recommend!! the rooms the ceilings the gardens... you will be transported hundreds of years back. Magical!

Amazing. Decided to visit here last minute, just before we left Marrakech. So glad we did. An amazing place with some fantastic architecture, mosaics and craftsmanship. Would have been disappointed if we had not seen this amazing palace

Excellent History. This is located in the Jewish Quarter known as the Mellah and is steeped in history - as are many of the Marrakech sites. It is well worth a visit here. It is clean and well cared for. Definitely we recommend this place.

peaceful visit yo the palace. The palace is beautiful, the ceramics are so stunning.you could almost picture life back then.the crilings were do ornate.it wouldhave been nice to see some furniture in the rooms, though.

Impressive architecture and Moroccan mosaic design. For only 10 dirhams it is one of many cheap visits in Marrakech, however the intricate design and still contemporary sense of touch sets it apart from other similar palaces and buildings. It's nice to have a garden walkway entrance to the palace; it really blocks out the noise from the cars and motorbikes on the roads. The only downside to the palace is that there can be large tour groups and you can get stuck behind them.

Interesting, cheap entry, but expected more from a Palace.. Very cheap entry... I think 10dr.. around 70 pence, so cant expect the Taj Mahal !! But that said, you only get the chance to walk through the various rooms on an Ikea-style route. Dont get me wrong, the rooms are beautifully adorned with intricate wooden carved arches, detailed mosaics, and overall lovely architecture.... but you dont get to see THE PALACE. It would be like going to the Taj Mahal (I've not been!!), but you cant look at it from the outside, you just get ushered through beautiful gardens, and then you are inside.I guess we were a little 'under-whelmed' by it all... which was a shame.
Stunning architecture and outdoor gardens. Beautiful grounds to tour. We went with a photography group and thoroughly enjoyed the place and the fantastic scenery.
Historic palace and lovely architecture. A pleasant visit for more outstanding architectural details of tiles, columns, arches and lovely gardens.

Beautiful little palace. This is a must see in Marrakech. Entry is only 1 euro (somebody here said it was expensive?!?!)
The palace is not too big, don't expect anything like the Topkapi palace in Istambul.
But the crafts and the floors and the ceilings are amazing.
Worth spending a couple of hours and escape from the crowds.
interesting. I did the palace after the gardens and before the museum of Marakech, palace very busy hard to get good photos with so many people. recommend museum of Marakech over the Palace

Relaxing oasis in busy city. We stumbled on the Palace en rote to the souks. Interior decoration was stunning and green spaces lovely. Very relaxing after the frantic streets and well worth the modest entry fee.
Nice trip. Nice to see if you're interested in the history and lovely Moroccan tile work. We spent a couple hours here

day trip. This was a day trip to the historical place of Bahia Palace.we saw all the belongings of the king and queen. It was a beautiful weather on this day.there were fruits on the trees.there were hard marble walls everywhere we explored.

magical. one of the most beautiful palaces i have ever seen spent a couple of hours strolling from one beautiful room to the other also beautiful courtyard filled with fruit trees a place well worth seeing

Agree with other reviewers. Good place to see tile work and ceilings. Well worth the reasonable admission fee. Perhaps an hour could be alotted. Agree with other reviewers. Do not expect an elegantly furnished palace. There are no furnishings, only empty spaces.

Beutiful palace and amazing history. We came here with our city guide in Marrakech. This is a MUST do in Marrakech. We did not get to visit the harem area, as it is being renovated. The rooms for the wives (four of them) are beautiful.
Palace, no more.. Beautiful palace but a bit too expensive regarding the other attractions. It's an overpromise compared to other palaces.
A must see Bahia Palace. A great place to visit has a lot of history and is very big palace to take amazing pictures the whole atmosphere is just amazing

Higly recommended !!!. For us It was the most surprising place in Marrakech!!!
Despite the palace is in ruins you can imagine how was it thanks to a video that you can see innside. Beautiful place to visit!

Bahia Palace. Excellent historical place to visit. A hidden gem amidst the hectic city life! Watch the storks on their nests or soaring on a thermal. Climb the panorama tower to get a birds eye view of the city and surrounding area!

Gorgeous palace but no information. Beautiful building with the most amazing ceilings in every room. If we could have found a guide I'm sure we would have enjoyed it much more, but as it was we could find very little information.

Exquisite architecture. The Bahia Palace is very beautiful, but I would have loved to see more information boards about the building's history, and also maybe just one decorated room - to see, what the living was really like back in the day.

Fascinating wander. Definitely worth popping into! Not loads to see, but a ridiculously cheap price for a quick visit! Amazing the stark contrast between how quiet it is inside its walls and how bustling and busy on the outside.
Lots of surprising hidden rooms and tunnels, so kids would definitely enjoy themselves!

Gorgeous!. Entrance fee is only 10 MAD (1 euro) per person.
Either explore on your own or get a guide. (extra cost)
Bahia Palace was gorgeous. If you wanted to capture Moroccan architecture, this place is ideal.

Astonishing display of craftsmanship in every possible nook & cranny.. Everywhere you look is decorated with tiles, carving or painting - to such a degree of elegance and beauty - so worth a visit. Extremely reasonable entrance charge - NOT TO BE MISSED!

Good stop in Marrakesh. I visited the Palace during a recent stay in Marrakesh. It was definitely a worthwhile stop but if you are looking for palaces similar to Alcazar in Sevilla or the Alhambra, you will not be impressed. The scale is much smaller and the decor and preservation is not of the same caliber. That said, checking out this attraction in Marrakesh is a good thing to put on the list.

Lovely old Palace and good way to escape. The Palace was reasonably large with grounds and buildings covering a wide area. Entry was about 10Dh which is very reasonable. The buildings are well preserved and there was much to photograph. Lovely mosaics and beautiful wood work. It was nice to be able to wander a while without being hassled by people to buy things.

A must-see in Marrakech.. As you can see from the photos this place is stunning. There's so much of it to explore and before you even get inside the palace there are tons of pretty trees and flowers to see, where the little cats and kittens of the Bahia Palace walk around.
One of my top 3 must see locations in Marrakesh. This is an exquisite venue and representative of Moroccan architecture and decoration. It can get a little busy but there is a lot to see and enjoy.

Beautiful. We attended very late just before closing time however was granted access to check the architecture out. What can I say high ceiling and beautiful architecture though out. I found the Palace was beautiful however you are unable to go upstairs therefore I am somewhat curious of the condition of the upstairs. Would recommend a visit as something to do with pretty pictures.

Lovely insight into the Palace. Bahia palace is only 10 mad entry and worth the small cost. I would advise all travellers to take a guide book as there is very little information about the objects on display. There are guided tours which my partner and I listened to which provided much more information than the guide book we had taken.

Charming place for a walk. In Bahia Palace you will find stunning architectural details, nice patios and some vegetation. It's a charming place to take up to 1 hour walk and the entrance is very cheap. The only minus is that the insides are empty.

Worth a visit. Certainly one of the gems of the city.Could be better looked after, but not bad considering local standardsInteresting to compare with the Al Hambra, since its the same workmen and traditions.
Lovely architecture. Lovely building with good architecture. It's really cheap, and only a quick visit. But it was nice to see such a grand building in the middle of Marrakech.
Nice palace to visit. Only 10 DH, about $1 and very neat architecture inside. Expect to spend less than an hour at this location.

Beautiful architecture. The architecture inside is stunning, with the intricate details of the ceramic tile floors and walls, and carved ceilings. Definitely worth a visit in Marrakech. Of the tourist attractions in the city, this was my favorite.
Beautiful. Beautiful and cheap. Lovely sites and great to learn about the history of Marrakech. Definitely a recommendation

Stunning Architecture / Decor & Reasonably Priced. At 10 MAD for entry this was a great value attraction. You get to see how the royals of Morocco lived and although the entrance doesn't look much some of the rooms are and courtyards are stunning.

history trip. We we're very lucky to have a good speaking English guide whos knowledge was past on to us, you dont need a lot of time to look around but you need to que to tske photos because it was very busy, worth going onthe trip ,
Disapointed. 10dm entry fee but limited information in English again the palace was really built up by the hotel staff and we were disappointed when we went
Probably the best tourist palace in Marrakesh. An interesting experience that allows you to explore the history of Marrakech. the courtyards are a tranquil space

Good value palace with a story. Only 10 dm adult entrance fee, then Pleasant entrance garden (by Moroccan standards!). Follow your own way through similar rooms with exquisitely painted ceilings, and through two main courtyards- one with orange trees for shade, admiring the delicately carved plasterwork around the arches.The only information is in French or Arabic, so we went on the lonely planet website, to find the human interest story- the local ruler lived here with his wives, concubines, and hangers-on...who as soon as he died, all looted the place!

Well worth an hour. I really liked this although I would say you would find it hard to spend more than an hour there, unless you really like photography and taking pictures.It is generally lots of nice ceilings and rooms to look at.What would have made it much better is an explanation board in each room or some kind of information.I guess they are hoping you will pay for a guided tour?Nice way to see some pretty tile work, fireplaces, doors etc

Fantastic melt of South Spanish and Moroccan Architecture. Bahia Palace is a great place to explore so many details about the culture and history of Morocco and its routs, all the path and rooms within the Palace are well-thought through. Fantastically nice place with so many things to explore.
A Riad not a Palace. This was built by a past dignitary for his offices and living quarters. The history of the building was interesting, more so than the building itself.
Beautiful palace. This was a fun building to visit, the tile work is stunning and the central garden is lovely. Wish they'd let people see more of it!

Morocoan architecture at its best.. Definetely visit this site to experience the architecture of Morrocco. Take a knowledgeable guide to fully enjoy the site. You will notice the Islamic, Jewish and French influences.
Don't expect too much. Not much to see takes about 1/2 hour to walk around but only costs 10dinar about 80p so worth a visit.

Historic & Beautiful, but lacks maintenance.. Interesting place to visit and see the glory of historic times. Amazing architecture, large rooms to stroll, beautiful mosaics, but often deteriorated. It feels like a lost place, sadly enough. The government should organize and maintain it better. But still a place worthwhile a visit.It is a 10-15 mins walk from the main square through some fun streets, however the last part is pretty dirty, as they are redoing the streets,
Interesting but not stunning. Useful starter point for a City tour. Interesting but not stunning. Good introduction to the culture of the city. Other palaces are of more interest and value.

"Palace of the Beautiful". A palace worth visiting, built in the 19th century by the Grand Vizier of Marrakech. He had four wives, 24 concubines and alot of children so he needed a lot of space! There are over 160 lavishly decorated rooms here! It was meant to be the greatest palace of its time so no expences was spared building this palace. It took seven years to build it with hundreds of craftsmen working in stucco and zellij. Well worth a visit indeed!
Lean about Morocco history via Bahia Palace. It was a very nice experience to visit the Bahia Palace. Morocco has a strong history and this palace is all about history of Morocco.
artwork. I had lovely time at the palace El Bahia...Iloved the architecture...The mosaics are just amazing and diffrent from a roon to another ..recommended !
Super place to visit. Great place to vist and enjoy the beautiful carved wooden doors and cielings of the room for an entry fee of 1 euro per adult

Another beautiful, but empty and soulless palace. Beautiful palace on a smaller more intricate scale than some of the others, stunning mosaics and a maze of apartments all of differing grandeur. I loved the architecture, colour and plaster work but there is no indication of what the rooms were used for, they type of furniture that would have been found there or how the original occupants actually lived, slept, cooked etc. there is no grid for understanding their lives. Every room is empty and devoid of clues for their original purpose or how it would have looked in the day.For me this reduces the experience unfortunately.

Lovely and traditional . The Bahia Palace is a lovely traditional large Morrocan home. Entrance only costing 10DH each. The courtyard was stunning and the decorative ceilings are amazing. A lovely time spent there.

Nice but overcrowded (10 am). Nice, but overcrowded with tourists. Guess you better go there before 9. We heard guides tell different stories about the same room, so maybe you should take your guidebook with you.

Beautiful building shame it's empty. Beautiful building with beautiful architecture but it would have been so much more interesting if it had still been furnished as a palace or residence as now it was just a succession of beautiful empty rooms without knowing what function each room had (as there are no signs)
Go early, lots of tour groups.. Very interesting palace of the grand visier. Lovely tile work and wood carving. Sad that the French trashed it during the colonial period.

beautiful palace with Moorish designs and colours. I lived next door to the palace/kasbah at Telouet which was the Glaoui Pasha for Marrakech's main headquarters and visited the few remaining rooms with opulent decorations and materials quite often - known to be a lot more opulent than Bahia palace but a visit to Bahia gives a good idea how beautiful the nobles liked their palaces to be

Beautiful rooms and gardens. The Bahia Palace is well worth a visit. Apart from the parties of tourists, constantly passing through, the building and the richly decorated rooms tell a story of times past and the gardens are really beautiful. I would recommend going with a guide as there is no information in English and yet there are many marvelous stories about the people who lived here. Without the background I don't think the visit would be as memorable. It is in such contrast to the bustling city just outside, an oasis of peace and a trip back in time.

Worth a visit to see the fab architecture . Worth a visit cost 10dh to go inside , very beautiful buildings with ornate roofs and stained glass windows with reflections on the white walls You can wander round yourself or take a guide there is no English information boards so if you want a bit more have the guide but if you are happy to wander the rooms and soak up the mosaic floors then it's great for around30-45 mins
Stunning. Well worth a visit, fight through the tour groups and you discover some beautiful decor. The streets leading back to the spuk is a lovely lunch stop on the way back.
A must see. Typical Moroccan architecture here. Very much worth a visit to see lovely ceramics. Great calligraphy artist who will write your name in Arabic which makes for a lovely picture.
Well worth a visit. stunning architecture, great craftsmanship. A lovely shady internal courtyard where you can pass the heat of the day reading.
Beautiful Building. Lovely building, the beautiful mosaic colours and building architecture are well worth going to see. Cant beat it for 10dh

Reasonable price to visit Palace.... We enjoyed Bahia Palace especially as so reasonable to visit. We were there rather longer than anticipated as got stuck there during a torrential downpour and thunderstorm for 2 hours...
Cool architecture. Great place to visit to see how the weathly lived in old Marrakech. Beautiful architecture, mosaics & Islamic art.
Beautiful craftsmenship. Very cheap to get in, you only see a small amount of the rooms but the details in the decor are worth looking at.
Cool and calm. Bahia palace is architecture, cool and calm, but just a bunch of rooms with pretty carving designs on the wall - costs 10 dh each to get in, not a lot if you wanna kill some time
Interesting but too many people. Interesting, but after you've seen 4 of the rooms it does get a bit repetitive. There were lots of tours going around at the same time so it was very busy.
Very pretty. It was very cheap to enter and the overall palace was beautiful. You don't need need to dedicate alot time for the palace but the tile work and overall intricacies is breathtaking.

Could and will be improved. Ruin palace?
Still a nice space, several rooms quite similar.
No cafe or explanation of areas.
Not well organized.
Needs some story line.

Beautiful palace with intricately carved stonework. One of the best things to see in Marrakech - tranquil and beautiful. Although mainly empty rooms, it's not hard to imagine how impressive it must have been during its hayday. Well worth a visit. We didn't have a guide but it might be worth getting one to take you around. We eavesdropped on a few tours and the history sounded quite interesting.

Loved the gardens, relaxing indeed, a must. This is probably the best-preserved palace we visited in Morocco, maybe because it is comparatively new. I fell in love with the garden, which was in a good condition and full of orange and banana trees, as well as lots of palm trees. Inside the palace you can admire the beauty of the architecture, woodcarvings and mosaics around you. The one thing i didn't like was that there wasn't any information in English displayed.

Good place to visit. Lovely place to visit and and if you have a right tour guide the experience is amazing becausd there is so many amazing facts you can learn from. However the man who was selling the tickets was extremely rude!
For when you've run out of things to visit!. Its ok, over very quick as not much morrocan craftsmanship to see. Go see the Ben youssef college instead.

Idyllic Palace within the Medina. We had an English speaking guide for the 4 of us. The Bahia Palace was the last attraction that we visited. Our guide explained how the Prime Minister, Sia Moussa built the first stages of the palace from 1859 to 1873 and then completed by is son from 1894 to 1908.You have the formal reception are and waiting rooms. there are the formal rooms which back onto a lovely courtyard. There are the rooms for the harem and the Prime Minister. There are also the servants courters as well.Building material came from all over North Africa with the Cedar wood from Morocco.Really enjoyed our time in the Palace. Entry was only DH10 per person.

Palace of the Favorite. Beautiful palace that consists of 2 parts the older built by Si Moussa it has an open courtyard with cypresses, orange trees and jassmin with 2 star shaped pools and the newer part built by Ba Ahmed, it's courtyard paved with marble and zellij tilework, very luxurious a must see.
Nice Palace to explore and relax in. Lovely palace in the Medina. Very central. Only 10DH entrance fee. Closes for lunch. Nice place to relax
