Beautiful but under renovation! . We visited here 25th Sept, got here early with our guide and it was pleasantly empty. Our guide told us the history of this place which was both interesting and informative. The favourite wife's room was beautifully decorated. They are renovating this place which should be completed in 6 months however that meant some of the rooms couldn't be accessed but for 10 dirham to enter was still worth the visit! Would definitely recommend as it is nice to walk around and offers plenty on shade to escape the mid day sunshine!
nice. Definitely worth checking out. it's beautiful and the amount of detail in this place is crazy. for 10 dh it was definitely worth it.

Pretty palace. Very pretty palace, and beautiful courtyard. An oasis from the busy hot streets outside. Would be very relaxing but it was absolutely packed with tourists, and quite hard to walk around.
Beautiful. Found this old palace after visiting the Saadian Tombs. The Palace is a series of courtyards and very ornate rooms with fantastic ceilings. Well worth a visit. Only 10DHs too.
Tiles & carvings. Well worth a visit - the tiles & carvings are wonderful. Don't expect rooms full of furniture. Enjoy the courtyard garden
Must visit!. You don't need a lot of time to visit Bahia Palace but should definitely visit - beautifully decorated and some lovely architecture.

Palace Made Of Marbles. The white walls of the Palace made from marble made this much more easier to appreciate compared to the Bin Madrasa. It's more impressive when the strong rays of the sun make the structure shine.

Good for Meandering. This in my opinion was more impressive than the Madersa Ben Youssef, it has some impressive intricate stonework and interesting plants to wander past. Good value at only 10DHS and very close to the tombs, so you're likely to be in the area at some point.

Empty palace. We visited the palace in September and recommend if you have a spare hour to fill in and are in the neighbourhood. This attraction consists of walking through a building comprising a number of empty rooms and garden courtyard. The cost for admission is €1.
Lovely palace. Very lovely palace. The entrance fee is very low, and it's worth a visit. All the walls and the ceilings are decorated in a traditional way and painted with natural colors.
Worth a visit. Worth the cheap admission for sure! The Bahia Palace doesn't take long to walk through but the ornate details are incredible.

Hussain Rassai . Lovely place overlooking the Medina.
Marrakesh its beautiful and amazing
It's an architectural design novel
Palace has lovely garden and chamber's

Attractive place to visit for very low cost. 10d entry. Pleasant grounds before entering the building itself. Good example of the style with centre courtyard and rooms off with very high ceilings. Worth a short visit, but if you only have time to take in one 'palais' the building that is the 'Marrakech museum' is better.

Beautiful Building. We visited the Bahia Palace as part of a tour organised by Thompson. The Palace was beautiful and the mosaic floors and ceilings are so well maintained. Really glad we got to see it all.

Former ruler's castle and harem building. This is a formers ruler's Palace where you can visit the ( now empty ) rooms of the castle. One can admire the beautiful sealing in fine carved stone. There is no more furniture in the places. One can see the old harem where several of the women of the house lived in luxury but also in closed quarters because they were not allowed to come out of the castle. Beautiful place to visit and with a local guide it is even more interesting. It is advised to take a guide from the tourism office or by the hotel reception. Do not get lured by self proposing guides that walk around in town!!!!!

Visite. Or was realy nice and interesting to visit this building Alm the architecture was wonderful and ambiance was nice the Woods seling beautiful and the plaster work also m'y family and i were really happy to assist to this nice explanation about the architecture tanks a lot.
Impressive. A truly impressive visit. Never expected to find it. Only downside is that it is a bit hidden away in the middle of some dodgy looking streets. Worth the trek to see it

Allright given the cheap entry . For 10 Dh ( 1 euro ) this palace is a nice place to escape from the busy streets. As there is little or no information provided don't expect to learn anything without a guide. If you have little time (half an hour is plenty to see everythin)or a limited budget it is worth a visit. However it is a bit redundant when combined with vusits to other museums.

Beautiful Moroccon Architecture. Beautiful building where artists have designed the tiles and detailing around the walls floors and ceilings. Look out for the ornate doors and lamps. I would suggest a guide who can tell you about the history , you need to arrange this outside.

Nothing too exciting. Though the palace was nice, it was not particularly interesting to go without a guide. There are no signs (to encourage hiring a guide and spending more money). You go, look at the very beautiful ceilings, but there is little else to see. Maybe with more information it would have been more interesting, but if you're just looking for something cheap to do, you may want to look elsewhere.
Enviable home. Beautiful palace which really gives the sense of gracious living that its owners enjoyed. Stroll through the beautifully decorated, spacious rooms and imagine a totally different life!
Worth a visit. This place is well worth the 10 Dhiram admissionLook up and around and you will see little detailsA fascinating place
Trip round Marrakech.. We went to the Bahia Palace as part of our horse and cart trip. It is only 5 dirhams entrance fee and the architecture was very impressive. Nice for a quick visit.

A historical treasure. I visited this with my five year old who loved looking around. We listened in on others tours to hear about its amazing history. At 10 dirhams to go in, you would be mad to miss it.

Like much in Marrakech: cheap entry but little to see. If you're in Marrakech for a few days, come by. It is pretty and it is peaceful. The entry fee is next to nothing, but don't expect to stay too long.
Passes 1.2. Worth a visit as its only 10Dh each to enter but only expect to be 1/2 hour as there isnt much to see although very nice
A nice break from the busy streets.... Cheap to see and a nice break from the busy streets. Some very pretty ceilings to be seen here!! Quite far from the main square and the medina.

Worth visiting but take a guide. We booked a guide through our Riad and as beautiful as it was without him we would not have understood anything about the palace and it would have just been a beautiful building. Ad it was we spent about an hour understanding about its history and who used to live there.
very pretty, nice garden. Very pretty inside, cool and relatively quiet after walking through the streets. Cedarwood is painted rather than carved, overall worth a wander through.
Nice but limited time. It has limited entry time so hard to fit in if you are not available on certain days but otherwise really nice.
Nice place. Very nice architecture. Not too big. We have finished the tour in about 20 minutes. It cost 10dir per person to get in.
A must-see in Marrakech. Very well preserved historic building in the Medina, about 10-15 min walk south of Jemaa el Fna square, a must see in Marrakech

Interesting to see how people lived. The architecture and structure of this building was interesting. Very peaceful inside. Amazing craftsmanship and detail in the construction.
Gardens are lovely both inside and outside. Worth a visit.

Well worth a visit - take a guide. Nice to see but ensure you join a tour. This is beautiful and very accessible, you aren't held behind ropes or not allowed to take photos but a tour guide really ensured that we understood what we were looking at.
Well worth a visit, drink in the culture.

Gorgeous building. We visited with a private guide who was able to tell us plenty about the history of the building.
The architecture is beautiful. My advice is each time you enter a room look up. The ceilings are stunning.
For only 10dh this is definitely worth visiting.

Better than expected. I expected this to be rubbish so I was actually really impressed. For 10 dh you get to see this beautiful palace with really impressive decor (especially ceilings and doors) and loads of rooms to explore. It's easy to find compared to most things in Marrakech and once you're inside all the exits and the way to walk are signposted so you can't get lost. Definitely recommended - my favourite palace in Marrakech.
day tour. did this as part of a day tour of marrakech a lovely old palace with some beautifully decorated ceilings

Exquisitely decorated palace.. This is one of the most beautifully conserved palaces around, great decorations, gardens and whatnot, definitely a must see.Too bad it's not completely open, during our visit even more parts were closed than the signs indicated. Bummer.
Visit the palace. A must whilst in Marrakech, lovely tilework, cool corridors and spaces to explore. Worth the tiny entrance fee.

Worthwhile visit and a bit of quiet from the street. After an adrenaline raising walk to get there it was a nice place to visit and see the restored rooms of the palace. Some amazing rooms to view the colours and architecture.

Well woth a visit. Very pretty palace built around the end of the 19th century. Very well preserved with much stone and iron work remaining. Signage did not include English so it was hard to understand what we were looking at. The ceilings and floors are beautifully designed. If you have to choose between this palace and the Badi Palace because of time restrictions, choose this one.

Worth a short visit. Bahia palace is definitely worth a visit, fantastic architecture, cool and calm in the madness of marrakesh, very cheap entry fee, only downside very little information available on the rooms or its history.......unless as we did u tag onto an organised tour lol.

Really nice get away . Beautiful place in Marrakesh, entry fee only 10dh which is a bargain. If you like beautiful buildings, green areas and mosaic tiles this is the place to go. Nothing particularly special, but the place is just beautiful as it is. Good get away from the hectic medina and also gives shade from the sun.

Interesting. Beautiful building that I visited as a part of my day tour in Marrakech. It wasn't busy when we visited and we didn't stay here for long but I would recommend here to visit whilst in Morocco.

interesting carvings and paintings. There are several rooms inside and each has its own unique design. But there is one room that is stunning with its design for the favorite concubine. Check out the ceilings and you will see wonderful carvings and paintings. The reason why the ceilings are done so beautifully is that the concubines do not leave the palace once they enter it. Thus, the ceilings are wonderfully made since it's the first thing they see in the morning. I learned this history from our tour guide.

Interesting palace. Very tranquil, not at all busy and intriguing insight into this typical Marrakech palace. We went round with our guide and therefore gained lots of extra information. Well worth a visit, and very cheap entry.
Take a look on a Marrakech Palace. Palais de la Bahia is a normal palace. although it is not an extraordinary one is always worthwhile to good and take a look
see the slights. Beautiful building with some great carvings. It really is a lovely building. We saw it as part of a full day discovery trip.

Beautiful! . I visited on holiday with my husband and i loved this palace with its charm and colourful architecture. It was clean.. Plenty of good photo ops if your into photography like me. Definitely a place to visit if you have the time :)

Fantastic architecture. We went here on a hot afternoon and what a wonderful place to spend time in away from the hustle and bustle. Fantastic architecture, lovely gardens and a very cheap entry. All in all we'd highly recommend. The only downside is (once again) there is very little information available about the rooms and stories behind the palace.

Beautiful Architecture . Well worth the 10 dirham entrance fee. Beautiful Architecture and painted ceilings. Great for the photo taker. We were there with very few visitors so made taking photos much easier.

A small palace with Andalusian architecture. Bahia palace reminds me Alcazar in Seville. But it is much smaller than Alcazar and does not provide anything to people who already visit Alcazar except its silent and cool rooms in the middle of crazy hot Marrakesh. So if you get tired in Marrakesh streets, you may visit it to get relax. By the way the entrance price is only 10Mrd.

beautiful palace. we did take a guided tour in the afternoon and we spent more than one hour at the palace . we really like it and its archetecture . still in good conditions as it is constructed recently
Stunning. Stunning place. Well worth the enterance fee. Enjoyed wandering around the rooms. It was very peaceful.

Highly decorated tranquil haven . Clinging to the southern reaches of the medina, the palace has an inconspicuous entrance that belies the architectural treasures which lie within. At the time of writing (August 2015) entry was a very reasonable 10dh for adults and 3dh for children. A beautiful quadrant garden with mature orange trees is surrounded by a complex of highly decorated rooms with stunning painted woodwork, stained glass and arches. Well worth a visit.
Not a great visit. Palace is rather original and unrestored but really one of the least interesting historic sights visited.
Loved the detail in the ceilings. Spectacular ceilings and gorgeous fire places. The quiet gardens were refreshingly cool. Would be very cramped in tourist season

Beautiful, peaceful palace.. We went to see this palace after visiting Badi Palace earlier in the day. It's definitely the best way round to view them. Having seen Badi Palace in it's magnificent ruined form it was nice to visit here afterwards and see what Badi palace would have looked like in all it's glory.The quiet riad courtyards through out the building were perfect for avoiding the midday sun, providing somewhere shady and tranquil to stop and catch your breath.The carved cederwood and zellij tiles are stunning, the colours are amazing.

Fascinating. We visited here as part of a Thomson toir 'history of marrakech'. Our tour guide was fantastic and told us lots of stories about the place. You cannot see anything from outside, you have to go in to see the beautiful decoration. It was worth having a guide though to explain it all.
simply stunning. must place to visit in Marrakesh. The palace is not too far from the old town so other attraction can be seen on the same day. The mosaic work is absolutely stunning.

Beautiful x. On entering the complex there are some beautiful trees and plants. The guard allowed us to pick some fresh oranges from the tree... delicious.The garden is so peaceful and beautiful, at the bottom of the garden is the entrance to the palace.Within the palace there is a range of opportunities for that perfect family photo highlighting the great mosaics and style of Morocco. This palace is a must visit in my opinion.The toilets are clean.The staff are helpful and polite, don’t speak much English, but there welcoming demeanour explains all.This attraction offers somewhere to seek refuge from the heat of the day whilst entertaining you for a short period of time (around 30- 40 mins) with its beautiful architecture.Reasonable rate around 10 DH per adult, my 2 youngest were free 8 and 10.

What a palace!. The entrance to the Bahia Palace is tucked away but once you found it you are in for a treat! The mosaics and stucco that adorns all the rooms in the palace are amazing. So much history and to think that its been so well perserved and restored. The palace really shows off the beauty of moccocan mosaics and stucco not to mention the carved wood ceilings too. A must see.

Very much enjoyed it. One of the first places we visited on our Moroccan tour-I loved it. The mosaic and plaster work is so detailed and pretty. Some furniture would enhance the visit but it was still good!

Just walk through a small street and then: bahia palace. Since i'm much interested in the history of a country I go, this time also I got the luck for 20dh and 10dh income, to visit the ruins and photomuseum. It was extremely hot, 44°! So take water and put nice sandals, the floor is hot! You get a fantastic idea how a muslim palace was laid out in the 16th century. The mosaics, the bows, the way of construction is very nice. I walk with an invalid stroller and it was good to do. People are very helpful to help you some steps up and down. I think it is less for children, they may not understand the meaning of the visit. At the end you can visit a small photomuseum which is interesting. Any question will be answered with pleasure!I found it a must to visit this place in the medina. You can also see the roofs of the roal palace, and the flag hanging out, since he was there. It is a big an quite place within the city walls!

Lovely Visit. Went here with my children and mother. A nice visit to walk around and learn a little history. Entrance fee was fair, palace itself was nice for photos etc. Toilets were standard. Would recommend if you are into history of the city.

Stunning architecture ..... We went in July 2015 and were happy to enter the cool rooms that are part of this palace which is very well preserved. Although there are no explanations written anywhere we just enjoyed looking into each rooms taking in the wonderful tiles, the stonework, the woodwork, the paintings and above the lovely smell of cedar. Also it served as a brief respite from the unrelenting sun! Not to be missed.

Classic Moroccan Architecture. As with a number of other buildings which are accessible to the public in Morocco, the Bahia Palace is a good example of classic Moroccan architecture, comprising the white plastered walls, combined with mosaic tiling to the floors and walls and the intricately decorated columns and ceilings.Whilst this building presents a number of good photo opportunities, particularly around the courtyard areas, there is nothing which really stands out as exceptional.The only examples of items which would have been contained or used in this beautiful building are locked away is glass display cabinets and these are somewhat limited.In summary, worth a visit if you are in Marrakech, but not for too long.
Stunning. Just stunning. One of my top 5s to do in Marrakesh . You should definitely not miss this site when you are coming to Marrakesh

Great for culture . Again here you need to be apart of a tour nothing is written on plaques or signs to fill you with the history. You need a local guide who will tell you all. Definitely worth going to.

Underwhelming. Paid our 10 dirhams, walked around the empty 'palace' taking pics of the lovely tiled walls and floors and left after 10 mins thinking 'was that it'? Like most things in Marrakech, over hyped and completely underwhelming.

Mmmmmm........ I think the average riad is just as good if not better.
Its pretty enough but a restored riad gives you just as good an idea of what a nice Morrocan house looked like.
Lovely. Lovely rooms to see, with some amazing architecture and mosaics. Not much furnishings so looks quite sparse. But well worth a visit

Traditional Palace. A nice place to visit to learn more about Marrakech. There are not many places to see, so I would add this to the list. You don't need more than an hour. it's a traditional king's palace with some great old architecture. Our tour guide was pretty knowledgeable and it helped to hear the history while viewing.

Gorgeous palace, worth visiting. I loved this palace. My favorite place during my visit to Marrakech. Beautiful architecture and detailed works. Plan to visit Bahia palace and Badii palace together for they are only 10-15 minutes walk away at most.
Bahia Palace. One of the recommended sites in Marrakech. Beautiful Islamic design/s and architecture. Much like many of the other beautiful Islamic architecture.
Worth a look. A lovely little find near our Riad. Tranquil gardens and free from people trying to hassle you in the neighbouring area.

A look into a different time.. is The palace is located in the middle of the Medina and is fairly easy to find, both by car and by foot. It is extremely photographic and colorful. The tiles and cravings are amazing and whilst a few small areas are still being renovated and preserved, the palace is a wonderful example of a time long past. Well worth the visit, and allow time to relax and reflect on the workmanship and skill of the people who built it.

Nice place to visit. The Bahia Palace is located in the medina of Marrakesh near the Jewish quarter. Its name translates as 'The Brilliant' . One of the most pleasing design features of this palace is the views it gives from one space into another. You can stand in one spot and have your eyes drawn through several perfectly-placed doorways that frame an architectural feature beyond.

A nice break from the hustle and bustle of the medina. A very photogenic place, particularly in the garden area. The tile work and carvings are amazing. The palace could offer visitors a printed and/or audio guide about the history and architecture of the place.
Well worth the visit. A nice little palace in the centre of Marrakech. Will use up a hour of your time but it's worth it. Good for photographs too.

Interesting place, can be visited on the way. If you are around you can stop by. The entrance is very cheap, around 1 euro. Although there are few other place, which deserve a visit, this one is so-so.
Nothing special inside, empty walls, small garden, some nice ceramics and paintings.

Nice stop inside the city. This palace is well-preserved and demonstrate part of Marrakech history. It is not big but good to visit in one hour.
Rooms are beautifully decorated but quite back in the old days.
Nice palace in the center of Marrakech. Nice palace but not very big. It's a bit run down. The ceilings are nice. Some restoration work is still going on.
Palace or Harlem ?. With 4 rooms for 4 wives and another sections for another 24 concubines !!?... So, was this place Bahia Palace or Bahia's husband Harlem ?!!
Beautiful. For a small entrance fee the palace is well worth a visit! The palace doesn't take long to see- around half hour but def take the time to visit

Oranges everywhere. Beautiful orange grove as you walk through the gates but quite disappointing when inside , the palace isn't that old some lovely mosaic tiles and hand painted ceilings , much of the palace was closed off , took 20 mins to go around .
Great place to visit. These is a quite well preserved palace with great mosaic tiled rooms and some beautiful wooden carvings, Dosn't take that long to walk around but its well worth a visit

Beautiful place but not much else. Visited with a tour guide as part of the discover Marrakech day tour. Stunning building but it was basically the empty shell and not much else to see. I wouldn't visit without a guide as I'm guessing there is no one here that will talk you though the history.

One of the better attractions in Marrakech. Lovely building. Doesn't need more than an hour to visit. No furnishings or English signs/explanation. Suggest reading Wiki article before visiting so you have an understanding.

Must see in Marrakesh. Probably my favorite building in Marrakesh. Great architecture, low entrance fee. I did not have a guide, and there is not a lot of information (best just to keep your ears open and listen in on other people's guides!) Alternatively a good guidebook in your hand will help.

Wonderful patterns and a great eye candy of a palace. It was a beautiful stroll through the colourful walls and ceilings, such detail and such an eye candy yet gives you a good idea of the local culture and heritage. Must see.
Great visit for a couple of hours . Great to visit for an hour or two . Very cool as we wasn't when it was 45 c . Free toilets but no toilet paper which could be difficult

Amazing craftsmanship. When visiting Marrkech there are a number of 'must-sees' on the tourist map and this happens to be one of them. We chose to take a private driver/guide to take us to the main sites to avoid all the hassle and of getting lost. The Bahia Palace is truly beautiful. The craftsmanship is breathtaking. Worth a visit.

A stunning example of old marrocon living. We visited the palace with a local guide arranged by our hotel and he was able to tell us so much you wouldn't otherwise realise about the palace. The architecture is quite stunning - the wall decorations were carved directly into plaster,the wood is hundreds of years old, never been restored but looks as good as new and all palaces and riads have 4 gardens, one for each season. Definitely take the time to see the palace and if you're able to have someone show you around it will really bring it to life for you.
Good looking palace and maze. Nice palace, not too expensive to visit, and quite cool as it's big stone walls.Easy to get lost in this maze.

LUCKY TO LIVE HERE. A very beautiful building with stunningly detailed doorways, cornices? (it seems too simple a word for what they have) and ceilings. The walk to the Palace from a chaotic rubble strewn square was between luxuriant foliage and took you from chaos to calm in a few minutes, also from heat(45C) to cool. The interior style of the Moroccan buildings is simply beautiful, the shapes of doors and windows, the simplicity of symmetrical structures and then the intricacy of stucco, mosaic and inlaid woods and this is a perfect example. Take a neck brace with you as you will spend most of your time gazing upwards. The only downside for me is that there is no interior furnishing to show how the Palace was used or how the inhabitants lived; for me that would have added to an overall appreciation.(obviously too much NT).

Beautiful Palace. We visited with a guide at the beginning of our trip. We entered the palace and walked along the orange trees, which then blossom into a fragrant flower. The palace has stunning architecture and outstanding colors. The cedar designs and center courtyard are not to be missed. During our visit, the concubine's quarters were under construction. It is not marked, but try to find the door and peer through the hole to get an ideas of the size and beauty of this place. Fun fact- Bahia means clever or smart.
Lovely setting, managable size. Well preserved and easy to wander through to get an appreciation of the architecture and craftsmanship associated with the culture.

Amazing Place to Visit. Absolutely worth a visit to Bahia Palace, very low admission fees & excellent value for money. Stunning Moroccan architecture and mosaics with a wonderful courtyard. Great for taking photos and capturing some really great pictures.

Traditional and very pretty . I would definitely recommend a visit here, the arches, mosaics, plaster work and ceilings are very pretty and traditional, plus at less than £1 to get in... What do you have to lose! It's quite small so you do not need more than an hour to see everything

Breathtaking palace and wonderful history. Bahia Palace is a breathtaking place, with ornate decorated ceilings, a wonderful courtyard and some really beautiful, traditional Moroccan architecture. If you go with a guide you can also enjoy the story of Bahia and the other wives and their lives within the walls of the palace. A wonderful place to visit very close to Marrakech old town.

My favourite - beautiful orange courtyard. Worth the trip - we paid around 20Dh each if not less. The palace is small but with stunning wooden panelling, massive fireplaces and just absolutely beautiful celing designs. The courtyard garden smells sweet because of its orange trees. All-round great experience.
Majestic and sublime. Stunning, sublime and peaceful. The architecture and tiling is mesmerising. Well worth a visit. Intricate hand carved wood finishes throughout the ceilings are incredible.

Beautiful, a must visit in Marrakech!. The Bahai Palace is gorgeous and can easily be seen within an hour. The entry fee is only 10 dh and the place overall is a must see!! The carvings, architecture, and courtyards are incredible. My friend and I visited during Ramadan, which meant the palace closes early (3pm, not the regular 6pm) so do make sure you go early so you don't have to rush.

Less than 30-45 minutes visit. Relatively well preserved. However, no plaque to explain what the rooms. You must read ahead of time to understand what origin of the Palace. Since there is no explanation, if you don't have a guide, visit to Bahia Palace will take no longer than 30-45 minutes as all the rooms looks the same after awhile. Unlike the royal palaces in Europe where it's stocked with arts, this palace is empty.

Nice with a guide. This is the sort of place you need to bring a guide to understand. The Moroccan architecture is well kept as this building is relatively modern (built only 100 years ago). During its operation, it hosted famous people, including the Kennedys. Nearby are a few other notable things to see as part of a nice half day tour. One of the top sites in Marrakech seeing traditional architecture.

It is a must see! . The Bahia palace is a must in your visit to Marrakesh. It's worth 10 dirhams (1 euro) and it is really beautiful. The palace has many empty rooms but the structure is amazing. Bahia means shining
Beautiful Palace. Visited here on a day trip around the city. Lovely architecture and it feels you are stepping back in time, so peaceful in the middle of the city

History & Culture in Marrakech. We booked a holiday in Marrakech to see some of our favourite Rock Bands as part of the Planet Rock Stock holiday, but thought it would be cool to get off the resort & see a bit of Marrakech. The Hotel offered a group tour of Marrakech, but because I have a bit of a problem walking too far, we chose to do a private tour (only £25 each including the driver & guide), which meant we could choose where wanted to go & minimise the amount of walking, the Bahia Palace for me was the highlight of the tour, with cool (in both sense of the word) rooms, beautiful gardens, the King & Queens rooms (4 of them), with a harem just beyond creating the mystery & legend of the Arabian tales, the king (Kalif) who built the Palace was know as the "Busy Man" principally as a result of his 4 wives & 26 concubines, apparently he died with a smile on his face!.....the whole tour took 2-3 hours, with each venue being 20-40 minutes, there was the option to visit several of the local traders, but we limited this to the pharmacy (a massage & some Argon oil for my wife) & then a carpet shop to look at some fine Arabian & Berber rugs - but no flying carpets & quite expensive, so we did not buy!....the general tour took the other hotel guests to all of the trader venues & it took several hours, so we were glad we opted for the private tour & went where we wanted to go, with the Palace being the highlight of the trip into Marrakech

"Moroccan masterpiece". You must put this on your to do list . Drag yourself away from the manic streets of Marrakech and emerge yourself in the beauty and grandeur of this palace. It will only take 1 Hour of your time but it's well worth a visit.The mosaic work and architecture are breathtaking. Lovely archways, ceilings and doors with courtyard gardens thrown in as well.its well worth the cheap entry fee.

Little Paradise. A must place to visit in Marrakech. Bahia Palace is a beautiful and peaceful palace with fantastic court yard in middle of hassle and bustle of busy Marrakech. Allow yourself at least 1 hour and enjoy the architecture combined with natural beauty of the garden and court yard.
Cultural beauty. Ornate Grandeur at its best with beautiful hand crafted ceilings and floorsThe court yards are beautiful tooCheap entry fee worth a visit

Place worth to visit. This place was pretty authentic. It was interesting to see how people used to study a long time ago. Many rooms seems look the same as centuries ago. Very interesting architecture and decorations, moderate price.

Taste of Culture. Nice large palace, the grounds are very vast therefore there is a lot to appreciate. The architecture is very nice for those who are photographers along with a reasonable entry price.
Interesting. A lovely palace which you have to use your imagination as there is nothing there, but worth a visit.

Definitely worth a look.. Entrance fee 10 dirham pp plus 20 dirham pp to see the minbar (the pulpit that was used to deliver the sermons) the minbar has been excellently restored the wood work is delightfully intricate. The palace its self has lovely mosiac floors and the terrace has wonderful views over marrakech. There were lots of storks all nesting on top of the walls and towers so would definitely recommend getting a closer look of these majestic birds from the terrace. As you walk further in to the palace there are chambers beneath to wander around which gives great relief from the high heat in summer months. All in all worth a visit.

Ornate but boring. We spent 15-20 minutes here because after a while of seeing medersas and museums and palaces, we got a bit tired of it. No one was sitting/ charging at the ticket counter when we went
Very nice. Brilliant place, would go again. You must see if in Marrakech. Go early or later in the evening to avoid too much sun.

Moroccan Style Palace. We went to see the palace when we were in Marrakesh. There is a lot of detail on the walls and ceilings done up in tiles.
It is a Moroccan style done up in white with blue highlights.
The Sultan at one time had his concubines living here.

Beautiful palace visit. A calm and relaxing visit to this beautiful palace with so much artwork, mosaics and painted doors, shutters and ceilings.
The visit is not a long one, but probably not ideal for young children.
Once outside in the gardens we watched as some 15 cats or more were being fed a chicken head each.

Avoid going at mid day. The palace itself was beautiful and a nice place to get away from the heat. The detail in the mosaic was stunning and I would have thoroughly enjoyed the trip had there not been 2 groups of around 30 tourists pushing their way through the other visitors. Although this probably can't be avoided, I would visit either early or late to avoid the main tourist busses.

A highlight of any tour to Marrakesh. Since non-Muslims cannot visit the mosques in Marrakesh, visiting the Bahia Palace and the Saadian tombs provide a good sample of the art and architecture of this region. A visit of less than an hour is enough. Be sure to have a guide or read a full description in advance.

Tranquil. This was the first place we visited, it was a wonderful introduction. It is incredibly peaceful and the courtyards are beautiful planted with trees and flowers. The architecture is very much what you expect it to be, beautifully, intricately, carved wood and plasterwork. The design of this palace makes you realise how clever the designers were at air circulation and climate control. A truly delightful introduction to North African royal life and history.

Beautiful/full of history/amazing/surreal..... I honestly cannot think of one word to describe this place accurately! Bahia Palace is such a stunning attraction with so much history behind it! My friend and I went as part of a discovery of Marrakech tour (which I recommend as you visit all of the main attractions in Marrakech and get to know all of the history behind them) Our tour guide was brilliant at reeling off all facts about the palace and telling us about the architecture/history. The only downside to this place is that it there are too many people around, but who can blame them for wanting to visit such a stunning attraction!If you're going to Marrakech, this place is a MUST!Oh, and don't forget to look up when you walk into each room! The ceilings are out of this world!

Bahia Palace Marrakech . I didn't really enjoy it i just went from room to room expecting to find something interesting to look at as I do enjoy historical buildings,finding out who lived there and how they lived but the rooms were empty and I didn't see any information boards of what the roo was used for, when I left I was a bit disappointed and still no wiser about its history

Interesting place. The palace is a former home of rulers of Morocco, and I agree with some of the other reviewers in that there is not a vast amount to see, as all of the furniture has been removed so you are looking at empty rooms, the architecture and the gardens, but that said for the entrance fee (10 Dirhams ie less than £1) you can spend an hour or so admiring the ornate walls and ceilings, and take a well earned break from the hustle and bustle of the city. I enjoyed walking around the grounds at my own pace without being badgered to buy something and would recommend a visit here

Not much to see. Frankly after having viewed several similar type monuments in Andalusia Spain, I found that the sites here in Marrakech had little to offer. I think I took more photos here of all the wild cats than of the actual Palace,...(If you can call it a palace!)
Amazing tiles!. Tranquil escape from the bustle of the souk and Jemma el Fna. Beautiful tiles and lush, cool courtyards. A great place to visit and take photos or sit take a break and people watch.
Stunning palace. Beautifully restored palace 10 minutes walk from the main square. Incredibly intricate walls and ceilings all restored to their former glory.

Splendid architecture . This was the palace of the Vizier of Morocco, named for his favorite wife. It is a spectacular oasis in the midst of a hot and dusty city. The central courtyard is beautiful and we really enjoyed learning about how the high born Moroccan lived.

Relaxing way to view a bit of history. This tourist stop was a nice, quiet escape from the bustling city. It wasn't too large a place to walk through, maybe taking about 45 minutes to enjoy. There wasn't too many people either which made it manageable and relaxing without being overwhelming. It's a good stop to make in Marrakech if you want a feel for the old style architecture and an idea about how people used to live.

Moroccan Architecture. Bahia Palace is an amazing display of Moroccan architecture, decor and tradition. You will not be disappointed during your visit. Please note that there are a lot of visitors and taking a good picture can be challenging.

Stunning. Well preserved although some parts were closed when we went. Still every room is in great condition and the walls and ceilings are amazing, although it was crowded you could still feel the peacefulness inside

Beautiful. A bit hard to find to be honest but once you get there is worth it. The details of the door frames, the ceilings and even the floors is great. As somebody said already I didnt have a clue on what I was looking and also I did not know that were underground passages. Was definitely worth to visit.

Beautiful!. Great display of wood,ceramic tiles and gardens! Loved trying to imagine the Sultans with the glorious decor and rich silk fabrics! We were there around mid-day and the tour groups had all arrived to see as well..so some of the areas were cramped...better to go early..but really a great visit!!

Interesting architecture ..but lack of info meant I had no idea what I was seeing. After the lunacy of the Marrakech streets, entering the Bahia Palace was a welcome relief from traffic dodging. The entrance fee was a pittance and my 7 year old got in for free. It's a nice walk up through orange trees with kittens and cats lying around to the Palace itself. We didn't take a guided tour (but I can't remember any tour being suggested) and my French is very limited and my Arabic non existent - I couldn't therefore read the information boards dotted on walls throughout the palace. Having just read the review below, we were completely unaware of there being any underground passages here. As the place isn't furnished, you get less of a feel of how it would have looked. Having said all this, it was all quite beautiful and peaceful and we weren't in a rush to head out back to the streets. Some brochures in different languages to explain what you're seeing would be a good add on for this attraction - I would have been happy to pay for one.

oasis of peace. badii palace in the jewish quarter of marrakech is a oassis inthe middle of a mad vibrant city you can spend two peaceful hours searching the ruins and under ground passages see the storks that nest around the walls all for 70p then back into the madness

Stunning - a must for Marrakech. The Bahia Palace is a beautiful place to while away an hour or so especially as a retreat from the madness of the souks. We visited as part of a tour of the sites with an excellent national official tour guide - Khalid Amor (khalid_amor@hotmail.com) who really enhanced our experience by giving us an insight into the history of the palace and evoking some of the atmosphere of the royal court. The picture he painted with words filled the empty rooms with the lush decadence and harsh cruelty of past times. He pointed out small details such as the Star of David in the Jewish waiting room that made the experience more poignant as it was a reminder that Islam is a religion based on tolerance. The courtyards were lush, green and serene and the architecture and the mosaic tiling were jaw droppingly stunning.
Peace and tranquility. Well worth a visit, it is a serene little tucked away palace, not a huge amount to see, just a nice way to laze away an hour or so

Worth looking for at the edge of the Medina. We enjoyed the Bahia Palace. While it is not large, it is very lovely with beautiful tile and carvings. The low admission price made me give it an Excellent rather than Very Good rating.
All I can say is wow. Amazing building with many rooms. Architecture and gardens are beyond expectations. The detail and colours will amaze you. Don't miss it.

Make more efforts . As a Marrakech-lover since 2006 i frequently used to visit this palace. It's too bad, that the big garden that I was lucky to see at my first visits as well as the big last court of the concubines are no longer open to visitors. Some parts of the building are constantly under construction. My suggestion is, that the city of Marrakech which has been voted as tourists no. 1 destination recently should take care more of this place and invest more money as well as take higher entrance fees (now €1) in order to reconstruct the Palais propperly and more quickly. Its a shame, that buildings of the same period in al Andalusia/Spain are kept as a more appreciated and preserved heritage, than in Morocco itself. Although it should be much more easier here, where craftsmans and authentic techniques are right beside! It could be such a beautiful place with the right management!

Beautiful mosaics and good story. We only saw about 25% of the place due to restoration but it was still worth it. The mosaics are beautiful as to be expected and our guide gave us a good story around the man behind the palace. Definitely worth the 10 dirhams.

Well Preserved Royal Palace. This is a really nice old palace. You walk through an archway and the gardens as you walk up to palace are very attractive and peaceful, especially considering the madness outside the grounds!There are lots of different rooms with beautiful old tiled archways, floors, ceilings and courtyards. It is amazing that they have survived so well.

Beautiful palace full of Eastern promise. The Bahia shows the most beautiful wooden carving, plaster work and mosaics that the Sultan could command. It is worth seeing but it won't take long. It may take you longer to find than to visit! Signposting is not the strong point of the Marrakech city council.

Mom's name. The fact that is my mother's name (Bahia) makes not perfectly objective about it ! I must say though, it is a beautiful place, where you can feel the story of old Morocco. The ruins are beautiful, the walls, the view on the mosque is absolutely wonderful if you get it through a certain angle.

well kept. the bahia palace is very nice for all the people interested in architecture and mosaics,the ceilings are wonderfully colored and maintainedthey were renovating the Hareem area, but we had a glimpse it looked stunning!so it's a must visit, but try to go very early in the morning because it's usually full of tourists that might not make you fully enjoy the experience.

A beautiful refuge away from the dusty streets of Marrakech. As far as tourist attractions in Marrakech go, the Bahia Palace is one of the best there is. For an entry fee of 10 dirham (about 70p), you have to make sure that it's on your to-do list. Look up, look down, and look all around you. You'll see the most gorgeous craftsmanship - what more could you ask for?

Better than many other Marrakech sights. Worth a visit, a modern (19th century) recreation of what the old Sultan's palaces would have been like. If you've seen the Alhambra then it will underwhelm you, if it's your first taste of Moorish architecture and decoration then you'll love it. Keep looking up! Loved the orange trees in the courtyard. Apparently there's a huge section still being restored, can't wait until it's all done it'll be magnificent!

Beautiful Palace lacking information. Bahia Palace is very beautiful, I'm a huge fan of architecture and I loved spending time just enjoying the atmosphere of the place whilst sitting in the shade. But as there is no information for guests to read you could easily walk away having learnt absolutely nothing about it. It would probably be useful to bring a guide.It does get very busy with tourists and the front gate would only accept the exact change for the ticket, so make sure you have 10 & 20 DH notes/coins with you.

The palace. Moroccan interiors outstanding - the amount of detail. I think the fact that there is no furniture whatsoever it was difficult to visualise what it would have looked like. The public toilets were 'different', but at least they existed.

A palace with not a lot going on. Visited the Bahia Palace one afternoon and sort of strolled through it. Donna is a quilter so we took pictures of some mosaic patterns for her idea book. The mosaics were nice, the rooms were cool on a hot day and the entry price modest. Not a "destination attraction" but worth a stroll if you are on that side of the city.

Beautiful and a break from the sun!. Gorgeous building kept in very good condition, the detail was amazing! A real insight into how ornate and detailed Moroccan interiors can be . There also some cute stray cats wandering about too :)

Sorry, but nothing like the Alhambra. A collection of linked rooms built in the 19th century, so not that old. Vaguely interesting but really nothing special. Minimal on site information, poorly maintained. Maybe they should increase the small entrance fee and spend some money on it.

Not Quite the Hype. The Ben Youssef Medrasa has it all over this venue, which is interesting but not worth waiting hours or walking to see. It is a pleasant review of moorish decor and little more. Marrakech itself is limited in significant historical "must see's" outside of the city itself and the Medina. I'd focus on relaxing, taking a trip to the Atlas, visiting the Jardin Marjorelle, the Souks and crossing off the Jemaa, which is chaos at nighttime and deserted at day.
Nice building, bit repetitive. It's a nice break away from the heat as there are rooms which get you out of the sun. Nice architecture and incredible detail when you look close, recommended.
Very pretty Palce. This was quite small, but very nice, similar to the Alhambra in Granada, but on a much smaller scale. Well worth visiting.

Bargain bit of culture. If you are popping to Marrakech for a couple of days and want to dip your toe in a little bit of culture in amongst all of the shopping and haggling then visit the Bahia palace. A 10 min walk from the main square it is easy to find, you don't need to book yourself onto any tour, and it is 10drn, about 90p for your entrance fee. Inside there is little information available but you could linger around a couple of the tours guides to pick up the basics. It is just a beautiful building to walk through.
Would recommend a visit. Easy to find from the Jemma El-Fnaa square, not too long a walk. Entrance only 10 dirrhams each. Lovely building with beautiful mosaics. Plenty of shade on a hot day.

Get a guide. Like a lot of attractions in Marrakech getting a guide brings a visit it life and much more interesting. The walls are nothing to write home about but the floors and ceilings are just something else. The guide brings it all to life and explains everything and the lives that the princes who lived there were explained and it all meant so much more. Do visit.

Beautiful mosaics but very little to see.. We visited the Palace with a guide who explained the history of it. The craftsmanship and the building must have been beautiful in its day but there is no furniture or decor so you are looking round and empty shell. It is a short visit and a small entrance fee . we were there less than an hour .
Worth a visit. Gorgeous palace well worth a visit. The visit will take you under an hour. The ceilings and the intricate work is not to be missed.Would suggest getting a guide

Absolutely underwhelming. Maybe my expectations of an 'ornate' interior and 'beautiful gardens' are different from other reviewers as the rooms in this 'palace' are in serious need of repair and attention and the gardens are minute. Glad it was only the equiv of 1 euro.

Impressive. Certainly worth a visit, if in Marrakech! Impressive walk through - or guided tour. I simply got a kick out of admiring the beautiful spaces, rooms, tiles, fountain...much to take in (even without a guide). A nice escape from the busy city, in the city itself, and for a cheap price. Do it.

Definitely worth seeing. Lovely and peaceful and calm in the Medina of bustle, this is certainly worth a visit. The walk in to the palace alone will make you feel calmer - the orange trees and cherry blossoms and shady spots to sit and rest make it really peaceful. The palace itself is really well-kept and you will be tempted to ask if you can stay here!
Worth a visit...... Only 10 dirham entry.Well worth a visit to see how a traditional palace would have been.Can get busy, but tranquil after the madness of the Square!

Go with a tour guide!. I went on a full day Marrekech tour with Chakib Elhiba and this palace was one of our stops. I don't think I would have appreciated this place not unless I knew what was going on as it could have felt like it was just room after room after room. Chakib explained the history down to the details of every room to us which were very interesting details you cannot read on any website. We unfortunately got in at a time when there was alot of tourist traffic so in the end, it was a bit stressful.

Interesting and peaceful. Without a guide this may just seem like a series of rooms, but they are beautifully decorated and for the low price of 10 MAD this is a peaceful oasis from the bustling streets. Use your imagination to bring the place to life! Tip: avoid anyone offering to show you the way to another palace or the Jewish cemetery upon leaving. Do not trust these men. They will demand money from you and may even take you in the wrong direction. This is Marrakech...
bahia palace. it is a wonderful palace, rich in decoration and well kept. The man at the entrace was not very friendly but the palace is nice and give an idea of how it was in the past.

A Moroccan palace worthy of a visit. This palace was created with no expense spared! The place is certainly ornate, with some gorgeous ceilings and tiled floors. Our guide led us round the small number of rooms that are open to the public, but much of the palace is off limits, probably because the Moroccan royal family still use it. It's a very peaceful place, despite being in the Medina. Shame you can't see more of it.

great visit. The grounds are very well maintained with beautiful flowers and orange trees. This is a very interesting place, you need to go with a guide to fully appreciate the history and to find out what different parts were used for. Definitely recommend a visit, beautiful architecture, mosaics and ceilings.

So peaceful. Would recommend a visit here. It is amazing how peaceful it is considering how close it is to the hussle and hussle of the Medina square. Expect it to be quite busy though with tourists, but go for the view of the central courtyard alone - it is beautiful!

Get a guide!. Your tour will almost be worthless without a guide as there is no signage. You will not know what you are looking at, or even the correct direction of flow. Sure, the rooms are pretty, but they all almost start to look the same after a bit, and you know nothing about them. Admission is only 10MAD, so not truly a waste of money, but maybe a waste of time. It was not obvious where you could hire a guide once inside the facility, or if you had to bring your own.

Bahia Palace. Our must do list was the Bahia palace. We visited the palace and strolled the court yards and terrace which was beautiful. When it was time to visit the palace we were turned away and told that it was closed. Such a shame as we paid 20 dhirums to have a full tour. So if your planing to visit ask the man at the ticket desk if the palace is open for viewing!
A wonderful oasis. Really interesting palace with really pretty gardens. We hired a local guide who was invaluable with his knowledge.
Amazing!. You must hire a guide once inside the building! They show you and explain to you the rooms... no information at all! no signs...Its their way to trap the tourists!!! but it worth it!

Poorly maintained. For a palace, the El Bahia was underwhelming. You can see that once upon a time, this was a great palace with beautiful detailing in the ceilings and the walls. However, without proper maintenance and up-keep, this palace will soon become a giant stork nest like the El Badi. The walls could use some fresh paint, and the fountain could be turned on. After all, the palace does receive hundreds (if not thousands) of visitors a day.

Very old and interesting. When visiting here you must have a guide to benefit all the interesting bit and pieces of information. The history of this place is extraordinary, going back so many centuries.But I do stress you have a guide with you or the visit will be worthless.As the title says a palace and it was - for many different people.for so many years.

Worth the trip. Tougher to find from deep within the souk, but worth the effort. It does have a little bit of a down at the heels feeling to it, but it also has stunning ceilings, doors, windows and atria. You can close your eyes and imagine living there!

Beautiful Alhambra style 19th century palace , close to the mellah. It is well worth a visit to this lovely place. Upon entering through the gate, you are greeted by the lush gardens with their laden orange trees. The palace courtyard is also full of plants. While visitors are not able to see all of the rooms, those that are open have magnificent painted cedar ceilings, fabulous zellige tile, as well as lavish and intricate plasterwork.
Nice. So nice place to visit in Marrakech. It is located in the old part of the city and it is a wonderful building to visit.

Good one in the centre of the city. Bahia Palace is good attraction to spend some amount of time away from the crowd and heat. It is maintained very neat. Trees and flowery plants occupy the entrance. Palace is typical of mosaic floors, decorated doors, fountain in between a huge hall etc. When we went some of the places were locked - so we visited almost 60% of what the palace is shown in the map. Entry fee is 10MAD. This is very near to Jemma El Fnaa and is walkable. Spice shops and others occupy the neighborhood. No information boards to give some history or importance of the rooms - this is something management can look at.

Stunning Craftsmanship. The history of the palace is very interesting, particularly the slave turned Grand Vizier aspect. The rooms themselves have beautiful tilework, woodwork, and painting. It is the height of craftsmanship at the start of the 20th Century. There is no furniture and no real information as you walk through, which is unfortunate.

Worth a stop if in the area. It was refreshing to get out of the busy streets and have a walk around the palace. 15-20 minutes will take you around the rooms and courtyards, with beautiful ceilings, decorations. tiling and woodwork. Worth a stop.
A compact Alhambra. A glorious riot of pattern and colour to be enjoyed in a cool retreat away from the madness of the Medina. Fabulous ceramic tiles, amazing ceilings and plasterwork.
Only ik. Visited this palace today and underwhelmed by the whole place. Very small viewing areas so we after 15'mins we had seen it all.

A breezy respite from the madness. The Bahia Palace has an interesting history and I was keen to visit after reading Edith Wharton describe it so dotingly in her book 'On Morocco'. The palace was, I thought, the most beautiful of the different palace in the south side of the Medina. The courtyards were lush and the architecture and the mosaic tilings were both stunning to see. It was great just to chill out their in the heat of the afternoon. It was rammed with tourists, of course, but as one of the offending tourists, I can hardly complain.

The best palace in town. The is the best place to visit in Marrakesh. It is a building with excellent architecture, painted and crafted ceilings and an amazing garden at the centre.Be aware that it is not accessible to wheelchairs. It is something that should take care of and make some ramps.
Wonderful Architecture. This is worth a trip while you are in town. The architecture of this palace and the garden were wonderful.

Lovely once-upon-a-time palace... The kind of palace, old and somewhat faded but with lots of hints at grander times, where your imagination can roam freely. If it is not too crowded, the vast number of rooms with beautiful ceilings and ornate doors, intricate mosaic floors and windows overlooking the courtyard gardens really convey the way the privileged lived away from the crowded and noisy medina.

Beautifully preserved, must see!. Intricate architectural work, beautiful tiled floors and storks nesting up above, this palace is lovely to walk around. There is plenty information about each section and although there were a lot of people there it did not feel overcrowded or busy. There is a lot to explore, from the underground rooms to the roof terrace which offers stunning views over El Koutoubia mosque and the Atlas mountains.
Historic palace. Very interesting place good place to relax from the crowds , lovely views from high points - look for crane nests dotted around wall

Stunning Moorish decoration. Taken here by our excellent guide from Riad Dar Najat. This is really quite beautiful; the intricate decorative plasterwork and the painting was fabulous. We were there in early March 2015, so the temperature was comfortable, and although there were a lot of people there it was not crowded. We took many photos!
Very nice, but crowded. This is a lovely, ornate palace. It is very crowded so go early in the morning to avoid the tourist buses.

Do go. Although it seems to be on every tour group's agenda, you should go. It isn't that big so does get a bit crowded. However the tiles, stucco and wooden ceilings make it a worthwhile visit. As an alternative or additional visit I would suggest the Dar Si Said museum which is much quieter.

"Bahia" means beautiful & it is!. We enjoyed our visit to the Bahia Palace to hear about the prime minister and his four wives that used to live there. No furnishings are there but that almost gives you a better view of the gorgeous floors and stunning ceilings.We did go round with a guide as part of a tour, but it would have been nice to look around at a more leisurely pace.

Beautiful, well preserved, palace - only 5 minutes from the El Badi palace. We really liked visiting this palace. It is beautiful, well preserved, palace consisting of a series of courtyards surrounded by lavishly decorated rooms, check out the mosaic floors, the decorative ceilings and the carved doors and window surrounds.It wasn’t too busy when we visited so we could just walk around and sit in the garden courtyard and enjoy the respite from the normally busy sites. Worth visiting and is just 5 minutes from the El Badi palace and only 10 Dirhams entry fee.

Look Up!. Go when there is no tour group and you can look and savour. This is hispano-moorish architecture and design at its zenith. Look at the ceilings. Then look at those in the next room. Imagine the harem living here in this splendor. Take your time to look at the carved plaster and the stalactites. The best buck you ever spent!

Lovely Palace near city centre. The Bahia Palace is a beautiful Islamic palace easily accessible from the city centre. Like all attractions in Marrakech, entry is very cheap (10 Dhirams/about 70p!) and it is more than worthwhile. There are some lovely gardens and many Islamic designs, Moorish arches, ceilings, windows etc. which are well worth studying and marvelling at....I couldn't stop taking photos and the scent of the Orange trees is delicious!

Nice place to visit.. Nice cool retreat after being out in the intense heat!Lots of great photo opportunities so is a bit of a photographers paradise, does get busy but still room to do your own thing.We never paid to get in though I believe it is relatively cheap at 10 DH each, don't think there was anyone taken money when we arrived, so we got lucky, haha!Lots of detail, ornateness and stunning colours, no furniture but lots to see nonetheless.Worth a visit.

Those painted ceilings!!!!!. Incredible building in a very good state of conservation. There's a series of patios surrounded by lavishly decorated (ceilings, windows, lamps) rooms. What I found odd was there there was not a single piece of furniture in the palace. Maybe they moved it all to the new palace (which is not open for the public).Don't forget your camera. There are loads of picture opportunities here.
Lovely place to visit. Excellent value and beautiful tiling and courtyards. Really lovely building, I would certainly go back next time we are in Marrakech.

Colourful mosaics. In the centre of the Medina, it is beautiful tiles, walls, floors and gardens. Many tourists but quiter than the noisy souks, we got really nice pictures.Pictures of this and the places we visited in Marrakesh are on my bloghttp://latravelera.blogspot.com

Gorgeous!. Like many other touristy areas in Marrakech, this palace gets easily crowded by a tour group so you might want to carefully time your visit - but the palace is truly stunning. It's definitely worth a visit and isn't far from the main square and the Baadi palace.
Fantastic palace. An oasis of peace and interest in a crazy place. There is also a spectacular minbar in the museum section

Beautiful Place!. What a beautiful place!We got there pretty early (between 9 and 10am) on a Friday so it wasn't so busy.The best part was that the orange trees were blooming, which made the beautiful sight so much more beautiful.

Blue&turquoise tiles all over. gardens. white walls. AMAZING. This was my favorite attraction in Marrakech, it is what I was expecting from Morocco. Full colored tiles on the floor and walls, open spaces, fountains, beautiful and intricate arches and QUIET. Most of the city is noise and hectic but here, you can just come and relax for a couple of hours. It's a small palace but it is unique a must visit! You can read more about Morocco on the travel blog www.nomadsventure.com
Peace & Quiet. Great place to chill after walking through the souks, nice gardens and pleasant walk through the palace

Words cannot describe. Simply one of the most beautiful places I've ever been. Blew me away, most incredible detail and such a peaceful atmosphere - despite lots of tourists! Photographers paradise :)

Definately worth a Visit.. This place is a great respite from all the chaos round the city. Worth a visit for only 10 dirhams (about 70p) per person. Although the walk round won't take much more than an hour or two, there is some wonderful architecture to see, and beautiful designs within this building.
Amazing tale of existence.. I loved the story behind this place of the palace being built to honor the wife whom bore a son. It is also an amazingly beautiful building.

Not worth the visit.... We went there happily as it is one of the attraction to see in Marrakesh until we actually get there...It only cost €1 to enter but what a disappointment! There were no tourist information signs. It was just an empty, old palace with nice tiled walls and no furniture. It was unfortunately for our experience a total waste of time...

Nice palace, worth a visit. Does look a little run down, so you do have to use your imagination to see how beautiful this place would have been when it was open as a palace. There is some restoration work going on, so hopefully it will be fully restored to its former glory one day!

Beautiful palace for an hour or so. Any place in Marrakech where you can get away from it all is worth a visit!!
This is a very pretty old palace with beautiful ceilings and carving work. At only 10 dirhams (about 70p) why wouldn't you go! Yes, lovely, go take a look.
Also in March the orange trees smell amazing.

Big empty space. This is a ruin of a palace, rather than a palace. You need a guide to explain what is not there anymore. A peaceful oasis in the bustling city with the scent of orange blossom and lots of storks flying around and nesting. Take your own toilet paper!
Stunning. We came away with cricks in our necks from looking at the wonderful ceilings! The little garden is most attractive, with unknown birds singing.

Somewhere must to visit in Marrakech. A famous spot you must come to see, on the list of Marrakech!
no one can resist a photo shot with this beautiful Moroccan Islamic pattern!
Though, a little too crowd inside, but you know you still can find somewhere to sit then enjoy the golden old age of the palace.
Beautiful place!. A must if you love architecture, lots to see and really cheap (1 euro). An easy way to spend and hour.

A little gem. Visited today with my husband after a crazy few hours spent in jemaa al fna. This place instantly gives you a wonderful chilled feeling as soon as you enter....beautiful mosaics, stunning gardens and an amazing courtyard....it really is such a welcome oasis to the craziness of the souks and jemaa al fna. I was so impressed at the entrance fee being a mere 10dh which is less than £1!!! I would recommend a visit to this stunning little palace.
Beautiful. Lovely little visit with the wife today.....very chilled, very cheap especially the beautiful surroundings you will walk in.
Worth a visit. This is worth visiting and is just 5 minutes from the El Badi palace. The Bahia gives a good idea of where a wealthy family would have lived in the 19th century.

Beautiful, incredible craftsmanship. Well worth having a look at this palace - stunning ceilings, decorative paintwork, woodwork, plaster work - stunning rooms when empty so I can't imagine how wonderful it must have been in its day.

Lovely architecture and well worth the visit. Guide books can be a little cruel to the Bahia Palace, mainly because of its history and owner, and the implication is that it's all OTT and in terribly bad taste, but in terms of what Marrakech has to offer it is definitely worth a visit.Located near the Place des Ferblantiers (and handy also for the El Badi palace and Saadian Tombs - see separate entries) the visit begins - as with many things - with a long walk down a narrow drive before reaching the palace itself. There is a circuit of the palace marked, but nothing to stop you from doubling back or doing the circuit again. In the palace are some stunning rooms and some internal patios well worth a few megabytes of your memory card.The palace can get busy with guided groups, but if it does, just wait until they have moved on, and you should have plenty of time to admire everything on offer.
A little Granada. The architecture and style is reminiscent of the Alhambra in Granada, but on a much smaller scale. The place has been renovated and has retained the original character and ambiance.
Beautiful piece of history. Beautiful piece of history...worth the visit. Impressive tile work, inlaid woodwork and architecture in harems, courtyards and grand court.

Very pretty. I really liked visiting this palace. It is beautiful, the archtecture is very nice. It wasnt busy when we visited so we could just walk around and sit in the little garden, really nice!! Would recommend this. Also, it isnt that big so you wouldn't need more than a hour or something

Well worth a visit, lovely palace in the middle of the old town. Really enjoyed our walk around the palace, well worth the 10 Dh, love seeing the Storks nesting on the walls. Do try and get to see this part of Marrakech.
Beautiful architecture. Located in the oldtown we payed 10dh to get in which is roughly less than a pound. It was well worth the visit the palace is absolutly beautiful. Architechture is amazing.

Amazing!. What a beautiful palace right in the middle of the old town. The architecture is magnificent, stunning floors, ceilings and doorways, vibrant colours. So cool inside away from the sun / heat. Suggest you get a guided tour to fully understand the rich history of the palace. Well worth a visit.

Great Architecture. Not as much history as other places in Marrakech, but the Architecure makes up for it. Definately worth a look at if you have the time. I wouldn't call it a must see though.It would be more interesting with maybe a bit of furniture and decorations, but I thought it was more than worth the price and time to see it.

beautiful building worth a visit. Amazing carving on walls and doors and highly decorated ceilings Worth stopping off for an hour or two Also cooler inside on a very hot day Not much in way of information to be found but still worth seeing this impressive building

Palace of a regent. Interesting enough to visit to round out your tour of Marrakesh. This was a palace of a regent, not the king or prince. It was still interesting and well preserved. The architecture is interesting to look at, though not too old.

Building worth a visit. People say there is nothing to see, but be aware it is just 19th century palace so walk inside it and have a look at the rooms, pretty ceilings and mosaics. Entrance is only 10 Dirham. Just read about this palace before you go as there is not too much info. We started our day trip with Bahia Palace. Next visit Maison Tiskwin and Dar Si Said if you like museums. Come back to Bahia Palace and walk south to see Jewish synagogue-hided-so follow signs to Riad 73. Next Jewish Cemetery and walk back through Jewish part of the town (lots of little alleys) to El Badi Palace and Royal Palace. Afterwards take a walk to west to Kasbah Mosque and Saadian Tombs and the most famous gate of Marrakech – Bab Agnaou. Walk north to Jemma el Fna , relax in one of the roof cafes.

Just beautiful. If you are staying anywhere round the medina, this is walking distance. The architecture is just breathtaking as are the gardens. Well worth a couple of hours. By walking from the main square you also go down the part of arty shopping area and there are some great finds.

Lovely architecture. For 10dhs this is well worth a visit, you only get to see a small part, but you get a taste of the splendor.One of the security personnel gave us a sneaky peak through a door to the rest of the palace beyond the public part - it was spectacular.

Stunning. This place is an absolute gem and should not be missed. I thought I would tire of the geometric stucco artwork, but no. It is delightful, so amazing and intriguing. Everywhere you look seems more beautiful than the last. I can't remember what the charge was to visit but no matter what it was it was no where near enough. This place is gorgeous throughout and I can thoroughly recommend it.
Bahia the favoured one. Went here on a tour very interesting site to see with history wrapped up in every corner, tile, ceiling and room.
Loved the ceilings. the place is empty, but you have to love the architecture, particularly the ceilings, the details are amazing. it doesn't take more than 1 hour, but worth the visit.

Beautiful. The mosaics and the ceilings are amazing, it is really interesting to see, but a little disappointing because you imagine a palace is a royal palace but this was actually a prime ministers residence, it is lovely anyway and worth visiting
Not so great. I would not highly recommend this place to visit . It is nothing great in terms of history nor to see , I would hardly call it a palace

Great mosaic tiles. Bahia has the most amazing Mosaic tiles and for us this was the great attraction. So if you like Mosaic, you have to go to Bahia Palace. Entrance is only 10 DH (1 euro) so to take the tour for approx 1-2 hours is higly recommended.
Kills some time. I stayed at a Riad near this place and thought i might as well go for a trip. The architecture is really nice however the place isnt as big as i thought it'd be.

Loved the architecture and the colors!. I know, there is beautiful architecture and color EVERYWHERE in Morocco, but I really enjoyed visiting this palace and got MANY gorgeous photos here. I did think it was nicer than other palaces and kasbahs that we visited. I would definitely recommend a visit here if you have time and you just can't enough of Moroccan architecture!

Kills half an hour.... Pleasant place but apart from quite pretty ceilings and mosaic, not much to see. But it did lead us to the pretty square next door (where Kosy Bar is) where there was a refreshing lack of hassle from shop owners, much cheaper pots and ceramics etc and no charges to take photos of the colourful spices! There is quite a bit of construction there at the moment but despite that, it was still a lovely square and will be even better when finished.

Better than Badi. Probably you will do this together with Badi. It's better, different architecture, and smaller with a symmetric set of rooms much better decorated than the outdoors of Badi.It's a nice attraction to see, and read up on the history behind it as well, it's an interesting way to get in touch with the history of the place you are visiting.Worth a visit, and if you have to choose between this and Badi, choose this.
Nice. Ruins are ruins!!!! Look for the storks and their nests. That was my favorite part!Photos can be taken and you'll wonder later....Where was this taken?

If you have time left. So, it's a palace. Nice tile work but that's it as far as I'm concerned. The story behind it is that the owner got too fat to climb the stairs so they never built a second floor. Entrance is 10 Dirham.

Sore neck!. Amazing building, amazing tiling, even better ceilings! you will get a sore neck from staring upwards! Don't be embarrassed to just lay on the floor and soak up the beauty of the work on each of the ceilings! Got some wonderful photos here. Peaceful compared to the souks outside.

Nice but no great shakes. To be honest, there are far nicer palaces in Marrakech, but the Bahia is still well worth a visit. It is small and compact and so of the tile work is amazing. It is only €1 to get in so I can't exactly complain about the lack of things to see. it is interesting but only if you have French as all the exhibits are explained in only French and Arabic.Well worth your time, a short stay will suffice though.

Quick visit / beautiful building / thats it. Its a 20 minute visit to a palace which has beautiful interiorsIf u go with a guide he tells you what the interiors are all about, if you go alone you just appreciate the beauty and quickly get outIf hard pressed for time ..skip it

Bargain. At just 10dhms the palace was a bargain. Unfortunately there is a lack of information but the tiling is amazing - and the ceilings are even better and you will get a sore neck looking up all the time!

Wonderful palace. The palace had lovely mosaic in all the rooms, with beautiful and large gardens. It was very fascinating as there was a guide that talked about the history of the palace and how the palace was built and it only cost 10 Moroccan dh.
A crowd-puller. Lovely symmetry, marquetry and mosaic...if you could see it for the crowds of guided bus tourists. Another one to "tick off", but not the most inspiring.

Interesting but crowded. It was very crowded when we visited - lots of school children on outings. But it was interesting to see especially the ceilings in the rooms. A good guide makes a difference in ensuring you get the full picture of the function of the various rooms.
Peace in the city. Cost just 10dh to go in (we used it as an excuse to change money) but enjoyed the tiling and architecture once inside. Good as a bit of respite from the bustling souks.

Beautiful palace. All I can say is wow - what a spectacle. The tiling was wonderful aswas the orange trees and we wanted to pick some, which of course we didn't. We have the most wonderful pictures which we are waiting upload.
Lovely palace. Very peaceful after the noise and bustle outside. Interesting architecture well preserved. Glad we had our own guide book which covered the essentials

Beautiful, but so much hidden away. This is 19th century building that is beautiful. Fantastic tiling, wood and stucco. Unfortunately only a small amount of it is open to the public; a guide pointed out a gap in a door and I could see that there was a much greater part of the building behind this. 10 dirham entrance fee.

Watch out for illegal guides. When we entered an old man asked to see our tickets so we duly showed him. Then he proceeded to give us a tour. I kindly requested that we wished to see the palace by ourselves and then he kicked up a fuss until a security guard appeared. The palace is very nice and mostly still complete.

Nice and relaxing. It's a lovely place to spend an hour wandering about the various rooms taking photos of the tile work and architecture. It's smaller than we expected because half the palace was being renovated so it'll probably be a lot more impressive during the summer months when it's fully open.
beautiful. one of my favorite palaces in Marrakech however they all look pretty much the same, if you have time definitely take a visit!

Architectural splendour!. La Bahia is the fruit of 14yrs of service by the best artisans of Northern Africa. The Harem, Grand & Petit Courts and Courtyards represent a harmonious symphony of Berber, Arabian and French architectural and artistic flavours.Thou only a portion of the palace’s 8 hectares and 150 rooms is open to the public, there is enough time you can spend here relishing the splendour at sight.
