Fabulous architecture. I was delighted by this beautiful palace. the walls are thick and when you leave the energetic streets of Marrakech, you enter a private peaceful place...Cost one euro I think...for an hour well worth it.

Worthy heritage. Surrounded by the old town the Palace has charm if not distinction. The corridors are maze like with fascinating decorative walls and ceilings. There are no artefacts or furniture, but one gains a sense of grandeur of what was in these thick walled rooms( keeping the sun and heat out). Did encounter a local aged guide who brought fun to the visit.

Beautiful Palace. I really enjoyed my experience walking through this unique palace. The architecture & the gardens were amazing. I recommend getting a guide to show you around as there is no information in the Palace.

Palace Ruins. Serene and beautiful ruins with footprints of the former buildingsOrange trees at the center following tradition full of fruit.Storks nestle on the ramparts making strange sounds with their beaks and occasionally fly overhead. Worth a visit
Not much to see. Like a lot in Marrakech, it has a lot of history but not much to see! Everything's in French so take a guidebook to find out

One of nicest palace in Morocco. We visited Bahia Palace towards the end of an extensive two week tour of Morocco and it was one of the nicest and most ornate palaces we visited. This was mainly due to the wealth of the builder and that it was done in the late 19th century. Go early for it can get crowded with tour groups since its one of the main attractions in Marrakech

not expensive to get in. we went here and it gives you nice views of the city over the terrace part. it is very inexpensive to get in (less than £1) and its a calm place to walk about, well worth going to see

Interesting architecture and mosaics. This has some lovely mosaics and interesting architecture. I would have loved to photograph this and get interesting angles but it was impossible as there were just too many people there. Our guide quickly took us through the palace and shared some if it's history but it was not as stunning as the guide books had led us to believe.

Not much to see. You had to pay 10DHS to enter which I don't mind, only the barriers were open and the people asking for money had no uniform and didn't give us a ticket... anyway...it is really pretty, classic Moroccan style and was nice to see, but there's no information, signs etc so it was pretty to look at but that's all. Don't need much time there.
Nice building, cheap entry but little to see. Bit disappointed as this is a huge building, but only a small area open to tourists. Classic Moroccan style.

Meh.... It only coat €1 to enter.We didnt have a tour guide, there were no tourist information signs, so it was just an empty, old palace with nice tiled walls and no furniture. The courtyard was nice with orange trees growing. But all the rooms looked the same. Maybe it would have been more interesting if we had a tour guide to tell us about the history. I can't complain about the price. It's worth a look around for €1. But don't be dissapointed if you miss it. The best part was the horse and carriage ride we took from Jemma el Fna. We paid €15 / 150 dirham. It's only a 5 to 10 minute walk, so the driver took a bit of a detour through some of the old streets.

Must see. Another fantastic palace in Marrakech, this and the Badii Palace are both worth the hour or so it takes to walk around. This palace is smaller that Badii but is as it was... not a ruin. Superb architecture beautiful courtyards and amazing mosaics. Again just the 10Dh to enter, fantastic value!

Sorry old palace. What a shame it has not been maintained over time to the standard of the Marjorelle Garden for example. It is really very run-down and neglected. Such a shame because there is some lovely architecture.
Worth a visit. Very good value for money but make sure you have a guide to explain everything as you will miss a lot of the history of the place.

Amazing archetechure. If you like intricate mosaics and Moroccan architecture this is worth a visit. It's amazing how much hand work and man hours must have gone into just the fireplace, let alone the rest of the palace. Don't plan on spending a long time here though, you can easily see the whole palace in an hour.

great historical place. The palace was mostly empty but some of the rooms still showed the rich Arabian décor. The many little gardens make it a very pleasant place to be during the hot days of the summer.

Worth seeing. One of the 'must-see' sights of Marrakech, and as can happen with these kind of things, we felt a little underwhelmed. It's a bit of an empty shell of a place, so you don't get any real sense of what it was like to live here, or indeed who lived here. There are some beautiful mosaics and architecture, although it does get a bit same-same as you walk around.They could do with more printed information around, but I suspect they would rather you pay extra for the guides.

nice to see. We came here after visiting the ruins of the other Badi palace easy way to spend 45 mins to a hour. Wish we had known more about the place. But definitely worth going to see and was less than a �1. Wish we had got proper guided tour to give us further information.
beautiful place. Breath taking decoration. What a shame no furniture survived. I wish I could see the place as it was fully decorated.

Nice building but short on detail. Beautiful architecture but it was just an empty shell. there was no description about the buiding and no way to get a feel on who lived there and what it was like. An aimless wander around an empty shell of a building with some nice mosaics. Expect to pay to use the lavatory.
Average.. If you have time then check it out but its not like a must see. Its more like the ruins of the Palace with a few good photo spots.
Dont expect to much. It isnt the grand palace that you imagine. It's small, modest, even Medersa Ben Youssef has better decoration. Worth to visit for 10 Dirhams in less than 30 minutes.

Detailed and Beautiful Palace. You can visit this Palace in 1h maximum.The Palace was very close from hour hotel and Cozy Bar, so it was a great plan have some drinks after this beautiful place of Marrakesh.
very nice artwork. Not as grand as you would expect from a palace, but we enjoyed staring at the intricate designs calved into the cedar wood ceilings.

Haven away from the hustle and bustle. Let your imagination run wild as you wander through the cool rooms and rest in the shay garden. You only see part of the palace as the rest is used by the royal family.

Amazing architecture.. This place is easy to find, we were able to rock in a taxi right outside the front door.Costs10 Dirhams each for the entrance fee, we got here about 9am and it was still fairly quiet at that time, about an hour later it was busier with tourists.The Architecture is beautiful, and I was able to take some amazing photos which I really enjoyed, but in all honesty, I just didn't "get" the place, if that makes sense. I might have enjoyed it more, if we had a guide, so that maybe my understanding would have been better.I do think it would have looked incredible with furniture etc,and the energies, I think would be different, but it was empty rooms. My husband really liked it here and I think he would have given it a higher rating, it's all a matter of taste, having said that, I'm really glad I visited the place, just wouldn't chose to return.

Stunning decoration. A must see. Stunningly beautiful mosaics and ceiling decoration. It would have benefitted from some information notices regarding the artwork but your guide book will provide some background to the palaces's history.

Wonderful. Beautiful garden and rooms, well worth the 10MAD fee.
Nice architecture and ornaments.
Good markets around with less touristic prices

peace and quit. After the noise and bustle of the main square we got a Taxi to Bahia Palace,The entrance fee is 10 dirhams.The gardens and Building are stunning with special praise,for the ceilings every thing is set in walled gardens with just the noise birds for company. you can have a guide which i would reccomend
Nice details. We were lucky that we did not have that many tourists in so we could enjoy and have a closer look at the nice architectural details. It is for sure worth a visit.
A "must see".. You can walk to here from the square or use the hop on hop off bus. It's magnificent and mind boggling ! Entry is a bargain 10Dh (about 70p). Don't miss it !!

The Grand Vizier had a grand life as a tax collector!. This is definitely worth a visit but like other reviewers you really need a guide to understand each part that you are allowed to visit. We were lucky enough to catch a tour that was passing through midway and learnt that the Grand Vizier had 4 wives, with number one wife living in an apartment the same size as the other three had to share! He also had 28 concubines! And that the beautifully decorated ceilings were reflected in rugs of the same design on the floor. With wall hangings and silk curtains it must have been sumptuous. It is a pity more of the palace is not open to the public as I expect it would be a treat to see the scale and beauty of the whole palace and perhaps the areas that the servants had to work and live in such as the kitchens, stables, etc.

A fabulous example of Moroccan architecture. I'd read previous reviews and this palace lived up to them. 10 dirhams gives you entrance to the delightful grounds teeming with cats and orange trees. You'll get a crick in your neck from looking upwards to take photos of the gorgeously ornate ceilings and archways. If I had to pick just one building to recommend in Marrakech this would be it.
A cheap distraction.... It's a cheap distraction, a haven from the hustle and bustle of the souk.Enjoy the peace and quiet or hire a guide for the full story.
Nice visit. This was part of a day trip and was okay - if you appreciate this sort of history/architecture then I would recommend it.

You need a guide.. A guide will explain the use of colours and the pattern in the tiles , the decorated ceilings , the Man that lived there had 4 wife's & 23 concubines somebody spent a lot of time looking up. Well worth visiting .
Fairly new palace. Entry is 10 dirham and the palace is a quiet place for a quick vist. Without a guide it's difficult to see whats so special about the place.
Interesting. Little oasis of calm, with beautiful interiors. It was a little difficult to find but we got there in the end.
Beautiful palace. The building is a beautiful example of artisan skills....and well worth a visit to imagine with the help of a guide telling the story how the people lived in those far off days.

use a local guide. I have been 2 in the palace and in the last time I hired a local tour guide. It was amazing to know all the history about the palace and she told as litle curiousities that make me see all around with different eyes. Nice and so cheap the ticket 1€.

Closed When We Visited. This review is quite late. We visited the Bahia Palace but it was closed then. We were curious to see what this Palace has to offer but were not lucky enough to make another visit. Anyhow, we had some photos taken outside the Palace Gate.

Great architecture. The palace is an interesting place. Th layout of the rooms and courtyards gives an idea of the life there. The mosaics, wall, and ceiling decorations are in place but all the rooms are completely empty. A guide is helpful in gaining understanding.

3 stars. We managed to sneak along with a walking tour in Bahia Palace which made the experience a whole lot better. We received some very interesting information from the guide which, if we had not had, would have made the Palace a little boring... So I'd recommend coming with a tour if you're not the most knowledgeable on Moroccan history.
Yes! Go!. I don't think there are many things worth seeing in Marrakech. But this palace surely is one of them.

Interesting Palace. it is a very interesting palace and nice islamic and moroccan artitechure. A lot of rooms though it is very bare and very little information about the history of the palace. I did not pay for the guide but some of the other travellers had guides so they probably got more info from the guides. For 10Mad it is interesting place to spend an hour.
nice afternoon. my hubby and i had a very pleasant wander around the palace the rooms where amazingly tiled on the floors, walls and ceilings. was very cheap to get in but well worth a look

Just okay. Honestly, I'm not sure I would recommend this site to tourists, especially English speakers, as the signs are in only Arabic and French. While some of the architecture is certainly beautiful, overall a disappointment.
History. Reflects life as it once was - could perhaps do a bit more with it - it would be good to know some of its history without having to look it up on the internet

Beautiful place. Amazing building, but yet it should be renovated and taken action to preserve building as such. I loved the attraction and the ticket was inexpensive. Near the palace is the local market - so called Jewish market.
palace. we only walked around the outside but very impressive and in a nice cleanly kept area we stopped here on the way to the tombs

Sadly nothing special. I feel a heathen writing this review after so many people have written positive reviews, however I don't get it.....It's a palace - much like any other palace in the world. Nothing particularly special about the architecture, and whilst it is big on mosaics, if you've been to Barcelona you've seen better.Perhaps most notable is that the whole place is empty - not a single piece of furniture to be seen. Just empty rooms and old fireplaces for you to imagine how it might have been. Walking around it was like viewing a property for sale!!

Peaceful. We popped in here on our last day. It only costs 10dh (80p) to get in so how anyone can say it's a waste of money astounds me!You won't know what you are looking at - there are no signs or notices: I don't think the Marrakech-ians understand that we tourists would like to know more! So just enjoy the carvings, the architecture, the tiling and have a relaxing wander around the place. My children (10 and 14) have always enjoyed exploring unusual places and we spent a very happy 30+ minutes here. They made up their own minds as to what they were looking at! (NB: They didn't get charged for entry so even more of a bargain!)Many reviews of Marrakech talk about the sellers trying to get money out of you at every turn, but my daughter summed it up for me when she realised what it was about the 'tourist attractions' in Marrakech that felt different - they don't do 'gift shops'. You are not made, as in England, to exit the place via the shop and made to part with money there. But perhaps they are missing a trick!

A charming and exotic architecture. This is a fine example of Arabic or Islamic architecture, with many intriguing wall tiles and ceilings. I wish I knew more about Islamic architecture and arts before I visited.
A beautiful arab palace.. Next to the Jewish district, inside the amazing and chaotic Medina, a relaxing and very beautiful arab palace Only en DHM: 1€!

Beautiful!. This palace, in the heart of the Medina showcases the most beautiful Morrocan traditional art. The painted ceilings and carvings are exquisite. A must see, but probably early in the day to avoid the crowds, and to enjoy the serenity of the courtyards.

architecture. if your into this, prepare for real treat worth getting an official guide to explain all aspects and different designs but if you not bothered with that just go for a look around well worth it

Enchanting. Combine a visit here with ones to the the Badii Palace and the Saadi tombs. Together they tell an interesting story of power and beauty. Throw in the Kasbah with lunch in between and you would have had a most enchanting day.

Well worth the 1 Euro entrance to visit this peaceful place. Well worth the 1 Euro entrance to visit this peaceful place in the heart of bustling Marrakech.The buildings are literally ruins by now, but it is so peaceful to wander round in here. There was the added bonus of a photography exhibition when I visited in January which was a lovely contrast to the hassle that can be Marrakech. Do not miss going up the stairs to the terrace for amazing views of the Atlas mountains: The best place in town to view them I think.

Historical place. Amazing building, but yet it should be renovated and taken action to preserve building as such. I loved the attraction and the ticket was inexpensive. Near the palace is the local market - so called Jewish market.
Interesting place.. Worth a visit, interesting to see some Moroccan history and the old architecture. Amazing mosaics, beautiful doors and windows.

Went with a so-so guide. The Bahia Palace was on my list but I wanted to go to the Tombs first. We were dissuaded from going to the Tombs first. As I booked the 1/2 day guide through my Riad, they sort of got the guy after it was arranged about a week or 2 ago. The palace was nice, more of the ceramics and large spaces. Not too much t osee. AS tourists we were late getting back to the Riad at 3:00pm instead of 2:00pm to meet the guide so somewhere around 6:00pm he had to 'go'. As this was my first and only personal tour guide in Morocco, I don't think we got value or attention for money. 1.) The personal guide wasn't that accommodating. 2.) He didn't help us to get the best rate for the taxi ride from Sidi Ben Slimane parking lot. He just let the beige taxi stiff us for the ride based on the taxi's opinion about the traffic he imagines he will meet. 3.) The guide had to take a different taxi and meet us at the front of the Bahia Palace. 4.) Warning: Do not go to the oil, perfume and the seed shop just to the right side of the palace. The guide took us there and it was a rip off. The girls are young and they don't weigh anything. They overcharged for the items I bought: black soap for hammam, 2 small tubes of orange blossom oil, 1 small tube of patchouli oil and finally 1 oz. of chia seeds for 20MOD - final total for everything ended up being about 180MOD. The Bahia palace was okay but as the guide mentioned to us in the middle of the square at Jemma el fna market square in Marrakech at 6:00pm. He actually said, do you want me to take you back to your Riad or do you stay here and shop a little more. All in all, we could have done without the personal tour guide. Thanks to my wonderful Riad they picked up the tab for the poor service.
Old castle. Empty castle with renovations going on. Beautifull mosaics and history but expected a castle like the ones we have here. No furnishings, nothing.

Must do if you want to see Moorish design at its best. Only 10Dhs why wouldn't you visit. Serene in the middle of the madness outside. The intricate detail on the ceilings windows arches etc is exquisite. Worth a visit
a tranquil retreat. Pretty gardens, stunning mosaics, graceful courtyards - if you liked the Alhambra, you'll love this. The lack of furniture serves to show off its tiled glories

Nice but surprisingly empty. The walls are the most impressive part. Once inside it is a little disappointing as there is not much to see. You have to pay extra to see the pulpit from the Kotoubia mosque. I found this worth the extra.
A nice ruin. The entry fee is only 10 Dhs so fair enough to have a quiet stroll around a ruin with good views. A fine place they say it once was...

They really lived in style.. It is well worth taking your time. We had a great guide who explained in detail the structure, built and purpose of the palace. The use of the light is magic. The mosaics – and craftsmanship in general – render you speechless. Enjoy the stroll in the garden. Very relaxing indeed.
Typical Moroccan Palace. Representative of tile work and carvings. Peaceful and nice gardens. But the peddlers outside are aggressive and a nuisance.
Palace. This is one of the master pieces of Moroccan achitecture and was built at the end of 19th century. It contains some beautiful gardens.
Must see. This is a must see. It gets you into a peaceful place where you can admire the interior of the building. Well worth the cheap entry fee

Only worth a pound. An empty decorative multi roomed building with nice orange trees in the garden. Limited signage and info inside and out and mosaic style ceilings and walls the only salient feature. If around the area worth popping in but don't make a special trip. The artisan centre close by also very busy with objects more easily bought in the souks.
Gorgeous palace. Bargain for £1, small palace which you can walk round at your own pace or have guided tour, architecture is so different to that in Europe

Beautiful Mozaic details. As we enter the palace, I was mesmerised by the beautiful mosaic details. The whole building was decorated very beautifully. The conditions of the building was maintained very well. I love it.. a place one must visit when in Marrakech.

Wonderful example of Islamic construction. This is a wonderful photo stop. The entire place is intricately decorated and just seems to go on and on. Very much enjoyed my visit and would highly recommend.
palace. very good visit for photos, beautiful ceiling and tiling and carving - only 10 dirhams entry fee - great value

Beautiful rooms and grounds... see it!. The palace was built at the 19th century by Si Moussa, grand vizier of the sultan and was name after one of his wives. We loved our time at the Bahia Palace. The admission was only 10 dirhams per adult, and all of our children were free. The rooms and garden were beautiful and it was a lovely way to spend a couple of hours wondering around the grounds, admiring the architecture and surroundings. It is located in the south of Marrakesh, approximately twenty minutes from Jemaa el Fna.

It was ok. Though the palace itself is beautiful you can't see very much. It is interesting but I wouldn't make this a special stopping place unless you're already there. Perhaps best to stick to the other lesser known palaces to see more of the rooms, history, etc.

Great architecture. Well worth a visit and only 10 dirham to enter. Reminded us a bit of the Alcázar Palace in Seville. Beautifully decorative mosaic tiles and a nice calming escape from the Medina, lots of courtyards and fountains. Does not take long to explore around but worth popping in and then afterwards visiting the "Mellah" (Jewish quarters).

nice design. lovely to see the internal architecture and arabic design
inner courtyard worth spending a little longer
can be seen in a hour without rushing

Nice architectural deco and pretty garden inside. This is a true Moroccan palace with lots of tilework inside and completely intact. Beautiful rooms with gorgeous ceilings and a lush garden inside. You wouldn't believe that such a beauty existed within the tight walls and streets of the Medina! Well worth a visit and cheap entrance fee!

A glimpse of a former grandeur. While this palace is lacking furniture it does give you a glimpse of what it would have been like. Some lovely design and artwork is left and it's well kept. Worth visiting and easy to find. Maybe they should recreate one room so you could see what a majestic palace this once was.

Not much beyond the gates. Small palace, amazing ceilings. Small entry fee and worth a look. Expect 30 mins to be enough to walk around and see everything. There are lots of tourists in a small area which makes it feel a bit more uncomfortable and cramped. Good photo opportunities and it is worth going inside and seeing some of old Marrakech .

A bit disappointing!. Historically we were aware that the palace had stripped of most of its decorations by various invaders. It was however an interesting experience especially if you have seen the Alhambra in Spain and anything in Central Asia or India.
Beautiful place. Very interesting to visit this huge place, to imagine what it must have been like in former times when it was filled with hundreds of people living and working there.
Okay. The Bahia Palace is nice, but for the well-traveled, it was a bit of a disappointment. It doesn't compare to the Alhambra.

Beautiful architecture. An excellent place to visit for a quiet hour away from the chaos of the souks. Go with a guide to get the full story - we did it as part of a morning walking tour which also included the souks, the synagogue and the Saadian Tombs (also well worth the visit). The architecture and decor reminded me of the Alhambra in Granada and although its not very old it is a masterpiece of craftsmanship. Go early if possible to avoid the tour groups.

Stunning. One of my favourite places in Marrakech, loved the approach to the palace through the garden. Beautiful decorations and mosaic work in the palace itself, everywhere you look is a photo opportunity.
Interesting architecture. Interesting architecture. It is really nice to visit and see the old palace! Especially coming from a totally different culture.

Am I missing something ?. It costs 10 D to go in. It's cheap I must say.But room is totally bare. No furniture and fixture in room. One Get to see the great art work in the ceilings and beams though among the many rooms or so.It's not a very big place.When I google, there is this picture of a very big courtyard which i don't think I came across. Am I missing anything ?
Worth a look. Definately worth a look and good for photos. You don't need a guide just get the free app from marrakech riad travel plus - also there is an amazing Hamam near by.

Bahia Palace. This was a very interesting place to see. What we noticed in Marrakech is that outside in the streets it is very very busy and all of ones senses are engaged but you walk into this palace and it is all tranquility. Lovely decoration and tiles. Beautiful interior.

Beauty. A lovely building, mind blowing detail in every nook and cranny, well worth a visit. The surrounding Jewish quarter is also worth the visit, people here more friendly, nobody asking to pay for directions and the market is less crowded with no pressure to buy

Nice attraction. A palace that has seen better days and not the most well maintained. The lights that lit up the ceilings were mostly not functioning. Nevertheless, the artistry of the work on the ceilings and walls definitely worth looking at.

the best touristic attraction in Marrakech. I think this is the best touristic attraction in Marrakech, very nice and big palace and the architecture is amazing! and the best, it's very cheap! 10dhr per person, super cool!!! it was low season and it was marvelous because we had the palace almost all for ourselves.
Ok. Considering that from the name the palace should be totally awesome, it was a bit of an underwhelming experience. Although it is pretty and quite quiet Amidst the hustle in the medina..:-)

Empty, Haunting, Beautiful. We visited in December with three children and an adult. The palace itself is empty, but the architecture and wall decor make it almost like visiting an art museum. There are some explanatory signs in French and Arabic, so if you speak/read either language you can get some information about the palace.Entrance is very inexpensive - less than two dollars per person - and it wasn't very crowded at all when we visited on a weekday morning. My children loved walking through the palace - we walked through some areas more than once. Because the tour of the palace isn't as structured as other places outside Morocco, the kids were able to spend more time and get closer to the things they found most interesting. Also - cats. Cats everywhere. We like cats, so this wasn't a problem. But just to have it on the record, so many cats.

19th Century Palace. For Morocco this is a fairly recent monument worth seeing. It is walking distance from Jamaa el Fna (Marrakesh main attraction) and it shows the architecture of nobleman's home interior. It is a great place to immerse yourself into the Moorish culture.

Breathtaking!. Amazing Moroccan art in a nutshell! All the breathtaking patterns, decorative tiles, carved wood decorations, wall paintings, indoor fountains etc in one place. If you're a fan of architecture and interior design Bahia Palace is a must-see. It's also in a nice area, and a good value - entrance only 10 dihrams. Great place to take amazing pictures and some nice selfies :)
One more palace. If you've seen one palace, no need to go here too. Considering the low entrance fees (10 MAD per adult), it doesn't hurt to step inside either if you're passing by...
Attractive. It deserves a visit to observe the luxurious life style of rich people in the past. It costs 10 Dirhams to visit.
Must see. This is a must see in Marrakech. Beautiful architecture and art. Beautiful peaceful garden between the entrance and the palace.

Worth an hour of your day. I think it's worth checking out. It's inexpensive at 5/person (or maybe 10, I can't remember). The palace is old and abandoned. It's very 'okay,' but it doesn't take long to view and it's cheap. I would recommend going if you have the time.
Colourful and wonderful visit. The entrance fee is less than 1 euro, and really worth it.Beautiful, colourful and very interesting place to visit.

Interesting insight into Moroccan life and history. At 10 dirhams it is a low cost opportunity to look at the kind of environment that rich Marrakech's lived in in the past. The detail is superb and has been well-protected over the years.

Not so old as you could believe. The palace made in late 1800 looks two hundred years older if you look the decoration and paintings and wood carvings. Worth to visit, but you must be a cat lover - there are cats everywhere!

Hidden gem. Highlight of our trip. Absolutely beautiful. Peaceful haven in the middle of the busy city. We wandered in by accident and spent a happy hour wandering round and taking photos. Well worth the short walk from the main square.

Okay, but forgettable. I really didn't remember that I went to this place until I returned home and looked at my pictures. A nice enough place, an oasis in a really crowded part of town, and full of moorish architecture for sure, but you are in Morocco and you are going to have the opportunity to see 100 of these types of places. If you have the time and are really into Moorish architecture, there is no reason not to go, but if you have to leave it off your itinerary, don't despair. Like me, you probably won't remember that you were here until you see your photos.
Nice place to visit. It is nice place worth visit but don't expect much it has been built in the 18 century and refelect the morrocon style of building and architecture

Loved this place. If you like morrocan archetecture - courtyards with fountains, gorgeous rooms with morrocan glazed tiles and the like - well this is for you.The entry was a bit haphazzard - some chap in a small portacabin (sure some people don't notice and just wander in). There is a row of modern gates - standing unused along the entrance pathway.The palace is a seriese of rooms and courtyards - all gorgeous. We made the mistake of visiting mid afternoon when it was busy which does get in the way of getting nice photographs - but it was neverltheless worth it. Along with the Merdressa in the Medina this was our favourite attraction in Marrakesh.
Bit disappointed. I thought this would be better than it was. It's a shame because if it had more money spent on it, it could be really nice. It is just the building, no furniture inside it.

Beautiful architecture. Must see for architecture and history buffs. This very quiet palace is located within the city walls. The tourist map is not very specific and the souk is a maze in which it is easy to get lost. Asking for directions may get you lead into a shop to buy something, so ask a police officer or student for assistance in finding the building if possible.

Be sure to go early. This was an impressive place to visit but be sure to go early or you will not be able to move around easily or absorb the atmosphere. If you visit any National Trust properties in the UK then the rooms have furniture which gives you some idea of perspective and I think that the authorities should consider doing this.

Beautiful floors and tiling. Not like any palace I'm used to, there are no furniture left so you walk around the grounds and insides. The tiling is still in place and is the most attrative part of the palace. There are no tours or english expalnations available so unless you have an idea of what to expect, it can be a bit of a let down. Also, when you walk in the gates, there is a little hut, this is where you are supposed to pay. If you don't realise this (and how could you, there are no signs) and walk past, a man comes running out, shouting.

Fascinating Place. Oh to be a princess this place is lovely,showing you how they used to live, the bathing pools and how the rooms were layed out, took some really good photos of the storks on the roof
A must see. So much so interesting - I love the mad busy medina streets and peeling off in to something quiet and peaceful.

Beautiful palace. I think that with anything involving history and architecture...such as this palace, you get out of it as much as you put into it. You will always have a much more rewarding experience if you go through these type of places with a guide. Our guide gave us quite a detailed explanation of the history of the palace, when it was built, how long it took to build it, when it went into disrepair, how it is being refurbished, and what it's present use is. Then he let us wander around on our own and take pictures. Also, keep in mind that not all of the palace is open to the public. The inner court had the retractable ceiling closed the day we were there. That made it much more dramatic upon entering as there was a HUGE brass lamp fixture hanging from the middle of the retractable roof. You can go down various hallways, seeing where the kitchen and other facilities were located. One little corridor led us to a spectacular find. This was the corridor that took us to the three room hamam. In the very back room was a man doing calligraphy in Arabic. For a very minimal fee...I think it was $14 durham but can't remember anymore, he would do your name in Arabic and in calligraphy style. There were also some paintings for sale along the walls of the haman, one of which I purchased. It reminded me of buying a Berber carpet while I was in Fez. The paintings themselves are unique as the frames are also painted and decorated to match the actual piece of art.

Visit only if you have spare time. This palace was so-so... quite small and unimpressive from the outside. Once you get inside it's interesting enough, and quite a pleasant place actually, but the rooms are quite small and all look the same after a while. It's nice but I wouldn't go out of my way to return.

not much to see. All the rooms looked more or less the same and it wasnt partucularly interesting. No guides sayin what was the purpose of each room or how they would have been used.
Not really worth a visit.

Nice place but not so much to see. Bahia palace is nice place outside the busy center around Djemaa el Fna. But there is not so much to see, the palace is small. But why not to come there
You can see some of my photo of this place here: http://hikemyworld.com/2014/12/07/osamela-cesta-marokem-cirkus-marrakes/
Interesting. This is an interesting palace our guide explained it's use in past times do not expect our kind of palaces it has no statues or fancy pictures if you have a guide he will explain.
Pas mal. A little anticlimactic but still beautiful. It's basically just a lake inside a concrete walkway. Didn't want to pay to go in.
palais bahia. one of the most remarkable monuments of Marrakech Bahia Palace with its 150 rooms has been offered by the sultan to the favorite
Boring. Nothing there except tiled floors and painted ceilings, no information or anything, best bit was the price 10DH.

Absolutely gorgeous. This palace is really beautiful and romantic.
It's amazing to see the palace rooms and its gardens.
A maze of colours.A must see.

back in time. this palace takes you back in the history . i was told that it tooks 3 years to be built with three handred workers and one painter who use to cover inches daily insteat of feet . i like the carved sailing which are painted in natural colors otherwise they would not resist all this time . i would like to recommend this site for those who want to know about the mixt archetecture . I enjoy the visit .

Another beautiful riad. We visited with the Thomson tour guide. He told us everything about it. It was a great place. . Another beautiful riad. We visited with the Thomson tour guide. He told us everything about it. It was a great place.
Nothing special to see. Just walls of old "palace". Went inside and got outside for 10 minutes. Not expensive but not much to see.
Architectural Gem!!. Tour guide explained all the various ways it was built and why, stunning Craftsmanship, which can still be seen performed in the area..

Beautiful architecture in Bahia Palace. Loved exploring the stunning rooms and courtyards of Bahia Palace. Only 10 Dirhams to get in, lots to see and admire. Stunning architecture, lovely gardens outside. For more details see my review my blog http://selimfamily.com/2014/12/01/bahia-palace-morocco-travels/
palace. Located in an interesting location - we walked but get a cab if you are unsure. Well kept and stunning photography opportunities. Great value for money, well advised to visit.
below the ground gardens. first visit was rather disappointing in 2011 but this year more parts are open. I like th way they use historic sights for art exhibitions

Exquisite detail in gorgeous architecture. What an incredible place to visit! The amount of exquisite detail still vibrant and visible in this centuries old palace in truly astonishing.Our small group of 10 had a guide for the day and he was well worth the money, given his knowledge and skill at sharing the history of the palace along with side stories about the harem section and the wives - fascinating!Plan at least a couple of hours to really tour the rooms slowly, and savor the skill of such beautiful artists - from ceiling to walls, down to incredible details on the floors, as well as doors and arches, so much of the spaces are utilized to showcase incredible geometric art from artisans hundreds of years ago with amazing textures and compositions filled with visual beauty. Truly inspiring.If you are an art, architecture or history lover, this is definitely a must see location, gorgeous!

Beautiful Building, Poorly maintained. The Bahia Palace is a beautiful palace however it is poorly maintained and falling into disrepair. The building is in poor shape and hasnt been restored since I first visited five years ago. Little to no signage so bring a tour book!
It was closed for repairs . Unfortunately we did not know it was closed the week we were there. Got to walk around it and see the stalks, but was disappointed that it was closed.

Part of the palace was closed for repairs. The palace had lovely ceilings and the architecture was beautiful. It would have been nice to see some period furnishings as all the rooms were empty The gardens and some of the rooms were closed due to repairs unfortunateley they did not tell us this before we went in, so it was a bit of a disappointment not to see it all.

nice palace. This is THE palace to see in marrakech for history. it is worth going with a guide to get the full story. if you dont have a tour guide or dont want to pay for one, look for a big group and tag along. this is what a few people did with our tour group and we didnt mind and nor did the tour guide (or so it seemed). only with the stories does the place come to life otherwise it is just a walk around a nice building.
Beautiful and serene palace. This a beautiful and serene place on the south side of the Medina near the Kasbah well worth a visit
Another hidden gem. only 100 Dirham and a hidden treasure. Lovely original doors and ceilings to gaze and wonder at right in the heart of the medina

Empty Palace with ornate architectural details. As a person that likes to understand history and culture of a place this was somewhere I wanted to go more than my wife.On arrival we realized we needed 10dh each to enter ( less than £1/$1.50). There is a walk way up to the palace which is littered with what I think are stray cats. Fine if you like cats but I thought I had entered a cattery instead of a palace at first.When we finally arrived at the palace all the writing explaining history on the wall was either Arabic or French so I couldn't learn anything about the history or culture so had to make do with being fascinated with the architecture which is definitely something I admired.The whole site has very nice vistas and new thresholds and the use of courtyards and light throughout the site is also admirable architecturally speaking. The fountains in the courtyards are not turned on which was a shame as that would have been quite soothing and added to the experience. Really, other than the fact it used to be a working a palace it wasn't interesting enough for English-only speaking tourists to gather more understanding of the culture and history which was quite disappointing.The whole site was visited in less than 25 minutes but for £1.00 you can't really complain too much. A pretty palace but ideally you need an english speaking guide to explain things otherwise its just a pretty place to tick off your list and say 'seen it'.

Don't miss the ceilings. The painted wooden ceilings are splendid and the tiling on the floors and some of the walls is interesting but unlike most western palaces there is no furniture and hence little feel for what it would have been like to live there.

EXQUISITE SCENT OF ORANGE BLOSSOM. A haven to be taken in allowing the time it deserves and best enjoyed when not jostling for space with hordes of noisy tourists. There is much to see and delight in but not when pushed and shoved and cameras clicking all round. Worse still the tour bus teams. A small site so pressure for space affects the experience.

Beautiful to photograph. Serene palace near the medina with wonderful Moorish architecture. Don't forget to look up at the ceilings. The riad was closed for rennovations when we were there in November 2014 - I believe this was the highlight - will just have to go back!

Very very interesting. Wonderful mosaic rooms and little courtyard gardens. Everything is ornate including the wooden ceilings - painted and carved. You pass through room after room and are quite stunned by the overal effect.
Beautiful place. The palace is a beautiful example of the exquisite moroccan architecture. It's worth going with a guide so that they can tell you a bit of the history and the story of Bahia.

Coule do better.. Interesting but lucky we had our own (excellent guide) - could do with more info in writing. A few English interpretation boards would be good, or perhaps a short pamphlet with the (10 MD, £1) entrance ticket.
Bahia. magnificent inner courtyard with beautiful architecture and design. impressive were all these tiny little rooms, where the students had to live
Architectural wonder. . Very pretty, with beautiful ceilings, plaster work and garden. Not a lot to see, maybe an hour at most, but at 10Dh to enter it is worthwhile.

Lovely oasis to visit, superb architecture and history. Really beautiful inside. Go there before the bus tours or after them to have the place to yourself. Definitely worth a visit. Plenty of restaurants nearby to have lunch/dinner after. Some interesting shops too

An absolute must.... ....beautiful palace in the south of the medina, close to the Mellah, the former Jewish quarters. Exquisite Magreb architecture and are. A must if you stay in Marrakech, even if all tourists do it.

Beautiful architecture. Well worth a visit in fact ! Forget about shopping and the hardship of cruising the souks for a while and get there ! Around, some very exciting local markets and street life ! Inside, beautiful architecture and peaceful feeling (we were lucky to get there before massive groups of tourists in shorts !). Early mornings are possibly better, especially when the weather is good !

Best of all Marrakesh sites. Well preserved and it is certainly a good representation of Marrakesh history and style. Decorative tiles and wall carvings are beautiful. You will see art students sketching the details of the palace sitting in the corners of the courtyard. My top Marrakesh pick.
An expensive fun night out. A bit "touristy" and expensive (around 400+ dinas per head). Nevertheless an experience in lovely surroundings with a floor show.
beautiful. a Beautiful Palace with wonderful Mosaics on walls and celings(same as the Royal tombs). a really quiet Place. why not bring lunch.
Visited on a rainy day.... Visited on a rainy day... not the best idea as it's all open. But it was worth a look and is quite beautiful really, even for ruins.

Worth a visit.... visited this after the Saadian Tombs and before the Madersa Ben Youssef ( with our guide, Moustapha). Again only 10Dh each to visit - a steal. Beautiful palace in the middle of restoration, but still gives a good idea of life in such a place ( the main wife's apartment, those for the other 3 wives and concubines etc) beautiful craftsmanship still evident and trying to be r created and preserved. Well worth a visit ( with either a guide or someone who can give background)

Not what it could be. Beautiful architecture but not exhibited to it's full potential. There were not signs or explanations so you literally are just wondering around looking at a pretty but empty shell of a building.

Worth seeing. Only 10 dirhams per person, about 1 euro, so very cheap. Not any descriptions of the areas within the palace, so we may have benefited from a guide. Still, with or without a guide it's great to see it, with the colourful Moroccan tiled floors, and stunning wooden ceilings. Only a small section of this palace is open to the public, so without a guide you could loop around the area in about 20 minutes or less. (Also the other palace, the Badi, is so close, which we only realised after so you could do both in a short amount of time).

A bit of history. I visited this palace with friends as part of a tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable and explained the historical significance of each area of the palace - and gave us a short history of Morocco - as we walked round. It's beautifully maintained.

Easy to find, just follow groups. At 10 dirham each this was cheap. There is only one way round, follow the arrows. There are some gardens, but not a lot in the way of description or furniture, so it seems a bit plain. Maybe if we had had a guide it would have been better.

Best museum in town, great value, shame the main courtyard is closed for renovations. This is so much better to see than the Madrasa nearby. good mosaics, good woodwork and if you google the history it tells you what you need to know. Display cards in french only which allows local guides to pick up business! main courtyard closed until next year for renovations which is a shame as it is the biggest bit! Nothing to tell you of this fact. nonetheless still worth the visit and best value by far.

Another wonder :-). If you enjoy the history of a place you visit, then visit this palace. It truly gives you an idea of the culture & history of Marrakesh. I do wish they had some rooms made up with furniture & mannequins dressed in the local clothes of that century, just to add to it all.
Beautiful but no signs in english. Definitely worth to see because it's beautifulness. It only cost 10 dh to enter, but I missed som signs in english that could tell you a bit about the palace.
Beautiful place. Our guide took us here. Gloriously nice place which should not be missed.Much more interesting than I expected. Great place for photos
Wonderful due to our guide. We had a guide who took us and explained the history of this wonderful palace. The architecture was amazing and it was very helpful having a guide who took us through.

Beautiful Palace and very cheap ticket.. I really enjoyed looking around this palace and could not believe that it was only about 75p to look around.The architecture is astounding, with the mosiacs especially beautiful. Worth seeing Badia Palace at the same time as it is about 5 mins away and is a complete contrast. There are also some lovely roof top terraces and a fixed price market in the area.
a worthy piece of culture. intersting history, architechture and decore. read about its background before the visit itself. take your time to strol between the yards and halls.
Very nice palace. The inside is a very nice building with magnificent walls, floors, ceilings, woodwork, riad,…a must visit when you are in Marrakech.
WORTH A VISIT. This is a interesting place and worth a visit. Beautiful rooms full of mosiacs and engraved wood. Would have been helpful to have had a guide leaflet so we knew more about the place
Another Mudejar palace. Very pretty palace with lots of lovely rooms and fantastic examples of Mudejar decoration. Well worth a visit.
Lovely site. This is worth visiting....beautiful site and wonderful architecture. Take a moment for sure to come here!
Do not miss!. Stunning, every room had wow factor. Essential viewing, not too crowded. Don't bother with a guide, just ask the security guards, they will answer your questions.

A must see in the Southern Medina. Built over 150 years ago by the then Grand Vizier, the Bahia Palace offers a great opportunity to see Moroccan architecture at it's best. The palace includes a number of riads (enclosed courtyard gardens) and fantastic examples of painted wooden ceilings and doors, carved stucco, and stained glass windows. Well worth a visit if you are touring the Southern Medina.

Fascinating palace. Really enjoyed all the beautiful carving and decorations that are all over the palace, as well as sitting in the shady courtyards full of greenery and fountains. Busy, but still a welcome change from the bustle of the city.

The perfect palace. This is a palace to go with a
Guide who can tall
You the story of the
grand
Vizier who built it and to see the
Ornate painted wooden ceilings. Highly recommend. When I was
There in mid October, the wens area (harem) was unfortunately closed for reconstruction which would have been even more interesting.

comparable to the Alhambra but without the crowds.. The Moorish architecture is beautiful and one does not have to
stand in line to see this palace.
The areas set aside for the family are quiet and private. It took
500 workers 14 years to complete.

This is a must. Beautiful place and so cheap to visit. Loved everything about this palace, amazing mosaic tiling examples in every room and the ceilings get more ornate as you progress throughout the palace.
worth a visit. we loved the relative calm here and the painting and mosaic work was stunning! Not the easiest of places to find, but for the 10MDM entry, more than worth it!

Strictly average. Mot much to see. Some nice architecture but nothing beyond it but there's not much else to do in Marrakesh so chances are you will end up going here even after reading this review! :) But iff you are short on time, you would won't miss much by avoiding it.
Boo Bahia. Dodged all the thieving conmen to find our way here but it was shut!! Thanks a bunch!! Wednesday 29th October! and it was only 1:30pm
Best with a tour. Easy to wander through and a bargain, but take a guidebook or a tour to get the most out of the experience.

So many people.. Beautiful building, but do not go in the middle of the day! I imagine if you go early or late you will enjoy it, but contending with the hordes from the bus tours was not my idea of a good time.

Beautiful architecture and ornate carvings. Well worth a visit although very busy. The ornate marble, plaster and wood carvings are a highlight of the visit. Finished with beautiful tiled walls and floors. You could easily spend 1/2 day at the palace without noticing the time going by. Multi0lingual guides are on hand if you wish to walk around with them. Entry price was 10 Dyrham per adult (approx 95p). Superb value for money.
So beautiful. Ornate ceilings and a beautiful courtyard, two of the things Morocco does best. Highly recommend a visit.

simple. Probably this used to be a very beautifull palace, but now nobody seems to care about the place. There is no furniture, all rooms are bare, lovely ceilings but that's all there is to see. >very hard to imagine what the place used to be like.A pity.
Beautiful. The artistry is evident in this palace. You could almost get a feel of what it would be like to live there even without any furnishings. Very tranquil and opulent.

Surprisingly busy beautiful palace building of empty rooms. its only 10 mdh entry fee and it's lovely decorated rooms in either traditional Berber ( flowery) or Islamic decoration. The harem rooms are probably the best. Lots of tour guide groups. Reasonable loos, always good. About 10 mins or more walk from the main square if you can cross the dangerous roads in one piece. A guided tour is ideal but you must take your guide with you.

Very atmospheric - and lots of storks !. This was a really nice historic site which wasn't as busy as many others. It's also quite big so it didn't feel crowded. We were amazed to see dozens of storks flying around and ten coming in to land on their nests. There was an iinteresting gallery of leading modern photographers with some really interesting and famous pictures e.g the famous one of Chrisitne Keeler on a chair from the 1960s. Quite strange to find it here.
Beautiful!. Loved the decorations on the walks, doors and ceilings and at only 10 mad entrance, it was worth every penny.

Nice little visit. Worth a walk around. Be prepared for Groups of people walking around with Guides, so taking photo's can be a problem if you do not want throngs of people in them. Just be patient. On the corner of a very busy road junction. Worth standing there for a while and just watching and being amazed
Don't miss. I went to almost all the medersa and palaces and mosques in morocco. This is by far the most impressive one to see in all the cities. Don't miss out!!!!

Stunning. The workmanship in the decoration is extraordinary, a 10 minute walk from the square and good to combine with a visit to El Badi Palace and The Saadian Tombs. All very cheap admission prices.
Beautiful mosaics. Worth a visit, beautiful mosaics and very tranquil. We didn't hire a guide and just enjoyed wandering around by ourselves.

Good without being outstanding. In the heart of the old medina and a welcome break from the crowds. Some interesting architectural points and decoration which perhaps did not grip quite as much as they should because of the relatively poor quality of the particular guide - a rare occurrence. Good if you could break away, as we did and do your own thing and meet up with the group at the allotted time by the giant fig tree
Interesting Place. Beautiful building in typical Moroccan style.Pity there wasn't any furniture there just to set it off but worth a visit.

Bahia Palace. The Palace is presently under restoration works, partial visit of the site is possible (Oct. 2014). If you are not in a guided visit, to fully understand the Palace you need to have previous knowledge about the plaster, tile and wood used technique. You need to to have as well understanding how was life in the palace that the purpose of each room. It is indeed not to be missed.

Good but similar to other places. We enjoyed Bahia Palace and for the Dh10 entry fee it's definitely worth it. However, if you have seen the medersa and the Museum of Marrakech then it is pretty similar.
Absolutely stunning. The palace was gorgeous. The architectural details outstanding. This place is very much worth a visit. Schedule at least an hour to just stand and admire the details.

Grand Palace. This palace lies in the heart of the old medina. It is nice to gently stroll around the palace, you can get plenty of photo opportunities, there were lots of other tourists in the place but because it is quite a large site, it never felt over crowded.

Lovely buildings. Cheap to go in and the buildings are beautiful. Small gardens on entrance to a series of courtyards and rooms with fantastic tiling and carvings. Must've been incredible in it's day.
Can't go wrong for less than a quid!!!!

Nice little ex palace and gardens. Had a private tour that stopped here; took some different doorways and routes to avoid the onslaught of tourists; very nice if small palace and gardens worth a stop, but not a highlight. Try to see first thing in the am before the marching hordes descend.

International significance in more than one way.. This is a wonderful place and if you are an experienced traveller there are important aspects to consider. the Roman and Florentine renaissance palaces would not exist without the inspiration from such middle eastern influences as this.
Truly amazing. A sanctuary from the noise of Marrakech which leaves you wondering what it must have looked like in its heyday

Hidden gem. The long walkway through its grounds to the entry gives no idea of the inside artisan work, though pillaged of it's luxurious chattels, back in antiquity, what remains is really awe-inspiring. As with many Marrakech sights, it closes at lunchtime for a few hours, but as with all such sights, just ignore the "locals" that say it's closed- they only want to guide you to their cousins adjacent rip-off shop
Amazing palace. A very well maintained palace for those who like beautiful zellij and marvelous carved wooden ceilings. A "Must see" in marrakech and quite easy to find.
Sultan life. Decoration, history, imagination of past centuries life here. Understand lot more about Marocco histrory and artDisliked: empty, no furniture

Amazing!. Better than the Alhambra. The craft and workmanship is out of this world, and even though it has been stripped of it's former glory, it is still possible to imagine what it would have been like in its heyday

Fabulous hidden gem. This palace is huge, and although not mush to look at from the outside is fascinating to wander around. Only a small part is open to the public, and it's truly beautiful despite being looted many times in the past.

Beautiful and Tranquil. You are in the middle of Marrakesh madness and find such a beautiful palace. Gardens leading to the palace are also lovely. The mosaic and wood carving and colours are so vibrant and typical of Marrakesh. Wonderful piece of history
Impressive Islamic architecture but with a faded elegance. A popular place to visit. Try & avoid the crowds by arriving early or late in the day. Look up to admire the ceilings.
Highly recommend visiting this place.. Amazing place-took so many phoitographs-we were exhausted and so didn't do this place justice-another trip needed.

Interesting palace. This was my first trip to africa, so i really enjoyed this visit and admiring the architecture.
It's a small compound, but really pretty. I think if you travel for culture, this is a interesting thing to see.

Beautiful architecture. Not much to look at from the outside. Situated on a busy corner to the south of the square.
It's only when you enter the building that you see the splendour. Keep looking up. The great details are in the ceilings.
This is also a very busy place to visit so don't expect a tranquil environment.

You need a guide. It's a hard call we walked around it and it's beautiful architecture is all over but without a guide it's just walls. The guide will run you $100 and explain why there are just random rooms all over that are just off the main area. Is it worth $10 per person plus $100 for the guide not at all. So your call.
interesting architecture. Very inexpenisve trip - walkable from main square. Great architecture and nice cool places to sit. Combine with other nearby palace

Interesting palace. This brings the history of the place alive. A guide is a good idea to get the best out of the visit. It is best to go early before the crowds and before the heat of the day sets in.

Worth A Visit. You ned to walk a short distance to this one through the old Medina, but interesting. The palace is empty, which spoils it a bit, but the architecture is stunning, with very intricate plaster work and mosaics.

Everything you would expect in a Moroccan Palace. The detail in the wood work, the ceilings, the doorways, all perfection! Very pretty to walk through.
This is a must see attraction in Marrakech. Fee is 10dh.
Amazing. Don't miss it! Situated in the South Medina and in between Badi Palace and Saidi Tombs it is full of History and wonderful architecture!
beautiful. so much history and the decorations are fantastic no two roofs are decorated the same , a must to see when in Marrakech
Interesting place to visit.. Good place to visit, nice ceiling/floor decorations to see. Beautiful courtyard and garden. Would recommend to visit.

Lovely little palace. You really can't go wrong with this one. The ceilings probably stand out for their gorgeous decoration. A bit like looking up at an elaborate carpet! But the whole understanding of how an important person's household worked is quite special.
A beauiful building. This imposing 16th century ruined palace is well worth a visit. The site is impressive, the views over the town excellent, and there are nesting storks
nice immersion. We really enjoyed the visit and spent about 1h30 at the Palace. It's really helpful to get a feeling of the foundation of the Arabic culture and architecture. Strongly recommend it.
Part of Guided Tour. We went as part of a guided tour which was very interesting but would have liked to spend longer there. Very busy with other tourists as well but beautiful none the less.

Nothing surprising. We were told that if the King was in residence we could not visit but this palace is actually for the Prime Minister, who was not in residence. It is interesting and beautiful but no more than many other attractions in Morocco. Worth a short visit.
Beauty Moroccan Style. If you are an artist or designer or even if you just simply enjoy architectrue and visual arts, you must visit Bahia Palace! Must be seen place!

Amazing architecture. This palace was built at the end of the 19th century and used by the French during their occupation. Currently the harem is being renovated so won't be open for a least another 6 months but the rest of the palace is a must see place. There are marble paved courtyards, one with cypress Orange trees, banana trees and jasmine as well as pools. There are cedar wood ceilings painted in arabesques, beautiful tiles on the floors and finely decorated fireplaces. The craftsmanship is excellent.
Very Romantic. It is a nice place to go and have your romantic dreams..especiall a walk inside the court yard, the floor looked amazing...
Interesting. Well worth a visit. Lovely grounds. Typical Moroccan architecture. Very interesting history. The interiors are all different and very beautiful. Well worth a visit.

Interesting 19th Century palace. The Bahia Palace is well worth a visit if you want to get a sense of how an eminent Moroccan personage would have lived in the 19th Century. The ceilings and architectural features suggest someone trying to show off, though I was a little surprised that decor was so undifferentiated from room to room. There are no explanatory signs in English, so best to read up on it beforehand. And it's very cheap at 10 Dirham per person.
Very Good!. The Bahia palace is a place of beauty and like a mini labyrinth of beautiful rooms which are all individually decorated

Read the background!. This is a lovely palace with an interesting story which you will have to read from your guidebook or on the internet. All the signboards are in French and there was no information in English during my visit. Many guidebooks say it closes at lunchtime but the staff told me it is open all day. It does not feature in many books' Top Ten but it should.

A grand palace. The architecture and mosaics are delightful and the painting of doors, windows and ceilings have been tastefully restored. It is a pleasure to walk through the many unfurnished rooms and glimpse at mirrors reflecting the gardens.

fantastic to see!. I love culture and found the palace very interesting. the mosaics, the painted walls and doors, it's impressing. Quite big building with a fantastic inner garden - the riad - which is very luxurious.
Great. Nice palace with beautiful green garden close to the Medina, a nice place to relax for an hour or two

The place to see in Marrakech. Entrance fee is cheap, 10 dirham per person , will take you around 1 to 2 hours to see it properly. This is the most beautiful building in Marrakech. Attention to the very small details and mosaics. If you like to take great pictures , stay behind the crowds and you'll get a chance to take amazing shots !
Quiet, but nothing special.. It's cheap and a nice little walk around. Cost for it is low and you can take some nice photographs.

Interesting place. Remember to take water as it can be hot and there are no facilities inside! Also a challenge to find it without a good map! Visit the KosyBar next door for drinks and Tapas afterwards...

For Photography fans. If you are in the Jemaa el Fna square, you should take a short walk to the Bahia Palace. It´s a must if you love Moorish architecture or photography fan. You will be able to take beautiful pictures and the tile work and wood carvings are amazing. At a 10 dirham entrance fee, it´s a good bet. Recommend a visit.

Beautiful place but obviously full of tourist. This is classic Moroccan architecture, beautiful spaces, and then you see a woman in the smallest shorts and a tank top leaning against a 19th century marble fountain and practicing selfies. It is worth the visit because is truly amazing but when yo visit an attraction do it with respect

Quite underwhelming. My wife and me visited this site in September 2014 as it was near our riad and was recommended. Costing only 10dh expectations should be low. The buildings are very beautiful but very sparse, no visual information or guides to explain. Maybe worth spending an hour of your time if you're passing by but I'd definitely not recommend going out of your way to visit this.
Interesting. We paid for a guide, which without you would have seen pretty things and know nothing about the History.

An empty Harem. The place has beautiful Islamic detailing in the mosaics, ceilings and millwork. Sadly all the information is in French and the rooms are all empty so you can only imagine what life was like when it was occupied.
Unexpected delight. This was a real treat and rather unexpected. The beautiful mosaics and carvings are worth seeing and the courtyards and delightfully quiet, cool and peaceful.
Magical Palace. Wonderful Moroccan traditional tiling everywhere and beautiful ceilings, some pretty ceiling lamps and fireplaces, too.
An attraction in Marrakech not to be missed. Loved the architecture and detail in the harems.Astonishing rooms we learned that the palace was built for an adviser to the ruler. Built in 1890
Well worth a visit. A beautiful museum with exquisite Moroccan architecture. Beautiful reception rooms with ceilings that are a work of art. I would not miss this!
Not much of a sight. Okay if you want to kill 30mins, but otherwise not much to see here...If you are interested in Mosaic-tiled ceilings then perhaps may be worthwhile.

La Pompadour de Marrakech. It's all about "luxury, calm and lust" Baudelaire would say...Even though the place i suited for a visit, as a museum it needs some improvement. Then again, and speaking against the tourist's wish, some more care ought to be given to the wooden structure and paintings that are displayed since too much human presence are going to take its toll on them. Besides this fact, this place is a very beautiful palace to see because it tells us a lot about the past and mores in Marrakech.

Worth a visit. Entry is cheap. The gardens are not much, but the unfurnished palace has some nice features. Very little information in English, so read up a bit first. It got a bit crowded, but you can relax and stay as long as you want without being hassled.

Average..... This is an old palace in the Medina. It's only 10MAD to get in so you are not spending a lot to see it. That being said, it is okay to see but you will only need 20 minutes here, I think. It took longer for us to find it than we spent there. It is nice to see if you haven't seen any old palaces before but again, it's only 10MAD so you are not investing a lot....
Interesting site. Our guide was very knowledgeable about the palace so the story of it was interesting. I would recommend it as a place of interest.
Really Enjoyed. Great seeing Moroccan traditional finery and architecture. It was lovely and cool and a very interesting history. Worth visiting to see all the amazing ceilings and carvings.
Not much to see. it was okay but not grand like we expected, fairly smallish and not much to see inside. For the price it was okay.

Plain. went here expecting to see something like the Monaco palace but was just an empty building with mirrors, nothing fancy at all, no tour guides or anything you just walk in and walk out, i love history and exploring but this was definitely not my kind of thing.

Bahia = The very pretty lady. This place will take you to another time dimension.. looking up to the roofs of the palace.. the exceptional architect.. imagining the beautiful lady who used to live there..

Vezyr palace. It is not a sultans palace - but in minor scala has all the attributes.
Very cheap as it costs only 10 dirhams ( 0,90 euro ).

Serene, intricate, cooling. Another nice relaxing place to spend 1-2hours out of the sun. Even though there were quite a few tourists around it still felt calm and relaxing wandering around the rooms. The ceilings are amazingly intricate with colourful patterns.
I was not expecting much given the cheap 10DH entry price but came away feeling glad I had visited this place.

Cultural, beautiful and a welcome break from the heat!. Stumbled upon this place while searching for the older palace (El Badi) in the similar area (also well worth a visit, both only 10 drm entry fee)! Gardens are lovely and well maintained, the building is well kept with stunning mosaics, ceilings and fountains. We pottered around here unguided and thoroughly enjoyed it, there are tours at certain times of the day but obviously groups tend to be large and you move around at the guides pace.Toilets are clean and well maintained but, of course, make sure you have some small change to use these!

Beautiful!. Spent a couple of hours visiting this beautiful building.10 dirhams entrance fee. Must admit I wasn't expecting much and was very pleasantly surprised. Lovely and calm inside. Fabulous architecture and mosaics - took loads of photos!

nice for visit. The Bahia Palace is a palace and a set of gardens located in Marrakesh, Morocco. It was built in the late 19th century, it mixture of the beautiful gardens with mosaic flooring under your feet.it nice place to walk & see in Marrakech.mosaic work very good.
Stunning. Simply stunning the mixture of the beautiful gardens with mosaic flooring below your feet then the intricate wooden ceilings and arches make the Bahir palace a must see.

Loved it!. This was a great place to visit. We wandered in from the Jmaa El Fnaa but if you can get dropped of by the Bab Agnou (sp?) gate- it is easier to find. My husband and I enjoyed taking some memorable pictures here and looking at the intricate woodwork and painting. Great to visit in the heat of the late afternoon to cool down for a bit.

Nice for a wander. Beautiful workmanship. This was right by our hostel, or we may have completely missed out on it. We didn't take a tour, so missed out a bit on the history of the place. But the mosaic work definitely made up for it. Make sure you look at the ceilings.

Beautiful palace in the Arabic style. This palace is truly exceptional in the beauty of its decoration. As you move from room to room the complexity of the decorations increases until you become overawed. It's also cooler than the streets outside and very peaceful, even when crowded like it was on our visit. Also it's a bargain - only 10 Dirhams. Well worth a visit Just up the road there's a square (Place des Ferblantiers) where you can get a drink and a bit to eat, and watch metal workers making ducts and other useful stuff from razor sharp metal with their bare hands.

Not that special. Some nice intricate decor for sure but I wasn't exactly blown away by a bunch of empty rooms that all look the same. Worth a visit if you're at a loose end as it only costs 10dirhams entry. But otherwise go do something else!

Pretty Palace, nice to wander around in. The mosaic work is somewhat mind-blowing and it's fascinating to walk around the intricate layout of this palace, the history of it is interesting as well. Definitely worth the visit, oh and make sure you take a tour or get someone to tell you the history otherwise you will be missing out.

Stunning Moroccan architecture. We visited here as part of a package tour of the capital, and we were not disappointed. We had a lovely local guide show us around a small part of this lovely building (as large parts of it are still undergoing restoration and not open to the public). But believe me it does not detract from the experience. The work that must have gone into the decoration of those rooms and the quality of that workmanship was amazing. Thoroughly enjoyed the visit and would recommend.

Right out of the 1001 Nights. For classic Islamic and Moroccan architecture and design, this is really it. Terrific places for photos and imagining the days of the sultans, vizirs, concubines, and sundry characters who epitomized Marrakech's ruling class over the past centuries.

Peaceful hour or two. On one of our walks with no purpose we found ourselves at the entrance to the Palace and thought, why not. Entrance fee was very reasonable and the place was a quiet haven in the middle of the day.The number of cats who seemed quite content would suggest that the staff must be good humans.As we prefer to go our own way, we did not hire a guide and we don't think we lost out. The colours were fantastic and the maze of rooms quite interesting.A must see for anyone travelling to Marrakech.
beautiful. its much larger than it looks with many stunningly designed rooms that inspire the mind. it was quite busy and hot when i visited and that was december, but still well worth a visit

Peaceful. A spacious and open palace ruins which were very peaceful, although i wouldn't recommend visiting during the day as it was REALLY hot! Great views from the terrace too, and for 10dh it was worth it

Most of Bahia is still under renovation. During our visit in Aug 2014, most of Bahia was under renovation and has been for a while. Instead, explore the berber market and the Mellah (old Jewish quarter) next door.
Beautiful. I visited the palace since it was very close to the riad we stayed. It's very beautiful but smaller than I expected. I expected something like Alhambra palace.

Great architecture .. but a limited little zone to visit. No doubt , that I enjoyed the visit of this palace , and I enjoyed so much the fabulous architecture , the ceiilling made of perfumed and coloreful wood , and the wall decorated with the beautiful colored mosaique , I was really astonished by the colors and the architecturebut the zone to visit is limited and so little in size that you can end your visit with guidance in only 20 minutes .. but it worth to be visited ..

Oasis. I really enjoyed this palace. Big contrast to the nearby stark Badi palace, but I liked them both. Bahia had a lovely cool courtyard that I relaxed in to escape the July heat. Very ornate tile and woodwork.

Empty and enigmatic. The ruins leave much to the imagination and the thoughts of how this palace was used boggled my mind, especially the labyrinthine chambers underground used for prisoners.Great storks, their beak clapping resonated around the stone walls and was highly evocative.Good view across the rooftops back to the Katoubia mosque and minaret.The photo museum was an unexpected delight too. Enjoyed the exhibition of photographs by the incredibly talented DonMcCullin, humbling actually.

Gorgeous!. Take your time visit this jewel of 19th century Moroccan architecture! You need to look everywhere: floor, ceilings and walls. It's absolutely stunning, and the internal courtyards, so typical of Marrakesh, are a peaceful repose after the Medina and the Souks. Do not miss!

Great example of Moroccan style. I visited the place without a guide, and I was amazed by the decorations, I could look at them forever just to notice more details. Probably I would have enjoyed it even more if there had been a few panels to explain about the history of the place, or the style, but one can find this kind of info on the internet beforehand, if one's interested in it.

Ornate wooden ceilings. Most of the ceilings are made wooden with intricate paint work, most floors r tiled, most palaces in morocco follow a simpler theme and this is no different. For 1 Euro you can gain entry and probably need about 1 hr to see everything. Their were some guided tours but we didn't join them just took our time and strolled around if u r in the area it's worth a visit and it is quite cooler in the palace than outside. There is a lovely little garden walk from the entrance and of course the ever present cats and kittens.
A Tribute to a Time Gone By. The idea of concubines and eunuchs is hard to comprehend. Wonderful history. And, the architecture and artistry make this a worthwhile visit.

Much of the same Moroccan tiling seen in other sites. The Bahia Palace is just a short walk from the Djemaa el-Fna, but you can get a petit taxi direct from your hotel if you'd prefer to keep out of the sun. The road is accessible and the cab should drop you straight outside. After paying the DH10 MAD entry fee you'll walk through the delightful gardens and enter the palace itself. A nice central courtyard awaits and there are lots of corridors to explore throughout the building. This should take you no more than thirty minutes to analyse and the visit may be a little too dull for some. Having been to Marrakech four times already, I left feeling that the Bahia Palace was 'nothing special', and that I had seen much of the same decoration and layout in other museums and buildings. Go if you have some time to kill, but I wouldn't advise people to venture out especially. If you're looking at the (more impressive) El Badi Palace, this is just three minutes away so see them both in a morning, then head down to the Djemaa el-Fna for a drink and some gelato.
Nice building and courtyard. I was staying in a Riad close by and it didn't take long to get here. It's not as nice as the Badii palace but still worth visiting

A real tribute to Moroccan architecture & style. During our visit to Marrakech, my wife and I visited the Bahia Palace.
