I must say that I never grew tired of the amazing buildings and gardens throughout Morocco. The gardens and the buildings which comprised the Bahia Palace were breathtaking. Every aspect of the buildings, from the wood work of the windows to the ceilings structures, the mosaic tiles throughout the palace and the gorgeous lanterns were magnificent. The wood doors and stained glass windows were particularly impressive. These grounds have obviously been maintained over time and reflect the pride of Moroccans in their historical sites. Just walking through the courtyard compels your eyes to be drawn to so many architectural elements of the Palace. The various windows, particularly the stained glass windows, are something to see on a sunny day!This palace dates back to the late 19th century and was built to be one of the most impressive palaces of its time. I am sure that any occupant would have been quite pleased to wake up and walk around any part of these grounds. It appears that all of the rooms lead to the courtyard and would have lots of sun. The gardens are lush and lend a lovely fragrance to the Bahia Palace grounds.This is a nice site to take a leisurely stroll through and soak up the atmosphere.

Traditional food. We came here an evening for dinner. The restaurant is primarily frequented by locals - the more wealthy ones. We had traditional food (tajin) and it was good, but we did not get this "whau"-feeling we have got at other places - even at restaurants with lower "status"
Bahia Palace. A lovely old palace - go for the architecture and the gardens. Most of he furniture has been removed.

Go. Go and spend some time in the palace. It is nice, cheap entrance - 1 euro, and very good place for photos. It is a bit hard to find at first, as there are no signs to point to it. Just before entrance, you have a lot of nice places to buy food, drinks, postcards, fruits ...
Not much to see. It is the ruins of a palace with a lot of stork nests...and the photo museum inside...if it's a hot day...there is very little shade...and very little info on the ruins...

Choose Palais Bahia over Palais Badi. This is a lovely introduction to ancient Moroccan design located in the heart of the old city and most photogenic. It also offers shade and a green inner sanctum courtyard for respite and to rest your weary travelling bones. If it's quiet you are lucky - countdown to the next stream of coach tourists. It just proves you have arrived at a "must do" destination. While the Palais Badi's name is similar it is completely different and not to be confused. Badi features massive expanses of dust and half demolished stone walls for you to imagine the life of 1300-1400s. With the 40 degree heat and not enough shade for an ant - it will not spoil your holiday to miss this substantial, though uninspiring ancient building remnant.
Worth a visit. At 10dh entrance fee, this is well worth a visit. Well preserved example of early Moroccan architecture. Lots of shade so great to get out of the heat!
Stunning. Well worth a visit if you are interested in seeing a classic Moroccan palace. Very cheap to get in, and some good photo opportunities inside.
Islamic artwork interiors. Lovely interiors to this palace, very inexpensive entry good photo opportunities. Very pleasant. Worth a visit
a good place. full of history and beautiful. Went on a trip, the guide was excellent. Just very hot in the day to stand around

Great value. If you've already done the Jemma el Fna you don't need to do this one too, unless you're in love with Moorish architecture or a photography nut. if you're on a budget and trying to decide between them, so the Bahia Palace, nearly just as good and you can't beat the 10 dirham entrance fee!

Underwhelming. This palace was disappointing and boring without the help of a guide. It is a somewhat pale version of Seville's alcazar. It should take 30 minutes maximum to see the palace. It is something to do in Marrakech.
stunning place!. The palace has some really interesting architecture and colours, which is great for photography. Worth visiting.

Beautiful place. I was so happy to have visited this landmark. I got to take some beautiful pictures. The tile work and wood carvings are exquisite. A lot to see just outside the palace as well, the Medina is a short walk.
beautiful must see. Stunningly beautiful gardens and mosaics - a must see and a calm oasis from the hussle and bustle of the souks and markets

Do this with a guide. You'll love it if you do this with a guide who will explain what all the rooms were for. That brought it to life for us. Amazing ceilings. Loved that the favourite wife had the best room

beautiful moroccan architecture. Palace is very nice. Beautiful architecture. Labyrinth of rooms around central courtyards. Great for exploration. It`s not very easy to find entrance. Be aware of people in the close vicinity telling you that the palace is closed at the moment for an hour or two, and trying to lure you to shops in jewish quarter while the palace is supposedly closed. We run into couple of these people. And of course they were all lying, palace was open all day without a brake. So take good map from your hotel and do not listen to people on the street. It`s just 15 minutes walk from Jemaa el Fnaa square. Take Rue Riad Zitoun El Kedim. At the end of the street is a little square. Take left before it and follow the street for about 150 meters. Then you`ll find the gate to this beautiful place.

Worth a trip . At just 10 dirham we popped in for a wander about 40 mins before close. It is an interesting story and the storks are a bizarre addition to this ruin. There was also a fabulous photo exhibition by an English war photographer on at the time we went. Would love to see this place during the film festival.

Stunning. We found this Palace, more by luck than judgement. The signs for the attractions are not good. The entrance is just a door in a wall and is only 10 dirhams to get in (about 80p), but it is stunning. The Palace is arranged around a central courtyard, and there are rooms with elaborately decorated wooden ceilings, beatiful stone carvings and tilework. It is not huge, and was named after the King's favourite wife. Well worth a visit!

Worth a visit. Entry costs 10dh (70p), so there's really no reason not to go and see this beautiful example of Moroccan architecture and escape from the heat of the day. The ornate decorations and careful layout, plus the history of this palace are really something to behold. Information is only in French and Arabic, which was fine for me as a French-speaker, but might not be for everyone!
Worth a Visit. A short walk from the main square but very calm and pleasant experience. Really good to see and a nice refuge from the speed and noise going on nearby.
Beautiful. Wonderful courtyards with orange trees growing in them. Great rooms, plenty to see and very cooling place in the heat of the mid day sun. recommended.

Beautiful Bahia. This is another must-see in Marrakech, with wonderful tiling, tiling, archways and painted wooden ceilings. Try and go early in the day or late in the afternoon to avoid the throngs of tourists and their rather loud guides getting in the way of all the pretty things...A cool place to go on a hot day, at 10 dirhams (about 70p!) it's a bargain.

Minor attraction. Unless you have seen no arabian palace before it's not really worth the visit. Still it's a nice little palace in a garden but i've seen it all before. It's not a primary attraction, even not a secundary.

So much to see in this well preserved palace. The Bahia was one of two palaces we visited close to our riad, the other being the El Badi - they are very different from one another but the sheer opulence of the surroundings at the Bahia, the beautifully decorated rooms, ornate ceilings, peaceful garden courtyard and stained glass windows ultimately sets it apart.This is a good value excursion too - like all of the historic sights we visited, entry was cheap and with so much to see, it was money well spent.

FANTASTIC ARABIAN ARCHITECTURE. After visiting quite a few fantastic palaces , mansions and hotels in Marrokkoyou get used to the fantastic wooden handwork and paintwork.But be assured- you dont get that blazee that you dont get utterly impressed here.It is absolutely worth a visit.

Sumptuous decor. Only a small part of the Palace and gardens are open to the public but those few places you can see are wondrous!The rather plan archway (with a modern street lamp stuck on it!) doesn't give you much idea of what you are going to see but the walk up the drive past orange and lemon trees gives you a hint of what the gardens must look like.There are various courtyards all with pools and fountains (but all alas dry on the day I visited!) which are lovely but the rooms are quite outstanding. Although empty of furniture and drapes, the marble floors and tiled walls are wonderful but as you look up, the carved, painted and gilded ceiling decorations and plasterwork are sumptuous.Don't forget to look at the heavy wooden doors with their carved and painted decorations. One can only guess at the intrigues that went on in these rooms and the harem when the palace was in its heyday!Once again, no information on any of the rooms is available so you have no idea what they were used for, so hire a guide if you can who can hopefully bring the Palace to life.
Beautiful. Must have been quite stunning in its day. The mosaics are quite something. Very beautiful and a very nice view from the roof.

worth a visit. We came here as part of an organised Thomsons 'Historic Marrakech' trip, but it is easy enough to visit yourself. A guide is worthwhile to bring it to life however, as there are no furniture or furnishings inside.

Beautiful. Quiet , peaceful , lovely original morrocan designs , and architecture. Pretty gardens with tortoises and cats everywhere Nice and cool to visit on very hot days , good to have a guide to explain the purpose of the palace and it's rooms
beautiful place. Lovely place to visit. beautiful caligraphy. Truly delightful place. The ceramic works are just wonderful with the Moroccan bright colours
The scale is impressive. Not a great amount to absorb but worth seeing. Must be fabulous backdrop for concerts and so on. Inexpensive to enter.
Astonishingly calm even in midday. Brilliant building, interesting history, beautifully kept. A world wonder. And surprisingly calm even in the heat of the day.
Nice Architectural Features. There are nice architectural features in this former palace, but it is just a shell of what was once a glorious place.
Paleis al Bahia. I liked it, because for me it was one of the smallest pallaces i've seen. But I have seen more beautifull ones in Marokko.

Not worth going out of your way for. Although this was a fairly interesting a cheap (10 DH each) excursion, it didn't fill much more than half an hour, and with no furniture and poor lighting, unfortunately you're simply left with some beautiful but empty/hollow rooms. If you're passing by, it's worth a look, but no more.

Just okay. It would be nice to have descriptions next to all the rooms. Also, we believe some of parts are in renovations that we didn't have a chance to visit the whole place. So it only took around 15 mins for pictures.
it was interesting. rather crowded. therefore it was difficult to take good photos. As matter fact it should have been good place to make memorial photos.

Massive former 19th Century Palace fantastic Stucco work.. An array of Stucco plasterwork, carved wooden arches and zellij tiling. Built 1895 and occupied by former PM and his 4 wifes. Admission 20DH. WC inside main courtyard. You need 1 or 2 hours in here as there are so many rooms, passageways and courtyards to see. The art work is fantastic. Take a camera and water. Dress conservatively. It's hard to find so take a public taxi and agree a price before hand. there's plenty of taxi around outside after.
nice place, but lacked something. This is a lovely interesting palace with a nice garden area and interesting decoration. A nice place to relax and take photos away from marrakech chaos.
Nice site to visit. I'll keep this short and sweet. It's a nice place to visit, if you have and few days in Marrakesh then pop in It's well maintained and doesn't cost too much

Really lovely! . Don't know how, but we spent ages here. Fascinating place. Lots of informative plaques but would have been better with a guide but for ?1 each was fantastic. Great views over the area and just very peaceful. Worth a trip of your in the area.

GO!. Even though the Palace is crowded with other tourists and the guides are talking over each one (actually, you can listen to what other guides are saying to learn more about the rooms!) but you want to see this beautiful building. There is little to show how the people actually lived but the architecture is beautiful. Make sure to look up at the ceilings.
not a lot to see, but nice walk through. Mostly just decorative wooden ceilings - theres no furniture or anything else except a central atrium of orange trees.

Who would build one of these as a present?. Wow! Just imagine your other half building you this wonderful place (especially considering he might be splitting himself into 12 or 20 when it comes to other halves)!Princess Madina was given this beautiful place, especially built for her because she have her significant other his first son - though granted that was important in this country!Architecture is stunning and unique, and the location gives tourists a test from all the hustle and bustle for a time.Shame that the place isn't all open to the public though really worth a visit
Beautiful building. One of the more beautiful examples of Islamic decoration we visited. Definitely worth a 1 hour visit to feast your eyes.

Stunning work all around. The palace is one of the few places that you should not miss while in Marrakech. Even though under restoration, the place is well worth a visit. Each room is different and bright with beautiful works. It was made with the intention of a building finest in all of the country and rightfully so. The place is not good with information so you either have to depend on the guide books or a proper guide along with you to experience the place.
Step back in time. This is a beautiful place, yes, it can be crowded but if you step back and let the tour groups pass you will find moments where you may be completely alone. Enjoy!
beautifull palace. really worth to visit it, the must of the medina with the medersa ben yousseflovely arabic architecture and beautifull garden with lots of fruits behind the honor court

A smaller version of the Alhambra. This is undergoing restoration so only part of it is open to visit. Well worth it though, with beautiful tiles and cool rooms due to its clever design. It was built by the "Moors" after they left Spain in the 15th century so is very similar.We went with a guide which I would recommend as he was very knowledgeable and there was not much information on display.

Peaceful and beautiful. A lovely little hideaway round the corner from the souks which can get very stressful so this is a great little place to cool down, have a sit and take in the beautiful mosaics and stucco.

Beautifully stunning. gorgeous! every room in the palace is paradoxically uniform yet distinctive. The palace is incredible to look at, rich in history and soaked in grandeur, a well worth attraction to visit!

Nice Palace, it needs to be restored!!. actually, The royal Bahia Palace was built to impress. also, It was intended to be the finest building in the world, and took a legion of master craftsmen shipped in from Fez 15 years to complete. It consists of 160 rooms, each one of which is decorated to the highest degree in marble tadelakt plaster, zellige terracotta tiles and polished cedar ceilings - all examples of the best in Moroccan interior design. I read that Morocco has some of the finest craftsmen in the world, but that nothing ever gets finished unless the King himself turns up to watch over them. Here you can see what happens when the greatest craftsmen complete their work on a massive scale.

Gorgeous Mosaics and courtyard garden. The Bahia Palace is quite stunning.. a jewel of white painted buildings smothered in beautiful colourful mosaic tiles and fabulously painted wooden ceilings and carved stone. The Courtyard garden was lovely with its orange trees and cool shade. A welcome break from the searing heat of the city. You do need to purchase the guide book though as there is not much in the way of information on display in English. A must see on a trip to Marrakech.
Really nice. Good opportunity to see more about Moroccan art and architecture. Really well kept, and one of the cheapest landmarks to visit.
Beautiful space. Well worth a visit..... spacious, airy, beautiful tiles and mosaics, many hidden corners to discover.
Stunning architecture. Definitely worth a see if you're in the Medina. It's a beautiful palace, with lovely gardens and really intricate stone carvings.
Potentially very lovely. ... but marred by lack of upkeep and large tourist groups. Amazing painted ceilings though - keep looking up!
Quiet. If you want to rest a bit from the noise and mayhem of Medina, visit the Bahia Palace, which right in the middle of Medina. Excellent place to relax, listen to the birds and visit the palace.

Great to visit - read why 5 stars!. OK. if you see everyone is marking this as 4 stars. When I review I take into consideration everything I have seen. WHY? because you are in Morocco, and I am not comparing it to things I have seen somewhere else. My guide was amazing and knew so much explained the significance of everything from the door shapes to colors, etc. This place if you are in Morocco go and visit, read a head or get a guide for the day. The history is amazing and compared to other things I saw in my trip, this was one of the more awesome things to see.Notes: A lot of graves and architecture is all you will see this is why reading is a must. Very small, but in your trip is a must.

"Magnificient" is No Exaggeration. 19 acres, 150 rooms - 14 years to build. While only a small portion of this palace is open to the public, what was viewable was incredible. The zelij-covered walls, massive (walk-in)fireplaces, lush garden courtyards, ornate fountains and the intricately carved wooden doorways are all works of art. And to think that what I saw (what is open to the public) was the harem! Hopefully someday more of this grand palace will be open to the public.
Nice. There is not a lot to see but the architecture is beautiful. The details in the building are vey unique.

Good to see. The palace with all its beauty was built with for Princess Bahia the wife of the king that gave him his first boy, very impressive Arabesque style courtyards and rooms, summer and winter!
Worth a visit.. Cool and beautiful architecture - unlike Palace Badia! well worth a visit. Atmospheric and stunning tiles.

Beautiful architecture. This palace has a beautiful architecture. Floors, walls, ceilings, mostly in a very detailed carvings and structure that made one certainly appreciated the beauty.
The palace is packed with tourists and groups but it certainly worth a visit.

A beautiful palace. This is a beautiful Morroccan palace, amazing architecture, floors and ceilings. There are lots of tourist tours with their guides, and we just followed one with an English speaking guide, which was very interesting, if you would like to learn about the context of the place and its culture and history.

Stunning Architecture. The architecture of this palace is absolutely beautiful. Every wall, floor, and ceiling in every room is decorated with different elements of traditional architecture and is definitely worth a visit, even if you aren't a fan of art.

lovely palace. This is a lovely place to visit whilst in Marrakech. Its easy to find, dont get mixed up with El Badii Palace, like I did! The architecture, tiling and ceiling paintings are amazing. Definitely worth a visit.

Classic Moroccan art. Lots of beautiful tilework and carved stone doorway, lintels, etc. Don’t forget to look up—the ceilings are magnificent. It’s best to come early if you can, though, because it can get crowded.

Amazing architecture. The ceilings and mouldings throughout this delightful palace are simply beautiful. Try to have a tour to get the most out of your time there, to learn the history and workmanship behind the sights.
crowded. A beautiful place which passed in a blur, due to being endlessly jostled by tourists and tourguides. Suggest going early morning to avoid this. Worth a look.
Lovely tranquil palace. Really like this place - only 10 dirham entry. Its not very big but beautiful courtyards, ceilings, carving and doorways. Well worth the visit.
Nice place to visit. It's one of the biggest palaces in Marrakech. It has no furnitures just rooms. But it's worth visiting considering the price is only 10 DH

Fascinating. Took this in as part of a city tour and found it fascinating.Our guide was superb and extremely knowledgable and informative.This place looks nothing from the outside but is lovely once your`re inside.R.ecommened

Quiet Palace next to Jemma el Fna. its a good little palace next to Jemma el fna.
Nothing much to see there but the carvings on walls and ceilings are nice. Cheap entry fee, think it was something like 10 dirhams per person

Worth an hour. Steeped with history but only a small amount of ruins left.
There was an excellent photographic exhibition, mainly war photographs in one of the rooms.
It was easy to imagine what a magnificent palace this must have been

Could be so much more. While seriously renovated, most of the rooms in the Palace are empty. Surely they could be filled with period piece furnishings which would explain how the rooms in the palace harem were used and decorated :) Once you have admired the ceilings and tile work, there is not much else to see. A modern art exhibit is set up in one of the rooms.

Pretty building, but not a lot to see. The building, or the part we could access during our visit was empty of furniture etc. The building is pretty but without a guide we really just waltzed through and back out again.

Unbelievable tile work. The tile work at the palace was beautiful along with the painted ceilings. It did not take long to visit the entire palace which was nice. The 10 Dh cost was a bargain for the craftmanship you saw. A definite must see while in Marrakech. Plus it was very easy to find.

The most breathtaking ceilings I've seen. Bahia was my favourite monument in Marrakech. It's unmissable. Many buildings, from Marrakech to Granada, have great examples of moorish architecture, but I've never seen so many amazing ceilings. It was good enough for me to go back again.
Traditional riad. Large riad with amazing decorations on the ceilings.We went there during a hot day, and we didn't feel the heat inside the riad. To be seen once...

beautiful and well preserved. one of the most amazing palace to visit in Marrakech. It deserve to have a local guide with you to explain not just the history of the palace but also all the meanings of the asthonishing decorations

Interesting Palace.. The Bahia Palace gave a good understanding of the why of life within the Moroccan Palace. Since majority of the palaces only allow the tourist to see from the exterior, the sight of the palace almost always of the entrance and part of the wall. Bahia Palace was refreshing for our sight from within the walls. For photographer, the contrast and internal lighting as well as narrow hallways created many opportunity for great photo shots.

Empty rooms that are falling apart. It's only ten DM to get in and if you are in the area be warned that it looks as though no one has done any work on it to keep it up in the past two hundred years so it is worn down and dirty. Without and furnishings all you see are empty rooms that have the remains of what I'm sure was at one time a very beautiful residence. The palace was not impressive at all.

Worth a visit. Only 10 Dirhams for this visit but, you have to find it first, and the locals are not all that helpful, wanting to lead you into their shops first. The surrounding area is full of fairly aggressive shopkeepers but they give up if you remain firm. If you take the hop-on/hop-off bus tour, get off at stop 14.

Nice well preserved palace.. It was very easy to imagine what it would have been like to live there in it's heyday as it is so well preserved and thankfully because we got there when it opened, we missed the crowds.
intersting. great view of the stalksoasis in the citynothing really in english which is a shameworth a look...........................

My highlight of Marrakech. From visiting Marrakech I soon realized that I enjoy peace and quiet, so perhaps it is it no surprise that Bahia Palace was my highlight. Go in the morning before the hoards of tourists come in! However, I also realized on my trip like I love Moroccan architecture and design, and this palace was no exception. The details of the ceilings were mesmerizing and the beautifully tiled floors. A must see whilst in Marrakech. Also if you like this, see Saadian Tombs!

Loved it. Bright, light, great mosaics great wooden panelsYou can really imagine the people having lived here and the information about the history of the Palace is worth stopping to readThe good sunny weather is a great help when sitting outside amongst the fruit trees

Worth the 10dh entry! Don't forget to look up. Beautiful ceilings!. Went here early afternoon and there was no line to get in and it was not too busy inside. Beautiful courtyards and traditional tild and woodwork. Some of the most amazing history can be found in the hand carved and painted ceilings. Beautiful, must see sight in Marrakech. Possible to see Saadian Tombs, Bahia Palace, and El Badi all in the same afternoon.

It's ok. For the entry fee; it was fine but I wouldn't say it was special. The tiling is nice but it would have been far more interesting if there were a few signs giving you the history or rooms set up as they would have been - we did tag along with a tour for one room and it was ok. Worth a visit if you're doing a few things in that neighbourhood.
New palace. For the price you pay 10 Dirham less than a pound well worth visiting,All the information was written in French,.Palais El Badi was Better look for the storks nesting on the walls.
Typical Moroccan architecture. Doesn't take long to visit, but very pretty. Don't miss the nearby square with all the metal working shops : nice buys :-)
Amazing gardens!. One of Marrakech's must-see sights! Beautiful tiles and designs throughout the palace. The gardens are beautiful, a great place to view Moroccan design.
ruins of an old palace. If you are interested in old architecture, visit this for ruins of the old Bahia Palace. If ruins aren't your thing, you could give it a miss.
beautiful. beautiful carvings and sculpture as lace, beautiful green-covered courtyard with fountain, very worth it

Most impressive place for me in Marrakech. Great architecture, and lots of rooms to explore! The Bahia palace usually isn't on a top 5 guidebook list, but for me it was surprisingly a very interesting place to visit. Great architecture, wooden ceilings, and courtyards.

Average tourist attraction. The palace was just around the corner from the riad we stayed in. It was 10Dh entry fee and was quite busy. It is a nice palace but all the empty rooms were very similar. Garden was small but nice with plenty of cats. If a cat lover good idea to bring some cat biscuits to feed the beautiful kittens. For the low entry price worth a visit.

Very busy and worth a short visit. This is one of the prime sites in Marrakech and so gets very busy.The architecture and decoration are wonderful, don't forget to look up.Like most historic sites in Marrakech the rooms are empty so you don't get the feeling of how they would have been used by their occupants.
Hidden Gem. The entrance gave no indication of what a stunning palace was inside. Beautiful place great craftsmanship, beautiful colours. Really super. 10 dirham entrance fee.

honest chaps. This is quite a small palace, costs only 10 MAD to get in. We sat down in the first salon to rest after the walk there. and as we made our way through to the interior my husband realised he'd left his camera on the seat. He beetled back so fast he was a sweating wreck when he got there to be met by two old boys who regarded him with huge amusement. One started fanning him with his little white fez, saying "don't worry, you left your camera, don't worry!" The other old bod said "you British?" to which we replied "yes" and he then shouted"British Airways" and fell about laughing! Eventually the camera was retrieved from a cupboard while our friend was still roaring with laughter about his British airways joke. A lovely moment for us all. And the rest of the palace is very pretty.

Unexpected gem. Visited here with no expectations and it was lovely. Very close to the centre, beautiful intricate décor and lovely cool space on a hot day. It could do with a bit of TLC and some better signposting, but if you're in Marrakech it's worth a visit- especially at only 73p to enter!
A must see!!. Such a beautiful palace!! Amazing detail on their artwork!!Wish we could see more furniture to see how they lived. I recommend this place and very easy to visit from the Medina.

Average attraction. This was nice to visit to cool off during hot days. It was a pretty average place to visit but as there isn't much to see or do in Marrakech itself I would still recommend it. There was some nice examples of moroccan tiling and interior decoration.
The most amazing and beautiful place. I loved this museum, the entry fee is cheap and it is well worth the visit, i was amazed, it is one of the most beautiful palaces i ever saw

Beautiful, tranquil place. Ornate doors, ceilings and walls. Very calm and beautiful spot away from the hustle and bustle. The rooms are empty but allow the imagination to fly with how this place must have been. Inexpensive and easy to visit.
Easter Visit. Beautiful Architecture and Design although the place was crowded with tour groups when we visited at 11:00 one morning. Despite this we enjoyed looking around the palace.

Semi worth it.. The price is 10 dirham (roughly 1 euro) per person. The palace is beautiful as the name implies. The work is detailed and wonderful to see. There are a bunch of different rooms and gardens and it was a nice break from the business of the city. Because the price is reasonable for what you see I think it was semi worth it to go. If you are interested in seeing different architecture and craftsmen work then it is a must. If you have time to kill and want a peaceful break from the city then the price is right.

Lovely architecture. An old palace displaying, Moroccan, Berber and Spanish architecture. The carving around the windows and doors is beautiful. The art on the ceilings is also beautiful. it can become quite crowded with tourists

Amazing artistry. In these old palaces you see some of the wonderful craftsmanship that makes Morocco special. Here are beautiful ceilings, decorated doors, hand made tiles, intricate plaster work & all types of fantastic decoration. For 10 dirham, well worth a visit.
Well worth a visit. Although quite dilapidated now, it still maintains all the charms and the islamic architural influences that you can wish to see.
empty. a nicely designed building in standard morrocan design esp nice ceilings but empty of furnishings so no insight in to lifestyle but cheap to enter

Beautiful. Very ornate traditional palace. Inexpensive trip (20 diram entry). The Palace Badi is also very close. This is a 16th Century Sultan's palace. It is, for the most part ruins but definitely worth a visit and also inexpensive (10 dirams for the palace or 20 dirams for palace plus mosque)
Good food on a pretty terrace. An attractive terrace overlooking the gardens and good traditional Moroccan food at a reasonable price
wow. Seeing is believing definitely worth a visit, amazing art work, don't forget to take your camera with you

underated beauty. Highly underrated in the tourist books. Beautiful architecture, great for an hour or so getaway at a bargain 10dh.
Avoid high noon, can become very overcrowded.

Nice and relaxing. Lovely old palace, with some awesome architecture,a very pleasant way to spend an hour or so away from the huslle and bustle (and heat) outside.
well worth a look,

Breathtakingly beautiful. The Palace is wonderful. Take the time to marvel at the stonework and the intricacy of the patterns, painted ceilings, and tile work. Truly a wonderful place - not to be missed!
Stunning palace. My mum and i visited this palace in March 2014. It is stunning! An extremely relaxing visit - beautiful tiles and courtyards. Great place to get out the heat of the sun

Mini-Alhambra. Bahia Palace is an easy to find and worthwhile stop in Marrakech. It is peaceful inside and cool. The architecture is (as always with the Arabs) gorgeous and the tile work is impressive. It reminded me of the Alhambra in Grenada, Spain although on a much much smaller scale. At 10 dhm, this is worth a stop.

Worth a visit. This wasn't in the top 10 in our guide book and we actually came across it by chance but so pleased we did because not only is it cheap to visit, it is also very lovely, particularly the ceilings. T think each wife was allowed to choose her own decor!
Wonderful ceilings, doors and arches. Lovely place, peaceful, lovely gardens and a very interesting building with some wonderful painting, tiles, plasterwork and stone. Well worth a visit.

Small haven. Bahia Palace is also not too far from the square. The term Palace is slightly misleading because it is quite an old building and not very big, but the mosaic roofs and doorways beautifully crafted out of wood make it good for a short visit, or a peaceful resting place if you have enough time
Wow, what architecture!. Really enjoyed our visit to Bahia, and spent a long time there soaking in the atmosphere. Would really recommend this to others.

Atmospheric and impressive. Bahia Palace has more to see than El Badi Palace. It has stunning tiling, mosaics and carvings. We enjoyed just wandering and soaking up the atmosphere...the ceilings in particular are beautiful. I think that an hour or two is enough time to spend here. It's not huge and there is no cafe. A must-see in Marrakech.

Beautiful. You can enter several rooms and stroll past a small section of beautiful garden as you enter. Well worth a visit to be amazed by the detail of the decoration. We got stiff necks from gazing at the ceilings. We did not have a guide but just enjoyed the atmosphere and wandering around admiring the stucco and decorated wood.

Marrakech Gem. One of the highlights of our holiday.
It was a welcome break from the hustle and bustle to find an oasis such as this.
Fantastic architecture and a great place to wander through. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful. As part of our tour of the city we looked around the Bahia Palace. Our guide gave us history of this Palace, however without a guide you won't really know what you are looking at as I did not see any descriptions of things explaining what each room was for etc. The palace itself is beautifully maintained and stunning to look at. Well worth a look and this little gem inside the city.

Impressive Palace in its day. Tour round palace gives an insight in Marrakesh's past wealth. Rooms, delicate wood carvings and wall sculpters remain but no furniture so a bit bare. Still entrance fee just a pound.
Restored 19th century palace. The architecture is quite lovely as are the mosaics and the stained glass window. Was fairly crowded with tourists and did not invite you to linger at all.

Interesting architecture. Not much in the way of guidance. If you didn't pay for a guide, then it's hard to figure out much. At least there was signage in the museum. Nonetheless, it's relatively inexpensive and a nice break.
Nice couple of hours. It was a lovey place to spend a couple of hours, away from the busy streets. 10dhm adult fee is really worth it. Spent some time just chilling on the cool courtyard.

Okay extra to day. Likes location History explained in detail nice information Size very large interesting storiesGardens pretty bigVery quick tour not time consuming Can still do a lot more in that dayLocation near shops
Interesting tile and painted wood designs. No furnishings, but ornate and varied tile and woodwork. Large place. No gardens save a small entry path.

A break from the busy souk. After getting lost in the souk and the medina for half a day, this was a welcoming break. Most beautiful mosaic and ceiling. Beautiful effect of the light on the tiles. I thought this is open until 6 PM but suppose it closes at 5, for I was driven away a little before five. I would have loved to stroll and enjoy a little longer.

Great place to relax and take pictures.... Only 10 dirhams to enter, less than a pound. The mosaics on the walls ceilings etc. are opulent and show the beauty and majesty of bygone days...Another easier to find place, well signposted and after the hustle and bustle of the souks, square and roads, this place is cool , calm and tranquil.It is a popular place and appears to be on the agenda of most city tours...Highly recommend....

If you are in love with details.... For those in love with architecture and the most little detail go to Bahia. you will apreciate the fine work done there especially on the ceilings and with the wood carvings.
Superb. A great deal of restoration is taking place at this Palace to restore it to its former glory Magnificent ceilings, plaster work.A must to visit.
Another peaceful retreat. Hidden behind a busy little square. Amazing to watch storks nesting atop the remnants of the building. Had art exhibition in the grounds.

courtyards and colours. For only 10 Dhs you can visit this lovely palace. It is not restored, but the colours of the paints and tiles are still vibrant. The shaded courtyard is surprisingly peaceful despite the tourists. Well worth a visit!

Rather disappointing. Although restored, this building was a bit of a disappointment and rather run down. There are some nice ceilings but it will not take long to get round. Worth a visit but don't expect too much.

Get a good tour guide or storyteller.. Bahia means Beautiful. It was built by a vizier for his four wives and tons of concubines in 19th century. It’s not an old palace, compares to the other old buildings in town. It seemed run down. Because when the vizier died, enemies and wives stripped the palace bare. Also, big part of this 150 room palace is under renovation and not open to the public.Still, it’s well worth visit. The garden and architecture is very beautiful, typical Moroccan style, courtyards and fountains, the wood carving, mosaics, painted ceiling... It was built by top artisans at the time.We had a very knowledgeable tour guide who told us the history and stories about this palace. We learned how to appreciate it even more!Only blind musicians could come in and performed in the palace, they don’t want the musicians to see how luxury the place is. Because most of the people are very poor outside of the palace. All the male servants are eunuch. It surprised me, ancient China, Egypt, India….all had eunuch. Did the emperors/pharaohs/kings communicate before? Or it’s just the cruelties of human nature?
Oasis of calm. It's a pleasure to walk round this old palace and think of times gone by when men and women did the same then as we do now !

Dar Si Said is better. Quite nice ceiling carvings/painting and mosaic work but you can see this, and a good collection of artefacts, just up the street at the Dar Si Said. Take a small pair of binoculars to get a better view of the ceilings.

Beautiful Palace for only 10dh. This palace was a great place to visit and is located right beside the Jewish quarter of the old Medina.The entrance fee was 10dh and it was well worth it. The gardens were relaxing and pretty but the interior of the palace was absolutely stunning. All of the architecture, tiles and paintings were beautiful. I would highly recommend visiting it!
Good Value. A pretty Palace, with some beautifully decorated interiors and calming gardens. Only 10 dh, so definitely worth popping into.
Beautiful.. We visited this yesterday. Very reasonable entrance fee. It was very beautiful inside and well worth a visit. It wasn't too busy either. It was a little bit like the Alhambra in Spain.

Modern mastery. It's easy to think that the best Islamic art dates from hundreds of years ago but the Bahia Palace shows that craftsmanship still existed at the highest level in the 19th century and probably still does today. A modest admission charge will open your eyes to some wonderful work.

A must see in Marrakech. This is an amazing palace of Ahmed Ibn Moussa that was built between 1894 and 1900. t was said that the Palace was built as a home for his concubines. They would certainly have had beautiful surroundings and ceilings. The architecture details are stunning. For 10 DH which is €1it is a bargain. Bring cameras as you will not want to stop taking pictures.

Better than the Guidebook suggests. Well worth visiting this is a large palace several rooms and courtyards --- the ceilings are spectacular. Not the easiest to find and unfortunately close to a spice shop where pressure selling is at its worst. We asked directions of a car park attendant who took us past the palace straight to the shop where the expectation was that we would spend lots. When that didn't happen we were asked for money. Obviously this is not exclusive to this palace but we did encounter a number of other people who had had a similar experience.,
splendid architecture. A well preserved example of the traditional architecture Can be a bit crowded with tourists but still a cool place in every sense of the word

nice relaxing walk. we visited here first thing in the morning, It was busy already and I imagine in the summer months it can be quite hectic. the palace is lovely and cool to walk around inside, there is no furniture on show just empty rooms with lovely tile work and fabulous ceilings. we did not hire a guide, we used our imagination to guess what each room was used for. small fee, literally a couple of pounds and only takes a short time to walk around - less than an hour.
Lovely architecture. A stunning building that from the outside doesn't look like much, but the workmanship on the inside takes your breath away.
Beautiful Place. If you like Moroccan architecture you will like Bahia Palace. It's one of the gems of Marrakech. There is a small entrance fee, but it's well worth it.

Nice palace. Ceilings and walls are stunning!! But I really wonder why they don 't protect the floors? A lot of them were already damaged.
Takes about a half hour to visit all the rooms and you don't need a guide.

Nice historic palace, not much on display except the interior architecture and garden, will take an hour max. There's a nice garden and beautiful architecture, but nothing grand or as memorable as palaces in other countries. There's no furnitures or interior decor whatsoever, what remained is just a shell of the beautifully constructed building and ground. Good that it's easy to get to inside he medina and takes at most a45 mins or an hour to tick the box.

A Thing of Beauty. A beautiful place to visit, reminiscent of some of southern Spain's Moorish architecture but with a more modern twist. The detail and craftsmanship are exquisite and an absolute feast for the eyes. You will want to take loads of photos! And all this for 10 dirhams - less than £1 entry fee. Don't miss it if you're in Marrakech.
Lots of tiles. Worth a visit . It was very cheap too...lovely place but can be very crowded. Courtyards and windows and fountains. Take a good guide book, don't book a tour

An almost overwhelming feast for the eye. We came with open minds, not really knowing what to expect. We were absolutely entranced by the beauty and intricacy of the plasterwork (stucco), the cedar wood carvings, the tiles, and the painted ceilings and doorways. We spent long periods in some of the less visited rooms sitting on the floor and gazing at the ceiling. The only problem is that there is such a feast for the eye that it can be hard to stop it roving to the next pattern or colour. We would both really like to visit this palace again, this time just focusing upon one or two rooms.
Beautiful Palace. Beautiful buildings and lovely to spend some time here away from the busyness and rush of the souks and traffic. Excellen value too and only a couple of pounds to get in

Beatiful Moroccan Architecture. Great for an hour or two visit. You won't see much as the palace is clear from furniture and art pieces. Its empty rooms and courtyards are full with orange trees. Nice to walk around and spend an hour in the morning or afternoon. Great for taking pictures with the shades.

Not the kind of palace you would expect!. It's of course true that in Africa the buildings are not made to last. You could perhaps expect that an exception would be made for palaces, but not here. Although you can sense that it used to be a special place, now it literally falls apart due to lack of maintenance. Sadly we left quickly to not to lose more time.
Stunning. The quality of tile work and decoration is excellent and the palace is vast enough to keep on surprising and impressing, without being so vast as to exhaust or to become repetitive.
Great architecture. Marvellous courtyards, tiles, plasterwork, woodwork, and a reassuring sense of enclosure. I wonder how much of an idea the historians have about the furnishings.

Good interior, but too crowded. Due to abundant people, I didn't spend long time here. The palace itself is empty. There are no furniture or other decoration. But it has many crafts on its walls and ceillings. It's OK to see when you're around the area.

Historical. Great hour and a half - get a guide to explain it all !
Lot's of interesting rooms and features, especially the wood work and the ceilings

Wonderfull Moroccan decor. The Bahia palace is an example of really beautiful Moroccan carving, tiling, plasterwork and design. Take time to look at the detail and you will really appreciate the craftsmanship.

Closed! But go and look at the storks.. Although the palace was closed to tourists when we arrived, it's worth a visit just to see the nesting storks on the battlements. Around the palace walls are nests which look like the workmanship of T-Rex. Storks abound. Get a drink at the Kosybar's roof terrace for the best views.
Faded glory. An old palace with an incredible history and some stunning carvings and ceilings . Sadly much of the original decorations and inlaid carvings were stripped out , but worth the tour

Great Value - Totally Worth a Visit. This is totally worth 10 dirham - not only to see the wonderful wood work, architecture, tile work, and decorated walls but also to escape the madness that is Marrakech. It's not nearly as impressive as the Alhambra in Spain, but for $1.00 you are crazy not to come. Fun to photograph. Expect to be there at least an hour. Enjoy it!
good site near Kasbah. It was well worth the visit for a one hour trip to see the architecture and cool down......................
Pretty place. A nice haven in the middle of madness. We went twice, once with a guide and the second time alone. There is plenty to see and all for a modest 10dirhmas (less than a pound).

Outstanding value for money. 10 dirham to get in whoop de do! Excellent for artists and photographers and well managed. Even the cats were friendlier and the tourist traffic was only unbearable due to a French tour guide at one doorway blocking anyone getting through.
beautiful. amazing value at 10 dirham/pers. beautiful state rooms with fantastic decoration on walls, ceilings, floors. a little busy but more than enough room to cope

Beautiful and well maintained. This palace reminded me of La Alhambra in Spain only on a much smaller scale. The palace is in excellent condition and has beautiful courtyards and intricate carvings and tile work. It's walking distance from the Medina and well worth the 20dh (2 euro) entrance fee. There are lovely gardens outside the palace but not much in the way of information so a guide book is helpful to understand what you are looking at.
Wonderful architecture. Beautiful décor and architecture. Loved it. It can become very busy though! Cheap entrance fee and an absolute must if you are visiting Marrakech.

Worth seeing. Even though we're a young group we do enjoy fully embracing the culture of a country whilst there. We decided to go to the palaces, it was something silly like 10 dirham, which is about 70/80p for entrance. The palace is very large and a good opportunity to take plenty of pictures. The whole thing can be done in about 30 minutes so don't arrange visiting this as your entire day out. It was worth seeing, very beautiful and we got some great pics.

lovely and peaceful. loved it .. the peaceful walk up to the palace and the intensity of detail inside .. loved it. Go early in the morning ... I went around 10am .. by about 10.30-11 it was getting a little congested.
roof top view. This dilapidated Palace still has a magic about it don't miss climbing up to the terrace and taking a look at the views across Marrakesh to the Atlas Mountains. Stunning

As a previous reviewer said "its a bit empty". to be honest if you are here for 3 days I would not bother. If you are here for longer and running out of things to do then the entry price is only 20MAD. The info board (such as it is) is in French and once you have seen one of these type of places you have pretty much seen them all.
exemple of an ancien riad. easy to visit, not far from the badii palace (with the large birds). The riad is empty, except some Fontains and trees.visit takes about half an hour to one hour.

Ornate and compact. You're just walking along in the medina and there's the Bahia Palace. It's unassuming on the outside, but beautiful on the inside. Archways, fountains, highly decorated rooms and hallways. I'd recommend seeing it, it won't take long.
Peaceful Paradise. The palace has some wonderful architectural features and totally isolates you from the noise and hustle-bustle of the city. Well worth a visit

Beautifully decorated rooms.. Cool and relaxing, wandering from room to room. The ceilings are amazing and the walls are covered in carvings as well as tiles. It is very close to the Jewish district, which is worth exploring.

a must see. Very quiet when we went in - worth a visit. The interior had beautifully painted ceilings, walls, & doors and stained glass windows in addition to the traditional tile and wood & plaster carvings. Entry charge was very little.
More of the same. Not sure if it is worth the visit. The big palace is not as beautiful, in terms of architecture, as other building in Marrakesh, such as the old school.
all for one fat greedy powerful man!. A wonderful glimpse of how the powerful lived, would have liked to see more furnishings, but he really lived it up

A late 19th century palace, stripped of furnishings. The palace retains its beautiful carved stucco and painted ceilings, but is otherwise empty of furnishings, they having been stripped from the place after the death of the vizier for whom it was built.

Partially closed for rennovation. We were disappointed as the palace was mostly closed off for renovation
It was still worth 10dm (less than a £1) for entry but not much to see
Nice architechture. The palace has nice ceilings etc. Not something to go out your way for but if you are in the area or have time to fill then worth a visit.

Very Lovely. The interior offers beautifully painted ceilings, walls, & doors and stained glass windows in addition to the more traditional tile and wood & plaster carvings. This is a definite visit as it is very lovely.

Not much to see. The court yards are beautiful but apart from them there is not much to see. It would have been so much more interesting if some of the rooms had been furnished. Ali Ben Youssef is much more interesting!

Well worth a visit. Wonderful decorative tile-work and painted ceilings and the charge to get in was only 10 drms!
The gardens though not extensive were very calming after the noise and bustle of the medina

A beautiful example of Architecture. This was a nice visit, to get off the streets and into a quiet garden leading to a largish palace. The tile work and plaster carvings were beautiful. This self guided tour, was well worth the 1 euro entrance fee!
Beautiful place of history. We went here with a guide, he told us all about the history beautiful architecture and colours, peaceful away from the streets for 10 dirham each..

Beautiful historic site. we nearly didn't go here because we thought there was nothing much to see but thankfully we did go. yes the Palace is not furnished but the architecture and design on the walls, floors, ceilings and windows are well worth giving an hour of your holiday to see. Entrance is just 70p 90 cents EU or $1, which is an absolute bargain for what you see.

worth a visit but information in english was missing.. In the midst of the busy souks is this compact but gorgeous palace. It is worth a visit and is very well preserved. However, the information available was only in Arabic and French and a leaflet about the palace history in english would have helped.

A fun quiet little escape from the hassle for a dollar.... It costs all of a dollar, can be visited in under an hour, boast some really nice wood carvings and is located in a very pleasant garden.The palace has been striped of most of its former glory. What remains are intricately carved ceilings. The tour leads through various chambers and courtyards a few nice fireplaces can be admired on the way. All the furnishings, carpets and tapestries are gone so you actually take some time to admire the incredible woodwork.I wouldn't necessarily cross all of town just to see it but if you happen to be in the area its definitely worth a quick visit!
Exquisite setting. A lovely quiet haven in a busy setting. Beautiful decorative tiles and painted ceilings with peaceful courtyards, cool corridors and fountains

Well worth a visit. Spent a very interesting hour or so here viewing the various chambers, beautiful courtyards and harem. With stunning architecture, beautiful carpentry and decoration, this is well worth a visit.

Typical Moroccan beauty. I am fascinated by architecture so I may be biased but this place exhibited what I imagine to be typical beautiful Moroccan architecture, well maintained with so much carved woodwork, mosaic and amazing stonework.It was crowded all day with tourist who come on buses from outside the Medina, and hard to get a good photo op without people crossing in front, but a lovely place to see nevertheless. Hardly any signs or panels explaining what we are looking at, so I eavesdropped on some of the guides to learn the history and background. Worth paying for one to show you around the place. There is so much more trivia to learn than just reading a travel guide book. Different rooms have different facade and decor, and each room seem to have a history of their own.

WORTH AN HOUR OR SO.. A lovely palace,a fine example of Moroccan architecture.It is worth a visit if only to regain your senses from the hubbub of Marraketch.It is very easy to find and certainly worth the entry fee of 10 Dirhams.
Very calming. Great for history, takes you ack to that time.Nicely preserved and very clean.Was not very busy when I visited so you can walk around and chill out.

Nice Palace. It cost only 10dirham and is a very nice old palace. Near the jemaa
el fna the central place of the Medina.

Great photo opportunities here!. In these palace attractions there is no furniture, you must just appreciate the architecture and landscape. In order to see period furniture you must visit one of the many museums in town. You may also dislike the hundreds of stray cats you will encounter.

A true Palace. Palais De La Bahia is a very true 'Palace' built in 19th century. Situated in old town of Marrakech 2 minutes walking distance from Mellah is a must see place in Marrakech. Entry fee is 10 Dirhams equals €1.
interesting place. the workmanship of the ceilings and doors was amazing. Interesting and lovely place, strongly recommend it!

Magic box, hidden in the souk!. Who would believe there to be a silent paradise, hidden away like that in the souk area. Tired and weary, we found peace and beauty like nowhere else. The atmosphere is at first a little belildering. My youngest son wondered what happened to the furniture(been to a few castles allthough 4 years old). Then he, and we got it. The floors, the cealings, the proportions... are sublime. This is a true sacredlike experience. Live it! And be nice to the cat´s in the coartyard. They are royalties, ignored by most.

Worth seeing. At first you think you're wasting your time, it looks fairly insignificant until you get into the Palace, It's empty, yet beautiful. The tiling, painting doors, ceilings are very beautiful

Beautiful Palace. Well this was the bargain of our trip. Only 10 MAD to get in. It was our first palace and we were bowled over by the inticate decor. The tiling, painted doors, ceilings etc. Lovely and cool inside too. Perfect for a hot day.

Best thing we saw. Got a taxi here, which dropped us right outside gate.Can be busy with tour groups but can make your own way round once in. The tiling is amazing. No furnishings just the tiling to see but lots of it
Worth visiting. This is a deceptive venue, looks fairly insignificant until you get into the Palace. It is Tardis-like, getting bigger as you go further in.

Don't be fooled. i am all about looking around places of interest when visiting new places on holiday, other people had written that hit would take 2 hours to walk round......... only if you photographed it inch by inch, there are rooms that have great detail, but it is an empty palace, we were in and out within 16 mins, luckily it only cost 10dr to get in.
Good. Good visit for photo opportunities of intricate Moroccan decoration, but very empty rooms apart from this. Cats galore!
Beautiful roof. The palace has lots of interesting details. As you have to pay to go in (not more than 3 euros), you will not be disturbed by false guides. It is worth the visit.

Very nice. We visited in January with not too many people around. The palace is very nice, pretty woodwork and plaster work with nice restoration where needed.
A peaceful retreat from the market!

A lovely way to spend the morning. As we were staying just down the road from the palace it was easy to find and very reasonably priced. We chose not to have a guided tour but then had to negotiate our way around multiple tour groups. We went in the morning before it became busy when this was ok, but I imagine it could become very tedious at busy times. The palace is very beautiful with typically Islamic decoration, though not on the same scale as somewhere like the Alhambra. Currently, only a small proportion of the palace and gardens are open to the public as there is restoration work being done on the rest. This means it is easy to get around at a gentle pace in an hour or so. I imagine that in the heat of summer it would, with its shaded courtyards, be a welcome retreat from the heat and noise of the city. Ladies, please note that if you want to use the toilets you have to pay the attendant 2Dh. Apparently there is no attendant in the Gents so they get to use the facilities for free.

Fascinating visit. A great deal to see. Very high quality architecture and internal stucco work and tiling and mosaic. Much more interesting than the palace El Badi. An essential part of a trip to Marrakech.

Worth Seeing. First of all...you can't beat the price of admission. It was relatively cheap. The palace was great for taking pictures and seeing how the rich lived at the time. It's ashame they didn't keep up the maintenance for this attraction because it's becoming rundown but is still beautiful. There is no literature in English at the palace telling you about the various rooms and courtyards. Read up on it before going.
Family holiday. You travel back in time and history visiting this palace, beautiful decoration in a very nice environment
Hard to find!. Very interesting but not well sign posted. We did have locals trying to mis-direct us for money but worth persevering.

well worth a visit. A palace built for the Sultan's wives and concubines this is an architectural gem that reminded me of the harem in Topkapi. lovely rooms and pools with some stunning ceilings - so don't forget to look up. Could have done with better explanations in English but at less that £1 for entrance I shouldn't complain!
beautiful. lovely and relaxing. its amazing that even after all these centuries the magnificent and glamour is still there. one tends to think what it would have been like with full glamour

The empty palace. When walking in the gate you pay a few coins and the surprise is orange tree's used as a garden. They are many people go to see and you will follow the crowd ... trying to take your photo's.Only a 1\3 is open as still in bad shape but you get the feeling of the wealth of old. I think the french used it for offices.
Beautiful old palace. Beautiful old palace with nice inside gardens and beautiful wooden ceilings! Definitely worth a visit to get an idea of how the rich used to live in marrakech.
Exotic Harem. Lovely tiled rooms with great architectural details. This is where the harem hung out. You can imagine what life must have been like when the Sultan ruled.

Pretty but not much info to digest. Pretty architecture especially the tiling. There's not a lot in the way of signs and information though so may be better if you have a guide. cheap to get in - 10 dh.

Interesting glimpse into the past of the life of a sultan. Built in the late 19th century the Bahia Palace is an interesting place to visit in Marrakesh, Morocco. The name is said to mean "brilliance". It is fairly well preserved although there are no furnishings. If you would like you can have a guided tour. We chose to walk around on our own, but still heard some interesting facts about this place. People who visited here, including movie stars when it was still occupied. This sultan had a large harem and nobody but himself could look at them. If one of the servants were to look at them they would be killed. It is amazing to look around at the walls, ceilings, doorways, and gardens and just imagine the palace when it was occupied.

A pleasant hour. Wonderful rooms, amazing workmanship.The only smelly loos we encountered in our six day visit!Don't accept guidance to the palace from 'helpful' local boys unless you are willing to part with a few dirhams!

Interesting history. I understand this palace was originally built in mid-1800 for a former slave who rose to be Moulay Hassan's chamberlain. Beautiful carved stucco and cedar wood features and don't miss the ceilings. Definitely worth a short visit especially for only 10 dh (app $1)

Stunning. You must go here! Its like a mini Alhambra, well preserved and gorgeous to look at. An oasis of calm even with all of us tourists taking photo's. take your time to look up at the ceilings not just the walls!
Worth a visit. Much is closed for restoration but worth a stop to see. The guide we had provided us with lots of historical info which makes it a better visit.
A must see !. A beautiful palace, a short but very interesting visit just outside the medina. Don't miss it ! A few steps away you should visit Dar Si Said.

Tranquil, not amazing but worth visit. It was a cool respite from the heat and the crowds. Even though what we saw was a series of empty rooms, each room was decorated on the floor, walls or ceiling in some manner. Compared to other palaces in Europe, it is not in the "amazing" category but it is interesting and a part of Marrakech that is worthwhile seeing.

Bahia Palace and El Badi Palace mixups. Bahia Palace and El Badi Palace are located close to each other in the southern end of the Medina. We visited it in October and would highly recommend spending 1-2 hours at Bahia Palace to see the craftsmanship of the ceilings, the tile work, and the garden areas. Unfortunately, a number of the written descriptions and photographs posted under Bahia Palace are for the El Badi Palace, which is larger larger but in poorer physical condition. Perhaps this error is due to the ease of getting lost in the medina or on the limited signage telling tourists where they are. If you have limited time in Marrakesh and are interested in Islamic architecture and Morroccan crafts, my three 'must see' places in order of importance are: 1) the Medersa Ben Youssef, 2) the Berber Art Museum at Jardin Marjorelle, and 3) Bahia Palace.To the good folks at Trip Advisor, I've submitted comments on a couple of the mis-located posts (such as the one by 589 MichaelP commenting about the storks and the photos posted by ilana613).
Nice. very interesting, beautiful buildings. Interesting rooms and architecture, ornate ceilings, fireplaces, musicians rooms. Good to see how the other half lived in luxury.

Good if you like ceramic tiles. The tiles, really. Probably most of them had been made in Fez. The architecture was intriguing, calculated to keep ambassadors in their place and the ladies in residence well hidden. The sculpted ceilings were worth a look but forgettable after the Alhambra in Spain

Great Ceilings. Too Many Empty Rooms. I have a good imagination but it would've been nice if they had put some furniture in some of the rooms so that we could have got an idea of what it had looked like at the time it was being lived in. We had a guide who didn't actually tell us very much which was disappointing but what I did really enjoy was the incredible ceilings, and I loved the architecture too. Would I go back? No.

very interesting palace. So glad I visited-fascinating. I think I got more out of it since we had a tour guide than if I went there without one. The courtyard was closed for renovation. The place is beautiful and so much history.
Stunning. Beautiful place. Amazing photo opportunities, it is almost too much to take in.Recommend the adjacent restaurant Bahia 11 with roof terrace.
bof.... I didn't really enjoy this place. If you have to choose between this one an the Medersa Ben Youssef, I would suggest the Medersa.On the good side, the price is so cheap... 2€
An absolute must see !!. Beautiful roofs, in fact that's pretty much all that there is to see, but so worth it ! Truly lovely !!!!
Well worth the visit. If you are interested in architecture and mosaics this is fantastic and cheap to visit. Great photo opportunities.
Poor information inside. This applies for almost all historical attractions in the Medina: lack of good information. The place is gorgeous but, this way, it's just a succession of rooms. A pity.

Nice architecture. This palace was definitely worth a visit for a small entrance fee. It is not large but it is very ornate with traditional tile work with plenty of photo opportunities. We loved the carved windows. Wish we could have bought something like that back to London.
Right next to Hayati. On the way to or from the Mellah it's right next to the Riad. You can get an idea of how opulent the ancient sultans lived.

Glorious palace. This place was amazing. When we first walked up to the main building I commented that it 'wasn't exactly Buckingham Palace' but once inside I was amazed at the detail and intricacy of the rooms.It looks just as amazing in our photographs as it did in the flesh, which is something you can rarely say.Only 10 Dirham (less than a quid) and definitely worth spending an hour or so away from the chaos of the Medina.

Lovely architecture!. Went here as part of the 'Marrakech Royale' excursion organized by Thomson, so the entrance fee was waved [included in the price that we had paid]. This of course included the use of a guide. Upon entering the Bahia palace, you can see why/how it is a palace with it's stunning architecture and beautiful grounds. Unfortunately I was unable to hear what my guide was saying [majority of the time] specially as there was other groups of tourists browsing the Palace at the same time. However the place is quite poplar and can get very busy at times.Lovely palace to visit, specially for the all the photographs you can take, unfortunately there isn't really much else to see apart from the above!

Best with a guide. We learned a lot but only due to the guide we had hired for a 3 hour walking tour of Marrakesh (only 40 euro!). Without a guide the Bahia is interesting from the architectural viewpoint, but without any signage one doesn't learn much. A personal guide is well worthwhile, but be sure to avoid be brought into their favorite carpet, herbal or artifact shop. Visit the historic places with the guide, not the souk. The souk can be discovered alone.
The only choice. Such a palace were visited by almost all tourist need to be cleaned and restored. Is not la Medina, clean please at least inside.

Enjoyable!. The palace is situated in the south of the Medina and is approached by a long garden driveway.Once inside you are directed by arrows on the wall which take you through a succession of rooms and courtyards.The decoration in the rooms with the tiling,carved wooden doors and ornate ceilings gives you a good idea of Moorish architecture.Very little information on view inside so you really need a guide.Enjoyed our visit here,and excellent value for 10 dirhams.

Nice traditional architecture, worth a wander. We weren't blown away by Bahia Palace, but for a minimal 10dH entry fee it was a nice way to spend a leisurely hour. On our visit in late November the place was almost deserted as well. We enjoyed admiring the traditional architecture - the intricate detailing of the ceilings, cornices and tiling etc. There is no signage or information (or none in English at least, and I saw only one sign in French) - I guess this is where a tour guide would come in handy to give you a little more insight into the purpose/history of each part, as the unfurnished rooms give little indication.
Nice wood work and roofs. The roofs were the most interesting part of all. It is a pleasant place to visit, it's only 1€ more or less, so if you are around it's half an hour in the shade!

Wonderful example of where modern society goes wrong.. The beautiful home is so insignificant from the outside and amazingly beautiful on the inside. Not externally flamboyant to distress the less fortunate people who pass by but internally, luxurious, airy, peaceful tranquillity that displays the success of the owner. All there but not in your face!

Beautiful Bahia. This is a beautiful place to visit if you don't have much time to spend elsewhere - it is a quick and nice walk. Although there is not much to see, if you want to get an idea of what real moroccan pottery and architecture is then you should go. It was pleasant to walk around in november without getting hot and bothered and it wasn't too crowded either. You should definitely go if you're in Marrakech because its not like anything I've seen elsewhere. Great photo opportunities but nothing available to read or listen to to hear about the building if you're into the history. I wasn't bothered to learn much to be honest I just wanted to see how pretty it was and enjoy the sun.

A pleasant enough way to spend an hour, but a tad disappointed. I had seen the Bahia Palace on a travel app and I have to admit, the pictures on the app promised far more than the reality delivered. Yes I totally agree, for 10 dirham it's a must whilst you're in Marrakech and yes, the architecture is amazing. Some of the tiling and wooden ceilings are absolutely beautiful and exquisite. All in all it was a very nice hour spent in there and I'm genuinely glad I went, but in the grand scale of all the magic Marrakech has to offer, I think it will quickly be forgotten when remembering my trip there. But still go, it's worth the time, money and effort.

Excellent. I loved the architecture, the painted wood ceilings, seemingly endless rooms and courtyard gardens. Okay - so its nineteenth century, but still wonderful. If you love Moorish architecture, you'll love this.

Average.... Like many of the sites in Marrakech it was ok but not of any great note. We went in November when the weather was a perfect temperature but in the height of the summer I would imagine it to be unbearable as its very exposed.

A bit bland..... Whilst it did have some amazing architecture and examples of amazing tiling, it did seem to have been a bit neglected in places and could do with some furniture fitting its time and use. Many of the rooms are identical......however for 10 DRH its not an expensive way to spend half an hour.

Well worth a visit. Very beautiful and enormous old palace. The view from the tower is wonderful. The underground hammam is very interesting. On a beautiful day in November it was quiet and peaceful. Lovely to see the storks nesting in the building.All for an entrance fee of 10 dirhams. Something similar in Europe would cost 10 times as much!
take a good guide. This Palace is not beautiful but if you hire a good guide he can make it seem much more interesting that it looks.

Interesting place, don't set aside too long for your visit though. This is a wonderful place with a lot of history but you don't need more than 30-45 minutes inside even with a guide. We combined it with a tour of the whole Medina including the Saadian Tombs and a walk through the the Souks and Djemaa el-Fna.
Beautiful architecture. Interesting, with beautiful architecture. Lovely mosaics and stucco work. Gets very crowded. No need to go with a guide - you can read all there is to know in the guide books!

wonderful. The palace is built in moorish style, with lots of ceramics and wooden carved door. Got to see it! The ticket it's cheap (10 dhr - 1€) and you can enjoy the garden and the palace, but believe, even if the palace is empty (no furniture inside at all), its decoration worth!!!!
Definitely go here. Beautiful palace with intricately carved and tiled decorations and lush gardens. The harem is the highlight. Worth using a guide to get the most out of the visit.

Not quite what we expected. Bit disappointed as I was expecting a palace to wander around rather than the ruins of one. But the catacombs were interesting and the terrace gave us good views across the rooftops (and satellite dishes) of Marrakech. The museum was closed as it was Independence Day. The storks that nest around the tops of the high walls made for some interesting photos but other than that we were disappointed!
Alhambra look alike. We have visited the Al Hambra in Granada, Spain and loved it, especially the gardens but this palace was even larger and more beautiful. Be sure to visit the "harem" section.
Lovely little palace. We walked down to see the palace and it was worth the trip.We spent an afternoon walking the jewish quarter and then the Bahia Palace.
Tranquility amidst hustle. The palace and gardens are a welcome respite from the hubbub of the medina. Beautifully decorated ceilings and doors, as usual.

Must go. Besides the Medina and the Square Jemaa el-Fnaa, the Bahia Palace is a must go. The Palace is amazing, big building with lots of beautiful rooms and gardens and a very nice riad. It's well maintained and very clean.

A beautiful place. This place could be stunning if it was maintained well. As it is, it is still worth seeing and very beautiful -- but one wonders where the admission fees are spent as those funds clearly do not go to maintenance.

A mosaic of tiles. The Palace felt very empty, filled with walls and walls of tiles, sectioned off by places used for historical segregation of women and nobles, you could tell by the lay out there were specific uses for certain areas, very impressive tiling and an impression of an imperial past.

A good visit to appreciate Moroccan craft and artistry. A good visit to appreciate Moroccan craft and artistry. Of course compared to other similar places in the world, this is not a "take your breath away" place. However it does give you in a small space a good background of Morocco's history and culture as well as the harem protocol of those days.Unfortunately there could be just too many tourists here.
Very nice place. If you want to have a chance to enjoy the palace, you should visit it early in the morning. Should go there with a guide to have explanations.

A peep into country's culture. Worth a visit but do not expect too much. Parts of the Palace are very ornate and some very simple. The calligraphy is beautiful like at the Madrasa. The Doors and Arches are highly carved and stunningly beautiful

Excellent palace, wonderful architecture. Well worth a visit. Beautiful building, excellent islamic architecture, wonderful ceilings.
The area around is rather busy and commercial but once you get inside the palace is a delightful quiet palace. The courtyards and interior are fabulous.
Don't miss this. An opportunity to see some very intricate painting and carving in a peaceful oasis on the side of the souk. The entrance fee was only 10 dirham and an absolute bargain.
Beautiful Palace. Only 10Dh each to enter and worth it. Takes a good hour to walk around the beautifully decorated rooms. Very peaceful inside.

Must-see for art & architecture buffs. A beautiful palace and a great example of Moroccan art & architecture. Hiring a guide probably would have been a good move, as often my sister and I didn't know what we were looking at (besides pretty tile work). Even my ability to read French didn't help much, as there were few signs, and they were usually surrounded by massive groups of people. If you don't want to know the history, though, skip the guide and just wander around. The tile work and the mosaics are exceptional, as is the painted wood on the ceilings. It's a beautiful place, and absolutely worth a visit (and the crazy-inexpensive admission fee).

Worth a visit. Just really a pity that there was virtually no english language there which made it a little more difficult to look around - my french is okay but just okay and no more. A little off-putting when the only english is telling you that you can buy a CD of the music that they are playing. Worth the visit though and not expensive.

Good escape from the crazy city!. Worth a visit if only to escape the crazy city for a couple of hours. Very peaceful and tranquil, though walking to get there from the main square was very hectic with some difficult roads to negotiate.

A must visit for any one. I would advise you to hire a guide because it's nice to know the history behind the palace and it's stunning rooms. Go there as early as you can because it tends to be packed by afternoon time.
Mini hambra. It is one of the few places that really deserves visiting in marrakech,it reminds me of Alhambra palace in Granada but of course it is very small in comparison with it.

Beautiful place.
