This place is so peaceful other than the crowds that is, as soon as you walk through the gates you notice a distinct lack of traffic / street noise.There are some amazing stone and plasterwork to be seen, the detail is astonishing.Don't forget to keep glancing up as well as the woodwork and painting in the ceilings is very well worth admiring as well.The garden areas are very well laid out and there is some wonderful shade afforded by the trees and the building itselfThis is definitely another must see when you are in Marrakech and it is cheap to get in as well.
Beautiful. this is a great cheap attractiobn with nice gardens and brilliant stucco and woodwork. One word of caution though if you have a child doing A Level art be prepared for a long visit!!

Wonderful islamic art. Although the Palace was only built in the 19th century it offers a wonderful display of wood and stone carving, painted wood and beautiful Moroccan tiles. If one has seen the Alhambra Palace in Granada the likeness will be obvious. Well worth the small fee of just 10 dirhams.

Just Beautiful. I couldn't believe the lovely ceilings as you go from room to room they continue to change and each one is more beautiful and interesting than the last. It only takes a short time to tour but is well worth the effort.
Disappointing. There was not much to see. It is basically a shell of an old brick courtyard. Not particularly attractive. Not worth the price or time in my opinion.

Astonishing palace. Wonderful place, located in south Medina. It is not in any case far away. you can reach that place in couple of minutes from main squere Jemna El Fna. Palace is not big it is huge. It offers very nice gallery on its main square and in the back is picturesque mosque where you can buy ticket in entrance as well. Just behind entrance is staircases goes upstaires to tower where you can find breathtaking view all over the city. On the walls of Bathia palace you will see so many white storks you wont belive it.

Great design. The palace has amazing design on the inside along the walls, roofs and the floor. Go here if you reqlly like to see some nice architecture and designs. It was quiet during the late hours of the morning but not much description about the various rooms so it is recommended to go there with a guide. 10 dhm for entrance and is well worth it. Very near to the Saadien Tombs so you can plan to do them together same day.
Lovely. A cool place to escape the craziness of the souk.Lovely artwork and a pretty little garden in the middle.

palace tour. Quite crowded so difficult to hear guide at times. A good english speaking guide is very helpful but palace has beautiful islamic architecture of the Andalusian style and well worth the visit

Peace & Quiet. We visited Bahia Palace during the craziness of Feast of Sacrifice last week which saw a lot of attractions close for the day during this festival. I think it cost 10 MAD to get in which is less than a £1. Its a beautiful place to walk around and take photos of the amazing craftsmenship of the building but it doesn't take long to see everything there is to see. We went next door to the Bahia Palace Restaurant but the menu has 4 items on it to choose from for lunch on the terrace and its very expensive, even just for a soft drink. If you turn right upon exit of the palace and wander down the alleyway there you'll find the Earth Cafe, which everyone raves about, or walk round the corner to your left to the fabulous Kosy Cafe and enjoy watching the storks nesting - one of the highlights of my trip :)

Nice respite from the madness. If you're looking for a little break from the madness that is Marrakech, this is the place for you. The moment you walk through the gates you feel completely peaceful and all the stresses of the city disappear. The palace demonstrates beautiful Moroccan architecture (a photographers dream) as well as nice shady spots.

Beautiful Palace. Like in other contries with Mosques or Arabian buildings, this palace does have ceillings, patios, plasterwork from centuries ago, Relaxing, quiet and very pretty place. Enjoy your visit

Nice to wander around - won't take long.... Nice architecture but an empty space to wander if passing. A herbalist next door which is interesting to visit as they do a little talk. Terrace cafe next door for refreshments.

An andaluz style. I liked the construction, the shinny, and the ceiling work of some divisions. The water elements, and the in a patio remember the andalucia constructions, in countries with very hot climateric conditions, as the walls and floor tiles.However, and I think that it was proposefuly in the palace planning the dividions of the palace are very desigual, some are big divisions and other are smallest.The palace has no furniture at all, but that is something that I have already seen in some arabian monuments.I enjoy the visit.
lovely palace.. A beautiful place to spend half an hour. The building is amazing. it was interesting to see how the rich people lived.

beautiful building, lots of rooms, nice and quiet. The rooms are stunning, the tiles, the plasterwork and the wood. A rabbit warren of interlinking rooms, with sprinkles of green planting. The central oasis features are lovely. Very cool and quiet after the hussle and bussle of the city. The walk up along the path from the gates with the trees and plants is quite pretty.Entrance is 10 Dh, and worth paying.Ensure you download the Trip Advisor Marrakech city guide - a LIFESAVER for any tourist wandering around the city.
a must visit. Do put this on your itinerary. Like all the best places to visit, it will be busy but it is worth putting up with the crowds.
Beatiful!. A beautiful palace in the south of the city. Ornate artwork, cool rooms and courtyards provide plenty of photo opportunities. Great counterpoint to the madness just outside.

Beautiful palace. Definitely worth a visit. While there isn't as much to see inside as Ben Youssef, it is still a beautiful place. There are a collection of courtyards that are accessible, along with some indoor areas. Make sure to spend some time admiring the intricate carving and painting of the wood ceilings.
Worth a visit. It is well worth a visit to the Bahia Palace. There are lots of rooms and courtyards to look around at the architecture is beautiful.
OK spot to poke around. For 10 DR, you can't go too wrong...we enjoyed a brief look around before heading up to the square. There is a nice hammam close by!

A quick visit, but well worth the 10 dirhams. You'll probably see everything in about 45 minutes, but the palace is gorgeous, and contains a number of shaded areas in which to escape the heat. It's got a fascinating history, and has plenty of interesting shifts in design and colour; certainly worth the wonderfully cheap entry.

lovely decorations. I loved the decorations in the rooms, they are still working on renovations but as bare as the rooms where of any kind of furnishings I just loved to have a look at the intracate designs on the ceilings, doors etc..

One of the highlights of Marrakech. This is a place that must be visited, but probably better appreciated with the services of a good guide who can give you more then just a potted history of this beautiful building. The whole atmosphere was amazing, very peaceful even with quite a lot of other people around. Fabulous architecture. Close to the Saadian tombs, which are also well worth visiting.

Outstanding. This review gets 5 stars, not for the palace itself, but for its restaurant which is located just next to the main entrance. The food and surroundings are just exquisite and great value for money.The chicken tajine with prunes is the nicest meal I had in all of Morocco.As for the palace, this is a nice place to spend half an hour.

You shouldn't miss this attraction. Bahia Palace is pretty close to the main square, this attraction is in my top 3 of the most beautiful ruins I've visit!When you arrive you have to select if you want a ticket just for the Palace tour, or an upgrade that includes a visit to a small room where you can appreciate an ancient atrium from Koutoubia's mosquée. I heard some people complaining because they were expecting more from the upgrade tour but considering that we are not allowed in the Mosquees by not being Muslims it was nice to be able to see it and they have also some pictures from inside of the Mosquee, so it's your call.Besides the ruins with beautiful tiles there's another exhibition of Comtemporary Art included in the regular ticket.Before leaving make sure you get on the terrace to have full vision of the place, the view is breath-taking.Finally, when my friend and I were on our way out we found out there was a "suggested route" for the tour, a little too late for us, but if you go there you could try to follow the recommended path.

El Bahia = Brilliant. This palace is still partially used by the Moroccan royalty and their guests. The palace has 150 rooms but only a small part of it is accessible. Despite of that it is still worth checking out as the interior is stunning and the charge to get in was only 10Dh when we visited.
Interesting guide to the history.... Set in the middle of Marrakech, this place is a real jewel. Lovely architecture, mozaics and painted walls.
Disappointing. The ruins and the palace are not necessarily outstanding. Rather ordinary. The tile work was interesting.

a 1001 nights. the Bahia palace offers a glimpse into Aladdin's 1001 nights...this glorious palace is a warren of beautiful spaces, each ceiling and doorway a breathtaking example of Moroccan art. The detail and intensity of each pattern will defy you to understand the hours it would have taken to create it. It offers a glimpse into a hidden past of harems and Moroccan folklore...take a camera...

underwhelming. I found the palace very underwhelming. Walked through a few rooms, awed at the ceiling. I had no idea what the different rooms were or what the designs were. I didn't have change at first (only 100 dhms) and the entry guys were not helpful at all. After the extreme disappointment, I couldn't bother going to tombs.

This is no palace. WE have visited a few Palaces through Spain, Portugal and Morocco. We saw the front entrance to the Palace at Fes. This Bahia Palace is poorly maintained. Absolutely no furniture. Apart from the tiles and the art work in the ceiling, there is nothing else for tourists.We had a local tour guide as well.Do not waste your time at this site.
a must see in Marrakech. This wonderful palace sets you back a couple of centuries. It has a beautiful but small garden. The artwork at the ceiling, doors and walls are plain beautiful

A beautiful construction of the 19th century. The ceilings are particularly gorgeous. This is an exquisite place which, although incredibly ornate, is still very beautiful.Don't miss this palace. It's a very good example of Moroccan crafts and skills.

It would have been amazing. The detail and skill of the craftsmen who built the palace is plain to see in the intricate detail of the ceilings and the woodwork. It is a pity that it has had all of the furniture removed as this, I have no doubt, would have further impressed the visitor with how it would have really felt to visit it when it was in full operation

Pretty boring but worth a look considering the price. We enjoyed the walk about but there isn't really much to see there apart from a nice garden and some very detailed ceilings inside the palace, luckily we speak French so could read the signs but if you can't then you are pretty stuffed unless you have a guide. Maybe I am being a little harsh as entry only costs 10 dirrum which is less than £1 but I just thought there could be a bit more detail, maybe I should have brought my own guide book?
Amazing Riad. Only 10% is to be visited but the room are beautifull. A must see! nice tiles wall and floors.A visit with a guide gives you more insight.
Beautiful. If you can, do a one to one guided tour. An early morning viewing may avoid the crowds. Look up, the ceilings are amazing.
Lovely. Lovely place for a wander. We had a guide with us and he gave us lots of helpful information as to how the palace was used. Very interesting.
Worth a visit. Easy to see that in its day it would be a splendid Palace. We went there on same morning as looking as other places in the same area.
Beautiful. Worth a visit the palace has an interesting history.loved the gardens but the streets to the palace are mad !

A brief visit. easy to find near the spice market. Although interesting it does not take long to walk around. With little or no information on the palace to read as you go around if you want information it would be best to get a guide.
Very interesting. I visited the Bahia Palace as part of a tour. I loved the tiling, ceiling artwork and central garden, which was a shady place to sit away from the heat/frantic traffic of the city.
Stunning. A great place to just walk around and marvel at the intricate detail and craftsmanship. A must do. Easy to find also and low admission cost.

Interesting visit. Interesting to wander around and see the staterooms - a big disappointment is that they are not furnished which makes them all very similar (tiled floor, painted cedar ceiling and marble worked friezes)

Beautifull. I've loved the palace. Is really beautifull.
It was fairly inexpensive entry - 10DRH. Worth a visit.
lovely. very beautifull and so much history but u need a guide or good book on maraketch to get the most from it
Great Short Visit. A wonderfully beautiful palace and well worth the low entry fee. Have camera ready...awesome handiwork!
Beautiful but bare. Beautiful building with amazing tiled/painted/carved walls, floors and ceilings, but completely unfurnished.

Beautiful Palace, My favorite attraction in Marrakesh.. This beautiful palace found in the heart of Marrakesh was one of my favorite attraction during my stay. The engravings on the walls are beautiful and the mosaic and wood work on the ceilings and doors are fascinating. While walking through the different rooms, your breath is taken away with the beautiful writing and designs. Having a guide makes this experience much more worth it and you feel a connection with what used to go on in this palace, you find out the history behind why it was designed in such a wonderful way.

Ornate decoration. Like many of the tourist sites, if you don't speak French - make sure you have researched this palace in advance. Effectively this is an empty building but the walls, ceilings & floors are amaxing & worth seeing.

My favorite attraction in Marrakech. This beautiful palace is my favorite attraction in Marrakech. I was amazed by the details in the engravings on the walls, the mosaic, the wood work on the ceilings and doors. While walking through the different rooms, you keep getting surprised by the amazingly artistic designs.

Moderately interesting. This palace was built in the late 19th. century for the then ruler. It only costs 10 dirhams to visit it and inside, there are a series of rooms which give some impression of what life must have been like. However, it is completely unfurnished, so it doesn't really compare favourably with some other places I have visited. The bare rooms give little idea of the vulgar ostentation of the times - as, for example, the Dolmabahçe Palace in Istanbul does.

Ok resting place. Visited the palaces via a thomsons trip. It was lucky we had a decent guide aziz who I had before on a previous excursion. Lucky for us he knows his stuff, not one of my most favourite trips, but I as part of history of Marrakech walk. Oh be prepared for lots of walking so wear good shoes. You will need to negotiate the narrow streets trying not to get run over by the hundreds of bikes that do drive through the souks, be aware at all times so please please do not think of using headphones walking around the souks, it can be pretty dangerous. The palace was so so, it was good that they have preserved their heritage, but toilets in this place are vile and they asked us for money as we left disgusted...sorry fix up your facilities and then maybe people would be happy to tip.

Love, love, love!. This place is a must-see in Marrakech, if you appreciate architecture and history, definitely visit this place. The work on it is amazing, very detailed, even though some of it is made of wood. Take a guide as this place has an interesting story and enjoy it. There are power outlets if your phone dies every 2 hours like mine. Beautiful place.
small but beautifull palace. don't leave Marrakech without to see this palace. It' s doesn't take time ( maybe 1 hour is enought ) and the roofs are amazing.the entrance fee is very cheep : 1 euro

Lovely but disappointing since half the tour seemed closed. We went since this is one of the 'must-see' attractions and while the courtyard we did see was lovely, it was absolutely heaving with tourists in big tour groups blocking the paths. The rooms themselves were beautiful but very similar to in the Dar Si Said where we were able to wander more freely and which was less busy. I think the main courtyard/riad/square of the palace was shut - a big disappointment to us since the map and previous reviews made it look like we would go through there, and this that might have contributed to making it so busy.

Famous name but not much to see.. I got lured in by the "must see" mark but was greatly disappointed as apart from lots of vast empty rooms and a courtyard there is nothing to see. We were done in 15 minutes. Only saving grace were the mosaics which seems to be everywhere in Marakech.
Wonderful. The palace as it was and how it was used was lovely to see, the guided tour was excellent in knowledge and spoke very good english.

Average Palace. Having traveled to Mughal palaces in India and seen more finer arts, it was not too exciting. The Palais El- Badi was more interesting than this empty palace filled dark hallways. The doors and woodwork was nice but not fascinating. Can go if you have time.

beautiful designs... The intricate designs on the doors, walls, ceilings were amazing.
Beautiful and peaceful to see it. Its unfortunate that the whole place was empty with no furnitures
or any other morroccan artefacts for display.
Took lots of pictures for the great memories...xx

very nice palace, it is a gem hidden away.. Do go in to the palace without thinking about the very poorly designed gate. The hidden palace is a very nice start to explore in Marrakech. Tiles, arches, doorways.

Beautiful but sparse. A beautiful building, where one could imagine meeting and being entertained by sultans and princes.
It would really come alive if it were furnished with period pieces to really give a feel for the way palace life was.
Quiet and peaceful. Lots of history about what the palace was used for where its name came from , very interesting a nice cool haven .
Lovely architecture. We enjoyed the Moorish architecture while walking through the lovely gardens and Riads. Our guide provided a close insight to the Palace. We recommend it to everyone.
Nice Palace!. It is one of the most importa Palaces to visit! Very good conservation and restoration! Must see with Dar Si Said very close to it!

very cute islamic piece of art. An oasis of calm in the hectic city. At no price (2 EUR eq.) a visit to this ancient islamic villa is worth the 60 min. Wander around and enjoy the calm of the scenery as well as the way the walls and roofs have been decorated.
Amazing!. This place is amazing! If you love design and decor and pay attention to detail, this place has so pretty key elements.

omg the tiles!. im not one to like tiles but the tile work at this palace is beautiful. i like this spot more and more each time i visit(which so far is twice). i like the different rooms and the fountain in the courtyard. its fun to imagine what it would be like to live there, i mean ancient morocco-amazing! there isnt much to do other than walk around from room to room which pretty much all look a like. i suggest going in with a guide who knows what each room was used for because it will bring a whole new life to the palace.

Moroccan Andalusian palace. Bahia Palace, Marrakesh, a late 19th century palace was built by two generations of Alawi vizirs, Si Ahmed ben Moussa and his son, from approximately 1860 until 1900. The palace is an example of late Moroccan Andalusian architecture, combining in its decoration, the tension of geometry with the lushness of natural forms and contrasting the drama of private, interior labyrinths with the blaze of sun and blue sky in courtyards filled with birdsong and fountains. The palace, gardens and pavilions cover almost 8 hectare. Maze-like corridors connect intricately decorated rooms, brilliant with colored zellij (colored mosaics of fired clay tiles), plaster carving, painted and carved wood. The courtyard garden at the heart of the complex is an oasis of banana trees, orange, jasmine and cypress. Definitely worth spending a few hours; would have been helpful to have some more explanation, captions, perhaps a catalogue.

Beautiful mosaics. Lovely mosaic patterns and carving, cheap to visit and worth seeing, only the architecture remains. I liked the ceiling patterns best, there were a few tours in that got in the way, but some were interesting to listen to.
Welcome break from the heat. A stone's throw from our riad and only £1 to get in. A beautiful cool courtyard and plenty of mosaics but not much information for those without a guide book.

A diversion from the Souks. The palace isn't that old and we didn't find it that special except for information on how they lived. The architecture in the hotel we were staying at (la sultana) was better. But if you are tired of the souks it is worth it. Not a must do.

The only palace you have to visit.. We visited Bahia Palace on our first day in Marrakesh and it was a great example of the Palace's that once were. It was the only palace that still had a feel of the olden days and most of the mosaics and tiles were still intact. We visited other Kasbah's but this was the one that was the best preserved so I would say to visit this one and then you don't really have to visit anymore.

Beautiful. It cost 10 dirhams to enter- so cheap. I thought this place was really breathtaking. We were staying a few minutes walk away, so while we did not spend the afternoon here, a nice hour or so was spent sitting, taking pictures, and examining the intricate decorations. The bathrooms do not have a fee like people say- they have attendants who are happy if you give them some money for their work. Hand over 1/2 and you're fine...it's not demanded of you though. This is a nice place to stop in for a visit- you will get amazing photos.

Nice tour!. We accidentally joined a tour group during our visit to the palace. We thought it was a tour we were meant to join! The tour guide was speaking in French, so I translated as best as I could for my husband and we followed them throughout the palace. There are some magnificent carved and tiled accents. It is a perfect place to visit during the heat of the day because the buildings are cool and there is quite a bit of shade when you are outside. Interesting architecture. You won't need more than an hour to visit.
Palace. It's okay.Not a lot to see but interesting enough. Could do with more explanation round the place. You won't need long there...
pleasant. A lovely palace but you can only visit part of the palace as part of it still used by the royal family. You can view living quarters, pleasure garden, courtyards and fountains.

Not really much to see. We had a city guide for Marrakech, not our regular trip guide. The palace is a pretty enough building with lots of Moroccan style mosaics but there is no furniture, artifacts, etc. anywhere. It is just a big empty building. Our guide would stand in an empty room and go on and on about what this room was for and who used it but it was pretty boring after a while looking at one vacant room after another. I think it would be okay to spend 30 minutes just wandering around here on your own but all the details from the guide were just too much. Not enough to see here for me.

Palace of A Sultan. The palace and gardens are being renovated, but it's still worth a visit as it' literally a minute from the Riad. The huge courtyard and sheer opulance of the old rulers must be seen.

a pleasure. a pleasant place to wander around- even with the crowds the spaces are so large that it's not a problem. a bit of a schlepp to get there, but the city now has very good signage so it's easy to find.

Interesting. If you are interested in Architecture you will love this Palace. Whoever built this place certainly paid attention to detail. the rich colours, the mosaic. beautiful. Unfortunately, there were a lot of unofficial guides who would try to get you to by their products which ruined the moment, however I found that it is a marrakech way of life. Just continue to say no thanks and they will eventually leave you alone.
Banquet. We had a conference banquet and the atmosphere at night is incredible. The show was superb using the walls as extra screens. The food was amazing and very generous.
bahia palace. this palace is an interesting visit , lovely tiles and ceilings , not very big , can be done in an hour
Great Palace. An enjoyable place to learn about Moroccan royalty. Unfortunately, lots of hustlers outside inviting you into shops and unofficial 'guides' who lead you to shops.

Unusual and interesting. Really unusual and interesting place, we originally intended a quick stop off but ended up spending about 3 hours here, a real maze of beautiful rooms, courtyards and gardens, highly recommend
Architecture. Very well planned and gives knowledge how planners considered and cared about environment in designing buildings and gardens
boring. really nothing to see, just a bunch of rooms with pretty carving designs on the wall - costs 10 dh each to get in, not a lot if you wanna kill some time
Interesting enough. Given that Marrakech really doesn't offer that many cultural attractions, the Bahia Palace is definetly among those, which is actually worth.

tranquil. Wonderful intricate craftmanship on ceilings and walls. Beautiful garden. Lacks info and furniture however there were a couple of guides there to explain. Only 10 mad to enter. Pop in if you are passing. Right next to the jewish area

Ok to visit. Had a private tour guide take us on a tour ofthe medina, one of the stops was this palace, it is actually beautiful and interesting to know how the harem works, however after having seen the Alhambra it is quite basic, obviously the comparison is not the best. Worth the visit.
Very pretty. Pretty, and visited it as part of a package. Limited tour but its a very picturesque site to go to. There is that fifty character thing again

Lovely week in Marrakech. Very nice palace lovely gardens.
Must see during your visit to Marrakech.
It's one of the palaces that is still up and actually nice to see and that you can visit.

Wuao! It's a must see and enjoy with your own eyes. Beautiful high decorated cedar ceilings, great doors, 4 seasons garden, fountain, different quarters and their histories. The palace provides a kind of serenity and peace even though it was not at its glorious state. Most of monuments we visited in Marrakech were not well kept but at least they're still there for us to visit, touch, feel and admire.

Beautiful for those who live arabesques, art & decorative haracter plafond. This small place is definitely worth to see however I strongly advice to visit it either very early or just before the closing time which is 16:45 thus you can avoid bumping on people and destructive crowd. Ceilings are simply stunning having in mind both colours & design. It revokes Alhambra in structure and overall taste , Istanbul in design and ceilings of castle of Nizwa in Oman.

Escape in the crowded medina. Visiting this palace was a wonderful experience. This place is full of history with unique Arab-style architecture. Even though it can get quite crowded, it is nonetheless it has a quaint and peaceful atmosphere. So for us it was a peaceful escape from all the chaos outside in the Marrakech medina.
A gem. The courtyard is delightful cooling and quiet if you get there before the coachloads! The decoration is wonderful too.
A must see!. The detail and decoration in this palace is wonderful! As well as the tile work, remember to look at the ceilings!
nothing special. Marrakech itself is a city with not much to do or see. This place is ok to see with architecture and decor.

Combine it with the Saadian tombs. Along with Ali Ben Youssef Madrassa, this was the other highlight in Marrakech. Again like being stuck in a very posh tiles-r-us showroom, but with the added advantage of beautifully decorated ceilings. You can easily spend a good 2-3 hours here, if possible go early or late and avoid the coach trips.
fab location. great location, full of history... its a pity its not conserved better.. but what a fantastic location , an oasis ...

Very beautiful building. Really enjoyed walking around this building. Get there early to avoid the crowds. The beautiful tiling and painted wood is really worth a visit. It is a highlight of our visit and very reasonable cost.

go early!. This is a spectacular place to visit, with every ceiling more fantastic than the one before it. the only draw-back is a lack of explanation of what you are looking at. I recommend going as soon as it opens to avoid the large tour groups (unless you are in one, in which case you might learn more about what was important about the place). When I showed up it was empty, quiet and peaceful.
Gorgeous!. Phenomenal architecture, elegant and timeless. The mosaics, plaster work and the wood work are beyond beautiful.
Beautiful escape from the medina. The palace is a grat escape from the hectic pressure of the medina. Very much worth seeing, beautiful and interesting

Great interesting palace - read up on it first. This is a beautifully painted palace, but its very empty and there is no information available - so either find a tourist guide or make sure you read up on it before you get there! 10 dhs per person to get in is well worth the price :)

Stunning. This place is simply amazing. You will find your selves wandering round looking at the very highly decorated ceilings, each room is different and each beautiful. Well worth the 10dh entrance fee.
Not to Miss. A great place to visit, refreshing ambience and beautiful gardens. The architecture is amazing great photos, good ambience it is a must see in Marakech.
Go with a guide. This palace is a beautiful place but I think that if we had gone with just a guide book we wouldn't have appreciated the history and stories associated with it.

Beautiful interiors. The interior of the palace is everything you might expect from Morocco. It is essential to have a guide who can explain the architecture and decor.Would be 5 stars if there was internal furnishings.

Nothing to see. Just a couple of empty rooms and a courtyard. Nothing really to see. Also have to pay for toilet roll if you use the ladies bathroom. Not worth a visit but it is only 10Dh so you probably won't feel like you've wasted money seeing it if you do visit it.

A marvel of craftsmanship. Be sure to add the Bahia Palace to your itinerary,even if you are only in Marrakech for a short stay.The walk from the street to the main door makes you feel like you are entering a haven away from the dusty hustle and bustle outside. Once inside marvel at the incredible work carried out by craftsmen from a bygone era. You will get a sore neck craning to see the roofs and can only wonder at what the colours would have been like when all was new.
Beautiful. Beautiful palace in the centre of Marrakesh. A beautiful collection of hand-crafted ceilings that will take your breath away!
Must see. very atmospheric location, must see and great insight into the history of Marrakech ruling classes, tranquil location and out of the heat

One of Marrakech's nicer attractions. We enjoyed our visit to the Bahia Palace. The palace is a good excellent example of Eastern Architecture from the late 19th century that represents the taste of the nouveau-rich of its time. Even though the detail may not be as rich as that found in earlier palaces, it is still a beautiful building. We especially liked the garden.

Something to do.. The place is cheap to enter, easy to find and it's in the Medina. The place itself is rather uninspired and not terribly big. Still, it does have some interesting art on the wall and ceilings and it also has some shade. For it's price point, it's not bad.
A quick stop.. Beautiful ceilings, very ornate, but when you've seen one, you're pretty much done, unless you have an informative guide, which we didnt.

Beautiful and Scerene.. Plan to spend some time here! I brought a sketch book and a fisheye lens and couldn't get enough. It is truly an inspiring place. Don't buy the tourist gifts here, save your money for the market. Don't take pictures of the locals, or offer them money if you do.
Well worth a visit. doesn't take long to have a look round and it is very near kosybar so you could go for an alcoholic drink after.
Very good, not to be missed.. Beautiful palace and gardens. Needs to be better maintained to preserve and show respect for the carving and artwork. Very peaceful and beautiful.

It is worth visiting it!. It doesn’t take you a long time to visit this place. However, the place is lively, full of colors. The walls, the ceilings are impressive. We visited the palace in the morning, so there were no many people, so after the visit, we had quite a long break under a big orange tree in the courtyard! It is worth visiting it!

Beautiful palace and interior gardens. Great daytime activity and very affordable at only 10 MAD. Right down the road from Koutoubia Mosque and Djemaa El Fna, adjacent to El Badi palace and the Mellah. Easy to find and well worth a visit.

Early or late... avoid the crowds.. This is a medium sized palace that takes a bit more than an hour to see. If you plan well then you can avoid the tours and crowds by arriving just as it opens, or within the last hour of the day - in this way you can see the lovely gardens, the highly ornamented interiors, and the stately rooms ... without the crowds.

Really amazing. Unfortunately, I couldn't see everything, when I was there. The entrance fee was 1 Euro what I saw was worth much more. When I left, lots of tourists arrived. So I would say, it is better to go there in the morning.

Beautiful detail. For the entrance price this was worth a visit - 10 dirham entrance fee. You can only see a very small part of the palace so only need about 30 mins to an hour here. The courtyards were lovely with orange trees and the architecture and detail on the ceilings is definitely worth seeing. There was less to see than we had expected and all the rooms are unfurnished but as another reviewer said you spend your time staring at the ceilings as they are breathtaking!
Beautiful and the historical. Take the guided tour through. The rooms are exquisite and the Palace has been through so many changes in its existence it's hard to understand without a guide.
Beautiful place. Enjoyed the Palace and walking around. Lets of gorgeous interiors, some of the areas that are run down and neglected are also interesting to see in its unkept stage.

knitted walls. spend your time with your head bended to the top of the building ceilings and doors, marble incredibly worked to appear like a bee nest. You watch it and you ask yourself how many people worked and for how long, and how hard was to prepare such a show for us 500 years later

Lovely palace with magnificent decor and courtyard. The Bahia Palace is a quick and lovely sightseeing element in Marrakesh and costs only 1 Dirham entrance fee.You can see parts of the palace rooms with awesome decorated ceilings and the beautiful floral courtyardIt took us 20 minutes to explore everyting without a guided tour. Unfortunately there are lots of tourists groups, so maybe you should come very early to avoid the masses.
Beautiful!. The palace was very beautiful even though it was not as big we went there a couple of years ago. I would definitely recommended going there if you like traditional arab designs.
Worth the trip. This is a lovely view if old Marrakech and does not take a great deal if time. Well worth it if you are interested in the beautiful gardens and architecture of Morocco

Bahia Palace, if you've got half hour to spare. Seeing as the charge for entry is so small, they don't half grumble if you only have notes in large denominations (as most of the tourists in our queue did). The palace is pretty small but the central garden is quite nice. All the rooms at which you are supposed to marvel are bare and plaster is falling off the walls. The toilets were terrible. All in all we were there for about 20 minutes, it's not worth going to such a horrible part of town for such a tiny adventure.
Go early. Very popular with the tour companies and can become very crowded and a bit of a scrum.Advise is to go early.

Beautiful building. This is a very pretty and impressive building, but there isn't much information about it. We were lucky to have a guidebook with us to tell us what we were looking at, otherwise you're kind of wandering around admiring. Still, it's worth a visit!

Beautiful Colors. The Palace is pretty empty so you will have to use your imagination to view how it must have been decorated. The ceilings wood and colored. The arches have typical Moroccan color and design. The tiles are brightly colored and make good photo opportunities. There is not much English written here and if you want to really enjoy the Palace you should research ahead or have a guide.The entire Palace should take no more than 45 minutes.

Quick visit!. I enjoyed the visit but somehow, although they are two different things, I preferred the Medersa...The palace is nice but I can say it could be better kept, specially the gardens which looked a bit unkempt. In the interior the most interesting things are the carved wooden ceilings (honestly amazing) and the size of the rooms: back in the days it must have been a real cool house :)We are not art experts so we visited without a guide in less than an hour.

Beautiful but not visitor friendly. It's a grand palace with beautiful wood and plaster work. The ceilings in particular are impressive. The building is still in use by the royals, apparently.The problem is, like some reviewers pointed out before, if you don't have a guide, it's just a nice building, with no signs, explanation or history on anything. You just wander around wondering what is what. If you have time to spare, it's worth a peek. If not, the Ben Youssef Merdersa is the place to go.

Beautiful imaginings!. The palace is empty but beautiful tiles, ornate wood work, and fireplaces, graceful archways, and fountains make it fun imagining the people who might have lived in such a place and what it would have looked like with furniture. Worth a visit,
Only interesting if you have a guide. There is no information available without a guide, it is a very interesting place when someone explains it but otherwise it is a series of empty rooms

Beautiful, but hire a guide. I went in 2008 with my cousin, and we just wandered, read our guidebook, and thought it was beautiful. I just went back with my fiance and his mother and a guide, and learned so much more! See if you can hire a guide for your visit, or even for the day, and you will get so much more out of it.

A beautiful building. For those who have been to Seville or Toledo in Spain this place illustrates how Spain and the North African countries were once connected. A bit busy to really enjoy throroughly but well worth a visit.
A Bit Overrated.. I would skip this in favor of the Madrasa if you are short of time. Large place to wander through but not much character.

Pick one. This place is lovely, and is historical. Like a few other palaces or large public places like Ben Youssef Medersea and the Saadian Tombs, the ornate tile and woodwork craftsmanship is exemplary and has a story to tell about the history of Morocco and Marrakech. However, if you have limited time and/or interest, pick one and visit it. At a surface level, you see pretty much the same thing. In this case, it is entirely empty of any furniture, as when its last inhabitant died, his slaves and others stole everything. Best value is Thessalian Tombs - only 10 dirham.

Not inspiring but worth the 75p entrance fee.. Stumbled upon this by chance whist wandering the souks off Jamma El Fna ( main square)..As the title states not awe inspiring but for 75p you are most certainly not being robbed.Small gardens / path, leads to a small palace with mainly mediocre mosaics on walls floors and ceilings.Some rooms are pretty average in design and call me a moron if you like, but some reminded me a bit of old fashioned UK public swimming baths.Some are more intricate, but nothing as facy as the Sistine Chapel here I'm afraid, but there again, what do you expect for 75p.Verdict ?Defenitely worth a visit and it at least provides some shade and half hour respite from being dragged around the souks by my wife, yet again.Do please visit.

not much to see here. we made a detour to see the palace while visiting the souks on marrakech.the road to the palace is more beautiful and interesting than the palace itself with the orange and banana trees (which happened to be fruit laden in spring).the palace is more like a collection of villas joint together most of which seem like large empty rooms with very little in the way of dramatic architecture or decorations which one might expect from a "palace". Most of the rooms (if not all?) are just empty with no furniture or other objects on display.The entry fee is small, so doesnt hurt to go here .... but apart from the shade of the orange trees, not much to see here or do here
Visit. Unfortuantely we got lost from the English group and didn't hear all the details but certainly worth a visit. The ceiling etc are exquisitr.

Just walls, ceilings and floors to be seen.. It was “ok” even with a guide, he was kind of vague on the details but for the concubines..LOL…The walls and ceilings are very pretty, done in mosaic tiles, plaster and wood, some of the floors were very pretty as well. There is no furniture or any other detail other than ceilings, walls and floors, so not much to see once you have seen the first or second room. If pressed for time, I would skip this one, I didn't find it very interesting.
Beautiful. Visited the palace on my first day in Marrakech and was overwhelmed by the mosaics, carvings , architecture and beauty of the place. Not to be missed.
palace. Exotic courtyards colourful tiled floors beautifully patterned ceilings. altogether a feast for the eyes and soul.

Fascinating visit. Located to the top end of the Medina the Bahia Palace is an interesting step into Morocco's past, great decoration throughout albeit empty. Very busy the day we went and no cafe facilities within the grounds but a good restaurant next door which overlooks the palace gardens.
Nice Islamic Architecture. When you like the Islamic architecture, this visit is a must, much like Granada. And, as usual in Morocco, very democratic admittance fee, and not overcrowded either.

Reminescent of Alhambra.. A beautiful palace worth exploring for it's gorgeous ceilings and doorways. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Marrakech. It's only about a 15 - 20 minute walk from Jma el Fnaa.

Must see sight. An amazing piece of Marrakech history and a must to go and see.
The architecture is stunning and the gardens beautifully kept. Take your time strolling through and into many courtyards and elegant rooms.
The huge concubine living quarters are of particular interest.

Fantastic Craftmanship. Just off the main Square well wort a visit for the ornate wood carvings & ornate ceilings.There is no furniture but fantastic fireplace, doors & ceilings plus a lovely courtyard full of orange trees.As with other places visited they miss a trick not providing foreign language audio guides or info sheets are we would have been intrigued to find out more about the Palaces history.They could charge a bit more to cover costs as it was incredibly cheap.

Nothing Particularly Special. This palace was on the top of my list of things to see in Marrakech after reading about it on TripAdvisor and in guide books. Unfortunately, I left feeling unimpressed. The entry fee is a cheap 10 dirhams, and there are some cool looking mosaics on the walls and ceilings. However, the palace is mostly run down and faded. We spent less than an hour here, and moved on.
What a dump!. The builders obviously had delusions of grandeur. This place is nothing special. If you have some time to waste, come here to get away from that godawful square.

Nothing outstanding. This is not a particularly interesting venue. In common with most of the palaces in Marrakesh, it has been stripped of its furniture and artefacts or perhaps they were never there in the first place. It just hits the average mark as indeed do most of the attractions in Marrakesh.Entry is cheap, but it falls well short of even the most average of palaces or attractions in Europe. Do not become too excited anticipation of your visit. Not sure that we would recommend it as a "must go and see place".

Bahia Palace. Very quaint. Very cheap entry. You can get some lovely camera shots here. There were no queues as we went early in the year. Would definately recommend a visit. Doesn't take very long to walk round.
Closes early. Went here to find it just closing, not so good as it was mid afternoon. You need to plan your visit and check opening times.

Mosaic palace. Good value well kept and had toilets however no cafe or eating area The mosaics were lovely we took lots of pictures and have some nice decldorating ideas. It was interesting to see how people would have lived in the palace however there was no guide or translations in English. We could only imagine what it was like when it was someones home.

A must see. El Bahia Palace is one of the must see attractions in Marrakech, Morocco. Intricate mosaic work combined with relaxing floral gardens. Make sure you visit on a quiet week day, not a Friday or a weekend. Allow 2 to 3 hours to look around, no more.
Really interesting visit. This was a really interesting place to visit, with the rich decoration, and traditional architecture. A guide is worthwhile.

nice architecture. Bahia palace is representative of Morroco architecture, it will give you a feel of the country.
It is a nice visit!
grand living, old style. We had a guided tour here. Very grand, lots of incredible decorations. Well worth an hour. It's good that photos are allowed.
interesting architecture. This place has very interesting architecture. Loved the mosaic floor tiles and decorated ceilings. Definitely worth a visit. There were a lot of stray (?) cats in the area.

Well worth a visit.. For only 10 DH each this is a lovely place to visit. Beautiful stone work and mosaics. It would have been nice to see some wall coverings and furnature but the ceilings were quite superb.
Bahia palace. A very beautiful palace, certainly worth the visit..it will take you a while to see this place..but take your time..

Well worth the entry fee.. Normally 10 dirhams entry but we got in free as it was world heritage day. Amazing mosaics, ceilings, tiles and stucco work. We had a guide book which was useful as there were few signs in English. To do it justice you need a official guide.

Well worth a visit. We did this attraction as part of a tour and had a really good local guide. The palace itself is interesting, particularly the blend of styles which are the new Moorish style and I particularly liked the cedar ceilings which had a lot of intricate work completed in every room. Definitely worthy of a look if you ate in the city.
Nice Palace. Beautiful place....nice small of wild orange flowers at the entrance...nice gardens inside...really arabic. It is quite similiar as palaces in Andalucia (South of Spain) but less rich.

interesting place. Interesting place if you obviously like history. I think its important to have a good tour guide with you as it definitely made all the difference for us. I had my twelve year old with me who usually finds this kind of thing boring but she too liked it.

Just try to imagine it alive... . The tickets cost only 1? and it's also peaceful place after the notice of moroccan people and roads. A nice garden is leading you inside of the palace. Unfortunately no sing in English so if you want informations find a guide, otherwise just look around that morrokean architecture and try to imagine how was the living days of the palace! Although the Palace could be better reserved.

Very important Monument, don't Miss. Upon our Visit to Morocco with Travel Tours Morocco, our guide took us to Bahia Palace. which is a very wonderful palace. The Palace built in an Arabo-Islamic Style.. it's a very important place to visite when you are in Marrakech.

Worth a visit. Nice peaceful, good value, visit. With some attempt to tell the story, it would have been worth 5 stars as obviously some history here, but without a guide it was difficult to know. Definitely worth 30 mins walk before heading to the nearby Kosybar for lunch on the rooftop!
small but stunning. if you like architecture....its beautiful.....the ceilings are stunning mosaics and the courtyards tranquility mixed with simplicity......and great planting in the garden rooms

Very Pretty. very pretty palace, very well preserved with much stone and iron work remaining. It was easy to walk through - however signage did not include English so it was hard to understand what we were looking at.
Bahia Palace January. really beautiful and better than we were expecting it to be and great space for a toddler to run around without distrubing anyone
Stunning mosaics. A very calm quiet place to look round with beautiful carvings and mosaics. It was well worth the visit.
beautiful ceilings. definitely worth the trip. wander through - take your time and imagine what once was in this palace!
beautiful. just lovely and well worth the visit. Only £1 to get in and its just lovely to walk around. There are lovely examples of Moroccan architecture and beautiful artwork on the ceilings.
Very interesting and beautiful. A little oasis of calm! Very pretty mosaics on the walls, floors and ceilings plus courtyards, fountains and gardens. Reminded me of Granada's Alhambra
Islamic interiors. Wonderful ceilings in empty rooms. You can only wonder what the Palace would have looked like in its heyday.

Not really my thing but very beautiful. The palace is gorgeous and very big. There are many rooms and sections to see. There are some picturesque carvings on walls and door ways. I appreciated it's beauty.

Good value, doesn't take too long. Only cheap to visit and is beautiful. It is worth getting a guide though as there is little in the way of information at all and nothing in English so we eavesdropped other groups but I expect we missed a lot.
Beautiful place. Lovely tiles and facinating place.The large space is beautiful and well worth a visit.It could do with a bit more history and somekind of timeline which would be very useful.

A quiet retreat from the noise of the southern medina. The Bahia Palace is at the southern end of the Rue Riad Zitoun Jdid, and part of the fun in getting there (if you are coming from the northern end of Place Jemaa-el-Fna) is the walk along this narrow road to the palace. The road is lined with all sorts of interesting shops on both sides and there are intriguing alleys to explore off the side of this road. However it is not a quiet walk as it is a busy thoroughfare for motorcyclists, who I am sure can use other access roads but probably enjoy hassling the tourists who frequent this area.So when you arrive at the Bahia Palace the calmness that greets you is such a welcome relief. There are orange trees lining the entrance which when we visited were heavy with fruit. The palace itself is devoid of furniture, which is a shame, but the architecture is beautiful and there is still a lot to see - tranquil courtyards, ornate ceilings, intricately tiled floors and carved doors.It costs 10 dirhams to enter and if you are short of time, this is a much better attraction to visit than the Ben Youssef Merdesa or the Museum of Marrakech.
Worth a visit. For 10dh you can't go wrong, a few signs with information would be nice, not everyone arrives with a guide

One of the few authentic architectural beauties of Marrakech. Well worth the 10 Dirham for the visit. Nice tile work and architecture of Morocco which is hard to spot elsewhere in the city. A nice break from people relentlessly trying to sell you something.
Splendor of the old Cadis. Visiting the Bahia Palace is easy tourism as it's literally right next to Riad Hayati. You really get an excellent idea of how the old rulers lived.

Palace Guide. If you can get one then its very interesting, as they tell you how they lived in the palace eg, he told us the musicians were blind so they wouldnt look at the women, about how the architecture was chosen, the passages are small so no one could look in another room etc Good photo ops as well
My favourite place in Marrakech. Loved it. Can't beat the price. So beautiful and serene. Lots of lovely cats. Brilliant for a wander round somewhere traditional. Definitely go.
Good view but quiet. You get to see all the sites by using one of the many horse carriages for £15, very nice pictures but average overall
Stunning. Well worth the trip there although its a maze so a guide would be helpful. We arranged a guide through our riad and it was free! Bargain

Brilliant. Masive palace modeled on palace in Granada Spain. Cost us 80pence each to get in, when we saw the inside hard to believe next to main area of Marrakech it is massive inside. Lots of interesting things to see underground rooms etc. is in the process of being done up but really good now. Storks nesting on the top of walls. DO NOT MISS THIS

Step back in time. One of the great things about visiting the sites in Marakkesh is that most all of them allow you to talk freely in any direction you want. The tours are not guided and very little is off limits. This allowed me to stroll through the gardens, wander the halls and find something to see in every nook and cranny. The mosaic work is incredible. From the windows to the walls, the floors to the ceilings - the colorful tile and inlay dazzled the eye. Some rooms had ornate iron work for skylights and there were many Moroccan-style chandeliers to appreciate. There are many cats that wander the grounds. I was fortunate to be traveling with a Frenchman - so he read all the descriptive signs to me. Everything is in Arabic or French so hire an English-speaking guide if you want explanations. The palace is on the outskirts of the medina. Depending on where you are staying, it can be a lengthier walk. I recommend going in the morning when it is cooler and you have the most energy. The crowd is light and the morning breezes through the palace are lovely. From the palace you can work your way back through the colorful souks. It is an enchanting and serene experience to contrast with the bustle of the souks.
Beautiful mosaics. Beautiful place, beautiful mosaics but please have a guide to tell you more about the place and its history.
Bahia Palace. beautiful architecture, well worth a visit. best to read up on the history before going unless you have a guide, or your french is fluent.

A visual feast!. As beautiful as ever this is a visual treat that should not be missed. One can still imagine the life that was led in the exquisitely decorated rooms and how the walls would have echoed with the sound of the wive's and children's laughter! There are cool courtyards with fountains and greenery, painted ceilings and doors, arabic friezes and endless rooms of colourful,patterned mosaic tiles. It's difficult to choose a favourite room and this is all for just 10Dhm, €1, there can't be better value anywhere!In comparison, the Saadi tombs are disappointing as the rooms are internally inaccessible - this palace tops my list of places to visit.

Must See ! Bahia Palace. Moorish ceramic tile extravaganza! Beautiful examples of inlaid timber and decorated plaster work. Fruit Grove courtyards with water features create a symphony of design.When you visit this palace you will have an appreciation of how the royals lived and you will see a fine example of daily life.

Needs signage. We spent a day independently in Marrakech and visited the palace. An amazing place but with no signage telling the visitor what the numerous areas were used for or any description of the magnificent decoration. Nor even a descriptive leaflet! Later in our holiday we went on a guided half day tour of historical buildings and revisited the Bahia Palace. The guide was extremely knowledgeable about the history (only built in 19thC) and explained the decoration, translating the Arabic poetry included in the decoration and describing the use each room was put to. Well worth a visit (entry fee is very cheap) but worth having a guided tour if you want to know anything about the building. The building deserves a rating of 4/5 but is marred by lack of information.

Beautiful but needs some work.. Loved the storks but the building needs some work. Obviously it must be very expensive for a poor country to pay for all the upkeep on the building but there is a real contrast with rich and poor here. The very rich could pay for more improvements perhaps?
Great example of Moroccan architecture. Some beautiful designs and architecture, and a nice place to escape from the mid-day sun! High recommended

Bare and boring. For 10Dh admission fee I should not be expecting much but this place is really overrated and not very interesting, just a large building with empty rooms with pretty floor tiles. If you'd like to see something more impressive I strongly suggest the Mamounia Hotel near Koutoubia Mosque. It's free to enter as long as you are appropriately dressed.

What a lovely place to visit!. I had hired a guide to take me to a number of places while in Marrakech and this was one of them. It was lovely and he knew the history of it. I saw a number of other folks in groups with a guide speaking their specific language. I think I got more out of the place with it just being me and a guide. I would say plan to spend about 1 hour+ here and go early in the morning before it gets too crowded.
Gorgeous surroundings. Lovely place to visit, peaceful and serene. The detail in the building, inside and out is amazing. Again, only a euro to enter well worth it

Very busy!. We visited around mid- morning, which seemed to be prime time for tour groups. As such, it was hard to take a photo without thousands of other people in it! This was the first of the palaces we visited and it is truly beautiful. Don't forget your guide book though as there are no explanations at all!
Overrated. Bare except for one stunning orange-tree courtyard. Maybe worth the cheap entrance fee just for that but the architecture of Dar Si Said or Musee de Marrakech far outshines it.

Worth an hour or so of anyone's time. I'll take issue with my guidebook here, which is distinctly sniffy about the Bahia Palace, dismissing it as a series of empty rooms and uninspiring courtyards. I found it a most enjoyable place to simply wander around in and marvel at the scale and intricacy of the painted ceilings and doorways. Marrakech is a little light on grand buildings and 'must see' attractions, so why miss out on somewhere that provides a cool and shady retreat from the hot crowded streets?

An insight into the past.. The palace only has certain parts open to tourists. As you wander round you can imagine how beautiful it was although maybe not for the 24 concubines! The tiling and the tradition behind their designs is fabulous and in its former glory must have looked amazing.
Tranquil. A lovely place with elegant cedar wood ceilings and tiling. Cool and spacious although not as beautiful as the rooms in the Dar Si Said Museum

Well worth a visit for 10 DH about 1 pound.. The architecture is wonderful, the Painted ceilings and doors are not to be missed. The colours of the paints used are beautiful. The garden in the centre square is lovely and greet. I loved this place on arrival it does not look like much but is well worth it
Ornate Palace. Superb insight in to the lives of the Moroccan nobility from the days when Marrakech was a centre of power.
Palatial experience. So different from European palaces and absolutely gorgeous in its own right. Definitely a must see on any Marrakech excursion.

A must visit location.. Nothing to dislike. A great historical site well worth a visit. An oasis of peace and calm in th emidst of bustling Marrakech. Wonderful courtyards with ponds, fountains and trees, the sounds of birds singing, cooll and calm. Wonderful architecture and amazing mosaics. Give yourself loads of time to get lost in this treasure. And at 10 Dirham for entry it's a must.

Not very interesting. Hard to find in the first place. Not so interesting to see, all rooms look alike and no explination, only at the entreance in french and arabic. Beautiful ceilings though. 10 dirham for adults and 3 for infants.

Peaceful place to while away an hour.. Lovely to amble round, but bring your guide book, or cough up for a guide (available in a myriad of languages) as there is little information around about the palace. Or do what I did and eavesdrop on several groups... What remains is beautiful; the ceilings especially so. Toilets good and clean.

Amazing architecture. Though it is not that old, it has a great architecture and one can see how the houses of rich people use to look before. Dozen of smaller and bigger rooms with a beautiful courtyard can keep you busy for about an hour, just watch for the opening hours (they close around noon time) and try to avoid the crowds.

Could be great, but no info / effort. So, it's only £1 to get in, but they should charge more and give you some idea what you're looking at. It clearly was an amazing palace at one point, but now it's just a collection of empty rooms that have nice ceilings.... We were there for about 5 minutes.If they put a bit of effort into it and had some more info I'm sure this would be more like a 4/5 rating.That said, it is pretty close to the square and cheap so worth popping your head in to get an idea.

Uninteresting Architecture, Little History. Frankly, this palace was the least palace-like palace I've ever visited. The architecture was uninspiring, the walls were dirty, and the history is simply not very interesting. It only cost 10 dirham (about 1 euro) to enter, but I don't think it's even worth that much. If you're in Marrakech for several days, consider visiting it, but you're not missing out if you don't.

The splendour that was 19th century Marrakech. A good place to see the luxurious quarters the rich of Marrakech enjoyed around as recently as 100 years ago. (In this case Si Moussa and his son Bou Ahmed, a King's chamberlain).Good place to go if you're interested in muslim architecture and design.

The Beautiful Palace. This 19th-century palace, once home to a harem with 24 concubines, is a beautiful combination of painted and carved wood, ceramics, and symmetrical gardens. It was built in the late 19th century, intended to be the greatest palace of its time. The name means "brilliance". The building is an excellent example of Eastern Architecture from the 19th century that shows how the wealthy lived at that time. The detail may not be as rich as that found in earlier palaces, but it is nevertheless still significant. Make sure you look up at the smooth arches, carved cedar and beautifully painted ceilings, shiny marble finishes, and stucco plasterwork. The rooms vary in size according to the importance of each wife or concubine, and there are 160 rooms sprawled out in an open, rambling fashion. The reception halls and private quarters are lavishly decorated and there are several tiled courts – often complete with water features – that serve as open air areas where the women could have washed and rested themselves. We were fortunate to have the services of an excellent guide for our tour of the palace, which was great because with so many rooms and passageways, etc, it’s probably very easy to get lost! So when you visit Marrakech, don’t miss the Bahia Palace.

The Beautiful Palace. Exquisite palace with exterior garden with kitties and banana trees.Only 10 dihrams to go in (about one Euro).The most wonderful interior courtyard is currently being restored.Next year inshallah!Still worth visiting now.

Beautiful carvings and painted rooms. A feast for the lens. You step back in time to a more opulent time. Even without a guide, you will love it. Pick one of the thousands of oranges growing, they don't mind.
Ok. It's an interesting place but if you are well travelled, don't expect an amazing palace, it is quite small
Amazing architecture. Beautiful example of Moroccan architecture and culture. Lots of great picture-taking opportunities. Don't miss this if you have the time.

beautiful building. This is a beautiful palace in the Medina. Entrance fee was 10Dirhams per person. The palace is definately worth the visit. Just to walk around in the peace and beauty of the building is very relaxing and should be on your 'must-do' list when visiting Marrakech.There are locals walking around near the palace (a block away) who would approach any tourist and say the palace was closed and try to redirect you to something else (probably their shops). Just ignore them, as we discovered they were not truthful and the palace was actually open all day.
so calm in the madness. easy to walk to, only 1 euro to visit well worth an afternoon just to see the mosaics and carvings, so lovely

Beautiful ceilings and doors. Not a very old place, but well equipped with wonderfully carved wooden ceilings and doors. Can be seen in well under an hour. Shouid be included in your top 10 list when visiting Marakech.
storks rule. The museum was nice but the storks and the view of the Atlas were the stars of the show. There was also an art exhibition in one of teh harem rooms which was interesting.
Stunning. Quite beautiful and definitely a camera-worthy place. It was a lovely place to spend some time and full of history.
Interesting. A beautiful building but perhaps you do not need to see this and the Medersa B Youssef, which is very similar and better. However this has gardens and may be easier to access.

Sultry. Sultry palace!! It reminds a lot of Topkapi palace in Istanbul in terms of architecture even is this is much smaller.
It def worths a visit!

Stunning place. It was a stunning place to see, such unique architecture. It was fairly empty on our visit, with only one tour group going around, and a few families. This made good opportunity for good photo shots. The décor look amazing, however the information of the walls in one of the rooms was in French or Arabic, but I was to interested in the patterns on the walls, floors and doors as I needed cultural photos for my upcoming art GCSE exam, this makes excellent links to travel, as it shows another culture style. The only problem we encountered was the toilets seemed to have run out of toilet paper, I think it applies to majority of sights, so make sure you have spare on you.If you have a spare 1-2 hours, I recommend a visit to this place as you will be taken away by the interior of it and it has a good range of photo opportunities

To appreciate the morrocan architecture. A bit busy, with a lot of tour guides and groups,but it is worth the visit. Take your time and appreciate the details of the tiles, the doors, the floors and get inspired...
Wonderful architecture!. Very good to do alongside of the Saadian Tombs as they are close by. Very ornate mosaics on floors and walls. Beautiful ceilings and courtyards! Really worth seeing.

Well worth a visit. A very innocuous looking place, very easy to miss the entrance. The route is laid out for visitors with plenty of signs once you are in there. No shop or tea room though so they are, unusually, missing on opportunity there!The rooms we visited had a beautiful level of detail - the photos are better than any explanation. 10 dhirams to get in (about 80p). It wasn't crowded at all when we visited and there were no pushy guides either.

Unfurnished. Loved the architecture with its inticately decorated arches, it's many courtyards & beautiful mosaic work & light fixtures, but it would be nicer if at least one of the rooms was furnished, with that periods furniture and accessories, to give the visitors an idea of how it would have looked furnished during that time period. You see that in all the palaces in Europe & Asia. It makes it more interesting & gives you more of a picture.
Boring!. VEry boring, nothing really to see. It costs 10 dirham to get in. But not really worth going! The quaran school is more interesting than the Bahia Palace.
too busy. we went with a guide to visit, while i am glad i did see it, i feel it was to busy and too small to enjoy

Great and cheap for history buffs. A well-preserved example of the past glory and intricate architecture of Marrakech. Once you know the history it is more impressive. Fits well with visits to the Saardian tombs and the Badia Palace which are also very cheap admission.

Barebones moorish relic.. Not much here in the way of outstanding architecture. A few nice ceilings, some old tile work, etc.Like most of Marrakesh this is a disappointment.The thing is, when your there you have to do something, so you join the meager legions of tourists flowing into this and other poorly maintained and exhibited "points of interest".If this and let say, the Badi Palace were in Paris, Rome, or Miami they would be considered eye sours and no one would pay anything to see them.Avoid at all costs!
Beautiful. Well worth a second visit - we spotted loads of detail that we didn't notice on our first trip. Don't miss this!
Magnificent!!. Truly gorgeous architecture, and wonderful detail on the ceilings and columns. It got a lot busier as we left so worth getting there early. Definitely worth the entry fee!
Historic space. Interesting experience but lacked any background historical information. The palace walls offered a great view of Marrakesh.

Bahia Palace. Sort of boring. No furnishings whatsoever. The garden had very few flowers. The courtyards were much more barren than in Spain. The ceilings were ornate, very reminiscent of Granada. Worth visiting if you are nearby; otherwise, don't make a special trip.

Great palace with beautiful ceiling.. It was a pleasure to visit this palace. So beautiful and rich. There is so many rooms and there are huge one. I would come back here. Highly recommended. Entrance price is 10 dirhams.

An andalouse Sphere. This place looks like the Alhambra in Grenada, Spain! But the main difference this building was still occupied a century ago. This Palace is wonderful of colours. The roof are fantastics.
grand ceilings. This is how the rich lived - that's what you would expect. The ceilings are fabulous and in extremely good condition.

A grand palace but in need of some repairs. It is well worth visiting the Bahia Palace. You can see the palace once being the focus of attention, it is very grand and exclusive.Having said this, it looks like parts of the palace are in need of some repairs, it should be done so that the visitors can appreciate the beauty of the place once again.Worth a visit if you are in Marrakech.
A must see. I can't believe this palace is not better known and publicised. Although not on the same scale, in my view it matches the Alhambra in Granada in many respects.
It's Worth a Visit. While this palace won't blow the seasoned traveler away, it's nice and worth a visit to take a few photos.
Ornate. the palace is beautifully kept. It's very ornate as you would expect so have your camera at the ready or better still your camcorder.

try the restaurant next door. like many sites in Marrakech its much smaller than you think its going to be rather like the saddien tombs but as you leave turn right and next door is the Bahia restaurant which is excellent
Ancient Sultan's Palace. This is easy sight-seeing because it is literally right next to Riad Hayati. Just pop over for an hour and get a glimpse of what likfe was like for the sultans of Marrakech.
A micro-mini Alhambra. Entrance fee only 10 MAD or about 1 euro and it is worth that. A quick 10 minute walk around to see some nice Moroccan tile work.

Worth a look and is nice and peaceful. The palace is unoccupied and empty. There's a nice courtyard and some lovely painted ceilings to see. It doesn't cost much to look round so offers a bit of calm compared to the streets outside.
Value for money. It was a bit boring, but then again was only $1 so what can you expect! The storks were the best part!

The Beautiful Palace. Named after the sultan's 4-th wife, a beautiful one, the place is a piece of art. With its laced stone, perfect tile work and harmonious interiors, it will capture your attention.

Worth a visit. A grand viziers palace about 150 years old. A succession of about 60 tiled rooms, courtyards, boudoirs etc. The perambulation is a bit dull, but worth it for the magificent carving and decoration
A good example of a typical plaace. Nicely maintained and a good example of Moroccan architecture. Worth the price of admission to see how royalty lived.
Ceiings. Beautiful place but a bit run down.Never mind as it is still great place to visit.The doors that are on pivots are a wonder.
Interesting. The building is interesting and yet it lacks furniture and fittings. I had the impression that something was mmissing. Still worth a visit if you're in Marrakech.

Better than the Alhambra Granada. Bahia Palace was one of the most memorable buildings I have ever visited. The plasterwork and wood carvings were stunning. Our guide explained the intricacies of the carvings and what they represented.
Verey special. A magic Place.You can feel the atmosfere in that time with ladies and business men around the roons, fountains.Great Riad to visit.Great gardens.

Very interesting, well worth a visit. We went to the Bahia Palace with a guide, which was well worth it because I suspect it would be tricky to find on your own. With the benefit of our guide, we had the opportunity to hear the history, what the different rooms were used for, how the French occupation changed the building's architecture and how the palace operated. It's a beautiful palace, rich in history and cultural heritage. The mosaic work is outstanding. Despite it being low tourist season there were many people going through the palace. Not sure it's somewhere to take children as it's more about the architecture as opposed to things while will entertain kids. Recommend visiting.

Storks and palaces. This took a bit of finding let me tell you! It's pretty much a ruin now but you can imagine it in the past and love the storks who live there. The Minbar is worth a look- 12th century work.
over crowded. Crowds of people swarmed throughout the Palace, which felt like several Riads joined together. Lots of amazing carving and mosaic.

Worth a visit. We visited this when we were wrongly told that the the Badhi Palace was "closed" - a favourite trick of the residents. However, it was worth a trip and the delightful painted doors and designs were lovely to look at.
Do not miss the ceilings. This palace is quite small but impressive. The details are beautiful (look closely at the roofs) and the entry fee is low. However, the Kasbah in Teluet was more impressive.

Well Worth a Tour. We visited El Bahia Palace as part of a cruiseline tour and we were not disappointed. The palace was built, in the Alawi style popular in the 19th century, by Abu Ahmed for his concubines, and it's named after one of them. The mosaics are incredible. Many of the rooms open onto elaborate courtyards, complete with large water basins where the women likely bathed and gathered to gossip. If there is royalty visiting Marrakech they will stay at the palace and no tourists will be allowed, so take advantage when it's open. You will not be disappointed. My only complaint is that we saw so few of its 160+ rooms. If you're not with a tour group the fee is really reasonable, about 10 dirhams.

Lavish Interior Decor. A 5 min walk from Jemaa El Fna and a £1 entry fee is the comparitivelly small, though beautiful decoratted Palace. A plesent walk down the quiet driveway leads to the interior which is impressivelly coverred with zellij tiling, sculpturred stucco and carved cedar wood. We found it to be very impressive, very Morrocan and when we went in January very quiet. Worth a visit.

The beauty is in the detail.... Architecturally, the walls and buildings are unprepossessing but the courtyards and interiors are gems.The courtyards are well planted and well maintained and very attractive with colourful mosaic pathways and beautiful wood and stonework around the copings under the roofs. There's a mirror in the entry on the south side of the first courtyard which is reflected by another on the north side. Thoughts of infinity? The insides of the buildings are also fantastically well decorated. You can end up with a cricked neck due to the beauty of the ceilings. Taking painting, marquetry, and mosaic the rooms are a tribute to Islamic art.There are resident, very well fed, cats.
Very pretty!. A very beautiful palace with the typical moroccan decoration, totally worth a visit! Also here, you can take plenty of pretty pictures.
Excellent Moroccan Architecture. The architecture, design and decoration of this palace is wonderful. It is a must see if you're in Marrakesh.
Interesting. After the castles, cathedrals, etc., in Spain this was a bit disappointing. Not that impressive. Some nice architecture but Spain was much move interesting.

an unexpected surprise. We visited in December 2012 and didn't know anything about it apart from its mention on a map of Marrakech. It is well worth seeing and is very cheap to visit - about £1 each. We wandered round ourselves but there were tour guides showing people around. If I was to visit again, I would find out about its history in advance so I knew what I was looking at. It was only afterwards that I found out about its history.
Not a lot to see. The only cultural element to our trip was a disappointment - poorly explained or described, not sure what what was what or what the 'fuss' was about!

If you are visiting the Badia and Bahia Palaces..... We first visited the El Badia Palace before visiting the Bahia palace. If you want to visit both of them it is important to visit the El Badia palace first...otherwise you will be extremely disappointed.The Bahia palace is wonderful, beautiful mosaics, architecture, etc. The El Badia palace is virtually ruins but still worth a visit.Entrance fees are very inexpensive, I believe 10 Dirhams.
For 10 Dh each you can't complain!. When you actually find this place it is lovely to walk round. Theres not a great deal to see, but the palace is nice and the gardens are too.
