Oasis in the middle of the town. We visited it with guided group. Learned a lot of life many years ago. Nice architecture, specially mosaics are beautiful. A lot of orange trees (we were there in March) and colorful shrubbery made this courtyard magnificent. Reasonable entrance fee. I recommend to visit it when you are in Marrakech.

Excellent display of Maroc architecture. French architect with dotted influences I visited this site with a guide who described the architecture, rooms, etc. Reading about it alone ad visiting it without one would prove useless. Most rooms are similar and the exciting bits are in the details.

Amazing piece of culture and history. Loved this palace, conjured up images of what it would have been like hundreds of years before. Mosaics beautiful.
Very reasonable entrance fees

Ancient palace right next to Hayati. This is easy sight-seeing, It is literally a minute's walk from the Riad. The courtyards are huge and you really get an idea what life was life for the ancient rulers.
impressive. large, beautiful but very empty, but a lovely building,could have done with a cafe, right next to the jewish market worth a visit

What a palace. This is place that worth the visit with a local guide! He will introduce you details that you could not see by yourself! The details are great! The natural colors of ceiling , the doors, the art! I loved!

Wonderful pulpit is worth the walk!. The ruins give a sense of teh scale of what must have been before, but are just ruined walls, albeit still very high. The pulpit (south east corner) is simply extraordinary in its craftsmanship and beauty

The Old Palace. We visited this site on our own with little difficulty. When you come from the Medina or Square, turn right as you go through the arches. There is work currently being done to continue preservation to this very historic building. If you climb the stairs you will get a good view of the surrounding area, and perhaps pick your lunch spot as we did. Some of the tile work is still in tact which is beautiful. This place is close to the souks as well as clost to the Musee d'Art Morroccan.
So... very... beautiful.... Set in its own lovely garden, the Bahia palace is, one room after another, sumptuously gorgeous. The admission fee is not very expensive. It's well worth seeing.
Al Hambra is much better. Some very pretty rooms admittedly but it is only 150 years old. There are so many places in Islamic countries or those with Islamic heritage that have more to offer
Bahia. Beautiful. Pay particular attention to the tiles and the ceilings. The amount and quality of work in them is stunning
Old Sultan's Palace. The Bahia is right next to Hayati. You can walk there in two minutes and get a glimpse of what the old sultans lived like.

Needs a power washer. You can see how beautiful this palace must have been in its heyday but it hasn't been well maintained. There are a few rooms with some items displayed but overall it's mostly empty. Still, is a refreshing stop over from the hectic streets of Marrakech.
How the sultans used to live. This is an excellent place to visit to see how the rulers lived in the early 19thC. The architecture is interesting and the gardens are extensive.

Serene and beautiful. This palace was a welcome oasis to escape the traffic fumes of the medina for about 45 minutes. Entrance was 10dh. During the short stroll through the entrance garden we were immediately transported into a world of peace. The palace itself is empty of any furniture and there were only a handful of rooms and courtyards accessible to the public so the visit did not take long but its wonder lies in the palace's spectacular ceilings, door panels, carving and tilework. The decoration and craftsmanship of these features is magnificent and a must for anyone interested in photography. The downside is the lack of information (nothing in English and only a couple of panels in French & Arabic).
If you are close give it a go. The palace is ok. It's Moroccan. It's antique. It not so special. But if your'e close, give it a go. You may be lucky and shoot an nice picture.
bahia is the nicest place in marrakech. Amazing palace, a oasis of peace in a horrible medina.. Beautiful architecture. I loved it. I would go again

Nice but what is the story?. Beautiful place but was packed with tourists so leaving you no room to appreciated fully. Not much descriptions does not help either. The staff at the tickets office was rude and refuse to sell any tickets if you didn't hand him the right change (10 or 20 D)! Not a good experience!

A palace without furniture. It is a place where you can take a brake from the hectic street life outside the walls of the Bahia Palace. The problem with this palace is the fact that there is no explanation at all. You just need to follow the arrows that guide you trough the palace and take a look at the different rooms, tiles and ceiling decorations. The fact that the palace lacked furniture didn't make it any easier to find out where they used to use the rooms for.

Nice looking place - not enough descriptions however.... Nice looking 19th century palace and good stroll around - shame not enough descriptions about each of the rooms there... Lack of furniture is also a slight let down but overall it's a pretty decent walk tour from Djemaa El Fna...
A Relaxed, Beautiful Stop. If you're looking for respite from the souk bargaining, this is a relaxed, beautiful palace showing older architecture. Lots of places for photo opportunities throughout.
Worth it. Only 10dh to enter and you can take lovely pictures. The architecture and design is amazing and its close to Badi Palace. Must go

A waste of time. Not sure what we missed reading the top reviews for this? It was almost a total waste. There are no descriptions or handouts on what rooms you are looking at, and there are no items to view outside of the typical cedar painted and carved moldings & plaster murals. If the personnel there had spent any time putting up some displays or paintings or something it would have held some kind of interest. Even if you speak French, there really is not much to read. We just sort of wandered around wondering - is this it? Dar Si Said instead, it's less than 5 minutes to walk to & for the same price you have some historical items to look at with the similar cedar carvings and painted tiles.
Nice place to visit. Lovely place to visit. Signs in the palace are in French and Arabic, so unless you are part of a guided tour you will not understand much of the history.
Bahia Palace. This site is beautiful and worth seeing. The history of the site was amazing and was beautifully restored.

Bahia Palace highly recommended. The Bahia Palace is gorgeous - beautiful arabic script, zillij (decorated, glazed tiles); and antique carved doors. The architecture is fascinating - there were 2 architects - father and son.

Power doesn'tlast. Not too many people looking round it so could hear the birds and stroke a local cat.Fot anyone who learned Ozymandius at school it had that sort of feeling, a man who had been all powerful but his palace torn apart by a later ruler. A bit creepy if you're in the mood and good value although not necessary to bother with the extra 10D for the museum bit

excellant example of moroccan architecture. It not big and won't take a lot of time to visit but it is gorgeous. A must see if you are into the architecture...There is a "tourist " hammam nearby too...check it out...ask for Mina.

Interesting. Although this is by no means the grandest of palaces we have ever visited it does give an insight into life in the past. Don't expect too much but enjoy the existing rooms and hints of the gardens. A short visit is worthwhile.
Pretty Disappointing. Worth a look but pretty ordinary - some nice mosaics but the buildings aren't particularly interesting compared to other similar sites that we have visited.
Discover Marrakech. This is very beautiful such a contrast to the surrounding area, again having background information helps and our guide was very good.
Lots of details. beautiful architecture, informative tour guides and getting there includes an interesting walk down the alleyways. clean, western bathrooms are a plus!
Impressive!. We had a private guided tour around the palace, you need a good tour guide or a very good guide book to enlighten you on the history of this palace. Well worth a visit

nice palace. This palace is very nice with not very old architecture from the 19th century. Nice rooms with decorated ceilings with wooden work and painted really nicely. The inner courtyards are really impressive.

Definitely worth visiting. Visited just after 3pm, 10 dirham entry fee, this was one of my highlights of the trip, the superb architecture, tiling and woodwork really stands out and must have been an amazing home in the past.Lots of unfurnished rooms which you can take in at your leisure, a great place to escape from the main square and souks. Well signposted too!
Amazing detail. Such beautiful carving, tiling, painting. Would work better I feel if they had at least one room decorated with furniture etc as it would have been in its hey day.
Beautiful. Very nice place to visit.... entrance is very cheap, the visit is interesting, with enough informations on the wall. A must see!
Nicely preserved. Nicely preserved with wonderful architecture. Nothing exciting, just a relaxing stroll through a historic building.
Nice attraction. Worth the visit :-). This was a nice place to visit. We took some good photos, we saw interesting mosaics and we felt like it was a traditional Moroccan experience.
Nice place. Really a nice place to visit, built in the 19th century, 150 rooms, great courtyards, but should really be renovated. It's probably the nicest palace we've visited in Marrakech.

Awesome craftmanship. Every room is different, but every room is perfect. Mosaic tiling on floor and walls,Carved white Stucco work above the tiles then the most detailed roof panelling I have seen. Good guide book helps to explain what each room was used for. But you can just go and admire the craftmanship.

Beautiful! do not miss it!. Incredibly crafted palace of teh 19th century... everywhere you look it is magnificent... a feast for the eyes... perhaps take a guide if you wish to understand the history of the place.
Go here with a good guide. Again, if you don't bring a guide, you will not understand any of the history of the building and the significance of each room.
Beautiful Architecture. Very ornate building with lots of marble, carved doors and spectacular ceilings. We went as part of an organised trip so got the low-down from our well informed guide.
What a life. More people around at this site. How did the King cope with all his wives and concubines. Ceiling wall and floor decorations stunning.

A glimpse of the luxurious past. If you have any interest in the architecture/history of the country thenThe Bahia Palace must be on your visiting list. The detail of the ceilings and mosaics is stunning.There are three distinct areas: one for the harem, one for adminstration and one for guests. If you are not planning to go with a guide then do some some quick research on the net so you know what you are looking at. Yes it is busy and you'll need to allow some time if you want to photograph.

Right next to Riad Hayati. It's too convenient to pass up. Literally 2 minutes from Hayati. It has beautiful gardens and courtyards and you can get an excellent idea of how the old sultans lived centuries ago.

Not Bad. Its ok, but if I had my choice I would Badia Palace only and skip this one. There is not a whole lot to see here. The rooms are nice but you can see rooms and decorations like this in places all over the city. Check it out if you have extra time but don't be disappointed if you miss it.
Beautiful, worth a look!. Very beautiful wood ceilings and period carvings. Not expensive to get in a definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful Tiles. This is the most beautiful site in Marrakech, it is perhaps best to go with a guide to get the background information and then spend some time trying to get away from the crowds to see things quietly.

Very worthwhile visit to an outstanding architectural relic.. At 10Dm for entry this is a real bargain. They should charge much more and do something to protect against further loss of tiles and wear to the floors.If not many people, this is a tranquil oasis. With three different language tour groups competing it is an acoustic hell. Go out into the garden and wait until the philistines go away.Beautiful tiles and astonishing woodwork in almost every room. Easil reached from Jma el Fnaa or from the Bus Touistique.

Lovely visit. I went with a guide and very glad I did. She was very informative. I am always impressed with the workmanship of these ancient buildings. The Palace was no exception. The tile work is amazing. Loved it! A very enjoyable tour!
must see palace. if you want see who the kings and pachas of morocco used to live and have an idea about the architectural buildings of palaces in morocco this the place
Bahia. Interesting history of Royalty here, especiall the fact that the King had 4x wives and Bahia was his favourite, hence the Palace was named after her. Tour guide assisted us with his knowledge.
A beautiful visit. A beautiful building and more tranquil than the manic Jardin Majorelle. As with everywhere else, we would have liked more information on the things we were seeing.

Don't go without a guid untill the renovation is finished. I've visited the bahia palace 2 weeks ago and it seems all nice on the internet but once I was inside, I found out that 90% of the palace is not open to the public because of renovations... later that week I came back with a guide who made the visit very interesting.. so don't go alone, take a guide or wait until the renovations are finished.....in 2015...

Decoration inspiration. Fascinating history (Read Walter Harris: The Morocco That Was) and stunning decoration in marble, stucco, painted cedarwood and enamelled terra cotta tiles. Glorious maze of rooms. Amazing how it looks like nothing special from the outside. Wanted to find the suite of the Grand Vizier's Favourite (as in Edith Wharton's In Morocco) but couldn't find anybody to ask! Try to avoid the crowds.

Good for a stroll around to spend an hour or so. Quite small interesting to see how they lived. Worth spending an hour or so - the mosaic work and carvings are quite stunning. The entrance fee is so small, I would happily pay to have some English guide pamphlets - my visit would have been much enhanced with a better understanding of what I was looking at. My French is rudimentary.
Because it's cheap it was ok.. It's only 10 dirham to visit. But it's not worth more either. We were in and out in 20 minutes. It just looks to much like any other riad.
Interesting in design. Loved the variation of intricately carved woodwork, mosaics and design. Another quiet haven from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech
Worth a quick look. Fascinating interior, and interesting to learn about the different rooms for the four different wives.
Harem scarum. Enjoyed the architecture and our guide showed us details that opened windows on small areas of local life a century ago. Lovely and cool in the summer heat too.
Quite possible the worst pound I have ever spent. This is an emplty house and that was all, the ruins at Badia were much more interesting to view in my opinion

Facinating to See another Countries history and archtecture. WE had our own private guide so were able to see everything and learn what each room was for and its history. This gave us a great insight to what and how the hirearchy lived in Morocco in the past and how they have evolved to the 21st Century. What was amazing was how cool it was in the various rooms and open courtyards. Not to be missed.
Palace. On the day we visited there were large tours visiting we were disappointed as other places in the region have more to see just walking down the street such as Luxor Aswan etc

A wonderful example of 15th century architecture. Whilst the rooms echo a little from the lack of furniture, the architecture is a wonderful display of decadence and ornate artisan craftmanship - a definite must see, particularly at the lowly price of less than a euro per adult.

lovely. pay for a guide. its really interesting but theres nothing to let you know where you are what youre looking at. pay for a guide an get the low down! its really interesting and the stories about teh palace are really different to what the place may suggest... a cool relaxed palace for the rich...when actually theres a whole load a stuff that gone down there!!

Go early............ ...to avoid the Tourist Groups. The architexture and gardens are exquisite. We have been to Marrakech seven times in five years, and as well as the Badi Palace we visit here each time...simply to wander around and enjoy the craftsmanship, beauty and tranquility.
Decorative tilework. The Bahia palace is nice to just walk around and enjoy the architecture and the decorative tilework. Unfortunatly, a part was under construction when we were visiting.

Check your times. We were told these shut at 6. On arrival on our Final day we were then told they had just at 3.30pm. We were very disappointed as we didn't get to see them in the end, it's a shame that inaccurate information is being passed round. It was also printed wrong in a guide book, so maybe check at your hotel first before setting out.
Not so special. we saw much better Moroccan architecture and tile work in Fez. crowded with tour groups, so go early or late for some privacy
amazing architecture. It was great to just walk around the palace and look at the architecture and details of the decoration.
Fascinating Historical Site. Great architecture & craftsmanship. Ceilings are amazing. Can be crowded but patience leads to some great detail photos.

Crowded but beautiful.... Beautiful tilework, woodwork, and plaster carvings. Intricate ceilings. Definitely a place to wander at your own pace. Tours and bus groups can make some of the rooms and courtyards feel crowded, but find a quiet room and wait them out. They will move on and you are in no rush.
Really beautiful. There is lots to see inside, traditional crafts and cultural items, but the building is also spectacular. Well worth the price to go in, which isn't very high on UK terms at all
Fantastic architecture.. A fantastic building with the most wonderful decoration. Shame that it is mostly empty of furniture though.

Worth a visit. We walked there arriving at 09.00 but there were two tour groups just going in! We skirted past them and were then able to look around empty rooms while they were still having the talk from the guides. Unfortunately there is no information in English about the different areas (unless you get a guide) but it is amazing to look at the architectural decorations. We were told that the stucco was carved by hand after being applied to the walls!

Large crowds while we were there. Unfortunately, we probably didn't give this the time it deserved. There were such large groups of tourists there! It was hard to get around them, as they would be oblivious to the fact that there were people there trying to walk around that were not with their tour. We looked as we tried to dodge the crowds.

Well worth a visit. Very tranquil and pretty, go early to avoid the tour groups and the heat. I would suggest paying a little more for a guide as not many of the signs are in English (french or arabic only)

Exquisite building, lack of interpretation. The Bahia Palace was very busy and lacked information for those who weren't with a guide, like us. For this reason, if you want to get into the history of the place, get a guide or a guidebook. It's beautiful and the tiling is stunning, but we felt a little let down by the complete lack of any information in English. I appreciate that French and Arabic are available but unfortunately my French is way too rusty. It's worth visiting if you're in the area, but be prepared for crowds.

Empty walls. Food without spice, salad without dressing, garden without flowers, river without water, room without furniture. How else can one describe a palace that once used to host the heirs of throne, missing everything else than its walls? This is a skull of a wonderful princess that was dreamt to have, dared to look at, impossible to talk to. But just a skull, nothing else. Palais de Bahia reminds that something used to be there but these remnants fail to raise any feeling in the present.If you have nothing else to do, visit this skull of the princess, entry fee is very low, price is definitely worth the visit, time is not.

Visit if you are nearby. The palace didn't take too long to walk around but it was not what I was expecting from our guide book! If you go with low expectations I'm sure you will not be disappointed however, as with all the sites I visited in Marrakech, it was not yet fully set up for tourists to walk round and understand the history and significance of the various rooms and elements of this attraction. If you are nearby it is worth a look as is not expensive however I wouldn't go out of your way.
Nice to see but I wouldn't rush back. It could be an interesting sight but it's not in great condition and there is next-to-no information about what you are looking at.

Nice place for a visit. Went with a guide, it has a beautiful architecture and a lovely courtyard. We were given a history lesson from our tour guide which was interesting. Entering this place you will see a few orange trees as well. This place is worth a visit located in the Old City
Just Ok. We went to Bahia Palace because it was right outside our Riad. It was much smaller than we expected but there were some beautiful architecture there.

Nice building, that's all. Beautiful architecture and decoration, sure, that's a given, but not much information or history posted about the place. Rammed with coachloads of people taking a million photographs they will probably never look at again.
Worth a Visit. The palace is definitely worth a visit, especially if you haven't experienced Kasbahs in the Atlas Mountains. The tile work and wood work in the ceilings is remarkable.
Beautiful palace. Go there with a guide, otherwise you do not know the details. Beautiful mosaic. Takes approx 45 minutes to visit the palace.

better than expected. Superb, really worth the visit. Do climb to the top for a view of the city roof tops.They are doing a lot of restoration, here you really get the feel of the richesse of those kings.
keep looking up. the painted and carved ceilings and upper walls in this palace are just amazing whether of painted wood or plaster or stone. very serene inner gardens and beautiful tiles as wekk
It's ok. Not that interesting and crowded, but ok for 10 dirhams. It's one of the main sites to see in Marrakesh.
Beautiful. Wonderful examples of Moroccan interior designs and how fabulous they can look. The floors and ceilings are really spectacular and extremely well maintained. Well worth a visit.
well worth a visit. lovely to look at, lots of intricate detail. quite a lot of people visiting but plenty of opportunity to look around in your own space without being rushed.
Bahia palace a delight. Viewed this with Madani of Medina Walking Tours : very good and interesting spot well worth visiting

Beautiful palace. Interesting history. The favorite wife = the wife who bore the eldest son. Her room is the most beautiful with separte sections for the babies, servants. Shocked to see that other wives/servants/babies lived under such small enclosures, separated by curtains. Wives are like sisters that took care of each other, yeah right!
Nice short break. Easy to find and easy to enter attraction. The palace is empty and whats left are the empty rooks with nice ceilings. Take about twenty minutes and your on the street again.

Nothing to write home about!. Although Bahia Palace was worth a visit and interesting to see, the experience did not make or break my visit to Marrakesh! Although compared to some of the other sites in Marrakesh such as Menara Gardens I would suggest that Bahia Palace is more worthy of a visit.

10/10. A beautifull palace, that is well worth the small entrance fee (1 euro) Takes approx 1 hour, i went on my own but plenty of guided trips going round. A perfect example of a Moslem palace. Do not miss.
How to live with 28 women. The palace where the Shiek lived with his 4 wives and 25 mistresses. Like the way that the wives were kept separate.

Culture and History. A fascinating place. Our guide gave us a comprehensive run-down on the history of this beautiful buildding with its decorative stucco work, colourful cedarwood ceilings.mosiacs and the harem riad. If you like history, well worth a visit.
Love the history. A tour guide took us hear - it was great to hear to history. There isn't a great deal to see and we spent about 20mins here then left.

well worth the tiny admission fee. Worth the 10 DH ($1.10 cdn/US) admission fee to see the beautiful artisan work on the ceilings and walls. Carving in plaster and wood, beautiful mosaics and painting, def worth a look-see!

Disappointing.. When we eventually found the palace the guide tried to persuade us to use his service but we felt he was too pricey. When we declined he spat on the floor and threatened us not to follow him if he had other tourists. He was the only rude moroccan we met. Ruins not particularly good and we were refused admittance into mosque as we hadn't paid extra although some visitors were admitted as they could converse in local language and so argued the point

A lovely palace , cool and peaceful. Like all Moroccan palaces, the outsides are very plain. Everything is on the inside, beautiful ceilings, mosaics, carvings and of course central courtyard garden. A lovely place to visit and then stroll down the souks to shop and stop for a cool drink or some lunch.

"pass a pleasant hour at the Bahia Palace. Amazing architecture, tiles and carvings which highlight the skills of the craftsment who built the palace. Very peaceful and well worth the 10dh entrance fee. The place is a little run down but this only adds to its charm.

A Must See!. This beautiful site is well taken care of and has a fantastic garden! What a wonderful place to take a break from the scorching sun. One of the best sites in Morocco because it is so peaceful inside.

Plesant morning activity. All buildings in Marrakech are unassuming from the outside, but when you get inside the palace you can see the luxury and beauty of life here. The details in the doors and the arches and the complexity of the designs were astounding. There isnt much to do other than take a gentle stroll around the rooms and grounds, but it is not expensive and a most plesant way to spend a couple of hours.
beautiful and sprawling. This is a nice old palace with really pretty courtyard gardens. Lots of amazing wood, tile, and plasterwork. You get a real appreciation of how the old 1% used to live here!
A definite must. Employ a guide as there is much to see and explanations from a qualified local are really necessary. I would be happy to visit again and marvel at the architecture and decoration

Fabulous Moroccan Palace. Set in the Mellah area of Marrakech, this ornate building of rooms and internal gardens has fine examples of geometric carved wall, floor and ceiling work so favoured by Arab cultures. This is one of three Royal palaces within walking distance of each other, but the current lived in one is not open to the public. Well worth a visit.

Lovely and Only 10 Dirham (1Euro). Lovely Palace well worth a visit and fantastic value for money, a tranquil haven in the city of Marrakech with beautiful carved decorated ceilings and tiled and decorated walls.
Good palace. In spite of being empty, you can still see the mosaics and wood works. The palace was just a big house of a politician and his wifes.
Beautiful. A must do visit while in Marrakech. Beautiful little place dotted in the middle of the hussle and bussle of the city.

lovely place. very beautiful, best to visit early morning before it gets too hot. a lot to be learnt from this place, so bring along a guidebook or get an audio guide to help you understand your surroundings a little better

needs tlc. It could be great.A historic place.Yet,it is run down,inside as well as outside.You can feel thegreatness of the past,but it is not enough .The palace needs tender loving care,landscaping,restauration inside.Do the locals care?Not really

Could not believe. We visited the palace in August. It is in the old medina near the Jewish quarter. From outside there is no sign t all that there is a palace. Once you enter through a small shabby door you enter through a nice garden and palace which has 2 parts - old and new. Both have a centre fountain, a garden and is typical riad in morocco. The wood, ceiling deco and ceramic tils isunbelievale. The whole place is like brand new and well maintained despite build in the 18 century. I understand the king named to the palace to his favorite wife Bahia. By the way gone had 4 wives because there are four rooms in one quarter abound the took turns!

One of the best sights in Marrakesh. Marrakesh has no main sights, but I would say this is one of the best things to see. It has beautiful stain glass windows and mosaics to see, but takes no more than 20-30 mins to look round in total.

Pretty. This was a very pretty building, and it was definitely worth visiting. The architecture is amazing in this city, and the stories which come along with it are the most enchanting things about the buildings, along with the ceilings remember to always look up when in marrakech!

Beautiful. Just go for the ceilings and the intricate artwork.the rooms are bare as everything got looted but its the tilework,the door paintings and carvings and the ceilings. Beware the number of tourists though.
Worth a look. Pretty tile work but not one of the best palaces I've visited as it's unfurnished. Not a whole lot to do in Marrakech so it was worth the visit.

mmmm. was ok but the room are the same, great wood work and stunning ceilings but i found ot rather repetitive....the guides are good and they seem to know what they are on about...but in the heat of the day its hard work to concentrate
Beautiful rooms and courtyards. Beautiful palace with spectacularly decorated walls and ceilings. We spent a very pleasant hour and a half admiring the rooms and patios.
great monument. not to miss , its location is by the anciant jewish neighbourhood that has been preserved for centuries where the Sultan Mohamed protected the jewish comunity back in 15century.
palace. very interesting, though a guide is needed for the full experience not much information around otherwise
Jusrt Next To Hayati. It is a glipse of what the sultans lived like hundreds of years ago. The gardens are dramatic and Riad Hayati is just over the garden wall.

Beautiful. we absolutely loved this place. It was so serene and peaceful. We spent a coupel of hours walking about seeing the beautiful marble and wood work that adorned this once fabulous palace,a nd were pleased to see it in a state of full restoration.

Beautiful palace. Wonderful palace, with really beautiful decorations everywhere. Very crowded, so we couldnt really get close to alot of things. Unfortuneatly there were many groups visiting at the same time as we did. Information on the signs around the palace was only in french and arabic, so we didnt get all the info that we wanted. But a beautiful place worth a visit!

Interesting. Its a nice palace and the history is good to know but why not put some tourist friendly signs up explaining the rooms and history of the place? Visited here as one place of 3 during a day tour and found it the best of the others (gardens and tombs)

Nothing special. The building need to be restore and there isn't much to see, the best is the view from its terrace and you can take a photo without have to pay for it!! You have to pay 10 dh to visit like each monument

Beautiful echo of the past. We were considering leaving a trip to this Palace off our already jam-packed itinerary but so glad we didn't. The site wasn't so big that we lost interest and we comfortably covered our visit off within around an hour. The ornate ceilings and tiling on the floors were so beautiful, and the courtyards were stunning, the only drawback being that there were very few information signs around to say what was what and those that were up were in French and Arabic only so was not always 100% clear on what we were seeing. Still absolutely worth seeing and at only 80p each to get in it was bargain!

Worth a visit. I visited the palace with a tour guide and like everything else in Morocco it has some fascinating history! It’s not too far out the way, so I would recommend a trip early in the morning to beat the crowds and get some good pictures!
Go with a guide!. We had a wonderful time here and learned a lot, but we went with a really amazing guide, arranged by our Riad (don't just agree to go with someone in the square).
Amazing. The Palace is jst next to Riad Hayati. It's amazing to see the way the old sultans lived. Lovely gardens, but the the place needs restoration.
Come-si...come-sa. nothing special . overrated . i think a visit to the old Jewish graveyard is far more interesting . Marrakech is not about museums its about people and the markets .

grandeur of the past still visible. Surprisingly, it's not a very old palace in fact it was only completed in 1900. Clearly the collaboration of artists and skilled workers from North Africa and Andalusia lend to Bahia Palace's grandeur which can still be seen today as showcased in this amazing palace. The first open courtyard, mainly planted with orange trees and a marble fountain in the centre surrounded by rich arched woodwork with fine painted details is the older part of the palace, Dar Si Moussa was built by the first grand vizier (chief officer of the state) of the sultan. Bigger rooms with spectacularly detailed painted wood ceilings, equally beautifully adorned wooden doors and plasterwork on the archways can also been seen parts of which were built later by the son, Ba Ahmed the successor who built additions creating an intricate yet irregular plan to the final stages of the palace until it was completed in 1900. After his death, the sultan himself allegedly ordered a raid of the opulent Bahia Palace to collect its splendid furnishings and prized decorative materials.
lovely. Didnt feel that we needed long here but was nice to see.
Great architecture and decor. One of the more interesting palaces particularly if you have a guide to explain the rooms and decorative tiling etc.
Good but...... Really could have been more one site, like furnishings etc, the place was a little bare

Lovely Palace. The rooms and courtyards of the Bahia Palace are lovely and display a number of aspects of Moroccan architecture. As we toured with a private guide we were able to understand what we were looking at. Not sure if this would be true if we had walked through on our own.
Ornate. Enjoyed this although it is hot inside and can make you feel ill. Take a bottle of water with you. Our Thompsons guide was boring. sorry to say,
Good example of Islamic decor. This is worth a visit. We liked the superb Islamic tiling and carved plaster work which decorated every room.
Very much worth the visit.. Amazing. The palace inside is really beautiful and doesn't take too long to visit. Worth the visit.
Beautiful!. It's all on the inside!! The palace inside is absolutely beautiful and doesn't take too long to visit.

Beautiful but needs more information. As the title says - also a lovely refuge from the 50 degree heat outside. But very little information about what the rooms were used for, and what there is, is in French. Although to be fair this did mean we were really able to take in and concentrate on how lovely the rooms and gardens are.

Beautiful and worth the visit.. We did this on our own, without a guide and really enjoyed the beautiful tiles and delicate, colorful ceilings. There were no English guides there when we visited, but you can really do it yourself.
Very touristy. A lot of turist!!! Plus, there are much nicer and authentic in Fes

Architecture and history. If you are dealing with architecture, interior design, photography, visual art, gardening and other Art& Design fields - do not miss!Historians will love it as well.I found it disturbing to be shown this plsce as a "normal" palace. Indeed, it was a place of slavery, and I felt very uncomfortable to be shown the rooms of the female slaves within the harem, within a general presentation of the palace glorifying the master of the place. I do encourage the visit, but in times where we fight human traficking and modern slavery, I would advise to remember what this "harem" was indeed - a place whete many women and girls were held against their will.
Worth a visit. The palace is worth a visit just to see the intracity of local craftmanship. It is undergoing renovation but it does take away from the pleasure of the trip, only 10 dirham admission
Cool shady very beautiful palace. Lovely rooms with beautiful decoration and carving
Buy cab or with guid. Beautful mosac,s lot,s to see but no video allowed take as many poto,s as you like a great place .
Beautiful. Loved the mosaics and architecture! The palace is bare though, so don't expect any furniture.
Tranquill. Apart from the dismantling of a concert stage and seating, it was a pleasant large area with a good view over the rooftops.
splendid. so cheap to get in - 10 Dihram! Could do with more information points - and in English (fortunately we read French)

Architecturally beautiful!. If you're interested in architecture then this is for you. The carved stone work, beautiful tiles and stunning ceilings are just fantastic! It isn't furnished so if you're looking for a palace that looks pretty functional then this is probably going to disappoint you. Brush up on your French if you want to understand the signage or hire a guide.

Lovely tile design. The tiles are beautiful and so is the middle garden. Rooms are empty so it takes some imagination to see what it was like in the day and how it was used. There is no explanation or history given on each room or section, so if you want to know more you would need a local guide. Work is in progress in some areas.

Nice palace with good photoshooting opportunities. Beautiful architecture and interior design. They have no café there, which is a shame as it would be nice to sit in the little garden in the front of the palace to rest a little.
Don't miss it.  Bring a guide to really understand the lifestyle of these people and the beauty of the place.
great history. do visit the palace with a guide on foot maybe.history is fascinating .must see option for sure
A must see. It is stunning and very inspiring. The colours are so nice, the intricate designs and the history. I loved it. Highly recommended.
Nice place to visit.. It is still very well preserved and the gardens and patios are lovely and fresh to take a break.

A palace with a harem. A beautiful palace with amazing ceilings. The visit must be done with a tourist guide to understand the history and the importance of the place. There was a real harem and Bahia is the name of the favourite wife.
Good. Good part of the country to learn about! we went here as part of our discover marrakech trip

Ok for passing the time. Nice architecture but heaving with people and fairly small. Worth a quick visit if you're in the area but not worth a special trip. It could also use a few signs to let you know what you're looking at!
Tranquil and beautiful. Go early to avoid the crowds - such an oasis. Inspiring architecture and ambience.
Don't waste your time. Nothing to see here, guys. Move along now? A ruin of a castle with nothing of any interest left
nice Moorish architecture. worth a visit - nice example of Moorish architecture and figurational design. But you've probably seen it already in Spain.

Facinfating to see the opullent contrast. The crowds are over whelming. They swoop in by the coach loads. It would have been amazing to see empty. The mosaic floors and carved and painted walls are over whelming
Could be great. If you read French you would probably have a better visit
a must!. We came here with a guide which was great as we learned so much about the buildings and the art.
What a maze. No wonder he had 29 wives, take a bit of finding your way around, no english, probably need a guide to get best value of visit
A must see!. Make sure your battery is charged on your camera! Such amazing art craft work here!
A work of Art. Really a stunning palace, much more than I had expected. The materials used mean it is quite cool with the open pool also.

Not bad.. An interesting building, which has been largely restored to something of its former glory.
Would have been better if there had been a little more investment in signs to inform people about what they were actually looking at though. Would have transformed it from a fairly dull walk around seemingly similar rooms, into an historical journey.
Gorgeous. A beautiful example of Moroccan craftsmanship. I must have taken a zillion photos!
Same decoration. Unfortunately a lot of the monuments have very similar decor inside. However, at 80p entrance fee, who can complain, enjoyable
Nice architecture. Beautiful architecture, after visiting the 'village des artisans' we had more appreciation of the beautifully skillful work.

Wonderful building and relaxing gardens. Bahia palace is a beautiful building that reflects the real Morish archeticture. It is a stunning palace with amazing ceilings and tiled floors. it worths a visit.

peaceful place to sightsee. The Palace is very calm and quiet, just what you need after a day in the Souks! Wander amongst orange and lemon trees and peer in to the underground passageways. Well worth a visist.
Great mosaics and cool. Bit of cool respite from the city streets. Nice palace, intricate wall mosaics.
Another World. Literally right next to Hayati this is a glimpse of what sultans lived like hundreds of years ago.
Bahia Palace. A stunning palace with amazing ceilings and tiled floors. Worth a visit.
Well done Hotels 4 you Trips. Beautiful Palace, the tour guide made it so interesting

Unbelievable. Make sure you read about these sites before going because there is not alot of information there to explain what you are seeing. One of the attendants on site was kind enough to tell us all about the wedding chamber - and was well worth the 10dh we tipped him.
Don't miss. Such beautiful interior decorations - it gives a real sense of Morocco's royal past.
When size mattered... Just let your imagine drift, and think how it must have been to live in such a massive, well designed and built place... And you didn't have to do the dusting
good but. You dan zee IT had being beautiful in the passes time nog everything is open, because there is a renovation going on

Nice, but needs some renovation. For me the best touristic attraction in Marakech (apart from the spa's). Here you can see where the art from the Al Hamra and Alcazar in Sevilla comes from (or maybe they took it back to here). It looks very similar... very nice courtyards, very nice rooms.. Great craftsmen!, really, really, really worth a visit.The best place in Marakech i visited and also one of the best places i visited in Morocco, the only thing I have to say is that Morocco needs to do something to protect this palace for future generations!. This is what people come for when they go and visit morocco!.

Beautiful decor. The Bahia palace is well worth a visit if you like architecture and beautiful decoration. Every surface seems to be covered in mosaic or amazing stucco. Even the ceilings are beautifully painted. The courtyards are a peaceful place to sit and take it all in
Hidden Gem. Worth a visit if you like history, excellent architecture
Rich decoration and grand design. The Bahia Palace and the Dar Si said museum nearby are two exquisite examples of 19th century grandeur.
A great place to spend a couple of hours. This old palace has amazing detail in the walls and ceilings and some beautiful courtyards. Entrance is cheaper on Fridays!

Worth a Visit. After travelling from Agadir this was a must. We had a good tour guide that knew the history and the places we needed to see. Without a guide it would not have been so good. Not all the rooms are open dur to renavation taking place. One of the most interesting places was what was the original stables and yard but it was used laterly as the rooms for the concubines of which there were 24 plus the wives of the minister who owned the palace. The cielings are in perfect condition and the art work is beautiful. Not to be missed
Beautiful Palace. Worth the entry fee. Wonderful place to walk around and see the architecture. Plenty of seats around to pause and take in the surroundings under the Marrakech sun.

Must see in Marrakesh. The El Bahia is a stunning palace and should be on every itinerary while in Marrakesh. The palace is adorned with beautiful tile, intricate scrollwork and the entrance is a welcomed oasis in Marrakesh. I easily spent an hour and a half just admiring the detail in the ceilings and archways. There are so many opportunities for great photographs and the palace is easily walkable. It is also convenient to the other major attractions in and around the Kasbah and medina and has one of the cheapest entrance fees in Marrakesh.

Absolutely stunning palace - must see!. A beautiful and quite well-restored palace with many fabulously decorated rooms. The tile work, plaster work and wood carving are regal. Walking through it, you get a very good sense of how life inside must have been. The top attraction in Marrakesh, along with Place Djema el Fnaa.

Best Value Tourist Attraction In Marrakech. At less than £1, this is an extremely good value visit. The mosaics, ceilings and doors in this palace will keep you snapping away with your camera all the way round.We spent just under an hour here, but many seemed to be here longer, so well worth the money.ONE IMPORTANT THING TO NOTE, all guidebooks we have seen say its shuts at 5.45pm, however, when we were there we arrived at 4.30pm to see it just shutting. When we returned at a later date, the site still said it shut at 4.30pm. Not sure if this is temporary or a new closing time, so dont get there too late.

Not so old, but very interesting site. If you like movie trivia, you can see the shooting location for many of the classics about Morocco, and overall it is an interesting vignette into the home of the former Secretary of Defense.

Beautiful Architecture. The El Bahia Palace has beautiful Moroccan architecture, mosaics, and ceilings. It is definitely worth a visit. The price is about one euro and the visit is about one hour or more if you take your time. It's a little hard to find if you walk there yourself. We had to pay a guide to take us there which wasn't ideal.
Worth a visit. Beautiful islamic decoration and a peaceful place away from the hubbub
Lovely. Well worth the minimal entry fee. We wandered round unaccompanied but we loved the building and how beautiful the whole palce was, if not a little suprised by the size of the place.

The best 80p you will spend.. After walking down the approach drive we were not sure whether we would need to join a tour but entered the palace to stroll around unaccompanied. At times we were surrounded by large groups with their sometimes egocentric guides.At other times we could 'latch onto' a group with a more sober and academic guide and listen to the commentary.The quality of the carving, the tiling and the painted ceilings is astounding with one room/ courtyard surpassing another. You shouldn't miss the fine examples of Islamic art.

Great palace! Bigger than it looks.. This palace was great! It had many rooms and courtyards, all with unique architecture and designs. I really enjoyed it. It's pretty easy to find starting from the medina, and all you do is take one of the streets that comes off the plaza and it'll go directly to a big pink gate/wall that's the Bahia palace, and entrance is only 10 dirhams. Try to follow the signs that show visitors what direction to walk in (the signs are small), as that willy guarantee that you will hit every room in the palace.
Beautiful. For only a few pence you gain entry to a beauiful old palace and gardens. A great place to see the remarkable decoration and the tranquil gardens

Ceilings and courtyards.. This former palace is now really an empty building, save a planted courtyard, but the tiles, doorways and ceilings remain and offer an insight into what this palace once looked like. Several courtyards are linked by a small maze of rooms and corridors. A few minutes from a number of other historic buildings, it makes for part of a full day of visits or just a worthwhile break from the busy streets outside. Entry 10D (~€1).

Beautiful cosy palace. Typical moorish palace built around an inner lovely garden, ceilings, doors and windows beautifully decorated with paintings, floors covered with colored ceramics. The place make you feel as told by the story that it was built for love and happiness. We enjoyed a lot our visit, probably the most beautiful old palace in Marrakech.
Nice architecture!. Nice architecture with beautiful details, and nice garden. Quiet atmosphere.
walls. a disappointment for me, just a vague memory of an unfinished palace from the 16th century; nothing left ; so go to sidi said instead ; a small complete informative museum;
Opulent and grand. An amazing venue, remarkably intact, and well worth a visit to see how relatively recent sultans have lived and lavishly entertained.

Worth the walk to find - break from the chaos of Medina. A very nice example of a Moroccan palace - very similar in style and feel to the Alhambra Palace in Granada. Beautiful and intricate carving and decoration - loads of photo opportunities.Note - don't believe locals who stop you on the way and tell you that the palace is closed - there plan is to take you to there shop or sting you by 'guiding' you elsewhere for a fee
Worth a visit. No furniture but you can still appreciate the majesty of this place. The ceilings are fantastic.
Undersold. Beautiful architecture, but suffers from lack of care and lack of visitor info

Better places to visit. If you have fee time stroll down from the square and take a look. It's only 10d to get in.
If you dont, don't worry your not missing much!

A peep into the past. The building is now empty of all furniture, but it isn;t hard to imagine the gracious and lovely rooms as they might have been. The beautiful decorations on celings, doorways and walls are wonderful. Lovely foundations grace the centres of rooms and courtyards, a reminder of the 'air conditioning' they once provided. Very well tended and a joy to see.
Seen better.. Not greatly impressed. Best features were the ceilings.
Awe-inspiring. It's hard to explain the beauty of Bahia Palace. You'll find yourself wandering quietly and muttering to yourself about all you see.
an interesting excursion. This was not fantastic as I am not an old buildings tour person bit it was still interesting and very worth seeing for the low price
Said to be the most beautiful palace of Marrakech. Very nice rooms but to bad they don't propose guides at the door.
Beautiful. Lovely example of a Moroccan palace, in fairly good condition with only a tiny entry fee. Worth an hour or so of your time.
Basic. I have visited palaces all over the world and this one is basic, there is no interpritation so buy a guide.

Cute place to visit. The Bahia Palace isn't as grand as its name suggests, but it's still something different to do in Marrakech from the souk and djemaa. It's about 20 mins walk for the djemaa and 10dh for entry. The architecture is interesting and very intricate and worth taking a few shots of. It should take about 30mins to see everything.
A jewel. Easy to navigate through the empty rooms where the masterpieesvare ceilings, doors, windows and tiling

Worth seeing the harem. It's a shame that only a few rooms out of 150 are open to public. The entrance is only 10Dh so why not. The museums in Marrakesch are not that different from one another, but worth seeing.
Nice, but.... worth a break from the Medina, but not mind blowing, a nice palace, great design, but some parts are falling into disrepair.
Worth a visit. For 10 dh this is a great place to spend some time. Gorgeous architecture. Signage is in Arabic and French only but you get the gist.

A place not to be missed. After seeing the ruins of the nearby Badii Palace, the smaller Bajia Palace was a real delight. The ceilings are magnificent and the patios are lovely, you get an excellent idea of the real splendor of its time.
Impressive. Very casual approach to such a historic site but very interesting and well signed with useful information boards
refined and beautifully restored. there are relatively few palaces to visit in Marrakesh. Do not miss this one

Best 10 dirams we spent. A stunning and quite condensed experience of Moroccan building at its best. Lovely little courtyard garden and a glimpse of living palatial style in the past. Lots of ideas for how to tile your bathroom too!
very ancient. Very interesting but area is too crowded , there are better places to visit like the Koutoubia and Jardin majorelle.
so lovely. If you love architecture and you are a bit of a dreamer this is a place to visit
Decorative Detail. This is a fantastic place to go if you want to see true craftmanship. There is real beauty in the intricate work.

One of the few palaces where you can see what it once was. Marrakesh has a long and interesting history, and many palaces. Since the king still lives in some of them (from time to time), it's nice to get access to one to see what it is like. This is far better than the Badia palace, which though nearby, isn't worth the trip.The architecture is intriguing, especially the ceilings. It should take you about an hour to see it.
A palace of love. Very well preserved building. Fantastic colourfull rooms decorated with mosaic. Wood hand painted roofs.The Vizir had 4 wifes and 24 concubines.
Vast!. An interesting visit. This place must have been magnificent in its day.

Grand 30 mins for 10 DHR. There is no furnishings and very limited explanation - if you have a guide, this may be worth while - otherwise, it is a grand stroll for 30 mins and at only a euro to enter, its fine for that.

Stunning palace in the heart of the Marrakech medina. Stunning and intricate tile work define the Bahia Palace. Entry fee of 1 Euro is a small price to pay to see this palace. The palace is not furnished, but this allows you to fully appreciate the spectacular tile work, ceilings, doors and floors. There is an interior courtyard and numerous rooms to view. Well worth the price of admission!
A pleasant respite. A pleasant break from busy streets of the Mellah, small courtyards reception rooms with beautiful carved ceilings,doors lovely cool walls of tiles
Bahia Museum. Worth seeing - a beautiful palace once the home of a king, with interesting displays.

Serene and interesting. Apparently P Diddy hired this place for his birthday, but don't let that fact put you off. A great place to see traditional Moroccan architecture at it's best, Bahia palace is a relaxing place to stroll around over an hour or two.
A view into the past. a site ot behold for all travelers imagine what it must have been like 700 years agao
This place is stunning. Beautiful interiors and at only 10 dirham entry fee you can't go wrong.
Beautiful 19th-century palace. Very photogenic and peaceful, with painted ceilings and monumental doorways. Lovely and quiet once you escape the Mellah and walk through the gates.

Pretty. The palace is very beautiful.
Excellent for picture takers looking for a combination of color, geometric and floral designs.
Cheap too 10 MAD entrance
One problem is that there are no guides on hand and limited information on a handful of information plagues in the palace (in french and arabic)

Ornate palace. We did not bother to do a guided tour of the palace and you probably need that to get a better understanding of its significance and purpose. However, our quick walk around was enough to get an idea. The rooms were ornate and interesting but completely bare of any furnishings that would have made them more interesting. It was completely lacking in any english signage to describe anything and even the french and arabic ones were rare. Worth a quick visit but really there were more interesting, intimate rooms like this in the carpet shops in the souks.

Mostly ruins and no illustrations on what it once was.. Just four walls there. You can go on the terrace and have a nice view around. There is also a small underground area for rooms. I suppose its worth 10 MAD for quick 30 min walk around.
nice. Really nice old palace and just amazaingly huge. You have to see it at all.

Mostly in ruins. Ofcourse was a palace but presently nothing much there..other that some pools and old walls which they are trying to converse in a modern way...found the bird nests more interesting than the building itself

el Bahia palace worth a visit. as a local visitor from Marrakech, i like el Bahia Palace as one of the must seen monumental places in Marrakech as i would recommend it for anyone visiting the red city of Marrakech.
Worth a look. Nice place, good sunset photos from the roof, otherwise not much to see inside except orange trees and walls of the ruin.

could have... should have... just fine to kill time on. When you have seen the first room there isn't much more to surprise you... beautiful tiled ceilings and floors but all rooms are empty and a average random village museum in Europe would probably excite me more.. The maintenance is of a low standard especially considering the number of visitors. On a positive note the entrance fee is cheap and you do have some photo opportunities and if reproduced old tiles exhilarate you, you may truly enjoy it!
Very Historic. Wood, tile and other work is very pretty, It is still being restored. Take a lot of pictures. Need flash for some area.
Better to have guide or guide book. We had a guide therefore visit interesting about 75p to enter - some areas closed for refurb and some not open to public
Courtyards and architecture. An area of Marrakech which is not so hit by tourists is el bahia palace. It is so pretty and full of vibrant colours. Visit at lunchtime to miss the mass tourist groups!
Very insightful. A great place to wonder around and really get a feel for how Marrakech once was...

Wonderful. The ambiance, the internal courts.
It seems very authentic, this is positive also if it is not fully restored
Fascinating. Worth a visit. Beautiful tiles and ceilings. In need of a bit of TLC from a wealthy donor.
Gorgeous, not to be missed. Gorgeous place, just wish they had one or two furnished rooms to give us more of a taste of how they lived.

Worth a visit!. This has gorgeous architecture and such a cheap entrance fee! Its a little hard to find, but getting lost int he streets of the medina is part of the fun. Its very peaceful, and the colours are incredible. Definitely worth a visit!
Well worth a visit. A bargain less than a £1 for an hours enjoyment, great piece of history, gardens and the atmosphere is lovely.
What away to live!. Step back in time and ogle at the exquisite architecture. Don't miss it.
Beautiful and interesting - but a one hour visit is enough.. A visit to this palace needs a guide. This is a beautiful palace and if you like to take photos you will find many photo opportunities.
Ancient culture. The plasterwork and ceilings designs are outstanding.
How the other half lived. The quarters of the vizier with lots of lovely decorated rooms - really lovely. Avoid the coach parties (unless earwigging for descriptions) as it gets a bit squashed
all these palace are a must to visit. good to take your camara very good place to visit lovely old style very well looked after and not exspensive

Brilliant marbles!. Very nice palace, nicely decorated with marbles and wood carvings. Beautiful! Peaceful place, where they let you wander around on your own. DH10 to enter. Definitely worth a visit!

Pretty but same same all over. The rooms and walls and ceilings were beautiful but the palace is big and after a while, there is nothing 'new' about the rooms. Because of this we found it was a short visit but for the price it is worth a see

Well worth a visit. We've been to Marrakech several times and on our most recent visit we were mostly revisiting places we'd been before. Looking for somewhere we hadn't been before, I found the El Bahia Palace in our guidebook and went to have a look.It's in an area of the city I'd not seen before and we got a little bit lost towards the end. The entrance to the palace is cheap (less than a pound) and there's a lot to see. Mostly this will appeal to people who love Islamic architecture and the palace combines many of the classical elements of Moroccan design. There are pretty courtyards and gardens, lavishly decorated rooms with ornate ceilings and colourful tiling and each room tends to be quite different from the others. We didn't hire a guide and didn't feel we needed one - we were happy to just wander around.The state of preservation is not as good as I'd have liked and I would happily have paid a higher fee if I thought more money would be spent to preserve this beautiful building.Watch out for tortoises in the gardens around the palace
Well worth a look. Worth going to look at the ruins of the palace. Although extra signage in English would have helped.
Beautifull palace, great architecture. Worth visiting it. It is opened till 5pm thou the people around the area told me it closes at 3! Glad I insisted of going anyway

great palace. unfortunately the big coutryard of this palace was closed for renovation, but you could still look into it, but just not enter it. This style of arab/spanish architecture is really fascinating. i took millions of pictures of the tile mosaiques.

Simplistic but tranquil trip. It reminded me of a country house in england on the approach by foot to this great walled and partially roped drive.But once through the first door, it was cooler than the heat outside, there were birds singing in the trees adorning the orangeries, and small courtyard gardens dotted about the palace.As I understood it, an over confident ruler lived in it, was overthrown and then eventually the locals at the time came and took anything that wasnt nailed down, or could be chipped-off. After I had left I came across a shop where the guy running it said the beautiful patterned tiles I was looking at and got me to venture inside, were genuine tiles from the palace.The tour is gently guiding you through in a one way direction. Within the palace is a series of galleried rooms, with smaller ones at each end and high arched ceilings. There was an enormous open courtyard which reminded me of the playground at school. Perhaps the heritage guardians of this palace could think of decorating it, and restoring some furniture and fittings so we could really see how it was. In one room were beautiful stained glass windows high up by the ceiling which were captivating all of us, as the palace had very little enduring decor left.The tiny gardens were the nicest parts, as they were so unexpected, and refreshing. You get a sense of imagining the Sultan striding through the very place you are standing and off into the grand room beyond the open doors. With fountains tinkling in the background, and the city with all its bustle not so far away, but at those moments a world away. It is this imagery that we expect of historical arabia, and this palace shows you a glimpse of it.
An little known gem. Fabulous zellij tiling. Scuptured stucco & carved cedar wood. Put it on your list.

Worth a visit.. Cheap entrance and a chance to see some good Moorish architecture. Most of the site is open to visitors to view, where as other palaces are restricted and not much can be viewed. Well restored and only a few minutes walk from the medina. Be sure to check out the spice markets on route.
Well preserved. Amazingly well preserved and upheld. There are no English explanations so we had to use our LP guide. Maybe better to hire a guide.
killing time. not looked after, needs a gardener. If you want to kill some time then this is the place to visit.
Bahia Palace. We read the Lonely Planet suggestion to visit the museum just a little too late! The main part was reasonably interesting but not thrilling.

Were else can you view such ruins for under £1. Amazing historical site to visit for under £1. A great view of Marrakech from the terrace and the whole site gives the feeling of what it might have been like in yester-year.

Loved it. The Bahai Palace is one of its kind. The rooms, the colour, the brilliance of it all, and most of all its maintenance was very good. The place was also quite cool and calm and provided wonderful respite.
I dont think I disliked anything. Would recommend the place to everyone.
Beautiful!. Beautiful site to see in Marrakech. It's in excellent condition and has many lovely photo opportunities.

Beautiful decorations but empty rooms. Loved all the restored interior decorations..stunning. Found it strange that they hadn't put any furniture in any of the rooms to show them as they would have been used.

Beautiful Moroccan Tiles and Architecture. This palace has remarkable tiled rooms and painted ceilings and a lot of rooms to explore. We didn't have a guide, which I think would have made the visit more informative for us. But even without a guide, the palace is gorgeous.

le palais de la Bahia.. this is one of the master pieces of moroccan architecture, and it was built at the end of 19th century, this palace contains bieutiful gardens, very pretty patios and very decorated rooms, one part of it is under renovation at the moment.
Well-Preserved. This palace was worth a look see. The ceiling work was intricate and breathtaking.
Stunning art. Wonderful tilework and impressive painted ceilings and doors. this was our favourite indoor site.

Palace. Amazing space, but would have really liked to have known more about what we were looking at. A guidebook or leaflet at the site would have been great as our guide books only had very sparse information about the history and building.

Nice Palace but need renovating. The palace looks quite nice but it is time it was renovated, some parts of it looked really grand but others looked like they were falling apart. There was a small fee to get in, I think they should increase the fee a little and spend the money on renovating this palace back to its original state.Worth a visit as it is close to all of the other attractions and if you look deep enough, you will be able to see the past glories of this palace.

A calm oasis in the bustling city.... Bahia palace is a beautiful and very tranquil place to figure in to your bustling Marrakesh trip. We sat there for a long time just taking in the garden and relaxing. It's relatively small and there isn't all that much to see, but for a quick 30-45 minute stop, it's well worth the visit to restore your senses a bit with it's lovely garden, beautiful mosaics, central fountain and overall calm vibes...
A little bit of culture. Only 10dhms to get in. Just the right size to wander round and see some beautiful architecture.
not worth a visit. not worth visiting , walled in mess that could have a lot more to offer. the guides were bad mannered and unhelpful.
bit of history to view. Reasonable price to enter.... doesn't take long to walk round... must see... upstairs view of palace and the storks nests!

Quiet and beautiful.. As soon as you walk through the entrance it seems as though someone has turned the volume down for any extraneous noise. It is beautiful and quiet - the mosaics are stunning as is the architecture.

Another Moroccan wonder!. It amazes me that this establishment is stil standing, and with much of its zellij-ed floors and walls, ceiling and archway carvings, still in mint condition. This is preservation at its very best.
Interesting enough!. It was a nice place to visit but does not really compare to some of the palaces we have in England. The guide we had was good though and very informative which helped.
Somebody actually lived there? Wow.... It's in pretty good shape, but parts of it were roped off with restoration efforts. If you like tile installations, you'll love this place.
History. tour guide Khalid was amazing, fascinating place, a little gem tucked away

Simply beautiful. Beautiful architecture and design.
All of the attractions are all well looked after and cost just 10 dams to visit.

Lovely place, but you need a guide to really appreciate it. We visited the palace on a day tour of the city with a guide (definitely recommended, but arrange for either a full or half days tour, and say what sights you want to see or visit first).The entrance fee was 10dh (with 12dh to the £), so very cheap.There was loads to see, but you need either a good book or guide to explain the different rooms, styles and everyday life of the women who lived there (both wives and concubines) and how the palace gossip worked!. The mosaics, carvings and decoration were all lovely.The Moroccans are still not very switched on to tourism so there are no leaflets, guide books or signs informing you of what exactly you are looking at. So on the whole a good guide book or guide are essential to get the most from any tourist attraction in Morocco.

Beautiful palace, but means nothing without a good guide. We visited the palace on a day tour of the city with a guide (definitely recommended, but arrange for either a full or half days tour, and say what sights you want to see or visit).The entrance fee was 10dh (with 12dh to the £), so very cheap.There was loads to see, but you need either a good book or guide to explain the different rooms, styles and everyday life of the women who lived there (both wives and concubines) and how the palace gossip worked! The mosaics, carvings and decoration were all lovely.The Moroccans are still not very switched on to tourism so there are no leaflets, guide books or signs informing you of what exactly you are looking at. So on the whole a good guide book or guide are essential to get the most from any tourist attraction in Morocco.

Not Worth Visiting. This so-called palace was built about 100 years ago, is empty of furnishings, has no architectural merit, and is just not worth a visit unless you are in the area and desperate for a break from the busy neighbourhood streets.

Beautiful architecture - go with a guide. The Bahia Palace is one of those attractions that you can't miss on a trip to Marrakech with it's beautiful architecture and arabic inscriptions - definitely a trip back in time but I would strongly recommend going with a good guide who can explain the different rooms and their historical meaning as the experience isn't really as insightful if you try and see this on your own. Also, be aware that this attraction closes at around 5pm so factor this into your plans.
Amazing. Go on a guided tour with a group as it will provide you with lots of information which you would not have got visiting by youself. The building is beutiful and you should def visit.
Amazing. Do not miss it.. Beautiful. Quintecence of marroacan style. Fantastic place to rest in the heart of Medina.

Beautiful Palace. Visited here as part of a tour. A stunning example of Moroccan architecture. Very busy with lots of tours. Some of it is currently closed for renovation. Get a guide for the full Moroccan experience.

The ancient meets the modern. We went with a guide in a car by ourselves. I felt this gave us the best of all worlds as there were so many tourists and we had individual attention to listen to the review of the Palace , to gain inside information from our guide and to ask our own questions for more historical infromation. Also being on an individual escorted tour , we were not pressured to " come on" the bus is going. We could go at our own pace. This is a truly amazing palace- beautiful architecture throughout and the different rooms and decorations were un believable.

Worth a visit. Given that Marrakech really doesn't offer that many attractions, the Bahia Palace is definetly among those, which is actually worth a visit, but don't plan to spend more than an hour there. The Palace architecture and the inner courtyards are beautiful.

Simple palace but some beautiful architecture. It's well worth the 10dh entry fee. It's quite simple, clean architecture with some very ornate and intricate designs in areas. It didn't take that long to wander around, under an hour, although you could spend longer and could also sit and relax in the courtyard for a bit if you wish. A nice respite from the hussle and bussle of the streets. There were toilets, although not sure if you need to tip a few dirham to use them.
Not so impressive.... If you have tons of time then I recommend a visit to the palace however if you are in a crunch for time then skip it and spend time at the outskirts of the city.

Nice Palace, worth a visit. The Bahia Palace is very nice and well worth a visit. Unfortunately the palace does need a bit of work done on it to bring it back up to the wonderful condtion it must have been at one point. Take a stroll down there, it does not cost much to get in (I think it was 10 Dirhams) and it will get you out of the hussle and bussle of Marrakech for a short while.
Worth a visit if you have the time.. Beautiful palace and gardens, worth a visit if you have the time. A very relaxing place to visit to get away from the madness for an hour.

Nice Palace.. Most of the attractions in Marrakech are on the smaller side and this Palace is no exception. Don't expect it to be on the same scale as palaces in other countries as you will be throughly disappointed, appreciate it for what it is. For just 10 Dirhams this doesn't exactly break the bank. We enjoyed our visit.

Worth a visit and couple hours of your time. This Palace is worth a visit and couple hours of your time. Even though there are no furnishings, it is worth the walk through it - and it is at least an hour if not too as much bigger inside then it first appears. There are several courtyards with beautiful gardens and it was easy to find your way from area to area. We went to the Palace with a guide and it was worth the extra cost as he explained the history of the palace and the way it was decorated.

Palace with traditional architecture and design. I loved the Bahia Palace. It reminded me a lot of the Alhambra in Granada, Spain, but unfortunately without the pleasant sound of working fountains and running water that you have at the Alhambra. I highly recommend going with a guide. We stumbled on it our first day and did a walk through, but came back with a guide the second day and got a lot more out of it. Make sure you look up, as some of the most decorated parts of the buildings are the ceilings.

Was a really big let down...read heaps of.... Was a really big let down...read heaps of reaaly good reviews from different places and I do not agree with them at all... There wasn't much to look at... All you looked at was the walls and the roof
Really good to go and see... It's very.... Really good to go and see... It's very different to the other sites of marrakech...better than the other palace around the corner

Well Worth Visiting. There are lovely rooms with mosaics and carvings in wood and plaster, lovely courtyard gardens. Worth a lot more than the 10 Dirham (1 euro) entrance fee. 100 times better than nearby El Badi Palace

Great historical place with wonderfull architecture. It's a wonderfull Palace, with lots of architectural and wall decoration details. Very nice gardens also. No furniture inside, but the walls, ceilings and gardens are more than beautiful. If you are not going there with a guide, make sure you learn a bout the Palace befor going, so you can profit the most from it.

Only go if you have too much time in Marrakech. The simple palace with the dreary rooms and ancient mosaics doesn't impress. The garden is a quite nice but I can't say there's anything more worth of seeing. I think the adverts make this place sound a little too fabulous and personally I liked the Badii palace (near Bahia) more interesting. One street vendor said to us "when you have seen one palace, you've seen it all". I have to agree.

Simple palace. Beautiful palace had many rooms for you to pop in to and take a look at stunning artwork. Had a lovely garden in the middle only 10dirhams not much if you really think about it, it’s about 65p in British Sterling.If you want to see historical sites Bahia Palace would be recommended as it has all that. Maybe does not offer you a great deal to see as most rooms are very similar, and has similar deco, but is a old and pretty place to visit while you are in Marrakech.

Not worth the 10dirhams entrance fee. This empty palace is not really worth the less than € 1 of entrance fee, apart from some engravings or beautiful tiles.What is really worth the money is the relative cool interiors, especially in the summertime, in comparison to the outside.Go visiting, instead, the hotel «La Mamounia», definitely a more remarkable place.
